title: American autobiography,
summary: N/A

title: American Autobiography 1945-1980
summary: N/A

title: As told to Furman Bisher. Illustrated. Revised edition.
summary: In a low-key, conversational style, the author tells how he went from shortstop in one of the great Black barnstorming baseball teams to a major league hitter pushing Babe Ruth's career home run record.

title: As high as my heart: the Sammy Aaronson story.
summary: The story of his fight against juvenile delinquency in New York's East Side and Brooklyn, where he set up gymnasiums and sports activities for boys.

title: The journey home: some words in defense of the American West.
summary: Author and conservationist Abbey describes his discovery of the West, his passion for the land, and his efforts to preserve it from destruction by machines, land developers, and excessive population.

title: Adventures in the world of science.
summary: An interesting record of his sixty years among international research scientists by a physicist who pioneered in solar energy and became affiliated with the Smithsonian in 1898.

title: Watching the world go by.
summary: Abbot tells of his lifelong career in newspaper journalism, finding fascination in politics.
other_places_lived: New Orleans, Kansas City, Chicago, New York, Boston

title: Mister Abbott.
summary: A successful showman writes about Broadway, his memories of friends and enemies among celebrities.

title: Memoir of the Rev. David Abeel, D.D.: late missionary to China.
summary: The life of a Dutch Reformed missionary is described through his journals and letters, revealing his dedication to spreading the gospel.
other_places_lived: Greece, England, Europe, Far East, China

title: The confessions of a hoaxer.
summary: A professional prankster describes his best hoaxes and the motivations behind his pranks.

title: Back roads and bicarbonate: the autobiography of an Arkansas country doctor.
summary: Recollections of his life as a country doctor and pharmacist in rural Arkansas and Oklahoma.

title: Ghost of Bataan speaks.
summary: An American soldier recounts the events surrounding the fall of Bataan and the experiences of the troops.

title: The making of a woman cop.
summary: Policewoman describes her development on the police force and her efforts against sexism.

title: The education of Sonny Carson.
summary: Covers his upbringing, education, and later beliefs in community control.

title: Bella! Ms. Abzug goes to Washington.
summary: Abzug chronicles her first year in Congress and her struggles against sexism.

title: Grapes from thorns.
summary: Collection of articles, speeches, and letters that provide a portrait of Acheson as a statesman.

title: Morning and noon.
summary: Acheson reflects on his New England boyhood and his experiences in Washington.

title: Present at the creation: my years in the State Department.
summary: Acheson shares his experiences and insights on foreign policy during World War II and the postwar period.

title: Sketches from life: of men I have known.
summary: A personal analysis of Acheson's career in the State Department and notable figures he worked with.

title: A pathfinder: inventor, scientist, industrialist.
summary: Overview of Acheson's life and contributions to science and industry.

title: Twilight of the tenderfoot: a western memoir.
summary: A contemporary narrative of frontier life by a poet who evaluates cattle ranching.

title: Here lies the heart.
summary: An account of her quest for a meaningful life as a writer.

title: My diary: August 30th to November 5th, 1874.
summary: Mrs. Adair kept this diary record of a cross-country trip she took in 1874.

title: Dinner at the White House.
summary: An account of a January 1942 dinner at the White House with Roosevelt and Churchill.

title: The education of Henry Adams.
summary: Adams analyzes his lifelong process of education and follows his personal development.

title: Henry Adams and his friends; a collection of his unpublished letters.
summary: More than 750 unpublished letters providing insight into Adams' intellect and compassion.

title: The selected letters of Henry Adams.
summary: A collection of previously published letters spanning 60 years, showcasing Adams' intellectual development.

title: My America: 1928-1938.
summary: A narrative combining personal and social history during 1929-1939 framed through the author's immigrant experience.

title: From gags to riches.
summary: A narrative filled with quips and gossip about the comedian's experiences in the New York show business.

title: The native's return; an American immigrant visits Yugoslavia and discovers his old country.
summary: Adamic visits Yugoslavia after nineteen years to reveal both its beauty and its political turmoil.

title: Cindy and I: the real life adventures of Mr. and Mrs. Joey Adams.
summary: An anecdotal account of the marriage between comedian Joey Adams and his wife Cindy.

title: Familiar letters of John Adams and his wife Abigail Adams, during the Revolution; with a memoir of Mrs. Adams.
summary: A collection of letters revealing the feelings between John and Abigail Adams during the Revolutionary struggle.

title: New letters of Abigail Adams, 1788-1801.
summary: A collection of 141 previously unpublished letters from Abigail Adams, focusing on her life and her husband's political career.

title: Diary of Charles Francis Adams.
publisher: Belknap Press of Harvard University Press
summary: A full publication of the diary kept by Charles Francis Adams, grandson and son of U.S. Presidents.

title: The God bit.
summary: A collection of humorous and serious anecdotes reflecting a faith in God.

title: Adams-Jefferson letters: the complete correspondence between Thomas Jefferson and Abigail and John Adams.
summary: Includes the complete correspondence between Thomas Jefferson and the Adamses.

title: Correspondence between John Adams and Mercy Warren.
summary: A lively exchange between Adams and Warren over the publication of her history of the American Revolution.

title: Diary and autobiography.
summary: Includes Adams' diaries and autobiographical parts, detailing his life and thoughts.

title: The earliest diary of John Adams: June 1753-April 1754; September 1758-January 1759.
publisher: Belknap Press of Harvard University Press
summary: Fragments illuminating John Adams' early thoughts and concerns.

title: The John Adams papers.
summary: Selected letters, papers, and other documents are arranged to show John Adams as a lawyer, congressman, diplomat, peacemaker, political philosopher, Vice-President, President, and old man.
occupations: Lawyer, Congressman, Diplomat, Political Philosopher, Vice-President, President

title: The papers of John Adams.
publisher: Belknap Press of Harvard University Press
summary: This judicious selection of Adams' papers includes letters to and from friends and acquaintances; committee reports; polemical writings, published and unpublished; and state papers which he contributed.

title: Diary of John Quincy Adams, 1794-1845: American diplomacy and political, social, and intellectual life from Washington to Polk.
summary: A selection from a twelve-volume Memoirs published between 1874 and 1877 traces a lifetime of public service in domestic and foreign affairs.

title: John Quincy Adams and American continental empire: letters, papers and speeches.
summary: A selection of writings by the sixth U.S. president intended to reveal his mind, his passions, his views of the world's political, economical, and ideological systems.

title: John Quincy Adams in Russia: comprising portions of the diary of John Quincy Adams from 1809-1814.
summary: A reprint of Volume II of his memoirs, comprising the record of his experiences during his successful mission to the court of Czar Alexander I.

title: Wings on my tennis shoes.
publisher: Sampson Low, Marston and Co., Ltd.
summary: The development of her career in tennis and her achievements as a professional player.

title: Letters of George Ade.
summary: With keen observation tempered by humor, Ade wrote stories and fables populated with characters typical of his small-town Indiana background.

title: I have considered the days.
summary: Adler writes with thoughtful eloquence of his distinguished career as a Middle Eastern scholar, president of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.
occupations: Middle Eastern Scholar, President of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America

title: Philosopher at large: an intellectual autobiography.
summary: Adler discusses his career as a popularizer of philosophy, particularly under the aegis of Robert Hutchins at the University of Chicago.

title: A house is not a home.
summary: A madam explains her life as a prostitute and madam in New York City, involving the Roaring Twenties, gangsters, and social stigma.

title: Memoirs of the life of John Adlum in the Revolutionary War.
publisher: Caxton Club, for the William L. Clements Library Associates
summary: An engaging account of a young patriot's participation in the Revolutionary War.

title: The last letter of James Agee to Father Flye.
summary: Dated May 11, 1955, this last letter to Father Flye was found unmailed in Agee's living room.

title: Letters of James Agee to Father Flye.
summary: Letters (1925-1955) reveal the bond of understanding and shared feelings between Agee and Father Flye.

title: A proper job.
summary: Born in England, Aherne acted in movies and on stage before making his debut on Broadway and in American films.

title: Ushant: an essay.
summary: An interior monologue autobiography that stresses the emotional and psychological life of the author in England.

title: A surgeon's fight to rebuild men: an autobiography.
summary: Recollections of a long active life in surgery including descriptions of innovative techniques and worldwide recognition of his work.

title: Dear Grandson.
summary: A letter to the author's 13-year-old grandson, detailing his adventures escaping from Russia to America.

title: Odyssey.
summary: A story of prospecting as a desert prospector, focusing on the experiences and memories gained.

title: Letters of A. Bronson Alcott.
summary: The first collection of all extant Alcott letters printed in full, providing insight into his character and interests.

title: Louisa May Alcott: her life, letters, and journals.
summary: Letters and journal entries are arranged chronologically, including accounts of her writing process and extensive reading.

title: Tales of my life and family.
summary: Alger recounts his career as an engineer at General Electric and his involvement in local governance.

title: A hilltop on the Marne, being letters written June 3-September 8, 1914.
summary: A series of letters written by a New Englander living above the Marne in France at the onset of World War I.

title: A whaler & trader in the Arctic: 1895-1944: my life with the Bowhead.
summary: Allen recounts his adventures as a whaler and trader of whale ivory and sealskin in Alaska.

title: Born to lose, bound to win: an autobiography.
summary: A poor Missouri farmer becomes a successful preacher and evangelist for the Pentecostal Church during the Depression.

title: Return to earth.
summary: Aldrin writes about the training, the trip to the moon, and his experiences with public relations after the historic moon landing.

title: Cavalry wife: diary of Eveline M. Alexander, 1866-1867.
summary: A diary chronicling her journey to join her husband and experiences with him during active duty among the Indian nations.

title: Chromatography: an adventure in graduate school.
summary: A look at the experience of being a graduate student doing research on chromatography in the late 1940's.

title: Pen and politics: the autobiography of a working writer.
summary: The autobiography of a working writer who gives up security to pursue a life of writing.

title: My love affair with music.
summary: An author writes of his passion for music and the arts as an ordinary man.

title: Israel and me: a behind-the-scenes look by a longtime U.S. Zionist leader and returned Israeli immigrant.
publisher: Schenkman Publishing Co., Two Continents Publishing Group
summary: Alexander focuses on the establishment of Israel as a nation and his role in supporting emerging Zionist organizations.

title: Mark it and strike it: an autobiography.
summary: A critical review of his career as an entertainer on radio and television, with an interesting analysis on the subject of comedy.

title: Reaching for the sea.
summary: Allin, a civil engineer and expert on port construction, tells about his extensive work at the ports of Houston, Stockton, San Francisco, The Dalles (Oregon), Miami, and Port Bhavnagar, India. He also describes his world travels, 1906-10, illustrated with many photographs.

title: Ambassador from the prairie; or, Allison wonderland.
summary: The author writes of his thirty-year career in the Foreign Service, beginning as a clerk and ending as ambassador, especially concerned with aspects of American foreign policy with respect to Asia.

title: The Arizona of Joseph Pratt Allyn: letters from a pioneer judge: observations and travels, 1863-1866.
summary: Allyn wrote these letters to his newspaper editor friend Charles Warner, recording his travels and information about settlements and outposts, mining operations, Indians, Arizona pioneers, and Mexicans.

title: From college to cow country.
summary: A college graduate raised in Brooklyn, Almirall went to Colorado to become a rancher, sharing experiences of his transformation from tenderfoot to cowboy.

title: Deer Creek; the story of a golden childhood.
summary: Describes the author's middle-class childhood in the 1880's, the strong influence of her Grandma May in rural Deer Creek, Pennsylvania.

title: Alvarez.
summary: Alvarez looks back on 93 years as a physician and son of a physician, focusing on emotional and physiological causes of stomach and intestinal disorders.

title: Incurable physician: an autobiography.
summary: Known as 'America's family doctor', this book reflects his popularity and critiques on subjects like Freud and conformity while portraying his compassionate nature.

title: Light of Notre Dame.
summary: Alvin uses 'The Lady of the Golden Dome of the University of Notre Dame' as an inspiration for his life, focusing on his career as a journalist and PR man in Hollywood.

title: Mile high: the story of Lyle Alzado and the amazing Denver Broncos.
summary: The account emphasizes Alzado's rise from a Brooklyn slum to the Super Bowl, contrasting his football fierceness with his gentle treatment of his wife and philanthropy.

title: If you don't weaken: the autobiography of Oscar Ameringer.
summary: Ameringer narrates his life as a socialist, his commitment to unionizing labor, and personal struggles in his pursuit of activism.

title: Beyond theology: the autobiography of Edward Scribner Ames.
summary: Ames interweaves narratives of childhood and career with his insights as a philosopher and minister.

title: Stay of execution; a sort of memoir.
summary: Describes his experiences with a rare form of leukemia, his efforts to understand and confront his illness and mortality.

title: To Marietta from Paris, 1945-1960.
summary: Letters written during the author's fifteen-year period in Paris, detailing her social life and observations.

title: A year at a time.
summary: Alston describes landmark ballgames and his career managing the Dodgers.

title: Momma: a start on all the untold stories.
summary: A poet writing about love, motherhood, independence, and the paradox of balancing love and freedom.

title: Call of the cricket.
summary: Harsh memoirs of a 'gentleman thief' detailing his journey from unhappy childhood to criminal adulthood.

title: Oakes Ames: jottings of a Harvard botanist 1874-1950.
summary: A collection of writings revealing Ames's dual identity as a major botanist and a family man.

title: Vibrations: The adventures and musical times of David Amram.
summary: Amram narrates his lifelong love of music and details his experiences with notable orchestras.

title: Outsider in the senate: Senator Clinton Anderson's memoirs.
summary: Major events of the 1950's and 60's from the perspective of a senator involved in key committees.

title: From sunflowers to bluebonnets.
summary: Anderson recalls her years as a school teacher, particularly her experiences at a one-room country school in Kansas.

title: Miss Elizabeth: a memoir.
summary: A memoir by Sherwood Anderson's wife, detailing her life and experiences during and after their marriage.

title: Personal recollections of Captain Enoch Anderson, an officer of the Delaware regiments in the Revolutionary War.
summary: Letters written to his nephew constitute a brief record of military life.

title: Main spark: Sparky Anderson and the Cincinnati Reds.
summary: Anderson recounts his philosophy as a manager and shares anecdotes from his time with notable players.

title: Notre Dame, Chicago Bears, and Hunk: football memoirs in highlight.
summary: Anderson recounts his experiences as a student athlete at Notre Dame and later coaching at various universities.

title: The Anderson papers.
summary: Anderson discusses the power of the press vs. the power of politicians, using various anecdotes including Watergate.

title: Out without my rubbers: the memoirs of John Murray Anderson.
summary: A theatrical director describes his various productions and experiences with notable personalities.

title: Pilgrim circuit rider.
summary: A record of a Congregational missionary's life, highlighting her experiences and the challenges faced by rural society.

title: The fiery fountains.
summary: An emotional account of a prominent artist's life and friendship with Georgette Leblanc.

title: My Lord, what a morning: an autobiography.
summary: The life story of a working woman and union organizer, detailing her contributions to women's advancement.

title: Dramatist in America: letters of Maxwell Anderson, 1912-1958.
summary: A collection of letters describing Anderson's views on poetry and theater.

title: The diary and journal of Richard Clough Anderson, Jr.: 1814-1826.
summary: Anderson's diary discusses political matters and social issues of his time.

title: Letters.
summary: Selected letters of the author discussing art and writing throughout his life.

title: Return to Winesburg: selections from four years of writing for a country newspaper.
publisher: The University of North Carolina Press
summary: Anderson reflects on his past and the impact of his work as a journalist.

title: Sherwood Anderson/Gertrude Stein: correspondence and personal essays.
summary: A record of the literary friendship and correspondence between Anderson and Stein.

title: A story teller's story: a critical text.
publisher: The Press of Case Western Reserve University
summary: Anderson's work delves into his personal history and experiences in the literary world.

title: Tar: a midwest childhood: a critical text.
publisher: The Press of Case Western Reserve University
summary: A semi-fictional memoir detailing Anderson's boyhood and the pain of losing his mother.

title: War-time journal of a Georgia girl, 1864-1865.
summary: The diary of a young southern woman reflecting on her experiences during the Civil War.

title: Woman at work: the autobiography of Mary Anderson.
summary: A record of Anderson's thoughts and experiences as a working woman.

title: Memory pages of my life.
summary: Autobiographical reflections of Andrews' life, focusing on her career and public service.

title: Memoirs of a poor relation; being the story of a post-war Southern girl and her battle with destiny.
summary: A descendant of a prominent Virginia family describes her post-Civil War childhood, the remnants of Virginia society, and her years as an art student in Washington in the 1890's.

title: Corner of Chicago.
summary: In the late Twenties he was hired by the Chicago Daily News where he shared an office with Carl Sandburg and established his reputation writing about Chicago.

title: An explorer comes home: further adventures of Roy Chapman Andrews.
summary: A naturalist's look at the people and animals of his rural Connecticut home, Pondwood Farm.

title: Under a lucky star: a lifetime of adventure.
summary: Based on journals of his expeditions between 1907 and 1930, plus recollection of personal experiences, the book describes the development of his career, his eighteen years in China, and his directorship of the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Dangerous voyages of Captain William Andrews.
summary: The first of two diaries by Andrews, a fanatical sailor, describes in detail the 1878 transatlantic voyage of the 19-foot Nautilus with his brother.

title: I was the Nuremberg jailer.
summary: For eighteen months during 1945-46, Andrus' job was to guard the 21 top Nazis and maintain the security of the Tribunal that was trying them for war crimes.

title: Diary of Colonel Israel Angell: commanding the Second Rhode Island Continental Regiment during the American Revolution, 1778-1781.
summary: Including notes on his experience at the Battle of Brandywine and during the winter of Valley Forge, the diary is a slim but interesting account.

title: Reminiscences of James Burrill Angell.
summary: The story of a prominent educator and diplomat who served as president of the University of Vermont and the University of Michigan and was sent on diplomatic missions to China and the Ottoman Empire.

title: Gather together in my name.
summary: The author has studied and taught dance, helped produce and star in plays, written for newspapers in Cairo and Ghana and for TV, and the theater. In this book she recalls experiences of her youth before she became a successful writer.

title: I know why the caged bird sings.
summary: The life of a young Black girl who later studied dance, starred on the stage, and wrote for newspapers and television. Her story is a sensitive narrative of her gradual awareness of the realities of life, of prejudice, of cruelty, of ignorance, but also of love.

title: Singin' and swingin' and gettin' merry like Christmas.
summary: In this third autobiographical volume, Angelou masterfully recreates her lean years as record shop clerk and B-girl, followed by her rapid ascent to cabaret singer and dancer and her subsequent role with the touring company of Porgy and Bess.

title: When I was a boy in Boston.
summary: A collection of stories, several of which were published earlier in little magazines, of the author's boyhood. Most focus on a particular character who had a strong influence on him.

title: A summer month; or, recollections of a visit to the falls of Niagara, and the lakes.
summary: The account of a tour of upper New York and Canada and observations of scenery and people, the joys and the difficulties of travel in the early nineteenth century.

title: Ransom & gems: the DeLong Ruby story.
summary: The author, a writer, was doing research in south Florida in 1965 on gem thefts when he discovered a clue that led him to the DeLong Ruby, stolen from the American Museum of Natural History by a gang masterminded by socially prominent yacht broker, Dick Pearson.

title: Bad boy of music.
summary: A glib and brassy narrative by the composer of 'Ballet Mecanique' describing his life as a concert pianist and composer among American expatriates in Europe in the 1920's, then among entertainers and musicians in New York and Hollywood.

title: This is where I came in: the impromptu confessions of Edward Anthony.
summary: An anecdotal narrative of the varied career of a writer — his Manhattan boyhood, his days as a cub reporter, his long association with the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company, and his work as a Hollywood script writer.

title: How to grow old disgracefully.
summary: Traces author's career as artist-journalist; he became editor of Ballyhoo, published by George T. Delacorte, Jr., a men's magazine whose style was later pre-empted by Esquire.

title: The ghost in my life.
summary: The namesake and grandniece of the famous suffragist writes of a life made difficult by that heritage, of various jobs as a reporter and broadcaster, of being a feminist and an alcoholic.

title: Youth in Acadie: reflections on Acadian life and culture in Southwest Louisiana.
summary: Arceneaux provides a brief history of the 1604 French settlement of Acadie, in what is now Nova Scotia, and explains how the Acadians migrated to Louisiana in 1763.

title: Bomber pilot: a memoir of World War II.
summary: After a brief eulogy to the victims of World War II, this book glorifies patriotism, fighting for one's country, war, and being a man among men.

title: Exiles.
summary: Arlen writes of his father, a celebrated novelist in the Twenties, his mother, and himself in a haunting quest of discovery in the movement and meaning of their lives.

title: Passage to Ararat.
summary: Arlen set out on a journey to discover the heritage of his Armenian forebears. He found sadness and horror as well as humor and hope in a land and people that conquerors have been trying to suppress for centuries.

title: Arsha's world and yours.
summary: Arsha was an Armenian teenager living near Istanbul when World War I broke out and all Armenians were deported to the interior of Turkey. Arsha stowed paper, pencils and her Bible in a sack and kept a diary of her family's forced travels and struggles to survive.

title: A boundless privilege.
summary: Harking back to the first twenty years of the twentieth century, the author examines the accelerated rate of change and its effects on the old simple life in the rural region of Rusk County, Texas.

title: Jay J. Armes, investigator.
summary: Armes is to private investigation what Melvin Belli is to trial law. He describes his hyperactive, flamboyant life, and unorthodox, not always legal, methods of solving crimes.

title: My life with women: confessions of a domesticated male.
summary: A prolific writer of spoofs and humorous books, articles, and poems, Armour here writes about himself, particularly about married life.

title: Cry Babel: the nightmare of aphasia and a courageous woman's struggle to rebuild her life.
summary: At 46, Armstrong was afflicted with aphasia that reduced her from a prolific author and theology professor to the physical and linguistic level of an eighteen-month-old baby.

title: House with a hundred gates.
summary: Armstrong tells of life with her author parents, Fulton and Grace Oursler, including estrangement when her mother's alcoholism became rampant and union when her father and then Armstrong converted to Catholicism.

title: Gloves, glory and God: an autobiography.
summary: In novelistic form, this third-person autobiography describes a Black athlete's rise to become the world's lightweight champion boxer, followed by a slow decline and many injuries.

title: Louis Armstrong— a self-portrait: the interview by Richard Meryman.
summary: The major portion of this interview was published in Life, April 15, 1966. In it the famous trumpeter tells anecdotes of his youth in New Orleans and his later success in Chicago and elsewhere.

title: Satchmo: my life in New Orleans.
summary: A wizard with his horn, Armstrong here tells of his childhood, his start in music, the bumptious life in New Orleans, great bands, great musicians, and his break into the big time in Chicago.

title: Through troubled waters.
summary: The story of a man and his three young children coping with the sudden death of their wife and mother.

title: It's a long way from Chester County.
summary: His career as a country singer was solidly established by his recording of 'That's How Much I Love You' in 1946. It peaked, declined, and grew again by the mid-sixties. His book describes the struggle and success of a young man from Tennessee.

title: Global mission.
summary: N/A

title: Voltaire and the cowboy: the letters of Thurman Arnold.
summary: The detailed, precise, and witty biographical introduction is a fitting prelude to the extensive selection from 17,000 of Thurman Arnold's letters, written from 1910-1969.

title: Old Burnside.
summary: With precise details and a homey nostalgia reminiscent of Wilder's Little House on the Prairie series, Arnow recreates her turn-of-the-century family life in Burnside, Kentucky, and supplies a history of this small rural town on the Cumberland River.

title: Indian agent in New Mexico: the journal of Special Agent W.F.M. Amy, 1870.
summary: Amy's journal records his visits (May-October, 1870) to various New Mexican Indian tribes — including Abiquiu, Apache, Navajo, and Ute.

title: Free enterprise.
summary: This is an extensively detailed history of Aronson's founding and development of the Aronson Machine Company in Arcade, New York.

title: The galloping Swede.
summary: At fourteen, he had saved enough money to immigrate to America, and he kept traveling west until he reached Montana. There he worked as a rancher, established his own construction company, and eventually served as a two-term governor.

title: Broken hills: the story of Joe Arthur, cowpuncher and prospector, who struck it rich in Nevada.
summary: Arthur told his wife this story of rough living in the turn-of-the-century American West, working on cattle ranches and prospecting for precious ores; recorded it in the first person. He also tells of deer hunting and other woodland activities.

title: Advantage Ashe.
summary: Ashe was the first Black man to play in the white-dominated amateur tennis circuit. Trained by a Black coach, he played tournaments in the United States and Australia. At 22 he became the ranking amateur in the United States.

title: Incidents in the life of the Rev. J. Asher: pastor of Shiloh (coloured) Baptist Church, Philadelphia, U.S., and a concluding chapter of facts illustrating the unrighteous prejudice existing in the minds of American citizens toward their coloured brethren.
summary: Asher's memoir is an account of personal indignities suffered in Northern states prior to the Civil War.

title: Actress: postcards from the road.
summary: A harsh and sometimes vulgar account of Ashley's struggle with success, professional blacklisting, insecurity, and mental instability.

title: The West of William H. Ashley: the international struggle for the fur trade of the Missouri, the Rocky Mountains, and the Columbia, with explorations beyond the Continental Divide, recorded in the diaries and letters of William H. Ashley and his contemporaries; 1822-1838.
summary: A dominant figure in Western history who was also a Missouri politician and U.S. Congressman, Ashley left a diary that sheds light on fur trading and Western exploration during the early 1800's.

title: Many-colored toga: the diary of Henry Fountain Ashurst.
summary: The diary (1910-1937) of one of Arizona's two first senators who served thirty years in the U.S. Senate and played a leading role in maintaining the independence of the judiciary through his chairmanship of the Committee on the Judiciary.

title: The Wallowas: coming of age in the wilderness.
summary: Ashworth wrote this evocative account of his decade of mountaineering in the Wallowa Mountains of Oregon as a plea for ecological conservation and to show the progressive stages of his relationship to the wilderness.

title: In joy still felt: the autobiography of Isaac Asimov, 1954-1978.
summary: This book is a continuation of Asimov's first autobiographical work, In Memory Yet Green. It describes simultaneous developments of the successful science fiction writer (with 215 books to his credit) and a frustrated academic career.

title: Steps in time.
summary: Astaire describes his years as a touring Vaudeville performer with his sister Adele in revues, musicals, and nightclubs, and relates his experiences as a USO entertainer during World War II.

title: Patchwork child.
summary: Because her father was a high-ranking Marine officer, she spent her childhood in several foreign countries from which she derived what she calls a patchwork of experience.

title: A life on film.
summary: Her second autobiographical work focuses less on her personal problems and more on her life as an actress, stressing the tension, difficulties, and tedium of that world.

title: My story: an autobiography.
summary: In the context of her film career, the book focuses on her struggle with and recovery from alcoholism.

title: The age of Jim Crow.
summary: A Black leader writes of his life disciplined by hard work, by illness, by deprivation, but successful in gaining education, knowledge, and the satisfaction of helping in the struggle for racial equality and equal opportunities.

title: Child of Satan, child of God.
summary: Charles Manson's alienated member of his sordid family writes of the events of her life that culminated in the wanton murder of actress Sharon Tate. As a born-again Christian she functions as a lay minister in her prison environment.

title: Intellectual tramp: the autobiography of a schoolteacher.
summary: An anecdotal illustration of the author's definition of 'intellectual tramp'— 'a human being . . . with considerable native intelligence, who . . . shifts from place to place as either necessity or opportunity may dictate.'

title: Texas surgeon: an autobiography.
summary: An ophthalmologist, internationally recognized for his work on glaucoma, devotes half the book to his early life and hard-earned medical education.

title: Wilmer Atkinson, an autobiography.
summary: Atkinson was a journalist in Delaware who founded the Farm Journal and supported the Woman's Rights Movement and Women's Suffrage.

title: Along the Alcan.
summary: Atwood, a carpenter from Minnesota, was a member of a construction crew that helped to build airports, hangers, line camps, and pumping stations along the Alcan Highway.

title: A writer's capital.
summary: A privileged life that furnished material for Auchincloss's novels.

title: Letters from Iceland.
summary: A unique travel book written in the form of verse letters with interspersed prose commentaries.

title: Rap sheet: my life story.
summary: An exciting tale from the robber's point of view.

title: Audubon and his journals.
summary: An unabridged edition of the journals of his travels and observations by a famous naturalist.

title: Audubon's western journal: 1849-1850; being the ms. record of a trip from New York to Texas, and an overland journey through Mexico and Arizona to the gold-fields of California.
summary: His daily journal is a sensitive depiction of the times, influenced by the painter's trained eye.

title: Red Auerbach: winning the hard way.
summary: Auerbach discusses his players, his strategy, his feuds, and his philosophy of the game.

title: Funny men don't laugh.
summary: Auerbach recalls five sober, tense years during the Depression when he worked as a gag writer.

title: Sad nun at Synanon.
summary: Her book describes the shock and difficulty of her experience working at Synanon, a rehabilitation center for drug addicts.

title: Literary America, 1903-1934: the Mary Austin letters.
summary: Editor Pearce supplies generous commentary and biographical background as well as sketches of many literary figures.

title: Back in the saddle again.
summary: Autry describes his discovery by Will Rogers as the 'singing cowboy' and his experience in corporate management and politics.

title: Ten years in the saddle: his memoirs.
summary: This highly detailed memoir discusses Averell's education at West Point and his military experiences.

title: Ridge runner: the story of a Maine woodsman.
summary: A colorful, well-written description of life in the Maine woods and experiences in logging camp and as a game warden.

title: Diaries 1871-1882 of Samuel P. Avery, art dealer.
summary: Avery's diaries record his purchases, itineraries, and observations from eleven years of collecting.

title: Florence Ayscough and Amy Lowell: correspondence of a friendship.
summary: Letters exchanged between Florence Ayscough and Amy Lowell, detailing their friendship and interests.

title: Actions and reactions: an autobiography of Roger W. Babson.
summary: A forthright, moralistic narrative based on a philosophy of common sense, ingenuity, and independence.

title: By myself.
summary: With candor, integrity, and humor, Bacall describes her upbringing by a strong Jewish mother and her marriage to Humphrey Bogart.

title: Journal of an itinerant artist.
summary: Bacigalupa's journal intersperses vignettes of his travels with brief portraits of memorable people.

title: Diary of Isaac Backus.
summary: The diary reveals his importance as a [Baptist] leader and describes his work in consolidating the growing Baptist denomination.

title: Rocks on the television.
summary: Collaboration with his wife Henny, detailing their sociable years in Hollywood.

title: Correspondence of John Badollet and Albert Gallatin, 1804-1836.
summary: The letters exchanged between two friends who participated in the development of their adopted country.

title: Daybreak.
summary: Reminiscences of her childhood, youth, and incidents during her career.

title: From the tablets of my heart.
summary: Bagby became a highly successful and inspiring minister despite being crippled by polio.

title: Sidestepping the barbarians: glimpses of a real experience.
summary: Reminiscences of life in the Japanese-occupied Philippine Islands, detailing evasion of Japanese forces.

title: Unfinished autobiography of Alice A. Bailey.
summary: Occult teacher relates her transition from British socialite to believer in the Disciples of Christ.

title: Sold to the lady in the green hat.
summary: Describes a family's move from urban New Jersey to rural Vermont and the opening of an auction house.

title: My summer in a Mormon village.
summary: Records impressions of the Mormon lifestyle during a summer visit to a remote village.

title: The defense never rests.
summary: Describes controversial American legal cases and critiques the justice system.

title: The raw Pearl.
summary: Pearl shares her life story and career experiences.

title: Talking to myself.
summary: Recollections about life after the success of Hello, Dolly!

title: High tension: the recollections of Hugh Baillie.
summary: Tells the story of his forty years in journalism.

title: The autobiography of Waldron Baily: the life of the novelist and politician from North Carolina.
summary: Recounts life history in North Carolina and his literary contributions.

title: I had to know.
summary: Accounts her experiences with mysticism and her conversion to Catholicism.

title: Josephine.
summary: Memoirs documenting poverty, a glamorous career, and espionage work during WWII.

title: Out on a limb.
summary: A humorous account of coping with life as an amputee.

title: More adventures with David Grayson: adventures in understanding, adventures in solitude, and great possessions.
summary: Entertaining narrative and analysis of life experiences.

title: Wheeling and dealing: confessions of a Capitol Hill operator.
summary: Tales of corruption in Congress and behind-the-scenes politics.

title: Fighting for life.
summary: Promotes hygiene and child health through her experiences.

title: Move that mountain!
summary: Narrates his spiritual journey and career as an evangelist.

title: Ingenue among the lions: the letters of Emily Clark to Joseph Hergesheimer.
summary: Letters giving a daily account of the journal and literary world of the Twenties.

title: Polish circuit rider: the Texas memoirs of Adolf Bakanowski, 1866-70.
summary: Memoirs of a missionary's experiences in Texas and subsequent life.

title: Come North with me: an autobiography.
summary: Aviator explorer describes experiences and expeditions.

title: Stolen sweets.
summary: Narrates juvenile delinquency experiences from a young age.

title: Time and chance.
summary: Records early training, travels, and experiences in journalism and illustration.

title: Of diamonds and diplomats.
summary: Recounts her experiences as social secretary for ambassadors.

title: Roman candle.
summary: Recalls her experiences as social secretary and glamorous life.

title: Reliquiae Baldwinianae; selections from the correspondence of the late William Baldwin, M.D.
summary: Correspondence significant to early natural history.

title: My threescore years and ten: an autobiography.
volume: Series: The Art Experience in Late Nineteenth-Century America.
summary: Documents his artistic challenges and achievements.

title: Melvin J. Ballard: crusader for righteousness.
summary: Biography of a Mormon missionary and church leader.

title: A naturalist's scrapbook.
summary: Reflections on life, research, and colleagues by a biologist.

title: The doctor wears three faces.
summary: Life and challenges of a doctor's wife with a humorous touch.

title: Forty odd.
summary: Explores a woman's coming to terms with aging and identity.

title: Just be yourself.
summary: A lively, pleasantly humorous account of a young mother's initiation and development as a Brownie troop leader in the Puget Sound region.

title: Portraits with backgrounds.
summary: Before becoming an American citizen in the 1940's, Madam Barjansky wandered many European countries, creating portraits of the famous and unfamous.

title: Ramblings in the field of conservation.
summary: Barker discusses his long career as director of the New Mexico Department of Game and Fish with concerns over wildlife management and conservation.

title: Missouri lawyer.
summary: His life in the law from 1898, with anecdotes related to prominent characters and legal matters.

title: The doctor has a family.
summary: Anecdotes of family life with humorous criticism of suburban mores and of modern child-rearing.

title: I love my doctor.
summary: Describes with humor the difficulties of early marriage and establishing her husband's medical practice.

title: That reminds me.
summary: The politician recalls his political career and association with various presidents.

title: I married the Veep.
summary: The story of her courtship and marriage to Vice-President Alben Barkley.

title: Recollections of growing up in America's Southland and of 26 yrs. in Pre-Communist China: 1888-1936.
summary: A well-written account of the author's development as a Christian missionary and his 26 years in China.

title: Life in Custer's cavalry: diaries and letters 1867-1868.
summary: Collection of letters between Captain Albert Barnitz and his wife Jennie during the frontier fighting between the Plains Indians and the U.S. Cavalry.

title: Barnum's own story: the autobiography combined and condensed from the various editions published during his lifetime.
summary: A reprint of the 1927 edition condensing two volumes, detailing Barnum's life and career.

title: Struggles and triumphs of P.T. Barnum: told by himself.
summary: The great impresario recalls highlights of his career as owner of 'The Greatest Show on Earth.'

title: Correspondence of Rev. Louis Baroux, Missionary Apostolic to Michigan, to Rev. M.J. DeNeve.
summary: Clergyman and missionary Baroux wrote letters detailing his missionary efforts among the Pokagon and Potawatomi Indians.

title: A shepherd without sheep.
summary: An anecdotal account of a shepherd's experience remaining in the fold despite being forbidden to practice his priestly powers.

title: Bowery to Bellevue: the story of New York's first woman ambulance surgeon.
summary: The author recalls her internship at Gouverneur Hospital, detailing her experiences on ambulance duty.

title: The natural bent: the memoirs of Dr. Paul B. Barringer.
summary: The memoirs cover childhood memories and educational experiences through military school and medical training.

title: Bellevue is a state of mind.
summary: An investigative report of a week spent in the violent ward of Bellevue, focusing on mental illness.

title: Forty years in Washington.
summary: Impressions of national and international events during his long tenure in Washington as a journalist.

title: I'll be seeing you.
summary: A veteran describes his recuperation and training for civilian life after being blinded in World War II.

title: Confessions of a basketball gypsy.
summary: A story of his rise, fall, and re-entry into the world of sports superstars.

title: Too much, too soon.
summary: Written after her attempted suicide, the book recounts her turbulent life and childhood.

title: All my sins remembered.
summary: Life with John Barrymore was characterized by violent passion, jealousy, and alcohol.

title: Memories: an autobiography by Ethel Barrymore.
summary: The autobiographical account of her long and successful career as a prominent actress.

title: Confessions of an actor.
summary: A superficial stroll through selected memories of his childhood and dramatic career.

title: We Barrymores.
summary: A reminiscence of his personal and professional life in theater and film from a significant member of a famous acting family.

title: I lost a thousand pounds.
summary: A theater and night club entertainer shares his childhood origins of obesity, exploring personal growth.

title: The papers of Josiah Bartlett.
summary: Collection of letters revealing Bartlett's political activities and personal insights during significant historical periods.

title: My lifetime in sports.
summary: A reminiscence by a sports reporter about notable events and personalities in sports over fifty years.

title: Travels of William Bartram.
summary: Bartram's record of his explorations in the South provides significant insights into early American geography and anthropology.

title: Baruch.
summary: A distinguished statesman discusses his personal philosophy and career.

title: Adventures of a prisoner of war, 1863-1864.
summary: A Confederate officer recounts his experiences of captivity, escape, and the turmoil of war.

title: I grew up with basketball: twenty years of barnstorming with cage greats of yesterday.
summary: A retired commissioner recalls early years of basketball coaching and management.

title: The long shadow of Little Rock.
summary: As head of the Arkansas NAACP, Bates led the struggle of the Black community to integrate schools in Little Rock.

title: The diary of Edward Bates: 1859-1866.
summary: A detailed record of Bates' life, serving as U.S. Attorney General amidst political and military events.

title: Through sunlight and shadow.
summary: The story of an American missionary couple working in India amidst personal challenges.

title: Harold Bauer: his book.
summary: A lively account of Bauer's life as a concert pianist and his experiences in Europe and America.

title: Secret service chief.
summary: A former Secret Service Chief describes his experiences protecting presidents and addressing threats.

title: It was all quite different: the memoirs of Vicki Baum.
summary: The memoirs of a successful novelist and screenwriter detailing her life in Europe and Hollywood.

title: Pass it on: four generations of missionary service.
summary: A third-generation Baptist missionary recounts his experiences in China and the intertwining of faith and politics.

title: Intermission: a true story.
summary: Movie actress recalls her marriage to rancher Ron Gait and the challenges of love, motherhood, and her career.

title: Bax seat: log of a pasture pilot.
summary: Collection of humorous columns reflecting a love for airplanes and aviation.

title: Village creek: the first and only eyewitness account of the second life of Gordon Baxter.
summary: A disc jockey discusses his 27-year marriage to the perfect mother of his eight children.

title: Marvella: a personal journey.
summary: Marvella Bayh's life story begins on an Oklahoma farm, detailing her marriage and activism.

title: MS and us: an autobiography.
summary: Beach describes her experience with multiple sclerosis, detailing her emotional struggles.

title: Shakespeare and company.
summary: Beach describes her life as a bookseller, librarian, and patron in the literary circle of Paris.

title: Yankee auctioneer: wherein are to be found the reminiscences and philosophy of a country auctioneer.
summary: Bean depicts a vanishing life style through his experiences as a country auctioneer.

title: My story: the autobiography of a down-East merchant.
summary: The autobiography includes family photographs and letters, emphasizing Bean's impact on the local economy.

title: Pro: Frank Beard on the golf tour.
summary: A year in the life of a golf pro during his successful tour.

title: Diary of a Kriegie.
summary: A journalist's diary while a German prisoner of war during WWII.

title: Journals of Charles Beatty, 1762-1769.
summary: Beatty's journals recount travels for preaching and fundraising from 1762 to 1769.

title: Memoirs of a volunteer, 1861-1863.
summary: Beatty’s diary chronicles the Civil War experience of a soldier.

title: Career ambassador.
summary: Highlights Beaulac's extensive career in American diplomacy.

title: Wm. Beaumont's formative years: two early notebooks, 1811-1821.
summary: Includes medical observations and travel notes from Beaumont's early life.

title: America day by day.
summary: Beauvoir's travel impressions of America in the early 1950s.

title: Treat it gentle.
summary: A jazz musician recounts his life experiences through dictated tapes.

title: All the years were grand.
summary: A minister's wife reflects on her lively earlier days of work and travel.

title: Second carrot from the end.
summary: Experience in developing the Farmers Market in Los Angeles.

title: Fighter pilot.
summary: A narrative revealing the spirit of World War II shortly before Beck awaited escape through the French Underground.

title: "What is the good of history?": selected letters of Carl L. Becker, 1900-1945.
summary: A selection of Becker's letters providing insights into his thoughts on history and politics.

title: The life and adventures of James P. Beckwourth: mountaineer, scout, and pioneer, and chief of the Crow Nation of Indians.
summary: The adventures of Beckwourth, a legendary figure of the American West.

title: Adventures with a Texas naturalist.
summary: Bedichek's experiences in the Texas outdoors as a naturalist.

title: Journal of Dr. Lewis Beebe.
summary: An account of Beebe's expedition against Canada during the American Revolution.

title: A bishop of the Great Plains.
summary: Recollections of Beecher's life as an Episcopal bishop in Nebraska.

title: Autobiography.
publisher: Belknap Press of Harvard University Press
summary: Correspondence and recollections of a New England minister reflecting on his faith.

title: A mind that found itself: an autobiography.
summary: Beers recounts his mental illness and the experience of recovery.

title: Deadline.
summary: Begley writes about her career as a reporter covering various significant events.

title: Martin Behrman of New Orleans: memoirs of a city boss.
summary: Behrman reflects on his controversial political life as the mayor of New Orleans.

title: People in a diary; a memoir.
summary: Behrman offers an account of his life among the wealthy and their social circles.

title: Josiah Belden, 1841 California overland pioneer: his memoir and early letters.
summary: Belden recounts his journey with the 1841 Bartleson overland expedition.

title: A journey to Ohio in 1810 as recorded in the journal of Margaret Van Horn Dwight.
summary: A witty account of a young woman's wagon trip from Connecticut to Ohio.

title: The lives and times of just Molly: an autobiography.
summary: Bell reflects on her experiences as a mother and grandmother.

title: Irregular gentleman.
summary: A narrative of travel and adventure by Bellah, conveying the significance of real experiences.

title: Melvin Belli: my life on trial: an autobiography.
summary: The life and notable trials of this flamboyant California trial lawyer.

title: To Jerusalem and back: a personal account.
summary: Bellow's account of a trip to Israel and observations on its diverse population.

title: The suspended drawing room.
summary: A collection of Behrman's shorter prose pieces.

title: Fabric of memory.
summary: The story of a prominent actress and her work as a patron of the arts.

title: Translated from the Hungarian; notes toward an autobiography. Illustrated.
summary: After serving in World War I, he became an architect in Philadelphia, where he reflected on his life.

title: Selected letters.
summary: A cross-section of letters selected from his extensive correspondence to illustrate the development of his personal and professional life.

title: Sage of Petaluma: autobiography of a teacher by J. Abner Peddiwell.
summary: A mythical autobiography reflecting on the universality of experiences of a generation.

title: Fifty years in neurology and psychiatry.
summary: Describes his own work and achievements in neurology and psychiatry.

title: Forts and forays: the diary of a dragoon in New Mexico, 1850-1856.
summary: A diary documenting Bennett's experiences and observations while serving in the Army.
other_places_lived: Rochester, New York; Santa Fe, New Mexico

title: An American in art: a professional and technical autobiography.
summary: An account of his technical development as an artist.

title: An artist in America.
summary: Amplified autobiography discussing his role in the regionalist movement in American art.

title: Bernard Berenson treasury: a selection from the works, unpublished writings, letters, diaries, and journals of the most celebrated humanist of our times, 1887-1958.
summary: An anthology of the art critic's writings, documenting his thoughts and reactions from 1887 to 1958.

title: Conversations with Berenson.
summary: A compilation of notes from many conversations with Berenson, discussing various subjects.

title: Passionate sightseer: from the diaries, 1947-1956.
summary: An art historian records his passion for visual art and nature in his travel journals.

title: Bennett playbill.
summary: Bennett's recollections of her theatrical family, reflecting on their fiery and controversial dynamics.

title: Molly and me.
summary: Berg's account of her family's Jewish life and her career in radio.

title: Memoirs of an anti-Zionist Jew.
summary: The memoirs of an anti-Zionist Jew advocating for Arab Palestinian rights.

title: Ingrid Bergman: my story.
summary: Bergman discusses her rise to film stardom and her personal life.

title: Navigating the rapids, 1918-1971.
summary: Berle records his interactions between corporate and political power.

title: Milton Berle, an autobiography.
summary: An autobiography chronicling Berle’s sixty years in show business.

title: The three worlds of Leonid.
summary: Leonid recounts his life in pre-revolutionary Russia and his journey to America.

title: Self-portrait of a family: letters by Jessie, Dorothy Lee, Claude and David Bernard, with commentary by Jessie Bernard.
summary: Bernard edits her children's letters to illustrate the experience of single parenthood.

title: Biography of an idea: memoirs of a public relations counsel.
summary: An account of public relations as a new discipline and the issues involved.

title: A surgeon's domain.
summary: Bernheim analyzes surgery and surgeons through his experienced eyes.

title: A sky of my own.
summary: Describes her experience learning to fly after World War II.

title: Yogi: the autobiography of a professional baseball player.
summary: An autobiography detailing Berra's experiences and popularity in baseball.

title: America is hard to find.
summary: A collection of writings during Berrigan's time underground and in prison.

title: Lights on in the house of the dead; a prison diary.
summary: Berrigan's journals from his time in federal prison.

title: Prison journals of a priest revolutionary.
summary: Journals written during Philip Berrigan's imprisonment.

title: Widen the prison gates; writing from jails, April 1970-Dec. 1972.
summary: A collection of journals and letters from Philip Berrigan's time imprisoned.

title: Amazing grace; with Charles Evers in Mississippi.
summary: Berry records his experiences during the Mississippi gubernatorial campaign.

title: John Bertram of Salem, Massachusetts: his own account of incidents in his life.
summary: Chronicles the life of a sailor during maritime activities.

title: Early memoirs of a country gentleman.
summary: Diary recordings of Best's coming-of-age experiences.

title: Northern farm: a chronicle of Maine.
summary: Explores farm life in Maine and the alienation from nature.

title: The outermost house: a year of life on the great beach of Cape Cod.
summary: A meditative description of nature and solitude on Cape Cod.

title: Bulls, balls, bicycles and actors.
summary: After working at a great variety of jobs in his youth, Bickford tried burlesque, vaudeville, road shows, and stock companies, acquiring there the training which led him to his first roles on Broadway and in the movies. His subsequent fifty-year career was marked with a defiance of conformity and a taste for rebelliousness.

title: A casual past.
summary: A record up to 1939 of his illustrious forbears, education, and early career as a Philadelphia lawyer by a man who later became U.S. Attorney General (1941-1945).

title: In brief authority.
summary: A continuation of the author's autobiographical A Casual Past, this volume is divided into four sections: 1. The Labor Board, TVA investigation and Circuit Court of Appeals; 2. Solicitor General; 3. Attorney General; and 4. The Nurnberg Trial.

title: Tahitian journal.
summary: Prefaced by some memories of his World War I experiences, Biddle's book is mainly the journal he kept during his stay in Tahiti (1920-22) where he went to isolate himself to paint without interruption. He lived in a remote village with the natives, learned their language and customs, and came to understand their ways.

title: The letters of Ambrose Bierce.
summary: A consummate satirist, Bierce wrote articles for newspapers and creative stories exploring, as he said, 'the ways of hate as a form of creative energy.' He is a coiner of words, creator of clear description, and master of verbal restraint.

title: Twenty-one letters of Ambrose Bierce.
summary: Samuel Loveman, an aspiring amateur poet, evidently sent several of his poems to author Ambrose Bierce, who functioned as a critic and agent in trying to get them published. These 21 brief letters, 1908-1913, concern this attempt; they contain some criticism of the poems as well as pleasantries.

title: Young sports photographer with the Green Bay Packers.
summary: His father was official photographer for the Packers. By the time he was thirteen he was skillful enough with a camera that his father allowed him to help photograph a game. He continued through his high school years, after which he wrote this book.

title: The journal of Andrew Bihaly.
summary: A victim of the horrors of World War II, Bihaly reflects on the cataclysmic changes during the sixties in his adopted America. Alone but trying to communicate his feelings, he sought help from a psychiatrist, worked in the Free Store on Cooper Square, but ultimately was overcome by despair and killed himself.

title: Of me I sing.
summary: A plainspoken, humorous narrative about a Michigan high school dropout who worked his way up in journalism to become editor of the Detroit Free Press. His book includes much of the social and political history of Michigan in his time.

title: Amazons: an intimate memoir by the first woman ever to play in the National Hockey League.
summary: A flip and often funny account of the unconventional characters she encounters in an athletic career as a rookie with the New York Rangers.

title: Something for everybody is not enough: an educator's search for his education.
summary: The President of Staten Island Community College, who describes his career as 'checkered' and 'rather difficult,' writes of those parts of his education that have turned out to be useful.

title: Notes on a journey in America: from the Coast of Virginia to the Territory of Illinois.
summary: Emigrating to America in 1817, Birkbeck, a knowledgeable English agriculturalist, traveled through eastern America and settled in Illinois. He records his impressions of the country he passed through and evaluates different areas as possible farm sites for his colonization project with an eye toward fertility, salubrious climate, and the character of the present inhabitants.

title: It was fun while it lasted.
summary: Recollections of his boyhood and family life in Harlem (1915-20) include stories of Sunday outings, apartment life in the then respectable suburb, the first family car, the coming of World War I, the growing pains of maturity, told with a poignant, critical affection for his parents and a deep love for his sister.

title: Letters of James Gillespie Birney, 1831-1857.
summary: Letters written and received by Birney give a contemporary picture of the antislavery movement from the perspective of a Southern abolitionist, advocate of freedom of the press, and Liberty Party candidate for President of the United States.

title: A lady's life in the Rocky Mountains.
summary: An English lady who traveled alone for her own recreation and interest, the author exercised her geographical knowledge, feeling for beauty, and capacity for description in her letters to her sister. She traveled and lived in Colorado, particularly in the Longs Peak-Estes Park region, enduring hardships cheerfully and appreciating the beauty of the mountains.

title: Abraham Bisno: union pioneer.
summary: A well-known leader among Jewish garment workers in Chicago and New York gives an account of his early life and the beginning of unions in the women's garment industry.

title: My life on the Mississippi, or why I am not Mark Twain.
summary: Bissell, who has been called 'a modern Mark Twain' because he writes books about the Mississippi and has been a riverboat pilot, protests with tongue in cheek about the comparison. His book contains amusing stories about his steamboating days on the rivers.

title: Moscow was my parish.
summary: A well-written account of the urbane Father Bissonette's experience as a chaplain in Moscow focuses more on his travels around Russia than on his clerical duties. In 1955, he was suddenly expelled without apparent reason.

title: This is my life.
summary: Mrs. Bjorn writes warm, humorous anecdotes of her life after the publication of her first book, Papa's Wife. No longer content to remain only a housewife and mother, she added lecturing, traveling, and more writing to her full life.

title: Sincerely your friend: letters of Mr. Justice Hugo L. Black to Jerome A. Cooper.
summary: A brief collection of letters from the U.S. Supreme Court Justice to one of his law clerks.

title: Black Elk speaks.
summary: A powerful narrative of Indian life, of the changes brought by white settlers, of Custer's Last Stand, of the Battle of Wounded Knee, but primarily of the old ways and their deep spiritual value.

title: Life of MA-KA-TAI-ME-SHE-KIA-KIAK, or Black Hawk, dictated by himself.
summary: The story of the famous Sauk chief, based on the 1833 edition which he is said to have dictated to an army translator.

title: The guts to win.
publisher: Golf Digest, Inc., New York Times
summary: Feminist golfer Blalock describes her career on the Ladies Professional Golf Association circuit, 1969-1976. She devotes two chapters to vindicating herself against LPGA charges that she cheated in tournaments in 1972 by moving the putt marker; she fought ostracism, harassment, and was threatened with suspension from the LPGA.

title: Torpedoboat sailor.
summary: Blackford writes of his naval service in World War I aboard the destroyers Paulding and McDougal. He skillfully evokes the group camaraderie among the enlisted men and re-creates military strategy in his accounts of naval raids on other ships.

title: Letters from Lee's army: memoirs of life in and out of the army in Virginia during the war between the states.
summary: The letters of Susan Leigh Colston Blackford and Charles Minor Blackford record their observations of war-time life in the South, 1861-1865. This is an abridged version of a small edition privately printed in 1894.

title: Pioneer work in opening the medical profession to women: autobiographical sketches.
summary: Blackwell fought to study and practice medicine in the mid-nineteenth century, learning first from medical books, then studying at Geneva University. Acceptance was hard won on all fronts, but she emerged as the first woman in America to receive a complete medical education. Dedicated to her profession and to furthering women's opportunities in medicine, Dr. Blackwell never married but adopted a daughter. She also founded a hospital.

title: Very Willing Griffin: the story of the smallest boat ever to compete in the Single-handed Transatlantic Race.
summary: After describing the extensive preparation for his race, the book is primarily his daily log kept for the 52 days of the race. Blagden writes of the technical matter crucial to such a voyage, but also of the mental stress common to this kind of rigorous but lonely adventure.

title: You have to pay the price.
summary: A football coach for 25 years at Dartmouth and West Point, his book is about the game, the Army, and the values inherent in both.

title: Of life and love and things.
summary: The ordinary life of a pleasant, ordinary woman living among friends and family in a small town in West Virginia, emphasizing her work as wife, mother, and Girl Scout Leader.

title: A sports editor finds Christ.
summary: Blake intermingles the account of his career as a newspaper sports reporter (mostly for the Atlanta Journal) with his activities, 1910-1940, as a Christian 'saved' from alcoholism by evangelical religion.

title: The papers of Alfred Blalock.
summary: An enormous compendium of the professional papers of Alfred Blalock, M.D., cardiovascular specialist at the Johns Hopkins University Medical School. These range from investigations of biliary tract disease, to mastoid disease, to the regulation of blood circulation, to a great many papers on shock and various aspects of heart disease. Though highly technical, the papers are lucid, articulate, and to the point.

title: Personal and controversial: an autobiography.
summary: A graduate of Harvard Divinity School and Brooklyn Law School, Blanchard traces his career 'from Christian fundamentalist to humanist atheist, from stodgy Puritan to sexual rebel, from doctrinaire socialist to socialistic pragmatist.'

title: Challenging years: the memoirs of Harriot Stanton Blatch.
summary: A brisk narrative of the author's childhood growing up in the 'cradle of the feminist movement,' her education and marriage, followed by a sometimes intense account of the suffrage movement in New York, the campaign for the Nineteenth Amendment, and finally a tough look at the world's work left yet for women to do — child-labor laws, activities to preserve peace, economic advancement for women, etc.

title: Narrative of John Blatchford: detailing his sufferings in the Revolutionary War, while a prisoner with the British, as related by himself.
summary: In 1777 he enlisted as a cabin boy on a continental ship which was soon captured by the British. For the next six years he was on several prison ships, was sent to do forced labor in the East Indies, and finally was returned home.

title: I remember you.
summary: The author of The Exorcist writes fondly of the difficult years of urban poverty in New York, his Lebanese immigrant parents, but especially of his mother with whom he believes he has made contact after death.

title: Fighting back.
summary: Pittsburgh Steeler linebacker Bleier offers an unusually candid and critical self-appraisal. After playing football for Notre Dame and for the Pittsburgh Steelers in 1967 and 1968, Bleier was drafted and sent to Vietnam in 1969. His foot was badly damaged by a grenade. Through perseverance and extensive physical therapy and weight lifting, he not only recovered but returned to the Steelers to play much better than before his injury.

title: Hoofs in the distance.
summary: 'The Gibson Girl of Madison Square Garden' horse shows nostalgically describes the shows she entered, mounts she rode, travels she took to Maine and Europe, and hunts she rode in as Mistress of the Fox Hounds.

title: Autobiography of Sol Bloom.
summary: In 1945, Bloom, aged 75, was one of seven American delegates sent to draft the charter of the United Nations. The son of Polish immigrants, he sold newspapers at age six, rose in the entertainment world to become the biggest publisher of popular music in the United States by 29, became a congressman at 54, serving under four presidents for over 25 years.

title: Bobst: the autobiography of a pharmaceutical pioneer.
summary: A magnate in the modern pharmaceutical industry writes a sentimental account of his rise to wealth and subsequent philanthropic activities.

title: Knight of the napkin: memoirs of fifty years' experience in many lands.
summary: A waiter, proud of his work, summarizes his apprenticeship in Europe before immigrating to the United States, his many years of service in restaurants here since 1907, with brief opinions about various aspects of his work life.

title: My life and loves in Greenwich Village.
summary: Poet Max Bodenheim recalls his encounter with a variety of often seamy, sordid aspects of Bohemian life in Greenwich Village in the 1920's and 1930's.

title: Letters: 1925-1967.
summary: Five hundred of the 2300 lively, perceptive letters exchanged between writers Bontemps and Hughes, 1925-1967, are included here, chronicling their social and racial conflicts as well as the Civil Rights revolution.

title: Love in Shadow.
summary: Boettinger provides biographies of his parents, exploring their relationship and his own reflections on their lives.

title: The honeymoon is over.
summary: Traveling as entertainers with four teenage daughters presented many problems, met with Christian resolve in uneven proportions but with general success.

title: What the woman lived; selected letters of Louise Bogan, 1920-1970.
summary: Bogan earned her living by writing literary criticism, but poetry was her life interest. Her letters provide insight into the creative process.

title: Between actor and critic: selected letters of Edwin Booth and William Winter.
summary: These annotated letters cover the twenty-year period of friendship (1869-1890) between theater and literature, documenting their professional activities.

title: Much have I learned.
summary: A thoughtful analysis of ordinary experiences that became significant for the prominent urban sociologist after his retirement.

title: Edwin Booth: recollections by his daughter, Edwina Booth Groosmann, and letters to her and to his friends.
summary: The collected letters of a famous actor reveal his affection for his daughter and details of his personal life while touring.

title: Alexander letters, 1787-1900.
summary: These letters of the Alexander family begin with their settlement in Georgia in 1787, chronicling their culture and experiences through 1900.

title: Witness to history, 1929-1969.
summary: Memoir of a diplomat involved in American-Soviet relations, providing impressions of the U.S. leaders during this era.

title: Backcount'y journal: reminiscences of a wilderness photographer.
summary: This book reflects the mystical qualities of his landscape photographs and aims to capture the essence of the landscape.

title: True adventures of a little country girl: an autobiographical narrative.
summary: Recalls cheerful childhood on a farm in Vermont with a loving family and lots of pets.

title: Under Gemini: a memoir.
summary: Mary Miller writes about her childhood after her parents died, focusing on her twin sister and the challenges faced by her family.

title: Ball four: my life and hard times throwing the knuckleball in the big leagues.
summary: A diary of a baseball season spent on an expansion team by a former New York Yankee.

title: The journals of Ashley Bowen (1728-1813) of Marblehead.
summary: Bowen's journals cover years spent as a seaman and merchant captain, detailing daily activities and navigation specifics.

title: Promises to keep: my years in public life, 1941-1969.
summary: A record of his public life which began when he was forty and lasted for 29 years, reflecting one man's futile effort to buck the so-called 'Establishment'.

title: Across the continent: a summer's journey to the Rocky Mountains, the Mormons, and the Pacific States with Speaker Colfax.
summary: An account dominated by mannered descriptions of American landscapes and cities, mixed with thoughts on the Indian Question and personal insights.

title: The world that was.
summary: A nostalgic recollection of his boyhood, emphasizing the strong influence of his father's wisdom and values.
occupations: Chancellor of the University of Pittsburgh

title: Belle Boyd in camp and prison: written by herself; a new edition prepared from new materials.
summary: An account of Boyd's espionage during the Civil War, and her life afterwards on the stage and lecture platform.

title: As I live and breathe: stages of an autobiography.
summary: Boyd recounts his journey from Hollywood to studying for the Episcopal priesthood, detailing his societal engagements and personal beliefs.
occupations: College chaplain, civil rights demonstrator, fighter against poverty

title: Baa, baa, black sheep.
summary: The story of Boyington's life and adventures as a military pilot, particularly his command of a group of misfits known as the Black Sheep.

title: The long walk at San Francisco State.
summary: A reflection by Boyle on her experiences during the student strikes at San Francisco State University.

title: Diplomats and demagogues: the memoirs of Spruille Braden.
summary: Braden’s memoirs reflecting on his experiences as a prominent diplomat and member of the John Birch Society.

title: The letters of Gamaliel Bradford: 1918-1931.
summary: The letters reveal the breadth of Bradford's interests and his wit conveyed through correspondence.

title: Life and I: an autobiography of humanity.
summary: A psychological and philosophical study of the 'I' and the contrasting desires that threaten the 'I'.

title: Born with the blues; Perry Bradford's own story; the true story of the pioneering blues singers and musicians in the early days of jazz.
summary: The story of his campaign to get recording companies to record Negro girl singer Mamie Smith and other musicians, which led to significant industry profits.

title: A soldier's story.
summary: Bradley recounts his experiences during World War II, including personal relationships with prominent military figures.

title: Along the way: an autobiography.
summary: An account of Bradley's prominent ministry and long career in the Peoples Church of Chicago.

title: Will Bradley, his chap book: an account in the words of the dean of American typographers, of his graphic arts adventures.
summary: An account of Bradley's journey through the graphic arts industry, reflecting on his impactful career.

title: Life on the run.
summary: Bradley's analysis of the life of a professional touring athlete, emphasizing the human elements of team dynamics.

title: Big top: my forty years with the greatest show on earth.
summary: An account of life with the Barnum and Bailey circus, including terminology and memorable acts.

title: Terry Bradshaw: man of steel.
summary: An account detailing Bradshaw's career as an NFL quarterback, interlaced with aspects of his personal life.

title: Superchic.
summary: An irreverent account of the fashion industry from the perspective of the former publisher of prestigious magazines.

title: I remember.
summary: A collection of memories focusing mainly on family life and American culture.

title: Journey with David Brainerd: forty days or forty nights with David Brainerd.
summary: A devotional guide compiled from selections of Brainerd's writings, aimed at fostering spiritual experience.

title: Yes, Lord.
summary: The memoirs of Bredesen recounting his seminary days and diverse Christian endeavors.

title: An immigrant's shenanigans: thirty-three jobs in twenty years.
summary: Breen shares his immigrant experience in America through various jobs and visits to relatives in Europe.

title: Life and diary.
summary: An account of Brainerd's life and missionary work among American Indians, revealing his spiritual journey.

title: Life with my Mary.
summary: N/A

title: False starts.
summary: An account of the author's early life and criminal activities leading to his eventual success as a novelist.

title: Fling wide the gates.
summary: An account of the author's spiritual journey and conversion to Christianity after a troubled youth.

title: Letters of Louis D. Brandeis.
publisher: State University of New York Press
summary: A collection showcasing Brandeis' role as a leading reformer and jurist during the progressive era.

title: Here's Bob.
summary: A recount of Braun's career in television and personal life as an entertainer.

title: Journal of William H. Brawley, 1864-1865.
summary: A journal documenting Brawley's experiences as a Confederate envoy and law student in Europe.

title: Helldorado: bringing the law to the Mesquite.
summary: A vivid recollection of life as a lawman during the late 19th century in Arizona.

title: The political education of Arnold Brecht: an autobiography, 1884-1970.
summary: An account blending personal reminiscence and political contemplation focusing on German history from WWI to the rise of Hitler.

title: An assassin's diary.
summary: Diary entries from the would-be assassin of George Wallace detailing his plans and thoughts.

title: From mine pit to pulpit.
summary: A memoir detailing the experiences of a retired Methodist clergyman from his time in the anthracite mines to his ministry.

title: The seven stairs.
summary: N/A

title: Brereton diaries: the war in the air in the Pacific, Middle East and Europe, 3 October 1941-8 May 1945.
summary: A personal account of World War II from the perspective of the Commander of the Far East Air Forces.

title: The little grandmother of the Russian Revolution; reminiscences and letters of Catherine Breshkovsky.
summary: A compilation of letters, speeches, and materials about Breshkovsky's role in the Russian Revolution and her fundraising efforts in the U.S.

title: Time of my death.
summary: An analytical recounting of a plane crash in which the author was severely injured, detailing his rehabilitation process.

title: The world of Jimmy Breslin.
summary: A collection of Breslin's writings, annotated to capture the nuances of his commentary on various subjects.

title: A story of toil and tears/of love and laughter.
summary: Brewer emphasizes his lifelong career as a gospel preacher and devotes chapters to confession, salvation, rebaptism, anthropomorphisms — describing God in human terms.

title: Up and down in California, 1860-1864: the journal of William H. Brewer, Professor of Agriculture in the Sheffield Scientific School from 1864 to 1903.
summary: Brewer wrote three picturesque letters while serving as a horticulturalist for the California State Geological Survey under the direction of Josiah Dwight Whitney.

title: Fifty years of prison service: an autobiography.
summary: Brockway devoted his long life to the work of reformation and rehabilitation of prisoners and the protection of society.
