title: This is Norman Brokenshire: an unvarnished self-portrait.
summary: A prominent disc jockey and radio commentator describes his life and his long struggle with alcoholism.

title: From my experience: the pleasures and miseries of life on a farm.
summary: A realistic but pleasant account of his years as a farmer, after assessing the experience of World War II and his fame as a writer moved him to return to the land of his boyhood.

title: Monkey off my back: an ex-convict and addict relates his discovery of personal freedom.
summary: The grim details of his life as a criminal and dope addict, with graphic descriptions of his experience in various prisons, including one in which he shared a cell with Clyde Barrow.

title: Big Bill blues: William Broonzy's story as told to Yannick Bruynoghe.
summary: Big Bill Broonzy tells fascinating tales about his development as a country blues singer and guitar player, showing how many of his over three-hundred songs lamented painful incidents in his life or the lives of his friends and lovers.

title: Days of the phoenix: the nineteen-twenties I remember.
summary: His personal reminiscences are also literary history, including his experience with such writers as Lewis Mumford, Sinclair Lewis, Sherwood Anderson, and Theodore Dreiser.

title: Morning faces: a book of children and parents.
summary: Narrative chapters describe the interactions of father and two sons growing up together.

title: I testify; my years as an undercover agent for the F.B.I.
summary: Mrs. Brown recounts her experiences as an FBI agent inside a communist network from 1951 to 1960.

title: Autobiography of a female slave.
summary: An excellent narrative of slave life, detailing the pain and degradation experienced by the author.

title: Adventures with D.W. Griffith.
summary: A memoir detailing Brown's experiences in the motion-picture business, particularly with D.W. Griffith.

title: I married a dinosaur.
summary: A humorous account of the author's early years of marriage and fossil hunting in India and Burma.

title: P.B.: the Paul Brown story.
summary: An account of Brown's career as a football coach, emphasizing his team philosophy.

title: The hills are strong.
summary: A memoir reflecting on growing up in southeastern Ohio and his development as an author.

title: Aaron Burr expedition: letters to Ephraim Brown from Silas Brown, 1805-1815.
summary: Silas Brown's letters detail his experiences as a member of Aaron Burr's expedition.

title: Narrative of William W. Brown: a fugitive slave, and a lecture delivered before the Female Anti-Slave Society of Salem, 1847.
summary: A best-selling narrative by a fugitive slave detailing his experiences and insights.

title: A dangerous journey: California 1849.
summary: A record of the natural beauty and violence encountered during Browne's journey in 1849.

title: J. Ross Browne: his letters, journals and writings.
summary: A collection of writings that detail Browne's ambitions and experiences as a traveler and writer.

title: Forty-four years of the life of a hunter: being reminiscences of Meshach Browning, a Maryland hunter, roughly written down by himself.
summary: A record of early nineteenth-century life in the Maryland mountains, chronicling the author's experiences.

title: Autobiography of Louis Brownlow.
summary: A detailed account of Brownlow's life, focusing on his career and contributions to journalism and city governments.

title: Brownson-Hecker correspondence.
summary: A collection of letters exploring the correspondence between Brownson and Hecker, alongside biographical notes.

title: Hog p.wild: the autobiography of Frank Broyles.
summary: Broyles details his career as an athletic director and football player, including anecdotes from his coaching experiences.

title: Honey: the life and loves of Lenny's shady lady.
summary: A revealing account of Lenny Bruce's wife during their tumultuous relationship.

title: How to talk dirty and influence people; an autobiography.
summary: Bruce's autobiography discusses his life as a comedian and explores themes of free speech.

title: Mr. Buchanan's administration on the eve of the rebellion.
summary: Buchanan's interpretation of the events leading up to the Civil War, emphasizing the role of Northern abolitionists.

title: As now remembered: the interesting life of an average man.
summary: A personal account detailing Brunner's life and contributions to social research.

title: The oilman who didn't want to become a millionaire: his own story.
summary: Brunson chronicles his life from a Mississippi cotton farm to finding success in the oil industry.

title: Memoirs of William Jennings Bryan: by himself and his wife.
summary: A life story completed by his wife using correspondence and documents from Bryan's life.

title: The letters of William Cullen Bryant.
summary: A collection of letters from Bryant to noteworthy figures, exploring various themes.

title: I have lived with the American people.
summary: An exploration of the Filipino immigrant experience in the U.S., addressing prejudice and understanding.

title: Women are my problem: the autobiography of an obstetrician and gynecologist.
summary: Bubis shares his experiences and thoughts on women from his perspective as a medical professional.

title: Airborne: a sentimental journey.
summary: In new journalistic style, laced with pithy observations, and with wit more gentle than acerbic, Buckley narrates the transatlantic voyage of his sailboat Cyrano with its crew of six, giving his history as a sailor since age 13 and analyzing his close relationships with his wife and son, Christopher.

title: United Nations journal; a delegate's odyssey.
summary: As a member of the U.S. Delegation to the UN General Assembly for three months during 1973, the author writes a readable and informative analysis of his experiences, discussing topics like Cuba, the Mideast War, human rights, African art, and freedom of information.

title: The unmaking of a mayor.
summary: Here is Buckley's account of his campaign and the events that led to the 1965 New York mayoralty elections.

title: This is my story.
summary: Budenz describes the rationale of his conversion to the Catholic Church, detailing his eleven years in the Communist Party and his eventual resignation to write and teach.

title: Don Budge: a tennis memoir.
summary: Budge describes key tennis matches he played, including the greatest match, and offers advice on playing tennis.

title: The memoirs of Clarence Clough Buel, 1850-1933: condensed from the original manuscript entitled 'Sixty Years with the Press.'
summary: This engaging narrative of Buel's life documents his experiences as an immigrant and a reporter, giving a glimpse into his interactions with iconic figures of the time.

title: The life and letters of Charles Bulfinch, architect, with other family papers.
summary: This volume combines diary entries and letters, depicting Bulfinch's life as a leading architect in Boston and his contributions to notable structures.

title: America is in the heart: a personal history.
summary: Bulosan describes his experiences growing up in the Philippines, immigrating to America, and the challenges he faced with racial bias and poverty.

title: The story of Jim Bunning.
summary: The story of a pitcher in modern major league baseball who pitched a perfect game, detailing his rise in baseball.

title: Now I remember: autobiography of an amateur naturalist.
summary: Burgess writes about his childhood and the evolution of his career as a writer and naturalist, reflecting on his experiences and contributions to literature.

title: The thief: the autobiography of Wayne Burk.
summary: A portrayal of the life of a professional thief and gunman, providing insights into his worldview and experiences as a fugitive.

title: The late Liz: the autobiography of an ex-pagan.
summary: A slangy, semi-tough account of the author's affluent marriages, addictions, and her journey to discover evangelical religion.

title: I love her, that's why!: an autobiography.
summary: Burns shares his experiences as an actor and comedian, detailing his career and partnership with Gracie Allen.

title: I'm an endangered species: the autobiography of a free enterpriser.
summary: Byrd discusses his life as a multimillionaire through wildcat drilling and his various business expansions.

title: Honest, Abe: is there really no business like show business?
summary: Burrows shares the story of his life, detailing his journey from salesman to successful figure in radio and television.

title: Discovery: the story of the second Byrd Antarctic expedition.
summary: An eloquent memoir detailing the 1934 return voyage to Antarctica, incorporating descriptions of exploration and survival.

title: The secret diary of William Byrd of Westover, 1709-1712.
summary: One of the earliest extensive diaries by a Southern colonist, this work was written in shorthand by Byrd, a prominent planter. It presents a detailed narrative of colonial life in Tidewater Virginia at the beginning of the eighteenth century.

title: All in one lifetime.
summary: The life of a distinguished statesman who served as Congressman, Senator, Supreme Court Justice, Secretary of State, and Governor of South Carolina.

title: Surgeon of hope.
summary: Byron's career as a surgeon at the City of Hope Hospital, Los Angeles, is permeated by his evangelical Christian faith, so strong that he risked court-martial for proselytizing when he was a doctor in the U.S. Marine Corps.

title: As I remember it: some epilogues in recollection.
summary: A narrative about his career as a writer, with extensive descriptions of his interactions with some of the people who most influenced him.

title: Between friends: letters of James Branch Cabell and others.
summary: Letters of authors during the post-World War I years reveal their varied opinions on numerous subjects, including Cabell's controversial novel, Jurgen.

title: The letters of James Branch Cabell.
summary: Most of the letters by a Southern novelist are to other literary figures, including Ellen Glasgow, Sinclair Lewis, Carl Van Doren, H.L. Mencken.

title: Preface to the past.
summary: A collection of commentaries and notes, most originally accompanied the several volumes of Cabell's Biography of the Life of Manuel.

title: The education of Abraham Cahan.
name_of_translator: Leon Stein, Abraham P. Conan, Lynn Davison
summary: After immigrating from Lithuania, he became a teacher, lawyer, socialist agitator, trade unionist — precursors to his editorship of the Jewish Daily Forward.
occupations: Teacher, Lawyer, Socialist Agitator, Trade Unionist

title: Autobiography of Charles Caldwell, M.D.
summary: This is the hyperbolic, self-defensive autobiography of 'the Horatio Alger of medicine,' a physician in the War of 1812 and a prolific author.

title: Call it experience: the years of learning how to write.
summary: Beginning with his early days as a stringer for local Georgia newspapers, Caldwell describes the hard work getting started as a writer.

title: The papers of John C. Calhoun.
summary: A thorough, scholarly collection of Calhoun's papers focuses on his presidential prospects and various political issues.

title: "And hearing not — ": annals of an adman.
summary: Deaf from early childhood, the author writes of his difficult adjustment to the world with this handicap.

title: The way of an investigator: a scientist's experiences in medical research.
summary: He writes of his experience as a teacher and researcher during a forty-year career at Harvard Medical School — his problems, his mistakes, and his satisfactions.

title: Frontier trails: the autobiography of Frank M. Canton.
summary: Although he was an outlaw in Texas in his youth, he later changed his name, moved north, and became a peace officer, serving as sheriff and deputy U.S. Marshal in various places, then as adjutant general of the Oklahoma National Guard.

title: Take my life.
summary: A Broadway comedian describes his early life on New York's Lower East Side and his long and happy career in entertainment.

title: The autobiography of Yakima Canutt.
summary: A narration of Canutt's exciting life, ranging from being a championship rodeo rider in his teens to twenty years as a stunt man, to directing others in film stunts.

title: A highly ramified tree.
summary: Canzoneri writes lyrically of the interplay of generations in his extended Italian family and of the effects of time and change on them all.

title: Slightly out of focus.
summary: A photographer and war correspondent writes of his experience in love and war during World War II.

title: Dogs bark; public people and private places.
summary: The author's collection of his short pieces — essays, profiles, travel pieces and observations — previously printed in magazines and books.

title: The Thanksgiving visitor.
summary: An autobiographical story about Capote's childhood years when he lived with distant, elderly cousins in rural Alabama.

title: Frank Capra: the name above the title: an autobiography.
summary: An immensely successful movie director, Capra rose from humble beginnings to eminence in the arts.

title: Silent Hattie speaks: the personal journal of Senator Hattie Caraway.
summary: Caraway, the first woman elected to the U.S. Senate, served 1931-1945. The diary verifies her life during her Senate career.

title: Carew.
summary: Carew describes his rise from an impoverished childhood in the Canal Zone to a comfortable life as a superb batter for the Minnesota Twins.

title: Autobiographical sketches.
summary: The author wrote and circulated a series of letters addressing his views on the rise and progress of the American system.

title: Island in time: a memoir of childhood.
summary: Analyzes her wartime exile on the ile d'Oleron, France, from the dual perspectives of her teenage years during World War II and her current viewpoint.

title: Bill Carlisle, lone bandit: an autobiography.
summary: Cowboy turned bandit, imprisoned twenty years and rehabilitated.

title: Two on the rocks.
summary: His fascinating adventures among the Eskimos on Little Diomede Island in the Bering Strait.

title: Sometimes I wonder.
summary: A fuller narrative of his life in the center of the jazz world.

title: Stardust road.
summary: The early days of jazz and Tin-Pan Alley, carrying the droll humor of one of the great jazz pianists.

title: Prison to praise.
summary: Colonel Carothers writes of his criminal youth, his life as a soldier-paratrooper, and his conversion to Christ.

title: Victory on Praise Mountain.
summary: Carothers describes incidents during his ministry of Praise Center focusing on overcoming trials.

title: We seven: by the astronauts themselves. And others.
summary: A collective autobiography and description of their training and missions by the seven Project Mercury astronauts.

title: Lucky 7: a cowman's autobiography.
summary: "Lucky 7" chronicles the odyssey of his adventuresome life as a cattle driver and trail boss.

title: A Cavalryman in Indian country.
summary: After serving with distinction during the Civil War, Carr was assigned to protect settlements and conduct police offensives against Apaches.

title: The continuing education of William George Carr: an autobiography.
summary: Carr, Executive Secretary of the National Education Association, focuses on national and international aspects of education.

title: Voyage to Lourdes.
summary: Relates a French-American surgeon's personal reconciliation at Lourdes, France, between faith and science.

title: Yankee batboy.
summary: The author discusses his association with the New York Yankees during the time of Mickey Mantle, Casey Stengel, and Yogi Berra.

title: Home to the wilderness.
summary: A writer and naturalist describes her childhood and early years, focusing on her relationship with her mother.

title: Journal of Charles Carroll, 1776: during his visit to Canada, in 1776, as one of the commissioners from Congress.
summary: Carroll's journal records his trip from New York to Montreal and describes the freezing rivers and lakes of 1776.

title: To remember forever: the journal of a college girl 1922-1923.
summary: An account of her first year at Bates College portraying life at a women's school.

title: Years away from home.
summary: This book shows the influence of her home life on her development as a writer.

title: The John Carroll papers: Vol. I, 1755-1791; Vol. II, 1792-1806; Vol. III, 1807-1815.
summary: This collection contains letters, ecclesiastical reports and a journal illustrating Carroll's concerns relevant to establishing the Catholic Church in America.

title: Kit Carson's autobiography.
summary: A dictated account of his career as a Western scout and Indian fighter.

title: Dear Bet: the Carter letters 1861-1863: the letters of Lieutenant Sidney Carter, Company A, 14th regiment, South Carolina, Volunteers Gregg's-McGowan's Brigade, CSA, to Ellen Timmons Carter.
summary: Carter's straightforward and unassuming letters to his wife cover the period from his enlistment in the Confederate Army in August 1861, to January 21, 1863. He was killed at Gettysburg a week later. The letters comment on Carter's food supply, supplemented from home when the viands survived the journey, on his intermittently bad health, and on the war in his immediate vicinity.

title: The Bern book: a record of a voyage of the mind.
summary: Though not strictly either an autobiography or a travel book, this book states the author's faith in himself and describes his experience of being an unpublished writer and the only Black man in Bern, Switzerland, where he gives English lessons and writes.

title: First person rural.
summary: The editor of the Delta Democrat-Times in Greenville, Mississippi, recounts stories of Southern life, travels, hunting expeditions, and people he knew.

title: Autobiography of Peter Cartwright: the backwoods preacher.
summary: Cartwright spent much of his very long life as a circuit-riding Methodist preacher in the Western territories of Ohio and Illinois, though he also preached in Kentucky, Tennessee, and New England. His autobiography elucidates church doctrine, describes camp meetings and church conferences, and recounts cultural particulars in travelogue fashion.
other_places_lived: Ohio, Illinois, Kentucky, Tennessee, New England

title: The journals of Jonathan Carver: and related documents, 1766-1770.
summary: A scholarly edition of Carver's journals of his travels throughout Michigan, Wisconsin, and the Great Lakes Region of Canada. It is supplemented by a daily list of places visited and miles traveled; by James Stanley Goddard's 'Journal of a Voyage, 1766-1767,' and letters, commissions, and travel authorizations to and from Carver, 1766-1770.
other_places_lived: Michigan, Wisconsin, Great Lakes Region of Canada

title: Life of Dr. William F. Carver of California: champion rifle-shot of the world; being an interesting and truthful story of his capture by the Indians when a child, and romantic life among the savages for a period of sixteen years.
summary: This oral history focuses on the events identified in the subtitle. It is supplemented by extensive records of Carver's performances in the rifle-shooting matches that comprised his later career.

title: Out of his treasure: unfinished memoirs.
summary: Dr. Carver, for fifty years a professor of theology at Southern Baptist Theological Seminary (Louisville), tells of his rural Tennessee upbringing as one of eleven children during the Reconstruction era; his education, secular and sacred; and his experiences as a pastor. He devotes two of five chapters to his theological 'heresies' and controversies.

title: Lazy-man-rest-not: the Burma letters of Brayton C. Case.
summary: Thirty years in Burma as a Baptist missionary.

title: Remembering; the autobiography of a mystic.
summary: From humble beginnings to a movie career and eminence as a mystic and founder of Astara, a mystical, religious organization of international scope, Chaney writes of psychic experiences, cosmic illumination, communication with those on the other side, astral flights, and the pilgrimage of the soul upward into light.

title: From gaslight to dawn: an autobiography by Julie Chanler.
summary: Raised in New York high society, she became devoted to the B'hai religion as a young woman. Her book conveys an image of her wealth and privilege, her international travel, her charitable work for B'hai, and her pet terriers.

title: A camp on the Yukon.
summary: Episcopal missionary in Anvik, Alaska, 1887-1930.

title: Ray: Charles' own story.
summary: The story of a famous Black musician, from his extremely impoverished rural Southern beginnings, his going blind, to those who helped him develop his great talent for playing instruments, singing, and composing. His music, his many sexual experiences, his problems with drugs, and his faith in his creativity make this story a statement of personal philosophy.

title: What's a woman doing here?
summary: As a photojournalist and war correspondent, she wrote front-line reports of the battles of Iwo Jima and Okinawa in World War II. Afterwards she and her husband covered the movements of refugees, the Hungarian Revolution, and Castro's overthrow of the Batista regime in Cuba.

title: Charles E. Chapin's story.
summary: Chapin was a newspaperman and city editor for forty years before he took the steps that led to his life imprisonment in Sing Sing. Having speculated on stocks and lost everything, he determined to end his life and his wife's to save her from a friendless, helpless future. Instead, after shooting his wife, he gave himself up at a police station.

title: Long Wednesdays.
summary: The editor of a small country weekly in Minnesota reminisces about his job in the 1930's.

title: Wobbly: the rough-and-tumble story of an American radical.
summary: For fifty years he worked in the American labor movement as rebel editor, writer of battle songs, agitator, and organizer. Like others with a similar commitment, he sees his life as the story of a movement; for him, it was the radical labor movement.

title: Diary and correspondence of Salmon P. Chase.
summary: A U.S. Supreme Court Justice during the Civil War, he corresponded with antislavery journalist Edward S. Hamlin, with Charles Sumner, and with George S. Denison, his personal representative in New Orleans.

title: When you and I were young, Nebraska!
summary: Written at age 82, her book describes her arrival in Nebraska at age two, the difficult life of pioneering in the late nineteenth century, the loneliness, boredom, physical suffering, as well as the happier moments of daily life and survival.

title: Backstairs mission in Moscow: the diary of an American worker compiled during three journeys in the forbidden land of the Soviets.
summary: Chauffeur to Ambassador and Mrs. Joseph E. Davies, 1936-1938.

title: "Inga-play!": the memoirs of Inga Hoegsbro Christensen.
summary: Mrs. Christensen's narrative describes her Danish childhood, her musical training in Copenhagen, her immigration to New York, where she specialized in teaching the works of Scandinavian composers to children of the wealthy.

title: Linda: my own story.
summary: Her life and loves in Hollywood, including her early romance with Errol Flynn, her marriage to Tyrone Power, and later to Edmund Purdom.

title: Medical missionary to Africa.
summary: Christie spent his first fifty years in a fairly conventional American way: he worked his way through medical school, married, raised a family, practiced general medicine in Pontiac, Michigan, and during World War II served in Australia and the South Pacific as a physician with the U.S. Army. In 1964 he went to Zambia as a medical missionary, particularly to treat people with Hansen's disease.

title: One man's gold: the letters and journals of a Forty-Niner.
summary: The editor acknowledges that the original documents have been 'quite freely condensed and edited,' augmented by newspaper clippings, and that names have been changed. The letters and journal entries follow Christman's passage from Philadelphia around Cape Horn to California and wealth, and back to Philadelphia. A plainspoken, simple account of one man's three years spent prospecting in the California Gold Rush.

title: My American pilgrimage.
summary: Describes the experience of a Macedonian immigrant in and around St. Louis, 1915-1920, his first five years in America, working first in a factory, then with his father laying railroad tracks in the Northern Plains.

title: Road across the Plains 1850: a guide to the route from Mormon Crossing, now Omaha, Nebraska, to the city of Sacramento, California . . . together with his diary of the same journey.
publisher: Fred A. Rosenstock, Old West Publishing Co.
summary: Especially valuable because it includes route maps and diary, this is an unusual record of the mass overland immigration to the California gold fields in 1849-50.

title: Life of an American workman.
summary: Automobile manufacturer describes his rise from childhood in Kansas in a railroad family to corporate responsibility in the auto industry.

title: Big Sam.
summary: With warm nostalgia, Churchill writes of his father, his family, and life in the logging camps of Oregon during the early days of the twentieth century.

title: Bellamy Park: memoirs.
summary: Born into an army family, Chynoweth spent his life at various army posts and duties from Cheyenne, Wyoming, and London to the South Pacific.

title: Detective Marie Cirile; memoirs of a police officer.
summary: As a detective on the New York police force for over ten years, she achieved some notoriety for cases she broke wearing various disguises.

title: A measurable difference: the reminiscences of Walker Lee Cisler.
publisher: University of Michigan, Graduate School of Business Administration
summary: This volume focuses on the world's energy resources (including atomic energy) and technological developments that contribute to the efficient production of inexpensive power.
occupations: President of the Detroit Edison Company

title: Didn't we have fun!: stories out of a long, fruitful and merry life.
summary: Claessens, a Socialist Party leader elected to the New York State Assembly in 1917, thoroughly enjoyed his career as assemblyman, his speechmaking tours of the United States, and the people he met.

title: My fifty years in rodeo: living with cowboys, horses and danger.
summary: A rambling account of rodeo announcer and promoter Clancy's fifty years on the rodeo circuit.

title: Doctor come quickly.
summary: Chronicle of a urologist-surgeon's experiences with patients during thirty years of practice in Seattle.

title: Memoirs of Roger Clap: 1630.
summary: A brief description of his good fortune in immigrating to New England seeking religious freedom and settling happily there.

title: Recollections: Autobiographical during thirty-five years' residence in New Orleans.
summary: Raised in Massachusetts, he graduated from Yale Divinity School and took his ministry to New Orleans.

title: Parson Clapp and the Strangers' Church of New Orleans.
summary: The autobiographical sketches (pp. 49-174) of a minister in New Orleans, providing a concise view of his life, his ministry, and the city.

title: The Shirley letters from the California mines, 1851-1852.
summary: In 23 letters to her sister in New England, the author describes the activities, people, and locale of a California mining camp in Feather River Gorge.

title: One lucky woman.
summary: With her husband, journalist Raymond Clapper, she lived and worked as a writer-lecturer in the midst of the Washington international set from the Harding to the Eisenhower administration.

title: Reminiscences of a centenarian: as told by Amasa Gleason Clark, Veteran of the Mexican War.
summary: Still active at 101, he dictated his recollections of boyhood, friends, and his extensive family. He fathered nineteen children.

title: Australian adventure: letters from an ambassador's wife.
summary: Out of the need to share her new interests and experiences in Australia as a U.S. ambassador's wife, Anne Clark wrote these letters describing her travels, social life, and observations.

title: Adventures of a home economist.
summary: An articulate, comprehensive account of Clark's career as a professor and Dean of the School of Home Economics.

title: Lady and the sharks.
summary: The sequel to Lady With a Spear adds twelve years to her memoir as a marine biologist.

title: Lady with a spear.
summary: An ichthyologist describes her life-long love affair with fish and her field work in the South Pacific and Egypt.

title: Man's reach: the autobiography of Glenn Clark.
summary: After describing his family and educational background, Clark tells how the power of prayer was revealed to him and his subsequent experiences exercising that power.

title: Skylines and detours.
summary: An account of the author's life, focusing on his 45 years teaching biology at Pacific Union College.

title: Telling it like it was; a country preacher tells his story.
summary: Clark, who served as minister in twenty different Baptist churches during his career, writes with humor and compassion of his busy life.

title: Carrier admiral.
summary: In 1925 he became a naval aviator. After that he was involved with many of the men and events which made naval aviation history, especially those related to the development of the aircraft carrier.

title: Calculated risk: the story of the war in the Mediterranean.
summary: Commander of Fifth Army recounts his campaign in Italy as a calculated risk to divert the German army from the French and Russian fronts.

title: Captain's bride, general's lady: memoirs.
summary: A warm personal narrative of army life by a general's wife.

title: Echo in my soul.
summary: As Director of Workshops and Director of Education of the Highlander Folk School in Tennessee she continued a lifetime's work educating the poor and ignorant and combatting segregation and prejudice.

title: The papers of Walter Clark.
summary: The letters, speeches, and articles of a prolific writer who became Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of North Carolina; includes descriptions of his boarding school and university experience, life in the Confederate Army, and his career as a country lawyer and Chief Justice.
occupations: Chief Justice of the Supreme Court

title: Village life in America 1852-1872, including the period of the American Civil War, as told in the diary of a schoolgirl.
summary: A record of childhood in ideal conditions amid the village life in New York State and of the effects of the Civil War told by a quick-witted schoolgirl.

title: Man of the world: recollections of an irreverent reporter.
summary: Recollections of his work and acquaintances while he was a reporter for The World precede the author's account of his psychoanalytic treatment for alcoholism.

title: Joy of service: memoirs.
publisher: Nat'l. Board of the Young Women's Christian Association
summary: For most of her 91 years, Elizabeth Dodge led an active, joyous life of Christian service, much of it devoted to YWCA work.

title: Back home in Oneida: Herman Clarke and his letters.
summary: Clarke, a young farmer in Oneida, New York, fought in the Civil War and his letters to relatives are forthright, articulate, and patriotic.

title: The letters of James Freeman Clarke to Margaret Fuller.
summary: A fascinating collection of letters (1829-1848) covering a range of topics, focusing on theology and personal lives of mutual friends.

title: Over there with O'Ryan's Roughnecks: reminiscences of a Private 1st Class who served in the 27th U.S. Division with the British Forces in Belgium and France.
summary: From diaries, memory, and published accounts, Clarke describes the activities of the 27th Division of the U.S. Army in World War I.

title: Bertha Fidelia: her story.
summary: Clawson emphasizes her fifty years of missionary work in Japan, devoted primarily to founding and directing Joshi Sei Gakuin, a Christian girls' school that eventually included an elementary school, high school, and Bible college.

title: The life of Cassius Marcellus Clay: memoirs, writings, and speeches showing his conduct in the overthrow of American slavery, the salvation of the Union, and the restoration of the autonomy of the states.
summary: A loosely organized account of his personal and public life, including his early conversion to the anti-slavery movement by William Lloyd Garrison, his political career in Kentucky, his diplomatic appointment in Russia, the context of the Civil War, his divorce, and Reconstruction.

title: The papers of Henry Clay.
summary: The letters and personal papers from his developing career as a lawyer and statesman, his growing influence and presidential candidacy, his tenure as Secretary of State, and his position as a political leader.

title: The private correspondence of Henry Clay.
summary: Unlike other collections of Clay's papers, this volume includes only his personal correspondence. The editor has chosen to present those letters to and from Clay which shed light on the history of the period without the cautiousness characteristic of more formal public documents.

title: A pioneer grandmother's story of her life.
summary: Recollection of a frontier life in the West including her youth, school teaching experiences, wedding trip in Wyoming, and farming in Montana.

title: Selected papers of Will Clayton.
summary: A successful business man and 'Southern gentleman,' Clayton served in Washington as Deputy Federal Loan Administrator, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, 1940-1944; Assistant Secretary of State, 1944-1946; Undersecretary of State, 1946-1947; was a prime mover in the Marshall Plan; and was an important delegate to the International Trade and Employment Conference in Geneva in 1947, the International Trade Organization, and the Atlantic Union.

title: The diary of a student at Delaware College: August, 1853, to November, 1854.
summary: From a manuscript of the lost original, entries in the diary record Cleaver's daily activities and feelings and include descriptions of the old college building. The editor has provided extensive notes with information from faculty meeting minutes, Athenean Society minutes, and entries from the manuscript diary of his friend David Lewis Mustard.

title: Sea fever: the making of a sailor.
summary: After finishing his undergraduate education at Harvard, he shipped out on cargo vessels for eight months, filled with romantic notions of life at sea. The voyage taught him much — that his love for the sea was real and that life at sea in modern times was impractical. That era had passed.

title: Hello, hello, hello, Doc.
summary: A collection of humorous, occasionally sentimental anecdotes concerning the author's practice of medicine in rural Virginia for 44 years. The autobiographer finds jokes concerning drunkenness and obstetrics particularly amusing and, though white, often writes in Black dialect.

title: Letters from the Earth.
summary: Consists of two main parts: (1) 'Letters from the Earth,' 'Papers of the Adam Family,' and 'Letter to the Earth,' all on Biblical themes, and (2) DeVoto's selections from unpublished Twain manuscripts, some autobiographical in nature.

title: A nostalgic look at the years of early middle age, the work and pleasure, the children growing up, the neighbors, and the simpler life in Maine.
summary: N/A

title: Maine ways. Illustrated by Mildred Coughlin.
summary: Contented with her life, Coatsworth writes pleasant, low-keyed stories about daily events, eccentric characters, and the ways of nature down East in her beloved Maine.

title: Personal geography: almost an autobiography.
publisher: A Janet Greene Book/Stephen Greene Press
summary: Coatsworth, poet and author of a Newbery award-winning children's book, has assembled a collection of excerpts from her notebooks and accounts of travel to Europe and the Far East, bridged by poetry.

title: Woman into space: the Jerrie Cobb story.
summary: After a brief description of her childhood in Oklahoma and her early interest in flying, she describes the rigorous training and testing program she passed in order to be considered for the position of first female astronaut and the conservative public and congressional reaction to the idea of a woman in space.

title: FBI man: a personal history.
summary: An account of Cochran's pre-World War II years as an FBI Special Agent, written with an eye for the hardboiled, Sam-Spade image and an ear for the sanctimonious.

title: The Cochran family book of ski racing.
summary: Cochran, coach of the 1973-1974 U.S. Ski Team which starred his four children, devotes the first third of the book to an autobiographical account of his family's passion for skiing; they own and operate a mountain ski area in Vermont.

title: Theodore D.A. Cockerell: letters from West Cliff, Colorado, 1887-1889.
summary: These attractive letters, enhanced by the naturalist's drawings of settings, animals, and insects, discuss Cockerell's life and scientific investigations in West Cliff, Colorado.

title: My life in poetry.
summary: A thoughtful account of his development as a poet and, incidentally, as a man of letters.

title: The times of an involuntary genius.
summary: A poet born and brought up under the repression of a communist regime, Codrescu fled from Transylvania after being expelled from the university and sent a notice of military conscription.

title: From the life of a researcher.
summary: In his narrative autobiography, required of academicians in the National Academy of Sciences, Coblentz provides family background, descriptions of decades of research in physics, and details of his interest in nature.

title: Alvin Langdon Coburn, photographer; an autobiography.
summary: This fascinating book combines Coburn's story of his career as a photographer with many of his photographs.

title: Walt Coburn: Western word wrangler; an autobiography.
summary: Coburn, a prolific writer for fifty years, published over one thousand short stories in popular Western pulp magazines as well as nearly one hundred books.

title: The first hundred years of Nino Cochise; the untold story of an Apache Indian chief.
summary: The grandson of Chief Cochise tells the story of the Chiricahui Apache Indians led by his mother who escaped to Mexico to avoid relocation to the San Carlos Reservation.

title: Stars at noon.
summary: The author describes her poverty-striken youth in Florida, her career as an aviator.

title: Letters from Buffalo Bill: taken from the originals now on exhibit at the Wonderland Museum, Billings, Montana.
summary: Buffalo Bill Cody's letters discuss business matters pertinent to his Wild West Shows and investments, good and bad.

title: Life and adventures of Buffalo Bill: Colonel William F. Cody.
summary: A myth in his own time, he includes stories of his childhood in Kansas, his service on the Pony Express, and his touring Wild West Show.

title: Life of Hon. William F. Cody: Known as Buffalo Bill, the famous hunter, scout, and guide: an autobiography.
summary: The book contains fascinating accounts of Cody's life on the plains as pony express rider, scout, buffalo hunter, and later, creator of Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show.

title: Frontier fighter: the autobiography of George W. Coe, who fought and rode with Billy the Kid.
summary: Recollections by Billy the Kid's best friend of the excitement and hardships of frontier life during the settlement of the Western territory.

title: Reminiscences of Levi Coffin.
publisher: Arno Press and the New York Times
summary: An abolitionist who assisted nearly three thousand runaway slaves to escape was called the President of the Underground Railway.

title: Lost paradise: a boyhood on a Maine coast farm.
summary: A poet's third person narrative describes his Maine boyhood with affection for its simplicity, the warmth of his close family life.

title: Once to every man: a memoir.
summary: Coffin aspired to be a concert pianist before World War II made him a Russian Liaison Officer, followed by Yale, Union Theological Seminary, and a stint training Russian agents for the CIA.

title: America in the rough: the autobiography of W.M. (Bill) Coffman.
summary: The youthful, often rowdy adventures on land and sea of the man who became a promoter for the Shriners.

title: Memoirs of Mrs. Coghlan.
publisher: The New York Times and Arno Press
summary: The daughter of Major Moncrieffe includes in her memoirs descriptions of America during the Revolutionary War.

title: A Canterbury Tale: experiences and reflections: 1916-1976.
summary: Cogley reflects on his spiritual and theological discomfort in a church unresponsive to changing times.

title: Twenty years on Broadway, and the years it took to get there: the true story of a trouper's life from the cradle to the closed shop.
summary: The book conveys a sense of what Broadway and New York were like during the early twentieth century, focusing on the theatrical life of an actor, composer, and playwright.

title: They builded better than they knew.
summary: Describes times, people, and events during his fifty years as a public servant.

title: Dreamer's journey: autobiography.
summary: Describes childhood in Russia and adolescence in New York's East Side, and his development as a philosopher.

title: Portrait of a philosopher: Morris R. Cohen in life and letters.
summary: The letters, diaries, and other papers of a prominent philosopher at Harvard, edited by his daughter.

title: Honorable men: my life with the CIA.
summary: Colby's account of his directorship of the CIA reads like the penultimate spy novel, detailing the complex, violence-ridden undercover operations.

title: Autobiography of Charles Francis Colcord: 1859-1934.
summary: Recognized for many years as 'First Citizen of Oklahoma City' and then as 'First Citizen of Oklahoma.'

title: Victorian lady on the Texas frontier: the journal of Ann Raney Coleman.
summary: Coleman recalls nineteenth-century Texas — the rough terrain, the Indians, the abundance of men and scarcity of women.

title: Experiences of an Arkansas backwoodsman.
summary: Coleman tells of his childhood in rural Arkansas, focusing on daily activities punctuated by the circus, pranks, and accidents.

title: Blue-collar journal: a college president's sabbatical.
summary: The journal kept during spring of 1973 when Coleman worked at blue collar jobs while on sabbatical from his presidency.

title: I buried Custer: the diary of Pvt. Thomas W. Coleman, 7th U.S. Cavalry.
summary: This twelve-page diary provides a terse account of Private Coleman's participation in the Battle of the Little Big Horn.

title: From every zenith a memoir, and some essays on life and thought.
summary: A committed humanist writes of his life as a social scientist devoted to the struggles of American Indians.

title: Soul rush: the odyssey of a young woman of the '70s.
summary: A wealthy flower child of the late Sixties and Seventies writes to demonstrate how much she has done.

title: Oh, didn't he ramble: the life story of Lee Collins.
summary: One of the great jazz cornet players, dictating and writing his story from 1943.

title: Carrying the fire: an astronaut's journeys.
summary: Astronaut Collins traces his participation in the selection process, the training, the Gemini 10 flight, and the moon orbit, explaining the operations of the machines and life in the artificial environment.

title: A girl of the Eighties at college and at home, from the family letters of Charlotte Howard Conant and from other records.
summary: This collage of reminiscences and letters describes the New England girlhood and college life of Charlotte Howard Conant.

title: Out of the depths; the story of a priest-patient in a mental hospital.
summary: A description of the ordeal of a young priest who worked through emotional illness and writes about his learning experience through therapy.

title: My several lives: memoirs of a social inventor.
summary: Conant writes about his important positions including the presidency of Harvard University and his inventions in education and defense.

title: Captain Moses Rich Colman: master mariner, Scituate, Massachusetts, 1807-1872; letters of a Yankee clipper ship captain.
summary: Excerpts from his letters depict the life of a typical seaman in nineteenth-century New England.

title: Born again.
summary: Colson shares his experiences before and after his religious conversion while working closely with Nixon.

title: Three years in California: together with excerpts from the author's Deck and Port, covering his arrival in California and a selection of his letters from Monterey.
summary: A naval officer and chaplain describes military operations and the daily life of a diverse population in California from 1846 to 1849.

title: Life and the dream. Revised with additional material.
summary: Her book includes rich descriptions of her intellectual growth in the literary world before moving to America.

title: Sixty years with men and machines: an autobiography.
summary: Describes his experience in invention, machinery, and production, including participation in the development of various vehicles and tools.

title: Myself: the autobiography of John R. Commons.
summary: The informal story of a labor historian and economist who influenced modern economic theory.

title: From dawn to sunset.
summary: A sculptor and professor of fine arts, Coppini discusses his life and work, primarily in San Antonio; his interest and involvement with commemorating and preserving historical events and places; his disappointments and awards of recognition in his field.

title: As I look back.
summary: Corey, reared in the Missouri Ozarks, became an ordained Disciple of Christ minister and a member of the Foreign Christian Missionary Society, traveled to Africa, the Orient, Latin America, India, and Palestine.

title: Cowboy Pete: the autobiography of Major General Charles H. Corlett.
summary: Raised in the cattle country of Colorado, Corlett attended West Point, served in World War I, worked with the CCC in the Thirties, and during World War II was in Alaska, Kwajalein, and Europe. After his retirement from the army, he filled several state government posts in New Mexico under Governor Mechem.

title: Sheepherder's gold.
summary: Writing in language surprisingly formal in comparison with the rough-and-ready prospector's life he describes, Cornelius tells of the searches he and others made for gold in New Mexico and Colorado during the early part of the twentieth century.

title: Anatomist at large: an autobiography and selected essays.
summary: Corner's details of his student years at Johns Hopkins and his career in biology as a professor and physician. Citing many distinguished members of the profession, he gives a short history of medical advancements in the first half of this century.

title: Miss Aunt Nellie: the autobiography of Nellie C. Cornish.
summary: Cornish traces the development of the Cornish School in Seattle, from its birth as a school for music lessons to an academy offering dance, puppetry, and drama as well as instrumental instruction. She recalls many of the 20,000 students she knew in her 25 years with the school, emphasizing their successes all over the world.

title: Like it is.
summary: Cosell thrives on being a controversial and abrasive sportsbroadcaster. In this sequel to his Cosell, he continues to follow his self-proclaimed goals of the pursuit of truth and the correction of wrong-doing. He writes of people he respects, answers questions he finds stimulating, and discusses his reactions to issues in sports.

title: Cocktails for two: the many lives of giant songwriter.
summary: A composer of over 500 tunes for films and Broadway musicals (including "Just One More Chance" and "My Old Flame") describes his fifty-year career in show business which also involved stints as a vaudevillian, singer, piano player, band leader, and film producer. In the mid-1950's, when music moved from big bands to rock, Coslow became a successful investment service advisor as publisher of Indicator Digest.
occupations: composer, vaudevillian, singer, piano player, band leader, film producer

title: Wanted.
summary: Coss ecstatically recounts his experience as a born-again Christian, which began in 1969 when he was converted in prison. A twelve-year record of 33 arrests for car theft, assault and battery, and other crimes had landed him in various detention homes and prisons, but Christianity and marriage to another born-again Christian completely reformed him; he now runs a full-time ministry for prisoners.

title: Spark for my people: the sociological autobiography of a Negro teacher.
summary: A Black teacher who lived in Virginia, Kentucky, and Alabama describes her growing racial and humanitarian awareness and how her teaching developed from such growth.

title: In the Senate: amidst the conflict and turmoil.
summary: Cotton covers the years he was a U.S. Senator and Congressman, from Truman to Ford. He discusses presidential policy, the problems in the land of politics. But basically, Cotton uses this book as a soapbox to propound his conservative views: he especially rants against government spending and Democratic presidents.

title: N/A
summary: Crawford was the first woman mayor in Madison, Mississippi, focusing on her activities in office and her childhood.

title: A portrait of Joan: the autobiography of Joan Crawford.
summary: A popular movie actress writes of her poor and difficult childhood and her life in Hollywood, including her marriages and adopted children.

title: The West of the Texas Kid, 1881-1910: recollections of Thomas Edgar Crawford, cowboy, gun fighter, rancher, hunter, miner.
summary: The love of the West preserved through entertaining anecdotes of outlaws and cowboys as told by 'The Texas Kid.'
occupations: Cowboy, gun fighter, rancher, hunter, miner

title: Rebel at large: recollections of fifty crowded years.
summary: Chronicles a hard life as journalist and gradual success as a writer and politician.

title: Blood and grits.
summary: Essays on various experiences reflecting the author's earthy, Southern lifestyle.

title: Childhood: the biography of a place.
summary: A re-creation of his childhood mingling poverty with richness of friendships and storytelling.

title: General George Crook: his autobiography.
summary: Covers Crook's life from West Point graduation to campaigns against Indians post-Civil War.

title: Call
summary: A Hollywood actor recalls his upbringing, career, and family life until 1952.

title: Passionate years.
summary: A poet and editor describes life as a member of the Lost Generation and her associations with notable figures.

title: The last stitch.
summary: Crosthwait describes his early life and career as a surgeon.

title: My life on the road: the autobiography of Cleo Crouch.
summary: A trucker's journey from building a truck line to retirement.

title: The autobiography of Delfina Cuero.
summary: Cuero lived as a hunter-gatherer and reflects the love and wisdom of her people.

title: Of battles long ago: memoirs of an American ambulance driver in World War I.
summary: An American volunteer ambulance driver for the French army in World War I describes hospitals and rescue missions at the front lines, major offensives (Verdun, Marne), and being wounded during combat, with personal observations and photographs of life in wartime France.

title: No time for rest.
summary: In a lifetime marked by enthusiasm and devotion to hard work, Cutler describes his experience as a student, a lawyer, a military officer, and as a government official in several capacities, including Special Assistant to Eisenhower for National Security Affairs, and National Security Council.

title: Mighty timber.
summary: Half of his book is a nostalgic recollection of his early rural life in southern Ohio; the rest depicts his education at Ohio State University, setting up his medical practice in Columbus, then moving to Modesto, California, where he became an active contributing member of the community.

title: Diary of George Mifflin Dallas: United States Minister to Russia, 1837-1839.
summary: An interesting record of diplomatic life in the early nineteenth century and the court of the Czar.

title: September child: the story of Jean Dalrymple, by herself.
summary: Widely respected as a theatrical director and producer, she has directed the Light Opera and Drama Companies for the New York City Center, the performing arts programs for the Brussels World's Fair (1958) and the New York World's Fair (1964-65). Her book is packed with activity and celebrity.

title: Forged in strong fires: the early life and experiences of John Edward Dalton.
summary: World-wide travels of a cowboy, boxer, and adventurer, around the turn of the century.

title: Across the years: memories of a Virginian.
summary: A Pulitzer Prize for Journalism winner and lifetime advocate of Virginia reminisces about his childhood in turn-of-the-century Charlottesville, college years at the University of Virginia, and his long career as editor of the Richmond Times-Dispatch. He based many editorials on first-hand knowledge from his travels, saw the rise of Nazism and spoke out against Hitler, and chronicled the changing South.

title: My musical life.
summary: His life in music began in Silesia, where his family was visited by Liszt and Saint-Saens, and he lived among the greatest musicians of his time for the rest of his life. His book is rich with stories about them and his career as a prominent orchestra leader.

title: Banker Dahl of South Dakota: an autobiography.
summary: N/A

title: An autobiographical sketch (1815-1842).
summary: A banker who has 'led a full, interesting, and rewarding life' relates his experiences during 48 years of banking, his thinking on various banking matters, and his assessments of his associates.

title: Because I was flesh: the autobiography of Edward Dahlberg.
summary: Colored by background reality of urban life, this is a son's portrait of his relationship with his remarkable mother, who fails repeatedly in her objective to achieve security for them both by acquiring a new husband.

title: The confessions of Edward Dahlberg.
summary: As writer and critic he came into contact with many others among the intelligentsia of the Twenties and Thirties. In remarkable aphoristic prose, he describes Edmund Wilson, Gertrude Stein, Charles Olson, and others.

title: Epitaphs of our times: the letters of Edward Dahlberg.
summary: A sampling from the many letters he wrote to literary and intellectual friends including Theodore Dreiser, Robert M. Hutchins, Herbert Read, William Carlos Williams, and Allen Tate, among others. The letters are grouped according to their recipients rather than by chronology.

title: The spider and the marionettes: an autobiography.
summary: An unusually egocentric, disturbing autobiography in which the author, a night club, radio, and television singer, discusses the vicissitudes of his career and unsatisfying relationships with women and men — mostly the result of his volatile temper and unstable personality. In abusing others, he abused himself and finally escaped the 'spider web' by becoming an independent entertainer in nightclubs.

title: The journal of Richard Henry Dana, Jr.
publisher: The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press
summary: Prefaced by his 'Autobiographical Sketch,' this edition follows Dana's text as he wrote it, providing a wide assortment of historical data as well as the opportunity to confront an attractive and remarkable personality. Volumes I and II contain his journal up to 1859, Volume III records his voyage around the world 1859-1860.

title: Signor Dottore: the autobiography of F. Michele Daniele, Italian immigrant doctor, 1879-1957.
summary: He settled in Youngstown, Ohio, to practice medicine in the Italian community, returned to Italy from 1911 to 1918, and came again to Youngstown where he became an outspoken leader of the birth control movement.

title: Fatal flowers: on sin, sex, and suicide in the deep South.
summary: A bitter, yet ambivalent analysis of Southern sexual mores in terms of her own life.

title: Oklahoma lawyer.
summary: Charming story of his life and career as an attorney in rural Oklahoma, by a man who became a district judge and spent most of his life in Guymon.

title: Life with the Lyons.
summary: With good humor, actress Daniels and actor-producer Lyons, married since 1930, recount their careers in films and film production, separately and together. Their love for each other and for their two children is reflected in their mutual enjoyment of their family.

title: Father feelings.
summary: Clergyman and family counselor Daley has written a series of vignettes.

title: White House witness, 1942-1945.
summary: During World War II, wartime secrecy shrouded the White House, the key power center of the world. Daniels' diary tells what it was like to work in the hidden corridors of the President's office and captures the hopes, labors and intrigues of the Capital.

title: The Cabinet diaries of Josephus Daniels, 1913-1921.
summary: Woodrow Wilson's Secretary of the Navy kept these diaries during his tenure of office from 1913 to 1921. Through them can be seen Daniels' relations with the President, other government officials, and subordinates, including Franklin D. Roosevelt, chosen by Daniels as his assistant. Daniels was the subject of much controversy despite the success of the Navy during World War I.

title: Editor in politics.
summary: Volume two of his memoirs describes his life from 1893 to 1912, when he was an editor and journalist becoming more involved with politics.

title: Shirt-sleeve diplomat.
summary: The fifth volume of his autobiography, describing his years as U.S. Ambassador to the Republic of Mexico (1933-1942). Previously he had served as Secretary of the Navy (1913-1921).
occupations: U.S. Ambassador, Secretary of the Navy

title: Tar Heel editor.
summary: The first volume of his memoirs, describing his life from 1885-1893, written by a journalist and statesman who was then editing a paper in North Carolina.

title: The Wilson era, years of peace — 1910-1917.
summary: A personal memoir of the times, written by Wilson's Secretary of the Navy, with more detailed accounts of the era than of himself, although he calls it the third volume of his autobiography.

title: The Wilson era, years of war and after — 1917-1923.
summary: Called the fourth volume of his autobiography, this work is, like the previous one, more a memoir of the times than of the man. This volume is based extensively on Daniels' World War I diary.

title: A tour from the city of New York, to Detroit in the Michigan territory, made between the 2nd of May and the 22nd of Sept. 1818.
publisher: Published for the author by Kirk & Mercein
summary: A tour the author took observing the natural history and geography of the region around the southern shores of Lake Ontario and Lake Erie, including the Thousand Islands and Niagara Falls.

title: My safaris via inferno: life and thoughts of an Armenian-American lawyer.
summary: A collection of sporadic memories and opinions written by a Detroit lawyer who immigrated to the U.S. from Turkey in 1912 as a young man.

title: When in doubt, fire the manager: my life and times in baseball.
summary: After his career as a baseball player, Dark became a baseball manager, often hired and fired by such teams as the Kansas City Athletics and the Cleveland Indians. His zealous Christianity was compromised by family difficulties and an extramarital relationship of five years that eventually led to a second marriage. This stability led to the reemergence of his strong religion and to professional success.

title: A Hoosier parson: his boosts and bumps (an apologia pro mea vita).
summary: Individualist, sportsman, and Christian, Daugherty affirms his faith in an autobiography which is candid and friendly.

title: Duffy: an autobiography.
summary: The well-loved coach of the Michigan State Spartans for nineteen years, who later became part of the ABC College Game of the Week team, recalls his successful career and tells tall tales of collegiate sports.

title: Chill yblast: a narrative.
summary: Youth in rural Iowa; college professor of math at Iowa State Teachers College and Kansas State College; narrated in eighteenth-century comic style.

title: Too strong for fantasy.
summary: Devoted to the world of music (her mother was opera star Alma Gluck) and of fiction writing, Davenport writes also of her support for Willkie's presidential campaign, her attachment to Czechoslovakia, and her admiration of the Masaryk Republic.

title: A Rhode Island chaplain in the Revolution: letters of Ebenezer David to Nicholas Brown, 1775-1778.
summary: The author joined the Continental Army soon after his ordination and wrote these letters to Brown, a merchant in Providence. They describe the life and activities of an army chaplain of the time and contain valuable accounts of actions in which Rhode Island troops took part.

title: Transfigured: the autobiography of Solomon D. David.
publisher: Disciples Divinity House of the University of Chicago
summary: In 1908 he immigrated to America from Syria to begin his education. He went first to Macalester College in Minneapolis, then on to medical school at the University of Minnesota. He established a practice as an orthopedic surgeon in Houston where he was also active in the Lebanese community. He published four books of Arabic poetry.

title: Bruce Davidson photographs: (including autobiographical sketch).
summary: Davidson's eloquent autobiographical introduction to this handsome collection of photographs reveals the intimate interweaving of representative life and art.

title: The literary correspondence of Donald Davidson and Allen Tate.
summary: This literary correspondence began when the two were apprentices to poetry and in 1922 agreed to exchange poems and criticism. Although they were different in temperament, personality, and experience, they continued to correspond until 1966, resulting in a remarkable dialogue about the nature of the literary vocation in the past two centuries.

title: The expedition of Capt. J.W. Davidson from Fort Tejon to the Owens Valley in 1859.
summary: Army Captain Davidson was sent to the Santa Clara Valley in California to apprehend the Paiute Indians who were allegedly stealing the white settlers' horses. In precise ethnographic and geographic notations, he describes the territory and the tribes.

title: Reverend Samuel Davies abroad: the diary of a journey to England and Scotland, 1753-55.
summary: Davies' journal chronicles a trip to England on behalf of American Presbyterians to solicit funds and support for the College of New Jersey and Presbyterians in Virginia. His observations are colorful and, to this age, quaint.

title: With my mind on freedom: an autobiography.
summary: In the late Sixties, Davis emerged as a central figure in revolutionary politics. One of the first Black women to popularize the Afro hair style, she focused most of her energies for several years on political activism and was imprisoned for allegedly supplying guns to members of the Black Panther party. Her story is a significant social document of the times.

title: On my own.
summary: Recounting the story of his youth, army experience, and the founding of his own public relations firm, Davis writes in simple language suitable for the guidance of children interested in careers in public relations work.

title: Clive — inside the record business.
summary: An important figure in the revolution in the record industry, which in the 1960's saw the emergence of rock music as a cultural medium. He focuses on his years with Columbia Records, 1960-1973, when he signed and promoted pioneering rock artists, many of whom he discusses here.

title: The age of indiscretion.
summary: Reflections on his childhood and youth in Missouri in the early twentieth century together with observations on how conditions have improved during the intervening fifty years.

title: By Elmer Davis.
summary: This is a collection of fiction and essays, some autobiographical in nature, by a news commentator who dared speak for individual freedom during the McCarthy era.

title: The world is my country.
summary: Determined to become a 'citizen of the world,' Davis renounced his U.S. citizenship in Paris in 1948 and for a decade traveled worldwide, voluntarily and by deportation. He wanted to 'prove' that an individual can obtain 'world legality grounded in reasoned freedom and justice,' but he was most often jailed and ridiculed for his efforts. A self-defense.

title: World on my doorstep: a venture in international living.
summary: Life in Geneva 1931-1941, while raising a family; revealing a deep concern for international peace.

title: World without a roof: an autobiography.
summary: The international adventures of an explorer, writer, and combat soldier.

title: The messages and papers of Jefferson Davis and the Confederacy: including diplomatic correspondence, 1861-1865.
summary: Without any sectional or political bias, Richardson has compiled and edited all the messages, proclamations, and inaugural addresses of Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States, as well as the important diplomatic correspondence of the Confederacy.

title: The papers of Jefferson Davis.
summary: Davis, the leader of the Confederacy, was blamed by both sides — by the South, because he failed, and by the North, because he tried to succeed. Later more objective assessments recognized his unquestioned integrity, courage, dedication to duty, and strong leadership qualities.

title: Private letters, 1823-1889.
summary: This selection of private letters by the President of the Confederacy includes some previously printed, but a large proportion, including those to and from his wife Varina while he was in prison after the Civil War, have not been printed before in their entirety.

title: A teacher's story: an autobiography.
summary: A strict conservative moralist depicts the spiritual and professional achievements of his life as a teacher in Chicago.

title: A life adventure for peace: an autobiography.
summary: Davis, a prolific author of books with a social mission and a professor of sociology at Dartmouth and at Yale, describes his life of social activism to promote peace, which took him to Russia and to the German death camps before World War II, and which led him to establish and subsidize Promoting Enduring Peace, Inc.

title: The saga of a schoolmaster; an autobiography.
summary: Davis, whose final position was Dean of the Boston University School of Education, achieved eminence as an educator through talent, kindness, and extraordinary energy. His life and career, encompassing jobs as high school teacher, principal, city director of guidance, junior college president, state supervisor of education, provide a micro-history of American secondary education in the 'Modern Era' (1890-1950).

title: Legacy of love.
summary: Memories of life in an extended family surrounded by loving individualists including her grandparents and father, John W. Davis, an attorney, ambassador to London, and presidential candidate.

title: A surgeon's odyssey.
summary: A wise, humane review of his medical practice and related experience by a man who became a neurological surgeon and Chairman of Surgery at Northwestern University School of Medicine.

title: The neglected thread: a journal from the Calhoun Community, 1836-1842.
summary: Diary of the early years of an educated writer gives an account of people and customs of the rural South and her feelings about them; ends with her religious conversion and decision to marry.

title: A narrative of the life of Rev. Noah Davis, a colored man: written by himself, at the age of fifty-four.
summary: This narrative, 'printed solely for the author's benefit,' was written to raise money so that Davis could buy his last two children out of slavery, having already purchased his wife and five of his children. His story is simple and to the point — he recounts his early slave life, buying his freedom, religious conversion, marriage, preaching, and multiple efforts to raise money for his family's freedom.

title: My first fifty years in the theatre: the plays, the players, the theatrical managers and the theatre itself as one man saw them in the fifty years between 1897 and 1947.
summary: In recounting many happy memories of his working life, the writer briefly lists his plays, producers, and casts over the years spent in New York and Hollywood.

title: Recollections of Mississippi and Mississippians.
publisher: University and College Press of Mississippi
summary: Davis served as a U.S. Congressman, was a leading lawyer, and a Brigadier General for the Confederacy. His book describes his prominent role in the development of the state of Mississippi before the Civil War.

title: The adventures and letters of Richard Harding Davis.
summary: Davis reported for Philadelphia and New York newspapers and was particularly noteworthy for his accounts of six wars, including the Greco-Turkish War (1897), the Spanish-American, and the first part of World War I. He wrote novels, short stories, plays, and travel articles featuring his personal adventures in picturesque places.

title: Year from a reporter's notebook.
summary: A journalist's notes on major international events from May 1896 to June 1897, including Czar Nicholas II's coronation, President McKinley's inauguration, and wartime letters from Turkey, Greece and Cuba.

title: The long loneliness.
summary: Raised an Episcopalian, she converted to Catholicism, became co-founder of the Catholic Worker, a newspaper based on a philosophy of anarchism and pacifism.

title: What? had I shot him?
summary: Written when he was over ninety, this book describes the long, successful career of a businessman who began his career in Marion, Ohio, and finally settled in Tulsa. He worked in a variety of businesses, the last of which was petroleum.

title: Yes I can: the story of Sammy Davis, Jr.
summary: After struggling many years to reach star status in show business, he was set back by a serious automobile accident and the loss of an eye, but still made top billing, overcoming racial prejudice along the way.

title: California Gold Rush merchant: the journal of Stephen Chapin Davis.
summary: An interesting view of the Gold Rush by a seventeen-year-old merchant from New England (1850-1854).

title: Seventy-five years in California: recollections and remarks by one who visited these shores in 1831, and again in 1833, and except when absent on business was a resident from 1838 until the end of a long life in 1909.
summary: A human and mercantile history of San Francisco (1833-1906) from the lively and humanistic viewpoint of a civic-minded merchant. An invaluable account of social, business, and civic customs and manners.

title: Half remembered; a personal history.
summary: A poet examines his life and his parents' gifts to him, remembering and unraveling the past. He concludes that his poetry comes from the midst of life — between childhood and old age, between the conscious and the unconscious, between home and work.

title: Len Dawson: pressure quarterback.
summary: Star quarterback for the Kansas City Chiefs (1963-69), he wrote his life story after he was accused of gambling connections. The book focuses on his performance in the Super Bowl 1969, the climax of his career.

title: Reminiscences of a vocal teacher.
summary: Voice teacher in Cleveland for 24 years, she was well-known and respected in music and literary circles in the United States and Europe.

title: Speaking out.
summary: The daughter of a Menominee Indian father and a white mother tells of her youth, education, and career in social work.

title: Out of my cabin.
summary: The author, a schoolteacher, describes how she, her ailing mother, and intermittently invalid husband lived through the Depression in 'Owl Center,' a home they built on ten wooded acres in the Ozarks, near Neosho, Missouri.

title: Union officer in the Reconstruction.
summary: An agent of the Freedman's Bureau in Greenville, South Carolina (1866-67), a young Union officer writes with compassion a first-hand account of whites and Blacks, Northerners and Southerners, the high-minded and the low-down in a country beggared by war.

title: Volunteer's adventures: a Union captain's record of the Civil War.
summary: DeForest's outstanding record of camp life in letters mostly to his wife (1862-1864); the author of Miss Ravenel's Conversion (1865).

title: Father of radio: the autobiography of Lee DeForest.
summary: Recollections of his personal life and long years of work in developing radio by electronic engineer and inventor.

title: Life among the doctors.
summary: Scientist-writer chronicles ten years (1938-1948) of medical practice advances.

title: God, woman and ministry.
summary: Demarest, granddaughter of Salvation Army founder William Booth, followed in her parents' and grandparents' evangelical footsteps and spent a vigorous lifetime preaching around the world. She devotes half the book to justifying the case for women clergy and the other half to describing her marriage, motherhood, and career as an internationally known clergywoman.

title: And promenade home.
summary: The story of her developing success as a dancer and choreographer and of her marriage to Walter Prude during the war years, 1942-1945.

title: Dance to the piper.
summary: The story of an American dancer and choreographer from her youth and early career to the success of Oklahoma and her marriage.

title: Speak to me, dance with me.
summary: Based on her diaries and correspondence, the book conveys the essence of her driving need to dance and the hardship involved in her struggle to become a successful artist.

title: Where the wings grow.
summary: A warm, somewhat nostalgic recollection of her lost youth, innocence, and rapport with the country woods of New England. She conveys a sense of her independence, lively spirit, and temperament which later made her a great dancer and choreographer.

title: The autobiography of Cecil B. DeMille.
summary: During his career in Hollywood (1913-1956), he directed seventy films, many of which were spectacular pictures like his last one, The Ten Commandments. His book, like his films, has a crowded set, filled with the history of Hollywood.

title: Dempsey.
summary: Dempsey recounts his career as a boxer, culminating in his defeat of Gene Tunney in Chicago in 1927. He was also a Hollywood film star, specializing in 'Big Hero' roles in which he beat up an assortment of rivals and villains. For 37 years he ran a popular Broadway restaurant.

title: Letters from prison.
summary: Eugene Dennis, general secretary of the American Communist Party, wrote letters to his wife and son throughout his imprisonment in the Atlanta Federal Penitentiary (1950-55). Jailed under the Smith Act for his communist activities, Dennis keeps a resolutely optimistic spirit, expresses interest in his young son's activities, and comments extensively on current events during the Cold War Era.

title: The autobiography of an American Communist: a personal view of a political life, 1925-1975.
publisher: Lawrence Hill & Co., Creative Arts Book Co.
summary: The common-law wife of American Communist Party leader Eugene Dennis presents their personal lives and the efforts of communists at home and abroad to promote social change, economic equity, and civil rights. They organized California farm laborers in the 1920's, worked for the Comintern in Moscow in the 30's, and left a son to be reared by the communists. Dennis was jailed, 1950-55, in a wave of anti-Communist sentiment, a particularly difficult time for Peggy.

title: Military journal of Major Ebenezer Denny: an officer in the Revolutionary and Indian Wars, with an introductory memoir.
summary: Most of the events he describes (1781-1795) occurred in various battles in Pennsylvania among famous contemporary military leaders, providing an interesting record of the men and their war. Appended are letters of the same period by his friend and commander Josiah Harmer. Denny later settled in Pittsburgh where he became a prominent banker.

title: The prodigal South returns to power.
summary: Special Counsel to the President, Richard Nixon (1969-72), Dent explains the 'Southern strategy' which he masterminded and which he claims restored the two-party system to the post-bellum Democratic South and brought Southern politics again into the national mainstream as a force to be reckoned with.

title: My memories of eighty years.
summary: A detailed insider's look at New York state and national politics during and following the Civil War. The author's rapid rise to national prominence is chronicled with portraits of the important people he knew from Lincoln and Horace Greeley to James Russell Lowell and Commodore Vanderbilt. A who's who of politics, literature, and industry (particularly railroading) during the author's eighty years as a public figure.

title: Love and dishes.
summary: Humorous accounts of his interest in young women and good food by the owner of El Borracho Restaurant in New York; includes large section of recipes from his own and other famous restaurants with accompanying remarks.

title: Walden West.
summary: Sac Prairie, Wisconsin, became his Walden — a microcosm of life in any world. With some nostalgia for passing times and values, he describes his childhood, his grandparents and others whose wisdom marked his experience, his interest in writing, his long correspondence with H.P. Lovecraft.

title: Warrior's way: the challenging life games.
summary: De Ropp discusses his upbringing in England, his education in biochemistry at the Royal College of Science in London, and his subsequent emigration to New York as a cancer researcher at the Rockefeller Institute. The dominant motif of de Ropp's life is his absorption with mysticism as manifested in the Warrior's Way, a philosophy of life that led him to be a disciple of Gurdjieff and Ouspensky.

title: Following the fire.
summary: Derstine's story is essentially a string of unusual manifestations of the Holy Spirit as experienced by him, his family, and his church brethren. The events that became commonplace to him included wrestling with Satan, speaking in tongues, being directed in every action by spoken works or mailed letters dictated by God, and on one occasion, his own metamorphosis into a worm. Abandoned and feared by his church and his family, Derstine became a widely known speaker/minister before being readmitted to the Mennonite Church in 1970.

title: As they were.
summary: Describes his life in France, 1939-40, while serving in the Polish Military Ambulance Corps.

title: My years with Xerox; the billions nobody wanted.
summary: The story of the remarkable development of Xerox from its origin as an invention by Chester Carlson developed by the Haloid Company to the evolution of one of America's largest and most dynamic corporations. The author was a prime maker of this history, having served as executive vice-president of Xerox, vice-chairman of its Board of Directors, and head of Research and Development. He recognized the potential of the invention and aided in its development from the beginning.
