title: A philosophical correspondence: 1932-1951.
summary: These wide-ranging, articulate letters form a series of philosophical dialogues between America's renowned philosopher and a foremost theorist in political science, sociology, and psychology. They discuss their respective work, the work of others (from Aristotle to Bertrand Russell), and such philosophical issues as the nature of perception, language, knowing, meaning, fact, experience, cognition, definition, space-time, transaction, and a host of other matters.

title: Forty years in the land of tomorrow, 1901-1940.
summary: A Baptist minister describes his life as a missionary in rural Brazil.

title: The hearthstone of my heart.
summary: De Trevino writes nostalgically about her family and childhood in Bakersfield, California, in the early 1900's. She talks about her start as a reporter in Boston, her eventual move back to California as a Hollywood reporter, and ends her story in Mexico when she meets her future husband.

title: My heart lies South: the story of my Mexican marriage with epilogue.
summary: While working as a reporter for a Boston newspaper in Mexico during the 1930's, she married Luis Trevino. Her book describes her life and marriage in Mexico. The 1972 edition adds an epilogue emphasizing the economic and social changes that occurred and the continuing centrality of the family in Mexican life.

title: Appointment on the hill.
summary: Lobbyist for the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom (1925-1946) describes her activities as a pacifist through the war years.

title: Wake Island. Revised and enlarged edition.
summary: An account of the defense of Wake Island based upon the author's own recollection, some few available records, and the recollections of other Wake Island veterans. Text includes photographs taken before and after the sixteen-day battle.

title: Forty years a gambler on the Mississippi: a cabin boy in 1839; could steal cards & cheat the boys at eleven; stack a deck at fourteen; bested soldiers on the Rio Grande during the Mexican War; won hundreds of thousands from paymasters, cotton buyers, defaulters, & thieves; fought more rough-and-tumble fights than any man in America; & was the most daring gambler in the world.
summary: In the language of melodrama Devol narrates some 150 anecdotes of life aboard Mississippi River steamboats, 1850-1887.

title: The letters of Bernard DeVoto.
summary: One hundred forty-eight letters selected from the thousands he wrote and arranged into topical groups reflecting DeVoto's opinions; controversies with Van Wyck Brooks, literary Marxists, art critics and others; and his private life. He was a professor at Northwestern and Harvard, an editor, and wrote the Easy Chair column in Harper's for over twenty years.

title: Autobiography of George Dewey: Admiral of the Navy.
summary: A narrative of ships, of sailing, of naval battles and strategy, written by one of the first great names in American naval history.

title: Push the button: the chronicle of a professor's wife.
summary: Cheerful account of her love for the South and Professor Malcolm H. Dewey of Emory University.

title: Twenty against the underworld.
summary: Dewey's unfinished memoirs together with public papers, trial transcripts, interviews, and other documents have been arranged and edited into this volume, which deals with his youth, his early career as Special Prosecutor fighting crime and racketeers, and his tenure as New York District Attorney when he became known as the racket-buster.

title: In quest: journal of an unquiet pilgrimage.
summary: Diamond is an American Jew who traveled to Jerusalem by way of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union in search of his family and religious roots. His journal describes numerous synagogues, museums, and art galleries in major cities as well as his reflections upon Jewish history and current Jewish life around the world.

title: Other Edens: the sketchbook of an artist naturalist.
summary: Dick, a naturalist who specializes in bird paintings, describes his world travels in pursuit of elusive species. He has become a conservationist in the course of many trips over the last 25 years to East Africa, India, Greenland, the Antarctic, the Galapagos, Central America, and the King Ranch in Texas.

title: Among those present: a reporter's view of twenty-five years in Washington.
summary: Personal and professional life mingle as Dickerson describes Washington according to the presidents: the Kennedys she found totally charming, the Johnsons congenial, President Nixon tasteless, and the Fords friendly and reassuring. Recounting dinners, personal friendships, and speculating on the sex lives of the presidents, she paints an attractive picture of Washington journalism.

title: Self-interviews.
summary: This is a 'talked' book. The poet, roughly following an outline devised by the editors, tape-recorded his thoughts: the first two chapters tell about the young poet's slow self-discovery and his rise to success after his first book of poetry in 1960; Chapter 3 covers a variety of literary problems from the creative process to politics; the remaining chapters are concerned with the poet's thoughts on his 'most important' poems.

title: Letters of Emily Dickinson.
summary: The letters, written 1842-1886, show the poet's sensitive development from girlhood to late middle life. Comprehensive listing of 1049 letters, 124 prose fragments, biographical sketches of recipients and persons mentioned, plus manuscript background of each letter provided.

title: Letters to Dr. and Mrs. Josiah Gilbert Holland.
summary: The letters to her close friends, written from her early twenties to the end of her life, sometimes including her poems, have been provided with background by the editor.

title: Selected letters.
publisher: The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press
summary: A selection from the complete edition of 'the most meaningful and most important letters plus a representative sampling of others — without losing the spirit of Emily Dickinson.'

title: Covered wagon days; a journey across the plains in the Sixties, and pioneer days in the Northwest; from the private journals of Albert Jerome Dickson.
summary: The editor has polished the memoranda, notes, journals, and private papers written by his father recording the life of a plainsman, a journey by covered wagon, mining camps, and a boat trip down the Missouri.

title: Chuckles behind the door: Lillian Dickson's personal letters.
summary: Missionary Dickson, also the wife of a missionary, worked with various groups in the Orient before founding the Mustard Seed, Inc., an independent Christian organization that supported hospitals, clinics, handicraft centers, vocational schools, kindergartens, boys' and girls' schools, and prison work.

title: Whither thou goest: the story of an uprooted wife.
summary: Dienstag recounts two painful years in her life when she and her family moved to upstate New York to accommodate her husband's new job.

title: Dancing in the dark; words by Howard Dietz.
publisher: The New York Times Book Co.
summary: He wrote the lyrics for such shows as Band Wagon. Sadie Thompson, Inside U.S.A., and English versions of La Boheme and Die Fledermaus for the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Pilgrim at Tinker Creek.
summary: A spiritual autobiography in modern times. Her journal is a meditation in her voice only, as she describes incidents she has observed on her solitary walks near Roanoke, Virginia.

title: Lucky to be a Yankee.
summary: The story of his outstanding career in baseball during the late Thirties and Forties includes anecdotes about many famous Yankees who were his contemporaries.

title: Leaning on a column.
summary: A round of embassy parties and White House dinners provides amusing anecdotes for this Washington columnist's account of his life.

title: Paul Baby: confessions of the mayor of Kneesville.
summary: 'Kneesville' is the imaginary locus of Paul Dixon's women-oriented daily television show on WLW Cincinnati. This book is intended to give his fans a look backstage at Dixon, his band, and backup stars.

title: It's a hell of a life, but not a bad living.
summary: In a fast-paced, rough-cut style, Dmytryk describes Hollywood life, recalling the films he has made and the entertainers with whom he has worked.

title: Roving naturalist: travel letters of Theodosius Dobzhansky.
summary: A collection of letters written by an expatriated Russian scientist widely recognized for his study of evolutionary processes in the twentieth century.

title: School of darkness.
summary: A teacher-lawyer explains how, in order to get union representation for teachers in New York, she became involved with the Communist Party.

title: The Baby Dodds story.
summary: One of the great New Orleans jazz drummers relates a fascinating history of New Orleans-style jazz in the process of describing his career as a drummer.

title: Southern rebel in reverse: the autobiography of an idol-shaker.
summary: An impetuous Southern clergyman, teacher, and broadcaster, Dodge fought for human rights and liberalism and against prejudice and narrow-mindedness of many kinds.

title: Crime reporter: the autobiography of Bill Doherty.
summary: Crime reporter of the Chicago Sun-Times and Chicago Tribune. Doherty describes the highlights of his 28-year career as one of six brothers, all of whom were reporters.

title: Alexander Dolgun's story: an American in the Gulag.
summary: Picked up by a KGB operative in Moscow in 1948, Dolgun, though he had done nothing, was held prisoner for eighteen months of interrogation, isolation, enforced sleeplessness, brutality, and near-starvation.

title: We shook the family tree.
summary: Growing up in Franklin, Pennsylvania, then making it in New York as a young writer.

title: Donahue: my own story.
summary: Donahue describes how he survived a hectic boyhood in Cleveland and college at Notre Dame to become the most popular syndicated talk-show host in America.

title: Tell it to the Mafia.
summary: After years with the Mafia, he was 'touched' by Jesus, quit the underworld, and became an evangelist-healer. This is the story of his conversion.

title: Third time lucky.
summary: The book's title evidently refers to the author's three-stage career as a chorus girl, a Hollywood starlet, and finally, theatrical success as understudy to Vivien Leigh in Born Yesterday.

title: Deliver us from evil: the short story of Viet Nam's flight to freedom.
summary: His first book tells of his experience as a Navy doctor in Indo-China, helping to build refugee camps for Vietnamese.

title: Dr. Tom Dooley's three great books: Deliver us from evil. The edge of tomorrow, The night they burned the mountain.
summary: A combined edition of the three books describing his humanitarian involvement with the people of Southeast Asia.

title: The edge of tomorrow.
summary: Here he describes his return to Asia where he established a hospital in the primitive Laotian village of Nam Tha, five miles from the border of Red China.

title: The night they burned the mountain.
summary: In his third book he writes of establishing a second hospital in Laos aided by two other American doctors.

title: Chronicles of Barabbas, 1884-1934: further chronicles and comment.
summary: letters and diary entries reveal the author's stand on various social issues.

title: The journals of Aldred Doten, 1849-1903.
summary: An extraordinarily complete diary of nearly 54 years by a newspaper man who was part of the Gold Rush days on the mining frontier and the Nevada silver boom.

title: Life of Silas Doty, 1800-1876: a forgotten autobiography; the most noted thief and daring burglar of his time.
summary: The adventures of a life-long thief and sometime murderer who stole everything from his teacher's penknife to horses, cattle, and money, and sometimes gave his loot to the poor.

title: Atlantic between.
summary: Gossipy account of society life in New York, California and Europe.

title: Off for California: the letters, log and sketches of William H. Dougal, Gold Rush artist.
summary: In letters to his fiancee and family, Dougal describes his impressions of San Francisco while engaged in business affairs and travel.

title: The Douglas diary; student days at Franklin and Marshall College, 1856-1858.
summary: Douglas was one of the first students at the newly formed school joining Marshall College and Franklin College. He comments on college life and mischief, the presidential campaign of James Buchanan, and other contemporary issues before the Civil War.

title: A funny thing happened to me on my way to the grave: an autobiography.
summary: A humorist, author, and script writer for radio and television describes his experiences as an entertainer, a stand-up comedian, and a writer for many prominent comedians.

title: Mike Douglas: my story.
summary: Douglas got his start on radio singing with 'Kay Kyser's Kollege of Musical Knowledge,' then worked on local stations during television's early years before his stint as a daytime talk-show host.

title: In the fullness of time; the memoirs of Paul H. Douglas.
summary: Douglas served as U.S. Senator from Illinois from 1948 to 1966. He describes some of his efforts on Capitol Hill.

title: The letters of Stephen A. Douglas.
summary: Letters written by Douglas, the 'Little Giant,' from 1833 to 1861. He espoused the cause of popular sovereignty and called himself 'a radical and progressive democrat.'

title: Court years, 1939-1975: the autobiography of William O. Douglas.
summary: The second volume of his memoirs, this volume recounts his 35 years on the U.S. Supreme Court, the cases that came before it, and the Chief Justices under whom he served.

title: The unfailing light: memoirs of an American rabbi.
summary: Life in service of promoting modern American Orthodox Judaism; Dean, then faculty member at the Jewish Theological Seminary.

title: Go East, young man; the early years: the autobiography of William O. Douglas.
summary: Covering his life from boyhood to his appointment to the Supreme Court in 1939, this book is filled with anecdotes and personal experiences.

title: Of men and mountains.
summary: Recollections of his teen-age experiences in the Cascade Mountains, their spiritual and physical importance, including his recovery from infantile paralysis.

title: American voyageur: the journal of David Bates Douglas.
summary: His detailed journal of the five-month expedition as appointed by Lewis Cass, Governor of Michigan Territory, to explore the Southern coasts and shores of Lake Superior.

title: Life and times of Frederick Douglass.
summary: In his third autobiographical volume, this book provides extensive descriptions of his Civil War and postwar activities.

title: The life and writings of Frederick Douglass.
summary: Includes all of Douglass' known writings, except for his three autobiographical volumes.

title: My bondage and my freedom.
summary: Retells his life as a slave and gives a vivid picture of his early years in the abolitionist movement.

title: Narrative of the life of Frederick Douglass: an American slave.

summary: Freiwirth explains the elaborate process by which he and his wife, Nellie, discovered the errors in Seventh Day Adventist doctrine and became astrologers instead.

summary: Friedan chronicles her personal experiences and the evolution of her views on women's place in the world since the publication of The Feminine Mystique in 1963.

summary: Describes his work in the publishing world and the fast, shallow world of the avant-garde, with many references to the world of books and literature.

title: Life and Liszt: the recollections of a concert pianist.
summary: Friedheim portrays the musical circles of the Victorian and Edwardian eras in European capitals and in North America.

title: Family letters of Robert and Elinor Frost.
publisher: State University of New York Press
summary: A narrative of the Frost family life recorded in letters, depicting their affection, concern, and exchange of ideas.

title: Assignment: rescue.
summary: In 1940-41, Fry worked as a secret agent in Vichy, France, to smuggle out French and German refugees on Hitler's blacklist.

title: Persons and events: reminiscences of Ludwig Ernest Fuerbringer, continuation of 80 eventful years.
