title: To a young bird artist: [his] letters to George Miksch Sutton.
summary: This book reveals the development of a mentor-pupil relationship between Fuertes and Sutton, an aspiring painter of birds.

title: Autobiography of James Gallier, architect. With a new introduction by Samuel Wilson, Jr.
summary: Gallier immigrated from Ireland in 1827 and established himself as an architect in New Orleans. He became famous as the chief architect of mid-nineteenth-century New Orleans, especially for Greek revival buildings. His book is interesting for its details on architectural practice as well as of a significant life in an interesting time.

title: Lucky Rooster: the autobiography of an impresario.
summary: The rags-to-riches story of an Italian immigrant boy who became a successful impresario bringing musical events — operas, ballets, symphonies, military bands — to the public and setting the pace in America's musical taste with such spectacles as the San Carlo Opera Company and performances under the stars in amphitheaters across the country.

title: Diary.
summary: This reprint of her diary, first published in the Pennsylvania Magazine of History and Biography in 1931 and 1934, furnishes an account of her life during 1778-1779. She and her husband had been prominent in the social life of Philadelphia. His loyalty to Britain made it necessary for him to seek refuge behind the British lines and eventually to sail for England. She remained behind in the vain hope of saving their property for her daughter.

title: Nyet: an American rock musician encounters the Soviet Union.
summary: Rock musician Gambino writes about his band's tour of Russia (Moscow and Leningrad), Latvia (Riga), and Lithuania (Vilnus) in November-December, 1974. Although this book purports to offer insight into the lives of typical citizens living under the Communist regime, it is written from a tourist's perspective combined with the 'cool' viewpoint of a suave musician.

title: My world line: an informal autobiography.
summary: Gamow's unfinished autobiography covers mainly his life until he arrived in the United States in 1934. His ideas played important parts in the foundation of physics, in cosmology, and in recent discoveries in biology. His books are classics on the history of physics, new ideas in physical science, and especially the popularization of physics, astronomy, and other natural sciences.

title: A hostage to fortune.
summary: Gann describes his many encounters with fortune, good and bad: expulsion from military academy, minimal success in the theatre at Yale, a rowdy trip around the world, the great passion of his life — flying — his entry into the airline industry, the death of his son, the disaster of his first marriage and success of his second.

title: Cream Hill: discoveries of a week-end countryman.
summary: In the early 1920's he and his wife bought a farmhouse in Connecticut. His book describes the pleasures of their irregular country life while maintaining their New York jobs, especially their delight in gardening.

title: The man from Keystone.
summary: Garai immigrated from Hungary to New York before World War I and soon obtained a job as a news photographer for the Keystone View Company, which he later managed. Although he obtained American citizenship, he and his family lived abroad for many years, often in London, which was the base for his quest of photographs of the famous and newsworthy that took him all over Europe, America, and into Africa. He writes as he photographs, with brash self-confidence.

title: Ready for the defense.
summary: An attorney involved in civil rights during the Sixties writes of some cases he was associated with, including those of Lenny Bruce and Timothy Leary. He was 'seeking radical change by representing the people whose conflict with the system might result in the creation of new rights and the clarification of old ones.'

title: Tough trip through paradise, 1878-1879.
summary: Garcia was a colorful character who lived nine years with Indian wives and became known as the Squaw Kid. Here he tells of adventures in the Musselshell country of Montana and Idaho among the Nez Perce and Flathead Indians during the end of the era of the Plains Indians.

title: Host with the big hat.
summary: Gardner describes his railroad trip to Mexico City via special train as a guest of the Mexican government and his visit to the controversial Julsrud Collection of 33,000 primitive figurines which may establish an earlier date and ethos of Mexican civilization, if their authenticity can be established.

title: Champagne before breakfast.
summary: Brief narratives about himself and his writing are interspersed in a collection of stories and incidents about the people and parties he writes about for his Broadway column.

title: A grain of mustard.
summary: Clairvoyant Gardner describes her impoverished childhood in West Virginia, her youthful marriage, motherhood, and the gradual emergence of her psychic, prophetic, and interpretive powers, represented by 'The Voice', which supernaturally dictates a variety of spiritual and political messages that determine Gardner's actions and beliefs.

title: The diary of James A. Garfield.
summary: Born in a log cabin east of Cleveland, Ohio, Garfield spent his early years there and later at what became Hiram College and at Williams College. He returned to Ohio as a teacher, then entered politics as a state senator and later served in the House of Representatives for seventeen years. Unfortunately the diary has gaps during the Civil War years as well as other periods of his life, but on the whole it is rich in candid remarks and presents a vivid self-portrait.

title: Why me? an autobiography.
summary: Gargan began acting in films during the Twenties; in the Fifties he starred in Martin Kane. Private Eye, the first television detective series. In 1960 he had surgery for cancer of the larynx. When he recovered, he made a new life and career as a popular fund-raiser for the American Cancer Society.

title: My father was Uncle Wiggily.
summary: The son of a father and mother who both wrote popular juvenile fiction— Uncle Wiggily, Motor Boys, Bobbsey Twins, and Tom Swift. His autobiography tells about living in small-town America with an enthusiastic and imaginative family which among them wrote more than a thousand books.

title: Back-trailers from the middle border.
summary: This reprint covers the years 1914 to 1928 in the lives of the author and his family, during which they moved east to New York and spent several summers in England visiting writers and the other men of note.

title: Hamlin Garland's diaries.
summary: The entries from author Garland's 43 diaries, 1898-1940, do not duplicate material in any of his other autobiographical volumes. Organized thematically by the editor, the entries discuss his social and literary experiences, his gloomy thoughts on the decline of his career in old age, literary personalities, political events, and social problems.

title: King of the dragsters: the story of Big Daddy Don Garlits.
summary: The story of his career in drag-racing is centered in the development of this sport during the 1950's and 1960's.

title: Letters from California 1846-1847.
summary: Prefaced by a 75-page biographical sketch, this volume presents a series of letters first printed in the Philadelphia North American and United States Gazette and intended to draw farmers, craftsmen, and merchants to develop the California Territory. Garner describes the customs, resources, and economic prospects based on his 22 years of personal experiences in California.

title: Adventures in the Supernormal; a personal memoir.
summary: Like My Life As a Search... this book explores in detail her childhood, youth and marriage, and coming to terms with the discovery that she has psychic powers. She includes discussions of different kinds of psychic power, as well as the research done by J.B. Rhine of Duke University and Gardner Murphy of the College of the City of New York.

title: Many voices; the autobiography of a medium.
summary: She is a trance medium through whom disembodied voices speak. In 74 years she has become something of an international figure, participating in psychic research, reporting facts and events that she has no evident way of knowing, and making no claims to supernatural powers.

title: My life as a search for the meaning of mediumship.
summary: A psychic medium writes of her childhood and adolescence, marriage, and the gradual awareness she had of her special powers. The major focus of the book is her attempt to understand and cope with being a medium, which includes participating in psychic research at Duke University.

title: Behold me once more: the confessions of James Holley Garrison, brother of William Lloyd Garrison.
summary: Garrison, brother of abolitionist William Lloyd Garrison, wrote these memoirs of his life as a youth and seaman, 1810-1840, as a form of penance for his lifelong alcoholism, allegedly conquered in 1840. His candid narrative conveys a moving account of a difficult, sordid life often spent in stupor and in irons.

title: Letters.
publisher: Belknap Press of Harvard University Press
summary: Projected to include letters up to his death in 1879, the present three volumes follow the journalist and abolitionist from his apprenticeship, founding of his newspaper and New England and American anti-slavery societies, his trip to England, courtship and marriage (Vol. I); his objections to orthodox observance of the Sabbath, 1838 Peace Convention, his efforts in support of women (Vol. II); to his urging disunion, his lecture circuit with Frederick Douglass, the Anti-Sabbath Convention, and his work for woman's suffrage (Vol. III).

title: Streetfighter in the courtroom: the people's advocate.
summary: This volume traces Garry's development from a poverty-stricken childhood to his position as folk hero of the New Left. As a lawyer, he used the courtroom to expose the system and attack the establishment.

title: The papers of Christian Gauss.
summary: A collection from the autobiographical notebooks, journals, and diaries of a prominent educator, who joined the Princeton faculty in 1905 and later became Dean (1925-1945).

title: Wayward child: a personal odyssey.
summary: Gayle analyzes his life as a Black 'bookworm' and writer from the South, a child and man prone to fantasies of violence and fond of passionate women. His lifetime inspirations have been Dostoevski and Richard Wright.

title: Rural parish: a year from the journal of Anna Laura Gebhard.
summary: An affectionate record of a year in the daily life of a young couple working with three small churches in neighboring towns that form their parish in rural Minnesota.

title: Autobiography of Peter Geiser: inventor, the Geiser separator, patented 1852-1855.
summary: Although the story is centered on the separator, it reveals the curiosity and inquisitive mind of the plainspoken inventor of the thresher.

title: Travels with myself and another.
summary: This is an entertaining, sometimes acid-etched description of Gellhorn's lifetime travels to China, the Caribbean, Russia, and particularly East Africa, which she loved.

title: Eskimo medicine man.
summary: As the last 'traveling physician' for the Department of Interior's Indian Service, Dr. George worked among Eskimos and traders in Alaska's remote north and northwest during the 1930's, accompanied by his wife and two small children. He describes the culture, medical practices, and superstitions of his Eskimo patients and conveys an unromanticized affection for Alaska.

title: Surreptitious entry.
summary: An operative for Naval Intelligence describes his experience in counterespionage during World War II.

title: Confessions of a Catholic worker.
summary: Garvey is a young man who has been keeping the Catholic faith by living and working at the Catholic Worker House in Davenport, Iowa, 1976-1977. He expresses his faith and the spirit of the Catholic Worker Movement in anecdotes about the poor people who receive the House's services.

title: There's a $50,000 contract on my head.
summary: Geraway's straightforward account of his life of crime, his 'quarter century of human and social failure,' including counterfeiting, check forgery, and being an accessory to murder, is told without the defensiveness that characterizes many such tales. His cooperation with the law while in prison caused the Mafia to put out a $50,000 contract for his murder. He lived to evade their grasp, to be freed from prison, and to find God and a good wife.

title: Green power; the successful way of A.G. Gaston.
summary: The grandson of slaves, Gaston grew up in rural Alabama, served in France during World War I, and returned to Birmingham where he began a series of hardworking business ventures that eventually made him a millionaire. He argues that green power must precede black power.

title: Chapters in my life: with the Frederick Taylor Gates lectures.
summary: A Baptist minister raised puritanically, Gates describes the liberal education he provided for his children, based on his belief that with maturity comes a natural personal religion. He also discusses his work with John D. Rockefeller, Sr. and his role in establishing the American Baptist Educational Society, the University of Georgia, the Rockefeller Foundation, and the General Education Board.

title: From the letters of Robert S. Gerdy, 1942-1945: a personal record of World War II.
summary: Gerdy, later a New Yorker editor, wrote over five hundred letters to relatives throughout World War II, which he spent in the U.S. Army as an enlisted man who eventually rose to captain, 'because I can write a bit, because I know the news when I see it, and because I can take news in and get it out fast and accurately.' The letters from Florida, France, and England reflect a sensitive newsman's eye for personalities, places, and events.

title: Letterbook, Paris, 1797-1798.
summary: One of the three ministers to France during the XYZ Affair which ruptured Franco-American relations, Gerry suffered the most censure, condemnation, and abuse from his countrymen.

title: To life: the story of a Chicago lawyer for more than forty years a defender of personal rights and civil liberties, a Don Quixote of the legal world.
summary: A renowned libel and civil liberties lawyer from Chicago, known for his celebrated defense of Henry Miller's Tropic of Cancer.

title: Public defender.
summary: Describes his experience as head of the public defender's office in Cook County, Illinois, and includes discussions of trial practices.

title: How to be rich.
summary: A billionaire shares his methods of business and advice on wealth building, supported by events from his own career.

title: Split seconds: a remembrance.
summary: A memoir of her youth in Russia, detailing her education and desire to become a ballerina.

title: Stalking the faraway places, and some thoughts on the best way to live.
summary: Describes several journeys in North America looking for foods used by ancient Indians and shares his philosophy of living.

title: Shadow and light: an autobiography.
summary: A judge shares his impressions of interesting people he met and moral commentary on the places he visited, especially Madagascar.

title: I always wanted to be somebody.
summary: The first Black woman to play in white tennis tournaments shares her experiences and achievements.

title: So much to live for.
summary: Gibson recounts her journey to becoming a professional golfer after achieving success in tennis.

title: Hugh Gibson, 1883-1954: extracts from his letters and anecdotes from his.
summary: N/A

title: Big league batboy.
summary: A youth's experience as a batboy for the St. Louis Cardinals, highlighting his associations with players and events.

title: From ghetto to glory: the story of Bob Gibson.
summary: The account of Bob Gibson's career as a pitcher for the St. Louis Cardinals and his views on racial equality.

title: The diaries of Walter Murray Gibson 1886, 1887.
summary: Diaries of Hawaii's prime minister that provide insight into his complex character and personal life.

title: Mass for the dead.
summary: Written in the form of a mass for the dead, this volume reflects on his mother's life and death.

title: The Jerry Giesler story.
summary: A noted California attorney recounts dramatic stories of his famous cases and legal strategies.

title: Man who lives in paradise: the autobiography of A.C. Gilbert.
summary: An Olympic gold medal winner describes his life combining sports and business.

title: Nuremberg diary.
summary: The journal notes of the prison psychologist at the Nuremberg trial of Nazi war criminals.

title: Dorothy and Lillian Gish. Edited by James E. Frasher. Illustrated. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons, 1973.
summary: Hundreds of photographs from their vaudeville, stage, and movie careers connected by Lillian's narrative tell the story of the Gish sisters, who established their reputations in the classic silent films of the legendary D.W. Griffith.

title: Lillian Gish: the movies, Mr. Griffith, and me. With Ann Pinchot. Illustrated. Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey: Prentice-Hall, Inc., 1969.
summary: A real trouper and an actress from the age of five, Lillian Gish grew up with the movies as they grew with her. Her book also describes her sister Dorothy and the life and career of D.W. Griffith, the great film pioneer who taught them the art of the film.

title: Letters. Compiled and edited with introduction and commentary by Blair Rouse. New York: Harcourt, Brace and Co., 1957.
summary: A selection of her letters (1897-1945) revealing her development as an outstanding novelist, her character interacting with friends, and her role in the literary and artistic life of her time.

title: Woman within. New York: Harcourt, Brace and Co., 1954.
summary: A writer recalls her childhood in Virginia, her development as a writer, and the experience of being part of a literary circle in New York. Includes genealogy and bibliography of her works.

title: Miss Willie: happenings of a happy family (1816-1926). Illustrated. Essington, Pennsylvania: Huntingdon Press, 1976.
summary: Anecdotes of the Elmore family when Willie was growing up in Alabama, including a collection of turn-of-the-century photographs of various family members. Glass focuses on the good times and sustenance from her enormous extended family and many friends.

title: And some believed: a chaplain's experiences with the Marines in the South Pacific. Chicago: Moody Press, 1946.
summary: Narrative includes very little description of the war or combat, focusing mainly on his functions as a chaplain.

title: I'm a busybody. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell Co., 1949.
summary: After interesting recollections of his childhood and adolescence in Iowa and Montana and his early attempts at writing, the book becomes a glib portrayal of a writer hustling on the periphery of significance.

title: Promoter ain't a dirty word. Illustrated. Foreword by Don McLeod. Forest Grove, Oregon: Timber Press, 1978.
summary: Glickman focuses on his efforts to promote various boxing, football, basketball, and hockey teams, particularly in Portland, Oregon. His happiest moments occurred when the Portland Trail Blazers won the National Basketball Association world championship in 1977.

title: General John Glover's letterbook, 1776-1777. Edited with introduction by Russell W. Knight. Foreword by Walter Muir Whitehill. Salem, Massachusetts: Essex Institute, 1976.
summary: A collection of letters sent in 1776-77 which focus on military strategy, day-to-day procedures in running an army, Glover's problems with money, family matters, and the uncertain postwar period.

title: My story. Edited with a preface by S.L. Shneiderman. New York: David McKay Co., Inc., 1961.
summary: Born in the U.S., a sister of Fiorello LaGuardia, she lived in Budapest with her husband, a Hungarian Jew. In 1944 she was arrested by the Gestapo and imprisoned in Ravensbruck. Her book recalls early family life in New York, her life and imprisonment in Europe, and her return to the U.S. in 1947.

title: Lives of labor, lives of love: fragments of friendly autobiographies. Hicksville, New York: Exposition Press, 1977.
summary: This autobiography includes incidents in the personal lives of Sheldon and Eleanor Glueck and their daughter, Joyce, but concentrates on their fifty years of joint research in criminology at Harvard Law School, conferences attended, awards given. It also includes Eleanor's diary and a bibliography of their voluminous writings.

title: Overview; a lifelong adventure in aerial photography. With DeWitt S. Copp. Index. Garden City, New York: Doubleday & Co., Inc., 1969.
summary: In 1917 he entered the Air Service and trained to be an aerial photographer and pilot. During the next fifty years he played a major role in the development of aerial photography as an inventor and practitioner.

title: Papers: including the reports of the Smithsonian Institution and the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation; Vol. I: 1898-1924; Vol. II: 1925-1937; Vol. III: 1938-1945. Edited by Esther C. Goddard (and others). Illustrated. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Co., 1970.
summary: These letters, diary entries, reports, and other papers tell the story of a pioneer in rocket research whose farsighted ideas, inventions, and accomplishments have made possible the space age.

title: The gilded age letters of E.L. Godkin. Edited by William M. Armstrong. Albany: State University of New York Press, 1974.
publisher: State University of New York Press
summary: A selection of letters by Godkin, who was first editor of the Nation, detailing his efforts to promote freedom and the well-being of freed men following the Civil War.

title: First person plural: the lives of Dagmar Godowsky. New York: The Viking Press, 1958.
summary: With verve and great comic spirit, Dagmar Godowsky tells of her flamboyant career as a film star.

title: Nothing to kick about: the autobiography of a modern immigrant. With Joseph Carter. Illustrated. New York: Dodd, Mead, 1973.
summary: Gogolak's family escaped from Hungary during the uprising and came to America where young Peter learned about a new culture. He eventually became a New York Giants football player famed for his kicking ability.

title: My last two thousand years. New York: Random House, 1972.
summary: A second generation American, novelist Gold tells of the journey back to his European roots in search of answers to 'Who am I?' and 'Is America enough?'

title: Crossroads Marseilles, 1940. New York: Doubleday & Co., Inc., 1980.
summary: A wealthy debutante from Evanston, Illinois, she was in France at the outbreak of World War II and stayed there to become a member of Varian Fry's Emergency Rescue Committee, spiriting hundreds of refugees out of France.

title: I don't need you when I'm right; the confessions of a Washington P.R. man. New York: William Morrow & Co., 1975.
summary: A humorous look behind the scenes in the world of public relations.

title: Rube Goldberg vs. the machine age: a retrospective exhibition of his work with memoirs and annotations. Illustrated. Edited by Clairk Kinnaird. New York: Hastings House, Publishers, 1968.
summary: Goldberg's works reflect a humorist's rebellion against gadgetry of the machine age.

title: The right time: an autobiography. Illustrated. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons, 1969.
summary: The crusty editor of the Carolina Israelite describes his readable account full of wit and humor but with a serious purpose.

title: Watermelon summer; a journal. Philadelphia: J.B. Lippincott Co., N/A.
summary: A revolutionary temporarily without a cause, Golden reflects on his summer working on a farm in Georgia, far removed from his affluent background.

title: Notes on an undirected life: as one anthropologist tells it. Illustrated. Bibliography. Flushing, New York: Queens College Press, 1978.
summary: Anthropologist Goldfrank draws from her journal and letters to document her years as secretary to Franz Boaz and working with Pueblo Indians and Blackfoot Indians.

title: The golden eggs. Edited with introduction by Meyer Levin. New York: Horizon Press, 1957.
summary: Veterinarian and proprietor of Vineland Poultry Laboratories, Dr. Goldhaft pioneered in making vaccines for fowl pox and fowl cholera.

title: Living my life. New York: Da Capo, 1970.
summary: The turbulent life of anarchist Goldman, who believed in 'perfect, unrestrained freedom for everyone.'

title: My disillusionment in Russia. Introduction by Rebecca West. Biographical sketch by Frank Harris. New York: Crowell, 1970.
summary: An account of Goldman's childhood in Russia, immigration to the U.S., and her disillusionment with the Bolshevik regime in 1921.

title: My road to opera: the recollections of Boris Goldovsky. As told to Curtis Cate. Illustrated. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company, 1979.
summary: Goldovsky, a child prodigy, recounts his experiences as a singer and conductor and his contributions to America's understanding of opera.

title: In and out of the ivory tower: the autobiography of Richard B. Goldschmidt. Seattle: The University of Washington Press, 1960.
summary: A distinguished zoologist describes his early years in Frankfurt, his world travels, and his internment as an alien in the United States during World War I.

title: Portraits from memory: recollections of a zoologist. Seattle: University of Washington Press, 1956.
summary: Describes Goldschmidt's years in Germany among celebrated zoologists.

title: Third man in the ring. As told to Frank Graham. New York: Funk & Wagnalls, 1959.
summary: A former lightweight boxer recounts his rise to success and experiences in the boxing world.

title: With no apologies: the personal and political memoirs of United States Senator Barry M. Goldwater. New York: William Morrow and Company, Inc., 1979.
summary: Conservative Senator Goldwater offers opinions on political and economic problems and comments on the chaos of the Sixties.

title: Close to home. New York: Simon and Schuster, 1979.
summary: A collection of Goodman's columns reflecting her personal and feminist reactions to the 1970s.

title: P.O.W. New York: Exposition Press, 1972.
summary: N/A

title: Recollections of a lifetime: or, men and things I have seen; in a series of familiar letters to a friend, historical, biographical, anecdotical, and descriptive.
summary: The author, under his pen name Peter Parley, wrote for children over 100 educational books set in fictional framework. He also wrote textbooks, histories and dictionaries, was a state legislator, a consul in Paris, a poet, and editor.

title: As I remember.
summary: A biblical scholar recalls the beginning of the University of Chicago and his own work on a new translation of the Bible.

title: Grenville Goodwin; among the Western Apache, letters from the field.
summary: During the 1930's Goodwin and Morris Opler were both studying different Apachean cultures. They exchanged information and ideas in order to compare systematically the Western Apache beliefs and customs.

title: It's good to be black.
summary: Goodwin's penetrating, beautifully written analysis of what it meant to grow up Black and proud as a coal miner's daughter takes the form of memorable vignettes about quintessential experiences.

title: Life on the King Ranch.
summary: The son of the ranch boss of the Norias section of King Ranch in Texas describes his childhood and youth with cowboys, riding and roping horses, and folklore of the Mexican hands.

title: I'm dancing as fast as I can.
summary: Award-winning television producer Gordon discovered at 41 that she was addicted to Valium; she writes movingly of her courageous battle to regain sanity.

title: Between two worlds: the memoirs of a physician.
summary: Memoirs of a scholar (both Jewish and secular) and physician who records his joys and sorrows, his zest for living, and his wish to leave a spiritual legacy.

title: Max Gordon presents.
summary: From New York's Lower East Side Gordon worked up through burlesque and vaudeville and became a major Broadway producer.

title: My side: the autobiography of Ruth Gordon.
summary: Actress Ruth Gordon tells the story of her career in the theater and later in movies, in dramas ranging from A Doll's House to Harold and Maude.

title: Myself among others.
summary: This autobiographical work is devoted almost entirely to her life in the theater, with anecdotes of dramatic celebrities described in a rather disjointed narrative.

title: Ruth Gordon: an open book.
summary: Anecdotes, advice, and remembrances of Ruth Gordon's seventy-odd years in the theater.

title: Years ago: a play.
summary: An autobiographical play describing her family and their reactions to her preparations to go to New York to become an actress.

title: Writer and critic: a correspondence with Henry Miller.
summary: The confrontation between writer and critic is illustrated in the exchange of letters between Gordon and Henry Miller.

title: Movin' up: Pop Gordy tells his story.
summary: Gordy writes about his boyhood in Georgia and his early married years in Detroit, revealing that a hard-working man from a hard-working family can successfully run his own business.

title: Let the glory out; my South and its politics.
summary: Gore interprets events and conditions of the South as they relate to American politics of the 1960's and 1970's, hoping to inspire able youth to public service.

title: Civil War diary.
summary: The 1861-1865 section of Gorgas' private journal is interesting as a description of his personal sensibility more than a record of battles and events.

title: Three and two! As told to Jerome Holtzman.
summary: Gorman focuses on his short-lived career as a player for a Mexican baseball team and his subsequent decision to become an umpire.

title: The mayor's man.
summary: New York Mayor Lindsay's right-hand man during the tumultuous late sixties, Gottehrer played a part in the changes made in the city by the administration.

title: Notes of a pianist.
summary: An American concert pianist and musician conscious of his role as cultural ambassador, Gottschalk traveled widely and recorded observations of social levels and political problems.

title: Sunlight and shadow; or gleanings from life work.
summary: Reminiscences of a temperance lecturer illustrated by anecdotes and personal experiences.

title: American story; memories and reflections of Bruce Gould and Beatrice Blackmar Gould.
summary: The remarkable story of a Midwestern couple who became joint editors of the Ladies' Home Journal during the Twenties.

title: Covered wagon geologist.
summary: Recollections of thirty years of adventure as an aviator and stuntman by a pilot who served on active duty in both World Wars.

title: Irish peacock; the confessions of a legendary talent agent.
summary: Grady was an agent for many famous stars, and his book is well-written with straightforward descriptions of his clients.

title: Autobiographical notes, verses and other writings.
summary: The life and work of an Episcopal minister who became a Christian Scientist during the late-nineteenth and early-twentieth centuries.

title: A Maine man in the making.
summary: A tale of growing up on a farm in Maine with the author's father.

title: Maine charm string.
summary: A curious view of her life in rural Maine described through a series of stories and events.

title: And one to grow on: recollections of a Maine boyhood.
summary: An easy-going narrative about his childhood in rural Maine.

title: This trifling distinction: reminiscences from Down East.
summary: Gould portrays local color in personal vignettes in this collection of anecdotes.

title: The witness who spoke with God: and other tales from the courthouse.
summary: Gould focuses his forensic skills on the New York State Court System, concentrating both praise and satire on judges and lawyers.

title: Yankee boyhood: my adventures on a Maine farm seventy years ago.
summary: Recollections of the harshness poverty imposed in his boyhood on a farm in Maine.

title: Yankee drummer.
summary: A drummer tells marvelous tales of his experiences traveling through New England.

title: Yankee storekeeper.
summary: Life of a country storekeeper in Somerset County, Maine, for four decades.

title: Rugged years on the Alaska frontier.
summary: Description of his sixteen years in Alaska, recounting the events and people he encountered while working throughout the territory.

title: Cowboy at the mike.
summary: Gowdy began broadcasting sporting events and became one of the most versatile sports commentators.

title: Visibility unlimited.
summary: N/A

title: My window looks Down East.
summary: Thoughtful reminiscences about her experiences living on a rural coast of Maine.

title: Our way Down East.
summary: The first of several she wrote about country life, this book tells of their first eight years on a farm in Maine.

title: The notebooks of Martha Graham.
summary: Dancer, choreographer, and teacher, Graham's notebooks detail the evolution of her ideas.

title: They call me Mother Graham.
summary: The mother of evangelist Billy Graham tells of her upbringing and family life.

title: The boy who sailed around the world alone.
summary: In 1965 Graham started sailing around the world and shares his fascinating experiences.

title: Dove.
summary: In 1965 at age sixteen, Graham set sail on his 24-foot sloop and shares his journey and experiences.

title: Beloved infidel: the education of a woman.
summary: The story of her difficult childhood, success as a chorus girl, and her romance with F. Scott Fitzgerald.

title: College of one.
summary: The account of a unique two-year liberal arts course devised for her by F. Scott Fitzgerald.

title: The rest of the story.
summary: From 1941 to 1963 she recovered from Fitzgerald's death, became a war correspondent in London, married twice, raised two children, and had her own radio and television shows.

title: Scratch an actor: confessions of a Hollywood columnist.
summary: Primarily a book of Hollywood gossip, her book represents, she says, the danse macabre of the film world, the illusion of fame and glitter which, when it vanishes, leaves nothing.

title: State of heat.
summary: Written in the tone suggested by the title, her book is an argument for the power of sex in a successful life, which she demonstrates by descriptions of her own sexual tastes and exploits.

title: The late Lily Shiel.
summary: At six, cockney Lily Shiel was placed in a Jewish orphanage by her ailing mother; there she stayed until she was fourteen. Although she was the brightest and most energetic of the orphans, a male relative prevented her from applying for a scholarship and insisted that she go to work as a housemaid. Through her personal attractiveness, grit, and enterprise, Lily obtained progressively more attractive jobs. She fell in love with her employer and married him at nineteen.

title: Red Grange story: the autobiography of Red Grange.
summary: A football player writes about his athletic career, emphasizing his experience at the University of Illinois, in professional football, and in flim.

title: Blondes, brunettes, and bullets.
summary: "Granny" relates anecdotes about his career as a publicist and producer of vaudeville and night club shows before, during, and after Prohibition. The Silver Slipper was his best known club.

title: When the melon is ripe: the autobiography of a Georgia Negro high school principal and minister.
summary: A bitter, defensive narrative by a Black principal of several high schools in Georgia. He was often at odds with the local white citizens because he encouraged social and academic racial intermingling in a highly segregationist region. Unjustly accused of sex crimes, his job and life were often threatened.

title: Born again.
summary: Written in response to public reaction to her first autobiographical account of her conversion to Catholicism, here she argues the importance of faith as a power to change life.

title: The personal memoirs of Julia Dent Grant (Mrs. Ulysses S. Grant).
summary: Mrs. Grant's story spans her life from childhood through the Civil War, the White House years, and up to the death of her husband.

title: General Grant's letters to a friend 1861-1880.
summary: These letters to his friend Elihu Washburne, Illinois congressman and later American representative in France, were written from famous battlefields, from the White House, and from around the world during Grant's extended tour. They contain Grant's views on men and affairs in America and foreign lands, particularly on British rule in India and on the Japanese.

title: Mr. Lincoln's general: U.S. Grant, an illustrated autobiography.
summary: Over 300 illustrations selected by the editor to match major extracts from Grant's outstanding autobiography, originally published in its entirety in 1885-86.

title: The papers of Ulysses S. Grant.
summary: After 1843 when he graduated from West Point, Grant served in the U.S. Army until he was elected President in 1868. Named General of Union Armies in the West in 1863, he was put in command of all Union armies five months later and accepted Lee's surrender April 9, 1865. After two terms as President, he retired, traveled extensively, ran unsuccessfully for a third nomination as Republican candidate in 1880, and wrote his Memoirs, the royalties from which saved his family from poverty after his death.

title: Personal memoirs of U.S. Grant.
summary: In a careful account of his life up to the end of the Civil War, the general, writing the year before his death, tells his story as an ordinary man.

title: Personal memoirs of U.S. Grant: a modern abridgment.
summary: This is an abridgment of the factual, moving account of Grant's life. Although he eventually became U.S. president, this book focuses on the Civil War and provides detailed accounts of the battles, campaigns, and personalities involved, including most of the prominent Civil War generals, Northern and Southern. Mark Twain suggested that Grant write this book to help pay his enormous debts; indeed, the book did become a posthumous bestseller.

title: Off at sunrise: the overland journal of Charles Gray.
summary: Gray, a young Forty-Niner, records in his journal the 2,498 mile trek from Independence, Missouri, to San Francisco, May 1— November 19, 1849, as a member of the Newark Overland Company. He describes the scenery, the weather, difficulties with the wagons, sickness, wild animals, and appears continually to be drawn by the spirit of adventure, rather than by a lust for the precious metal.

title: One woman's life, the steppings of faith: Edna Gray's story.
publisher: The Franklin Printing and Publishing Co.
summary: A novelistic narrative of her marriage to a tyrannical husband and the difficulty she had surviving his cruelty. When she left him, she was ostracized by church and community, but finally recovered her four children and began a new life with them.

title: Pioneer adventures.
summary: Frontier and pioneer life in area of Cherokee, Texas.

title: Sole survivor: the battle of Midway and its effect on his life.
summary: An ensign in the U.S. Navy aboard an aircraft carrier during the Battle of Midway, he was the only one in his squadron to survive the shots from enemy aircraft, the crash of his own aircraft, and the treacherous ocean which supported him until his miraculous rescue. Text includes photographs.

title: Third strike.
summary: The unfinished diary of a sailor suffering from alcoholism gives a striking impression of his mental anguish prior to suicide.

title: For those I loved.
summary: The story of Gray's survival through the Holocaust and annihilation of his people in the Warsaw ghetto and the lower camp officer at Treblinka. He was later an importer in New York. After he had established an idyllic life in southern France, fate struck again in the form of a flash forest fire which destroyed his wife and four children. Despite the repeated blows, he struggles to keep going and to fight for the environment through the Dina Gray Foundation.

title: The diary of Millie Gray, 1832-1840: recording her family life before, during and after Col. Wm. F. Gray's journey to Texas in 1835; and the journal, giving particulars of all that occurred during the family's small voyage to Texas in 1838.
publisher: Printed in the name of Rosenberg Library Press, Galveston: F. Young Pub. Co.
summary: The diaries kept by the wife of Colonel William Fairfax Gray in Fredericksburg, Virginia, and later in Texas contain glimpses of her nineteenth-century character and everyday personal life. Her description of the ship voyage to Houston is of particular interest.

title: Somebody up there likes me.
summary: Former middle-weight champion writes of the street life of his New York boyhood, his years in prison, and his hard work for the championship title.

title: The gypsy in my soul: the autobiography of Jose Greco.
summary: Dancer and choreographer Greco intermingles accounts of the financial and artistic successes of his flamenco dance company with tales of his multiple marriages and love affairs, often concurrent. His tastes in dancing and beautiful women reinforce the Spanish dancer stereotype he cultivates in this book.

title: An overland journey: from New York to San Francisco in the summer of 1859.
summary: The major purpose of his journey was to explore for himself the Western territories in order better to promote a transcontinental railroad and the development of the West. A magnificent frontier travel book.

title: Recollections of a busy life.
summary: Originally published in the New York Ledger, these essays describe the life and times of a prominent journalist, with sections on Margaret Fuller, Henry Clay, Abraham Lincoln, Jefferson Davis, the Civil War, socialism, literature, politics.

title: With much love.
summary: After early childhood in Savannah, Green describes her family life in Paris through 1920, where her father was business agent for an American cottonseed oil company.

title: Drums in my ears; jazz in our time.
summary: A musician and celebrated jazz critic, the author presents a potpourri of jazz pieces full of the history of the era. He writes from personal experience as well as with critical acumen, for he lived and worked in the jazz clubs himself and knew personally the musicians he describes.

title: The stones of Zion; a novelist's journal in Israel.
summary: Every stop on his itinerary in modern Israel reminded Green of biblical events. Friends and guides presented historical and archaeological evidence which enforced or redefined his understanding of the scriptures and brought to life the ancient religious stories.

title: I am Eskimo — Aknik my name.
summary: Written in the style of oral tradition, his book mingles folk tales and hunting lore with his life story among the Alaska Eskimos.

title: The Goldenberg who couldn't dance.
summary: Greenbaum writes about his childhood in Buffalo and his brief career in the Navy, but he focuses mainly on his career as a television writer for shows like Mr. Peepers, Gomer Pyle, and Mash. He discusses Hollywood friends like Wally Cox and Marlon Brando, but the book is also a paean to his friend and co-writer, Jim Fritzell.

title: Play it a bust: The Super Cops.
summary: A controversial policeman in the New York Police Department, the "Batman" of the "Batman and Robin" detective team writes of their work in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the tough Brooklyn ghetto.

title: N/A
summary: N/A

title: Life at Greene's Corners.
summary: Greene's account of his childhood years at Greene's Corners, Michigan, focuses on children's common experiences such as blackberrying, the village blacksmith, washing and shearing sheep, school, and holidays.

title: Memory collector.
summary: A collection of memories, topical and trivial, from his long experience as a columnist for the Detroit News.

title: Don't come back without it.
summary: Greene humorously narrates her first two and a half years as a reporter on the New York Post, including an evening with Elvis Presley, an attempt to lose weight at Slenderella, an expose of Arthur Murray Dance Studios, and a variety of amorous escapades.

title: Papers of General Nathanael Greene.
summary: Volume I details the significant part he played in the triumph at Trenton as general in Washington's army. Volume II follows his career from the battles of Brandywine and Germantown in 1777 through his joining Washington at Fredericksburg. His letters lend insight into the economic and political history of the time.

title: Calvary in China.
summary: A Catholic missionary priest tells of his treatment, imprisonment, and deportation while in China between the years 1949-52 when the communists took over the country.

title: Hsiang-Ya journal.
publisher: Archon Books for The Yale China Association
summary: A missionary analyzes the "war-to-the-death conflict of ideas between the forces of Chiang Kai-shek and the forces of Communism" which she and her medical husband, Phil, experienced during the 1920's-40's as representatives of the Yale-in-China Missionary Program in various mid-Chinese provinces. Much of her moving account is derived from letters.

title: Letters of Warwick Greene: 1915-1928.
summary: From 1910 to 1915 he was director of the Bureau of Public Works in Manila. He was with the American Red Cross in France, and after serving in several significant positions during World War I, he was discharged in 1919 as a lieutenant colonel. His letters focus primarily on political events during and after the war.

title: A child called Noah; a family journey.
summary: The painful diary of a family through the first five years in the life of their autistic child Noah. Although at first Noah seemed completely normal, by the time he was two and a half, he could not perform simple tasks or communicate. His parents and his brother had to find ways to cope with their despair and his autistic condition.

title: Higher than the sky.
summary: In an evocative, perceptive, entertaining autobiography, Greenman narrates her upbringing in rural South Dakota as a daughter of a dynamic suffragist mother and understanding father. She received art training at Washington, DCs Corcoran Gallery, traveled throughout Europe painting, married and lived the good life in New York City until her husband went broke in the Depression. Thereafter, she traveled over the United States, painting portraits of the famous, the infamous, the rich and the vain, and had a wonderful time on her own forthright terms.

title: Letters of Horatio Greenough: American sculptor.
summary: In addition to family letters, this collection includes many to artists and architects known by Greenough, America's first sculptor. Among other projects, he was commissioned to do two sculptural groups for the National Capitol.

title: Letters of Horatio Greenough to his brother, Henry Greenough.
summary: A reprint of the edition originally published by the sister-in-law of America's first sculptor.

title: Where I stand: the record of a reckless man.
summary: An editor often at the center of controversy, the author has fought against corruption and the abridgement of freedom taking on such adversaries as Senator Pat McCarran, columnist Westbrook Pegler, and Senator Joe McCarthy.

title: Designing male.
summary: An account of his younger life, primarily in Paris and New York after World War I, and Hollywood during the Twenties, by a custom dress designer who started out as a Nebraska farm boy wanting to be a writer.

title: The Indians and the nurse.
summary: From 1922 to 1924 Miss Gregg was nurse on the Rosebud and Pine Ridge Sioux Indian reservations.

title: Diary and letters of Josiah Gregg.
summary: Gregg, a Santa Fe trader, knew the central plains, the Plains Indians, and the Mexicans during the 1830's, and wrote the classic Commerce of the Prairies.

title: Nigger: an autobiography.
summary: The compelling story of Gregory's youth and continuing fight against racial prejudice and poverty.

title: The house on Jefferson Street; a cycle of memoirs.
summary: Gregory recaptures a vanishing era in a spiritual journey from his grandfather's house in Milwaukee through the literary worlds of Chicago, New York, and London.

title: Just call me Doc! Fifty years as a pharmacist.
summary: The author recalls everyday events he observed while working behind the counter as a pharmacist.

title: Ten years in Japan: a contemporary record drawn from the diaries and private and official papers of Joseph C. Grew.
summary: An ambassador to Japan from 1932 until the attack on Pearl Harbor, Grew witnessed a series of crises in the internal and external affairs of Japan.

title: Turbulent era: a diplomatic record of forty years, 1904-1945.
summary: The books contain the recollections, letters, and diaries of an American diplomat's forty years in the foreign service.

title: Valley of shadows.
summary: An outstanding account of his early life in Illinois and Missouri (1858-1863) that perceptively anticipates the effects of the inevitable war.

title: Black like me: with a new epilogue by the author.
summary: Through the use of skin dyes, Griffen masqueraded as a Black man in the Deep South, where he encountered the fear, prejudice, and hatred whites have for Blacks.

title: Archie: the Archie Griffin story.
summary: This as-told-to narrative is a mixture of biography and autobiography, emphasizing Griffin's athletic career at Eastmoor High School (Columbus, Ohio), his football career at Ohio State University where he won the Heisman Trophy in 1974 and 1975.

title: Lying in state.
summary: A businessman and diplomat relates his career in business, his World War II experiences in Finland and the Pacific, and finally his postwar diplomatic missions.

title: Papa's delicate condition.
summary: Describes her early affection for her father during his fight with alcoholism, which eventually made family reconciliation possible.

title: This you won't believe.
summary: Light, chatty stories of her earlier years of fame and glamour as a Hollywood star.

title: The man who invented Hollywood; the autobiography.
summary: The unfinished autobiography of movie pioneer Griffith is presented as originally dictated.

title: Life and adventures of Revenooer No. 1.
summary: Griffith, a lawyer by training and an Internal Revenue Service agent, has written an account of his experiences trying to capture moonshiners.

title: Waist-high culture.
summary: A philosophical analysis of his childhood and early days as a journalist.

title: Turnip greens and sergeant stripes.
summary: Written in Southern dialect, with a glossary included, his book is a down-home memoir of rural life in Alabama and his service on the Japanese front during World War II.

title: Letters on equality of the sexes, and the condition of woman, addressed to Mary S. Parker.
summary: Fifteen letters written in 1837 by a now famous feminist discuss the conditions of women in America, Europe, Asia, and Africa.

title: Jolly Cholly's story: baseball, I love you!
summary: One of the great characters of baseball history writes of his experience as a player or manager in various teams.

title: Fighting with Ross' Texas Cavalry Brigade, C.S.A.; the diary of George L. Griscom, adjutant, 9th Texas Cavalry Regiment.
summary: Griscom reports on the efforts of a Confederate Texas regiment in cryptic diary entries.

title: Beyond the schoolhouse.
summary: A school superintendent's background offers perspectives on his efforts and philosophy of education.

title: Time of my life.
summary: Griswold discusses a number of chemical processes he developed and offers advice for successful living.

title: N/A
summary: N/A

title: I looked and listened: informal recollections of radio and television.
summary: A newspaper columnist in New York City describes the early days of radio and television broadcasting.

title: The pastor: the life of an immigrant.
summary: An immigrant from Russia became a clergyman, recounting his experiences.

title: His life and work.
summary: This volume presents a chronological view of Grosz's drawings and paintings, accompanied by interpretive commentary.

title: A little yes and a big no: the autobiography of George Grosz.
summary: A famous painter and cartoonist writes of his early life and career in Germany, his immigration to the United States.

title: I went to the Soviet Arctic.
summary: The author set out to find out about the status of women in the Soviet Union, discovering much about the people of the Soviet Arctic.

title: The party's over now; reminiscences of the Fifties — New York's artists, writers, musicians, and their friends.
summary: An active participant in New York art circles during the 1950's, Gruen reconstructs the activities of avant-garde painters, poets, writers, and composers.

title: Many battles; the autobiography of Ernest Gruening.
summary: The battles were fought during his sixty-year career as a journalist, editor, public official, governor and senator of Alaska.

title: Diary of Benjamin F. Gue in rural New York and pioneer Iowa, 1847-1856.
summary: As a young man, he and his brother became respected citizens in Iowa and were influential in the founding of the State Agricultural College.

title: Touch of time: myth, memory, and the self.
summary: Guerard reflects on his much traveled youth, wartime experiences, and literary heritage in a series of connected essays.

title: Personal equation.
summary: Educated in France and England, he taught at American colleges and universities and became unshakably Americanized.

title: Mountain Charley: or, The adventures of Mrs. E.J. Guerin, who was thirteen years in male attire; an autobiography.
summary: An intriguing story of a woman who dressed as a male, went on a wagon trek to California, and prospected for gold.

title: Ossie: the autobiography of a Black woman.
summary: Ossie Guffy writes about her life and work fighting against discrimination, poverty, and ignorance.

title: Confessions of an art addict.
summary: A woman of great wealth and influence in modern art describes her evolution as a gallery owner and patron.

title: Out of this century: the informal memoirs of Peggy Guggenheim.
summary: N/A

title: The Southern Negro nun: an autobiography.
summary: The writer is a member of a religious congregation of Black nuns in the South who work in education and human relations.

title: Rainbow in Tahiti.
summary: Describes new life she established with her husband on ten acres in Tahiti, 1923-1940, with a sense of humor about cultural conflicts.

title: Letters of Louise Imogen Guiney.
summary: The author took much pleasure from writing letters, expressing her free spirit and commenting on public figures and events.

title: Death be not proud.
summary: A moving account of his son's illness and death from a malignant brain tumor, including letters and diary entries.

title: Discovery at the Rio Camuy.
summary: A caving enthusiast writes of his exploration of the Rio Camuy cave in Puerto Rico.

title: Making changes: the politics of self liberation.
summary: Gurtov describes his transformation from a conventional life to a communal humanist and political science professor.

title: My time in the army: the diary of a World War II soldier.
summary: Private First Class Gustafson provides an account of his life in the U.S. Army using a diary and letters.

title: Turning on.
summary: The author explores consciousness-expanding experiments.

title: The uncorrupted heart: journal and letters of Frederick Julius Gustorf, 1800-1845.
summary: Gustorf's travel journal documents his journey from Philadelphia to St. Louis.

title: Blue hen's chick: a life in context.
summary: A nostalgic story of his youth in Montana, followed by his college days and newspaper work.

title: Bound for glory.
summary: A tribute to the grit and goodness of America's plain people, including migrant workers.

title: Seeds of man: an experience lived and dreamed.
summary: A rambling tale of adventures the author had when searching for his lost silver mine.

title: Folk poet, folk singer, author, ballad maker.
summary: Guthrie's articles reflect his individuality and influence in the folk revival of the 1950s.

title: American rainbow: early reminiscences.
summary: The story of his immigration to the U.S. from Ireland and his early adventures as a writer.

title: Diary (1843-1852) of James Hadley: tutor and professor of Greek in Yale College, 1845-1872.
summary: An eminent Yale professor's diary describes campus life and his experiences in the university community.

title: Alaskan diary of a pioneer Quaker missionary.
summary: Her diary is a daily record of her life in a remote Alaskan mission, including temperature and living conditions.

title: Confederate letters of John W. Hagan.
summary: A collection of letters written by a Confederate soldier to his wife during the Civil War.

title: The hyphenated family: an American saga.
summary: The book describes the painful conflict in loyalty and patriotism across two countries.

title: The Walter Hagen story: by the Haig himself.
summary: The story of an internationally famous professional golfer.

title: Diary of my European trip.
summary: Records Father Hagerty's sabbatical tour of Europe and the Holy Land.

title: Guerrilla padre in Mindanao.
summary: The story of a Jesuit priest who lived and worked with guerrilla forces during WWII in the Philippines.

title: England to me.
summary: A description of postwar England after recovering from life in a Japanese concentration camp.

title: Crosswinds: an airman's memoirs.
summary: Halaby recounts his rise and fall in corporate aviation and his experiences as a test pilot.

title: Halas by Halas: the autobiography of George Halas.
summary: The autobiography of an influential figure in football, detailing his life and contributions to the sport.

title: My second 25 years: instead of a footnote, an autobiography.
summary: A potpourri of autobiographical essays from his Socialist monthly, The American Freeman.

title: The world of Haldeman-Julius.
summary: A collection of personal essays from Haldeman-Julius's Socialist monthly.

title: A New England boyhood.
summary: A depiction of boyhood experiences in New England.

title: Life in the studio.
summary: A reminiscence of her exceptional parents and an examination of the nature of art and the artist.

title: New England girlhood.
summary: Recollections of childhood with her artist parents, combining memory with fantasy.

title: Letters of Susan Hale.
summary: Conversational letters revealing Hale's life comprised of teaching, traveling, and keeping house.

title: Roots.
summary: A bestselling account of family history tracing ancestors back to their roots in Gambia.

title: Whale hunt: the narrative of a voyage by Nelson Cole Haley, harpooner in the ship Charles W. Morgan, 1849-1853.
summary: A vivid description of early whaling based on Haley's journal kept during his voyage.

title: Personal memoir: an unforgettable autobiography.
summary: An account of life as an engineer, including various topics such as birth control and energy.

title: Life with the Esquimaux: a narrative of Arctic experience in search of survivors of Sir John Franklin's expedition.
summary: A detailed account of Hall's Arctic exploration and search party experience.

title: Arctic rovings and the adventures of a New Bedford boy on sea and land.
summary: A narrative of his adventures at sea and land as a boy.

title: String too short to be saved.
summary: A beautifully written recollection of Hall's boyhood in rural New Hampshire.

title: Doctor reminisces.
summary: Recounts Hall's experiences as a doctor through case histories during his career.

title: Letters to Jonas Gilman Clark.
summary: Correspondence from Hall's European pedagogic tour.

title: Forgotten one and other true tales of the South Seas.
summary: Author sketches his experiences with people living in Tahiti during the 1920s.

title: My island home: an autobiography.
summary: A writer tells of his early days and his interest in literature.

title: Bird of time.
summary: A memoir written with a sense of sadness for time lost to technological society.

title: Journey to the end of an era: an informal autobiography.
summary: The worldwide travels of an adventurer with a romantic sensibility and a restless spirit always in search of the new and unusual.

title: Do you remember?: memories of a schoolteacher.
summary: Elementary schoolteacher writes an elementary account of her forty years in the classroom, lacing it with children's remarks and misspellings collected over the years.

title: The main trail.
summary: Unable to finish school because of eye trouble, Hall began his career riding circuit in New Mexico as a lay missionary. He later preached from coast to coast at churches, conferences, colleges, and seminaries sharing his spiritual power and the Gospel of Christ.

title: Stormy petrel in linguistics.
summary: A professor at Cornell for many years, Hall studied under or worked with many of the principal contributors to the profession, including Leonard Bloomfield, Edward Sapir, and Hans Kurath. Hall's autobiography verifies his reputation as a scholar and an ill-tempered polemicist.

title: Sharlot Hall on the Arizona Strip: a diary of a journey through northern Arizona in 1911.
summary: Serving as territorial historian of Arizona, the author traveled by wagon through the Arizona Strip, a region north of the Colorado River, in order to survey its people, resources, and history. In terse prose, she describes the territory and by the way gives some sense of the experience of camping and traveling in this rugged land. Includes bibliography.

title: A lion in court.
summary: A flamboyant and controversial lawyer in San Francisco describes his career in litigation, with bold criticism of the judiciary system, penal codes, and American society.

title: Good-bye, Union Square; a writer's memoir of the thirties.
summary: Halper recalls his life during the thirties when he went to New York to find his way as a writer. He nostalgically remembers literary and political conversations, sales of his stories, people he met, a productive summer at Yaddo, his acquaintance with Whittaker Chambers and others.

title: West Pac '64.
summary: He writes of his experience as a Navy doctor serving in the West Pacific in 1964. His story ends with an account of the Battle of Tonkin Gulf.

title: Bessie Yellowhair.
summary: Halsell changed clothes, names, and identities with an Indian woman to live among the Navajos and then 'pass' as a Navajo among whites. As when she previously 'passed' for Black (described in Soul Sister), she found the transition shocking, necessitating considerable psychological adjustment.

title: Admiral Halsey's story.
summary: Retired as a fleet admiral in 1947, Halsey served the Navy over 45 years. Describes his life, primarily military, primarily in the Pacific, with few traces of his personal life.

title: Gentleman's progress: the itinerarium of Dr. Alexander Hamilton, 1744.
summary: The diary of his journey from Maryland to Maine is lively, witty, and informative, with incisive descriptions of people, lodgings, taverns, countryside, and manners, an interesting view of eighteenth-century life.

title: The papers of Alexander Hamilton.
summary: This edition of Hamilton's papers contains letters to and from him and documents written by or concerning him. All are in chronological order. Hamilton occupied a central position in the government of the United States, serving as Washington's aide-de-camp, as Major General in the Army, Secretary of War, Secretary of the Treasury, author of The Federalist Papers, and a major contributor to economic and fiscal policy.

title: Ambassador in bonds.
summary: A Christian missionary describes life in a Japanese concentration camp in the Philippines, 1941-1945. She draws an analogy between 'bonds' of prison camp and 'bonds' of marriage.

title: Little boy in Confederate Mobile.
summary: Brief recollection of his boyhood in Alabama during and shortly after the Civil War.

title: My sixty years on the Plains: trapping, trading, and Indian fighting.
summary: Most of the book describes trapping, trading, or fighting with different Plains Indians, 1842-1845. Begun when he was on a hunting expedition at twenty, the book concludes with a summary of his later years as trader, agent, scout.

title: Father was a tenor.
summary: Hamlin focuses on the career of her father, George Hamlin, as a tenor in oratorios and recitals around the United States and in Europe, 1890-1920. She made her own musical debut as a singer in Lake Placid in 1920, but her account of her own career is fragmentary and ends in 1925.

title: Flamboyant judge: James D. Hamlin, a biography.
summary: The editors have integrated two manuscripts which they persuaded Hamlin to dictate — one on a wire recorder, one to a typist — in the mid-1940's. The result is an interesting account of a lively character deeply involved in the economic and social development of the Southwest, especially western Texas and Santa Fe-Taos, New Mexico.

title: Soul sister.
summary: Influenced by John H. Griffin's Black Like Me, the author determined to pass herself as Black and live in Harlem and Mississippi as part of the Black community. Her experiences — terrifying, shameful, and nightmarish — reveal much that she learned about the struggle between the races for survival, identity, and dignity.

title: Kuno: one of the last of the general practitioners.
summary: The son of Swedish immigrants, he became a general practitioner in the town of Clare, Michigan. The book recounts his four decades of service delivering babies under adverse circumstances, performing many kinds of surgery, and making life and death decisions.

title: No laughing matter: the autobiography of a WASP.
summary: Halsey describes her WASP upbringing in a Germanic.

title: John Hammond on record: an autobiography.
summary: Hammond, a Vanderbilt heir, was the family maverick because he dropped out of Yale and hung around Harlem musicians in the Twenties. He turned this fascination into a useful and engaging autobiography which discusses all the musicians (mostly jazz) he has known and their performances he recorded for 45 years with Columbia Records and other producers. His career is related to his other equally engrossing commitment to civil rights, as his long service on the NAACP board testifies.

title: The autobiography of John Hays Hammond.
summary: After his youth on the Western frontier, the author went to Africa where he became a business associate of Cecil Rhodes, worked with the Reform Movement there, was charged with high treason, condemned to death, then released, and went on to other adventures. Later he was a political figure in the Republican Party before and after World War I.

title: Remembrance of Amherst: an undergraduate's diary, 1846-1848.
summary: Vivid, precise description of his individual development as a student and of the contemporary' educational process.

title: South after Gettysburg: letters of Cornelia Hancock, 1863-1868.
summary: Raised a Quaker in New Jersey, she was a prominent nurse in the Civil War, setting up aid stations and hospitals at Gettysburg, the Battle of the Wilderness, the White House, and Richmond after its capture. Later she established a Quaker School for Blacks in South Carolina, described in the second half of this volume in letters not included in the earlier edition. A later selected edition has been published in 1971 by Books for Libraries Press.

title: Lady in the Navy: a personal reminiscence.
summary: She served as Yeoman (F) First Class, USNR, during World War I; later she learned to fly and as a civilian worked for the Bureau of Aeronautics. She was one of the first officers commissioned in the WAVES when it was mobilized in 1942 and was Director of the WAVES, 1946-53, when she retired. Her book documents the history of women in the U.S. Navy.

title: Yankee in gray: the Civil War memoirs of Henry E. Handerson with a selection of his wartime letters.
publisher: The Press of Western Reserve University
summary: He was raised in northeastern Ohio, but his family moved to Tennessee in 1852. His memoir, written in the 1890's, describes his life in Civil War times (1859-65), when he served as a Confederate officer. He later became a highly respected medical historian in Cleveland.

title: Father of the blues: an autobiography.
summary: Saved from a career as a clergyman by an early desire to play the trumpet and to sing with minstrel groups. Handy provides an engaging story of his lifelong career as a jazz musician, blues composer, and music publisher, interwoven with a history of blues music. This includes the reception (and plagiarism) of his most notable works, such as 'St. Louis Blues,' 'Memphis Blues,' and 'A Good Man is Hard to Find.' Handy's prose is as rhythmic and vigorous as his music.
occupations: Jazz musician, blues composer, music publisher

title: Tell him that I heard.
summary: A moving tribute to an international correspondent's dangerous, peripatetic way of life, and to the man himself, NBC newsman Welles Hangen. Married in Cairo in 1958, for the next fourteen years they lived in Lebanon, Egypt, Kuwait, Jordan, India, Germany, and Hong Kong as Welles covered revolutions, wars, invasions, and other highly charged events. Pat loved her husband and their adventuresome life. Her description of his capture and disappearance in Cambodia (1972) is especially poignant.

title: To be young, gifted and Black.
summary: A pastiche of her own words from letters, speeches, diaries, and plays, compiled by her husband, Robert Nemiroff, after she died of cancer. Her first play, A Raisin in the Sun (1959), won the New York Drama Critics Award; she was widely respected for her involvement in the Civil Rights movement as well.

title: N/A
summary: N/A

title: A Victorian in the modern world.
summary: Because he was born and brought up during the Victorian Era, Hapgood pictures the modern world 'strained through the Victorian temperament.' He views the revolutionary significance of the labor movement, political and social conditions, and standards of life and ethics as changes rooted in our democratic history.

title: Father of California wine, Agoston Haraszthy: including grape culture, wines, & wine making.
summary: A diary of travels to European wine-growing areas that describes quality and character of grapes for use in selecting cuttings to take back to California, with some attention to the culture of other fruits and nuts. The author was in large part responsible for the development of California vineyards. A biographical introduction sketches his fascinating life — a Hungarian nobleman immigrant who made and lost fortunes in various ventures.

title: A narrative of the sufferings of Massy: from Indian barbarity, giving an account of her captivity, the murder of her two children, her escape, with an infant at her breast.
volume: Narratives of North American Indian Captives, v. 42
summary: In 1791 Harbison was captured by the Indians. She had a horrifying escape and recounts the events in lurid detail.

title: The life of John Wesley Hardin: as written by himself.
summary: Notorious as a Texas gunfighter, he finally received a pardon, studied law, and briefly led a reputable life before he became involved in the saloon life of El Paso, where he was shot.

title: An Ohio school mistress: the memoirs of Irene Hardy.
summary: Hardy writes about her childhood in Ohio, her desire to be educated and later to become a teacher. She fought for women's rights, better education, and eradication of racial prejudice.

title: Skyo.
summary: Describing herself as 'an old maid school Ma'am,' a math professor retired from the University of Washington writes of her adventures in the woods of Washington where she had a cabin and many friends among the mountain folk and forest animals.

title: Through cities and prairie lands. Sketches of an American tour by Lady Duffus Hardy.
summary: A light and airy account of this British noblewoman's tour of North to New York, westward to California and back to Boston. The author passes judgment on everything she sees without reserve, from behavior of the Chinese in California to the reading of the 'Act of Independence,' as she calls it, in Boston.

title: No compromise with principle: autobiography and biography of William Hardy Harris.
summary: The long and active life of a prominent attorney in Mississippi, including his service in the Civil War, his work during Reconstruction, and his major contribution to the development of the railroad in the state.

title: malice towards none: the musings of a retired politician.
summary: An official in Michigan state government for over 25 years, Hare evaluates his experience, analyzes what he believes to be the failure of big government, and recommends several measures for reform which he urges are imperative for adjusting to the complex needs of modern society.

title: Why son I fight for a Christian America.
summary: Christian crusade leader Hargis writes about experiences influencing

title: Grace abounding.
summary: Through scripture, poetry, prayer, and autobiographical meditation, theologian Harkness praises her parents, comments with pleasure on her rural upbringing and the natural settings in which she has lived and taught theology, and voices opinions on social action, particularly the benefits of pacifism, racial integration, and the Civil Rights movement.

title: Without fear or favor: odyssey of a city manager.
summary: Harlow describes the ups-and-downs of managing various cities in Minnesota, Oregon, Florida, and elsewhere.

title: Such is life.
summary: The story of her seven-year experience as a writer-researcher for Life magazine; a vivid description of the spirited and competitive world of Time-Inc.

title: Memoirs of Thomas B. Harned, Walt Whitman's friend and literary executor.
summary: Harned's life touched on those of many political and social leaders of his time including clergymen, scholars, and writers, particularly Walt Whitman.

title: Hawk.

Y. and Cornell Medical College), Helpern focuses on the various deaths with which he had to deal as Chief Medical Examiner of New York City.

Her brief unfinished autobiography is contained in the first 65 pages of this book.

title: New dance: an unfinished autobiography.
summary: Humphrey recalls her training and early professional experiences as a dancer, providing an interesting background of her development into 'one of the half-dozen women of great vision and total dedication' who made possible the growth of American dance.

title: Hubert Humphrey: the man and his dream.
summary: This collection of Humphrey's speeches, letters, and articles reflects his career and expresses his concerns with civil rights, international interdependence, defense of Israel as a nation, desegregation, party politics, and full employment.

title: From the prairies to the mountains: memories/ especially of Illinois and Eastern Kentucky.
summary: A chatty reminiscence about the author's long career as an English teacher, full of details about people, places, and events.

title: Farther off from heaven.
summary: A writer's memories of his boyhood cluster around the death of his father in an automobile accident and the end of his childhood.

title: Evening sun turned crimson.
summary: Huncke tells his own stories of friendship, drugs, jails, hospitals, and 'hanging out,' reflecting the emergence of the hip subculture after World War II.

title: Give us this day.
summary: Hunt spent nineteen months on the Cuba Project and writes his account of the way the project was organized and why it failed.

title: Undercover: memoir of an American secret agent.
summary: A key operative in the Watergate episode, Hunt recalls his role in the OSS during the Cold War, and his involvement in various operatives, including the Bay of Pigs.

title: The Western journals of Dr. George Hunter: 1796-1805.
summary: Commissioned by Thomas Jefferson to accompany William Dunbar in exploring the Louisiana Territory, he traveled in parts of Kentucky, Louisiana, and Mississippi, recording his observations of the land, climate, Indians, and daily life.

title: Memoirs of a captivity among the Indians of North America.
summary: Orphaned and raised by Kansas and Osage tribes, he was nearly twenty when he learned to read and write. His book was published in early 1823, resulting in immediate fame as well as suspicions about the verity of his story.

title: Daughter of Zion.
summary: Daughter of a prominent Mormon family, she writes critically but lovingly of her life as a Mormon in contemporary society.

title: The generous years; remembrances of a frontier boyhood.
summary: The well-known TV commentator tells of his early years growing up on one of America's last frontiers, the prairies and towns of Montana from before World War I into the mid-1920's.

title: Impresario: a memoir.
summary: Filled with backstage anecdotes about artists in ballet, opera, and on the concert stage, the book describes the life of one of the great American impresarios.

title: S. Hurok presents: a memoir of the dance world.
summary: A narrative of dance in America and his role in organizing and promoting it in this country.

title: Anatomy of me: a wanderer in search of herself.
summary: A popular fiction writer traces her development as a writer, growing up in St. Louis, living in Greenwich Village during the Twenties, moving around New York's literary circle.

title: Sixty-one years in the school room.
summary: Rambling reminiscences of his school years, from age six to retirement in 1950, by a farm boy who became a college professor.

title: Autobiography of a plain preacher.
summary: A Methodist minister writes of the early influence of the church on his life, his call to the ministry, and his service as minister and superintendent.

title: My eyes are in my heart.
summary: A pioneer in the development of radio broadcasting, Husing's book tells of his career, illness, and spiritual growth after becoming blind.

title: My pleasures and palaces; an informal memoir of forty years in modern China.
summary: Hussey writes about his experiences as a successful architect in China and his observations of major changes in Chinese government and culture.

title: Mislaid in Hollywood.
summary: Hyams writes about personal encounters with Hollywood's greatest actors, blending stories about their private lives with his experiences.

title: Quest: an autobiography.
summary: This is the story of a physicist from a Polish ghetto who became a colleague of Albert Einstein at Princeton. His journey is marked by recurrent barriers of anti-Semitism as well as lucky breaks that provided opportunities to leave Poland just before Hitler invaded. The epilogue briefly relates his decade in Canada and his eventual return to Poland, clouded by the suspicion he would give away 'atomic secrets' which he did not possess.

title: Point of departure: an adventure in autobiography.
summary: The beginnings of a colorful, successful career are described with relish up through his stint as first managing editor of the fledgling New Yorker.

title: Top secret.
