summary: An officer in the planning group of the Chief of Staff to the Supreme Allied Commander (COSSAC) during the final two years of World War II writes of the large-scale planning, direction, and execution of the Allied victory and the lessons learned and applied.

title: The letters of Robert G. Ingersoll.
summary: These letters, arranged by subject matter and preceded by interpretive essays, show Ingersoll as a family man, humanist, orator, and lover of the arts as well as articulate agnostic. Letters about his career as a lawyer have been left for another volume.

title: The life and letters of Robert G. Ingersoll.
summary: Distinguished lawyer Robert Ingersoll's witty, principled, forthright letters to a multitude of correspondents, known (Walt Whitman, Annie Besant) and unknown, are arranged topically: patriotism, religion, literary criticism, epicureanism, birth control, capital punishment, freedom of thought, sex equality, etc. His heroes are Voltaire and Thomas Paine; his messages, humanitarianism and agnosticism: 'I thank God every day that he does not exist.'

title: Journey to Washington.
summary: Born of Japanese parents in the Territory of Hawaii, he served in Europe during World War II, receiving the Congressional Medal of Honor. Later he worked for Hawaiian statehood, served as U.S. Representative and then as U.S. Senator.

title: As I remember: recollections.
summary: Ireman recounts a joyous life in and around Ithaca and Cornell University where he lived and worked. His illustrious family had helped to settle this area. A Cornell graduate, he practiced law in Ithaca until his retirement. His love of life and music, of the natural splendors around Ithaca, and his philanthropic services are all well reported in this book.

title: A shepherd watches, a shepherd sings.
summary: He grew up in a Basque family in California, was apprenticed as a shepherd at age six. His book recalls life in a little-known ethnic group in a vanishing way of life.

title: Clifford Irving: what really happened; his untold story of the Hughes affair.
summary: Irving's bizarre story of the Hughes hoax, a fake autobiography of Howard Hughes supposedly based on tape-recorded interviews. Eventually the whole scheme was discovered and Irving was sentenced to two-and-a-half years imprisonment.

title: Crayon miscellany.
summary: This volume contains a textual study of A Tour on the Prairies and Abbotsford and Newstead Abbey, both of which record personal experiences and have a basis in Irving's journals. The former deals with a brief expedition he made of his native land after a seventeen-year absence.

title: Journals and notebooks: complete works of Washington Irving.
summary: Most of Irving's journals were written while he was traveling abroad and contain accounts of daily activities, miscellaneous notes, expense accounts, anecdotes, observations, and reminiscences. Although he was the first American writer after the Revolution to come into extended contact (over 22 years) with European culture, he makes no comparisons or penetrating analysis of the American and European character.

title: Letters.
summary: Irving was a typical representative of middle-class, nineteenth-century America whose work reflected prevalent attitudes and satisfied popular taste. His letters to friends and relatives, however, express his own ideas more forcefully and directly though with warmth and geniality. In his diplomatic role he corresponded with other officials about delicate political, social, and economic issues.

title: Letters from Sunnyside and Spain.
summary: This book consists of nine letters Irving wrote to his sister and nieces while living at Sunnyside, his Tarrytown, New York, home, 1840-1841, and nine written 1842-1845 from Spain, where he was the American minister. They deal primarily with his observations of social events he attended — receptions, parties, a coronation, parades — and sketches of some of the participants.

title: I'll see you in court.
summary: Isaac recounts a number of his most memorable cases as a trial lawyer, including an investigation and defense of Sirhan Sirhan for client Teddy Charach, who wanted to prove that a 'second gun' had killed Bobby Kennedy. Isaac's legal acumen was often supported by the intuitive hunches of his tempestuous second wife, Roena.

title: Autobiography of Asa Brainerd Isham, M.D.
summary: Isham grew up in Ohio and worked briefly as a printer's devil and as a reporter before enlisting in the Seventh Michigan Cavalry of the Union Army. Much of the book deals with his Civil War experiences, including being wounded at Haymarket, Virginia, and taken prisoner at Richmond. After the war he became a physician, taught at the Cincinnati College of Medicine and Surgery, and aided in the development of a unified medical education program for Cincinnati.

title: Christopher and his kind: 1929-1939.
summary: Writing of himself in the third person, Isherwood blithely describes a decade of his life and the 'boys' he loved in that time.

title: Lions and shadows: an education in the twenties.
summary: Playwright Isherwood writes of his experiences in and loathing of British boarding schools and universities, raging 'against the dictatorship of [his] elders.' He expresses enthusiasms he is 'shy of confessing to, because they are so passionate' and writes of his anxieties and the roles he plays.

title: My guru and his disciple.
summary: Isherwood describes how his friendship with a Hindu monk from 1939 to 1976 influenced his life in terms of religion, friendship, and self-awareness. Diary entries are interspersed; Isherwood's reminiscences are more factual than spiritual.

title: Forty years of sound and forty years of silence: an autobiography.
summary: Israelsen, a devout Mormon, is proud of his 59-year marriage, four children, and various homes in Logan, Utah, where he taught irrigation engineering at Utah State University. Although the book exhibits considerable stylistic naivete, Israelsen tells movingly of his deafness at forty from an illness and of his 'soundless' but highly successful career — including testifying at many court trials.

title: Wayfaring stranger.
summary: Written at the hard age of 30, Ives' travels led to his career as a writer and singer of modern ballads.

title: Memos.
summary: These memos by a distinguished composer were dictated to a secretary or jotted down to form an autobiographical scrapbook of reminiscences demonstrating to derogatory critics that they did not know what they were talking about and supplying information to Ives enthusiasts. Numerous appendixes include letters and other information.

title: Steamboat up the Colorado: from the journal of Lieutenant Joseph Christmas Ives, United States Topographical Engineers, 1857-1858.
summary: In 1857 Ives, a U.S. Army engineer, was sent by the War Department to explore the Colorado River to find out how far north it could be navigated and to learn whether, near Needles, California, it could be linked with a Mormon road to Los Angeles. His return route, 320 miles to Ft. Defiance, was successfully made by mule train, though threatened by Indians and drought.

title: Link with the past.
summary: The achievements of a prominent oral and plastic surgeon at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: The papers of Andrew Jackson.
summary: This is a well-edited collection of business papers and letters to and from Jackson during the years when he was successively a schoolteacher, lawyer, United States representative, senator from Tennessee, and superior court judge. They reveal his role in helping his country to gain political independence from Great Britain, to become a republic and to expand westward. The letters reveal his developing leadership, loyalty, honesty, and sometimes irascible pride.

title: Early stages.
summary: Anne Jackson describes her childhood in rural areas outside of Pittsburgh, where her freethinking Croatian immigrant father and Irish Catholic mother led an unconventional, sometimes hand-to-mouth existence. After their move to Brooklyn, Anne metamorphosed into a 'show-off and a hellion,' stealing, flirting, and even threatening suicide to pursue her favorite pastime, watching movies. Her native talent led her to acting classes; her mother's mental illness ended her childhood.

title: Memories and reveries: a physician's philosophical review of eight decades.
summary: Jackson's chapters follow his train of thought rather than chronology, as informal prose intermingles anecdotes of rural boyhood activities such as hunting and fishing with his views on 'time,' 'fate and destiny,' 'egocentricity,' and religious faith. He barely alludes to his career as a physician.

title: Blood in my eye.
summary: Finished just a week before he was shot and killed inside San Quentin Prison in 1971, this book expresses Jackson's rebellion against imprisonment and the conditions that lead to it. In prison he became committed to the ideas of Marx, Lenin, and Mao and to the idea of Black revolution, which he discusses here.

title: Soledad brother; the prison letters of George Jackson.
summary: In the first letter of this collection, the author unashamedly sketches his double life — one part of him at home in a loving family, the other part in the streets. It is the second life, the life in the streets that leads to Soledad prison and a charge of murder. In the letters that follow expressing his anger and frustration and chronicling prison abuse, Jackson does not look for excuses, but the finger he points is directed at what he sees as a racist society in which Black men and women must rebel or be destroyed.

title: There's nothing I own that I want.
summary: A Black woman's story of her struggle to escape the ghetto: her love for her mother whom she saw murdered when she was six, her pregnancy and marriage at sixteen, the mental illness of her oldest daughter, and her dogged sense of survival.

title: Memoir of James Jackson, Jr., M.D., with extracts from his letters to his father, and medical cases, collected by him.
summary: This book includes a memoir written by his father, followed by James Jackson's letters (pp. 81-194) and his observations on various medical cases. The letters were written from Paris (1831-33) where he was studying medicine.

title: Running for Jesus.
summary: Jackson straightforwardly recounts how her major concerns, Christianity and running, have been inextricably intertwined from early childhood. She won a gold medal at the Mexico City Olympic Games in 1968, but ran the worst race of her life in an attempted comeback at the Montreal Olympic Games in 1976. For a number of years after graduation from Tennessee State University, Jackson worked for the Salvation Army in Cleveland, her hometown, but always spent considerable time promoting the gospel.

title: Movin' on up.
summary: The warm story of a simple, loving woman who spreads the joy of her faith through her gospel singing. Through hard times, poverty, and prejudice she has faced the world with good humor, determination, and religious dedication.

title: Life among the savages.
summary: The book describes the move a writer and her husband make to Vermont, the birth of her third child, and her experiences as a housewife and mother to three young children.

title: Raising demons.
summary: A novelist known for her fiction on themes of horror and paranoia writes of her more cheerful side — pets, kids, Little League baseball, and being a housewife.

title: Autobiography of Ulys Jackson, M.D.
summary: After much effort Jackson graduated from the University of Arkansas School of Medicine and became a surgeon in Arkansas. In World War II he served in North Africa and India and was among the 500 survivors of the sinking of the H.M.T. Rohna, in which over 1000 troops were drowned. After the war he returned to Arkansas as a physician and coroner.

title: The diaries of William Henry Jackson: frontier photographer; to California and return, 1866-67; and with Hayden Surveys to the Central Rockies, 1873, and to the Utes and Cliff Dwellings, 1874.
summary: During his long and productive life, he was well-known for his photographs and murals of Western frontier life. Three of his numerous diaries of Western exploration are included here. In addition to paintings, photographs, and diaries left to libraries in New York and Colorado, forty thousand glass negatives were left to the State Historical Society of Colorado.

title: Professor's odyssey: a portrait of a profession.
summary: A retired professor of sociology reflects on his fifty-year career working in nine colleges and universities. He compares large and small colleges, pre- and post-war teaching, and administrative and academic tasks.

title: Incidents in the life of a slave girl.
summary: Born a slave, she remained in the South until she was 27 before escaping to the North. This story of the hardships, indignities, and abuses she suffered was written 'to arouse the women of the North [and] ... to expose their condition.'

title: Epigramus of an ignoramus: the life of Michel Jacobs. Illustrated by Michel Jacobs.
summary: Jacobs, who was a lieutenant colonel in World War I, may have found his true vocation in military service, but he regards painting (mostly stereotyped portraits) as his true love.

title: Is Curly Jewish?: A political self-portrait illuminating three turbulent decades of social revolt, 1935-1965.
summary: Jacobs attempts to describe the period 1935 to 1965 from the point of view of a radical and 'to discover whether that view is related to how I feel about being a Jew.'

title: Diary of a San Diego girl, 1856.
summary: Written during the year before her marriage, the diary depicts a young woman's courtship in the context of middle-class life in the then small, rustic town of San Diego.

title: Alice James, her brothers — her journal.
summary: The journal describes her life in England, 1884-92, where she had moved for reasons of health. Her entries are caustic and tender, but always acute.

title: The diary of Alice James.
summary: Long unpublished at her brother Henry's insistence, this diary records her sickroom world during the final months of her life.

title: Chief of the Pomos: life story of Allen James.
summary: An account of his life up to 1933 which describes the traditions of his tribe in order to preserve them.

title: Years of discontent: Doctor Frank L. James in Arkansas, 1877-1878.
summary: A candid account of medical practice in backwater Osceola, Arkansas.

title: Autobiography.
summary: A collection of works edited in one volume on the fortieth anniversary of his death.

title: Henry James and H.G. Wells: a record of their friendship, their debate on the art of fiction, and their quarrel.
summary: Their letters (1895-1915) contain a debate about art as individual expression and art as social welfare.

title: Henry James and Robert Louis Stevenson: a record of friendship and criticism.
summary: All surviving correspondence between James and Stevenson (1884-1894).

title: Letters.
summary: A selection of letters intended to show the evolution in a personal literary form by one of the masters of the art.

title: Letters to A.C. Benson and Auguste Monod: now first published.
summary: James's correspondence with poet Arthur Christopher Benson and Auguste Monod.

title: Notebooks of Henry James.
summary: Notebooks recording his work in progress during thirty years revealing his ideas and approach to technical problems.

title: The selected letters of Henry James.
summary: A selection of 120 letters intended to provide a guide to the varied types of letters written by an outstanding American author.

title: Letters from a Civil War soldier.
summary: These letters focus mostly on the food and living conditions during the Civil War, reflecting life as a Confederate soldier.

title: Selected letters of John Garland James to Paul Hamilton Hayne and Mary Middleton Michel Hayne.
summary: These letters relate primarily to some books of poetry and oratory he was developing, revealing a growing friendship.

title: Three years among the Indians and Mexicans.
summary: The perils of life on the frontier amid savages and grizzly bears.

title: Hanging rattling: an autobiography.
summary: James has lived most of his life in the back country of Idaho as a rancher, guide, packer, trapper, and horse raiser.

title: Letters of William James and Theodore Flournoy.
summary: For twenty years the American and the Swiss psychologist corresponded, sharing professional interests and news.

title: Selected letters.
summary: A selection reflecting the charm and brilliance in James's correspondence, including many of his famous contemporaries.

title: An historian's world: selections from the correspondence of John Franklin Jameson.
summary: A selection from the correspondence of a prominent historian, founder of the American Historical Association.

title: And across big seas.
summary: Grandmother's tale for her grandchildren about childhood in Braila, Rumania, and immigration to America.

title: Life and adventures in California of Don Augustin Janssens 1834-1856.
summary: Born in Belgium, migrated to southern California at seventeen, where he became a prominent rancher and businessman.

title: The life of the Reverend Devereux Jarratt in his letters to Rev. John Coleman.
publisher: Arno Press & The New York Times
summary: Written as a series of letters, Jarratt's autobiography describes his youth, beliefs, church work, and religious questions.

title: I'm mad as hell: the exclusive story of the tax revolt and its leader.
summary: This spirited autobiography chronicles Jarvis's campaign to convince California to adopt his tax-cut proposal — Proposition 13.

title: A time to remember: growing up in New York before the Great War.
summary: Jastrow nostalgically recalls immigrant life in New York City, 1905-1917.

title: Confession and avoidance: a memoir.
summary: Jaworski discusses significant criminal cases he participated in as prosecutor and defense attorney, including Nazi war criminals at Nuremberg.

title: The right and the power: the prosecution of Watergate.
summary: Jaworski describes the Watergate investigation and the prosecution that led to the convictions of officials in the Nixon administration.

title: Correspondence and public papers.
summary: This edition reprints the earlier selection of Jay's important personal and semi-official letters.
occupations: Chief Justice, Member of Continental Congress

title: The selected letters of Robinson Jeffers: 1897-1962.
summary: Jeffers' letters reflect on his work, the art of poetry, events, and friendship.

title: Memoirs of a Monticello slave, as dictated to Charles Campbell in the 1840's by Isaac, one of Thomas Jefferson's slaves.
publisher: University of Virginia Press for the Tracy W. McGregor Library
summary: Recollections by Isaac, a slave at Monticello, recorded during an interview.

title: The autobiography of Joseph Jefferson.
summary: Jefferson, an actor, toured the American South, West, and Mexico, introducing drama to the Western Hemisphere.

title: The autobiography of Thomas Jefferson.
summary: Written at 77, recalls events of 1776 and significant political career moments.

title: an introduction by Saul K. Padover
summary: A selection of 180 letters intended to portray his character and extensive range of interests.

title: The Jefferson-Dunglison letters.
summary: Letters between Jefferson and his physician concern Jefferson's health but primarily deal with matters related to the Medical School of the University of Virginia.

title: The reminiscences of John B. Jervis, engineer of the Old Croton.
summary: The leading consulting engineer of the antebellum era, Jervis was chief engineer for the Delaware and Hudson Canal project and significantly contributed to multiple engineering projects.

title: Letters of Thomas Jefferson.
summary: This selection covers such topics as The Rights of Man, Alien and Sedition Laws, Foreign Wars and Treaties, Slavery and the Missouri Question.

title: The papers of Thomas Jefferson.
summary: This edition aims to present Jefferson's writings and actions as completely as possible, particularly pertaining to the early growth of the Republic.

title: To the boys and girls: being the delightful, little-known letters of Thomas Jefferson to and from his children and grandchildren.
summary: Jefferson's letters to his daughters and grandchildren filled with advice and familial insight create a picture of his life.

title: An American at large.
summary: Jelke reflects on his wealth, travels, and the differences among races and cultures.

title: Forty years on the force, 1932-1972; Herbert Jenkins reminisces on his career with the Atlanta police department.
publisher: Center for Research in Social Change, Emory University
summary: The book reflects on Jenkins's career with the Atlanta Police Department and includes insights on race relations and integration.

title: Terror of Tellico Plains: the memoirs of Ray H. Jenkins.
summary: Jenkins recounts his life and legal career with humor, focusing on cases and personal experiences.

title: And . . . I'll throw in the socks; the memoirs of a Kentucky storekeeper.
summary: Jenkins reflects on his life as a country storekeeper, bringing style and elegance to his rural community.

title: I am Chrystie.
summary: An autobiography by Chrystie Jenner detailing her identity and desire for independence.

title: This way, miss.
summary: An entertainer discusses the entertainment profession in Hollywood, various personalities he has known, and his Jewish faith.

title: The fishbasket papers: the diaries, 1768-1823, of Bradbury Jewell, Esquire.
summary: The diaries record the life of an ordinary man prominent in his day, with historical context supplied by the editor.

title: An American engineer in Afghanistan: from the letters and notes of A.C. Jewett.
summary: Jewett notes experiences during eight years in Afghanistan while supervising a hydro-electric plant installation.

title: Letters.
summary: Contains 142 letters, documenting Jewett's development as a writer.

title: Letters of Sarah Orne Jewett now in the Colby College Library.
summary: A small collection of letters showing Jewett's development as a writer.

title: Narrative of the adventures of John R. Jewitt: only survivor of the crew of the ship Boston, during a captivity of nearly three years among the savages of Nootka Sound.
summary: Jewitt recounts his captivity and experiences with an Eskimo tribe.

title: Pioneer's progress: an autobiography.
summary: An economist and educator recalls his childhood, youth, and college career in Nebraska during the late-nineteenth century.

title: The papers of Andrew Johnson.
summary: This volume presents the writings of Andrew Johnson, reflecting on his presidency and political career.

title: Smuggled into paradise: saga of an immigrant youth.
summary: Johnson recounts his journey from Sweden to America and his experiences as an immigrant.

title: A soldier's life: the Civil War experiences of Ben C. Johnson.
publisher: School of Graduate Studies/Western Michigan University Press
summary: Johnson details his experiences in the Civil War as part of the Sixth Regiment, Michigan Infantry.

title: White House diary.
summary: The diary presents an honest picture of Lady Bird Johnson's experiences during her husband's presidency.

title: Leaves from a doctor's diary.
summary: The book publishes excerpts from Dr. Johnson's diary concerning her practice of obstetrics and gynecology.

title: Autobiography of a centenarian.
summary: Johnson recounts his life, family, education, and long career in law.

title: The Tumbleweeds: somersaulting up and out of the city streets.
summary: Johnson rehabilitates five youths in a Puerto Rican neighborhood and shares insights on social mobility.

title: Diplomatic memoirs: serious and frivolous.
summary: Recollections of 35 years in the U.S. Diplomatic Service.

title: Jack Johnson is a dandy: an autobiography.
summary: Johnson examines his boxing career and provides a detailed account of significant events in his life.

title: Along this way: the autobiography of James Weldon Johnson.
summary: Johnson, a man of varied talents, shares his experiences across many fields, advocating for minority rights.
occupations: Teacher, Editor, Journalist, Lawyer, Songwriter, Principal, Author, Poet, U.S. Consul

title: The story of a county pastor.
summary: The story chronicles Father Johnson's 31 years as a pastor in Hollywood, Maryland.

title: Seven houses; a memoir of time and places.
summary: Stories from her life are organized around the seven houses her family lived in, evoking vivid memories.

title: Vantage point; perspectives of the presidency 1963-1969.
summary: Johnson reflects on significant problems and accomplishments during his presidency.

title: My brother Lyndon.
summary: Johnson discusses his brother Lyndon's political career with a critical perspective.

title: Samuel Johnson, president of King's College, his career and writing.
summary: Volume I contains documents related to Samuel Johnson's career, including his autobiography and significant letters.

title: Autobiography.
summary: Johnson emphasizes his impoverished childhood and career in law in his autobiography.

title: From the St. Croix to the Potomac: reflections of a bureaucrat.
publisher: Big Sky Books, Montana State University
summary: Hutchinson reflects on his career in the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

title: My story.
summary: Elected mayor of Cleveland in 1901, Johnson brought his resourcefulness and his training in big business to bear on city government. He applied the merit system to city departments, instituted a model building code, built public bathhouses, laid out parks, and increased the city's assets.

title: Work is my play.
summary: He was born a Mississippi sharecropper. In 1953 he and Kemmons Wilson started the first national motel chain, Holiday Inn. In 1968 he received the Horatio Alger Award. His book is a version of that great American myth.

title: William Johnson's Natchez: the ante-bellum diary of a free Negro.
summary: Johnson's diary spans 1835-51, when he was murdered in a dispute over land ownership. This narrative provides an extensive account of his barbering business and farming in Natchez and dispels the myth of the totally polarized Mississippi society of rich planters and poor slaves.

title: Overland to California: by a member of the wagon train first to enter California in the memorable year of 1849.
summary: His party originated in Pittsburgh, traveled by steamer to Independence, Missouri, and after six weeks preparing for the journey, started on the Overland Trail. Based on his diary, the narrative was written over forty years later.

title: When God says 'no': faith's starting point.
summary: A woman Congregational minister in Illinois discusses her spiritual struggles as well as her struggle against sexual prejudice in her profession.

title: Double trouble: the autobiography of the Jones Twins.
summary: A first person plural narrative by twin photographers, their training in the Marines, and their experience in the Korean War.

title: Cleon.
summary: After a brief description of his boyhood in a small Alabama town, Jones writes of his career in baseball, focusing on the 1969 World Series win by the New York Mets.

title: A song of ascents: a spiritual autobiography.
summary: Jones, a Methodist evangelist, writes an eloquent and detailed spiritual autobiography explaining his views on God. The book has many biblical references but little personal information.

title: Diary of Henry Boswell Jones of Brownsburg (1842-1871).
summary: Jones recorded many details of thirty years' farm life including sales, plantings, droughts, and children's births.

title: Fifty fabulous years: 1900-1950: a personal review.
summary: Radio news analyst describes world travel, interviews with national leaders, and opinions on current affairs in recorded interviews with his son, which Kaltenborn edited and revised.

title: My life, my theatre.
summary: Her mother was known as the Mother of Yiddish Theater; she herself soon followed in the theatrical footsteps traveling and acting throughout Europe. She and her husband directed the nationalized Yiddish State Theater in Poland after World War II and she continued acting on the stage and in films, emigrating from Poland when anti-Zionist hatred became unbearable after the Six-Day War.

title: Hollywood: stars and starlets, tycoons and fleshpeddlers, movie makers and moneymakers, frauds and geniuses, hopefuls and has-beens, great lovers and sex symbols.
summary: In 1937 he was hired by Samuel Goldwyn to learn the movie business. His book recalls almost forty years among the personalities of film and theater. In addition to many of the famous, there are stories of figures lesser known or past their prime, such as Mrs. Patrick Campbell.

title: But look, the morn: the story of a childhood.
summary: An excellent recollection of a writer's boyhood in Webster City, Iowa, written without nostalgia but depicting the character and values of middle America in the early twentieth century.

title: I married a prince: a Cinderella story from Hawaii.
summary: After fifteen years of worldwide traveling and hiking with a friend (in Hawaii, Japan, China, and Iraq), she settled in Hawaii to teach school until her retirement in 1962. In 1935 she married a Hawaiian prince, David Kaapuawao Kamehameha, and lived in a grass house for most of their marriage until his death in 1971.

title: Main Street lawyer.
summary: A pleasant reminiscence that focuses on Karcher's life-long relationship with his hometown, Sayreville, New Jersey. There he grew up, studied law, became a practicing lawyer and, for twenty years, magistrate judge. His love for the law, the town, his family, and 'The American Heritage' is pervasive.

title: Memoirs of an American prima donna. Illustrated.
summary: A confident, spirited account of Kellogg's youth and operatic career, 1860-1880. She writes of many wealthy and famous figures she met and describes operatic tours to Europe and Russia singing for the crowned heads of Europe.

title: Doctor at all hours; the private journal of a small-town doctor's varied life 1886-1909.
summary: A turn-of-the-century family G.P. with a large rural practice in upstate New York writes of his patients, family, and his avocational interests, including local history, nature observations, mountain climbing, collecting china and Indian relics, and archaeology.

title: M.K. Kellogg's Texas journal, 1872. Illustrated.
summary: A journal kept by a non-Texan who was employed as an artist on the Texas Land and Copper Association Expedition of 1872. Although his sketches have not been found, the journal describes vividly the progress of a mineral expedition, largely unsuccessful, across northern Texas.

title: Clown.
summary: After his boyhood on a Missouri farm, he joined a circus and later became one of the most famous clowns in circus history. Here, his story of Willie the Tramp.

title: "Yellowstone Kelly": the memoirs of Luther S. Kelly.
summary: The life story of a prominent Indian Scout on the western frontier.

title: Of me I sing: an informal autobiography.
summary: Kelly, a comic actor and monologist, describes his travels, triumphs, and tribulations on the vaudeville circuit in the Midwest and East. As "The Virginia Judge," Kelly presided over comic mock trials on and off stage, including some involving retired prizefighter Jim Jeffries.

title: Flute solo: reflections of a Trappist hermit.
summary: Kelty writes introspectively of his life as a priest and his decision to become a Trappist hermit in New Guinea. He dwells at length on his love for solitude and on his constant quest for a complete spiritual union with God.

title: It's different at Dartmouth: a memoir. Illustrated.
summary: The wife of Dartmouth College's thirteenth president writes of the frustration and satisfaction of her "profession." Warm, funny, and sometimes irreverent, Mrs. Kemeny describes an ill-defined, thankless job as she portrays an institution, its personable president, and her life with both.

title: Autobiography of Amos Kendall.
summary: The author gives an extensive account of his family life and career affairs in public life as selected by his editor from the mass of written material Kendall produced.

title: Never let weather interfere.
summary: Steeped in the traditions of the American dream, the book describes the life of a lawyer in a family of lawyers, confident of achievement, independence, and success.

title: Mannequin; my life as a model.
summary: The ups and downs of a modeling career make it plain that a model's life is not all glitter and glamour, but involves hard work and determination. Despite the fact that photographs are basic to her career, the book does not contain pictures.

title: Memoirs: 1925-1950.
summary: After a brief summary of his youth, Kennan devotes his memoirs to his training in Foreign Service School for service in Russia and his subsequent service abroad in Moscow, Prague, Germany, and Portugal. After World War II he worked at the National War College, on the State Department Planning Staff and with various policy-making functions in Washington until his retirement from government service in 1950.

title: Memoirs: 1950-1963.
summary: Based on his later years of government service as Ambassador to Moscow and to Yugoslavia, this volume continues Kennan's description of the evolution of his philosophy of public affairs and, particularly, foreign affairs.

title: Color me Flo: my hard life and good times.
summary: A Black lawyer and political activist describes her family, education, and social philosophy. Often outrageously blunt, she was a founding member of NOW, but left it in 1971 to form the Feminist Party which backed Shirley Chisholm for President.

title: Times to remember. Illustrated.
summary: A remarkable history of three generations, written to reveal them "in their settings, their humanity, their natures, and destinies," by the woman who has often appeared to be the power behind the throne of this modern American "royal" family.

title: Shotter. Illustrated.
summary: A Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer assesses the risks and rewards of photojournalism. He discusses his successful career as apprentice in Oregon, bureau reporter covering Spiro Agnew's downfall and Robert Kennedy's final days, UPI's Saigon Bureau chief photographer at 24, and President Ford's personal photographer at 27.

title: What I am pleased to call my education.
summary: Kent's purpose in writing is to record the events of his life and how they fitted him for his career working in museums and libraries — Norwich Free Academy, Slater Memorial Museum, The Grolier Club, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York. A bibliography of his writing and editing is appended.

title: Mrs. Appleyard and I. Illustrated.
summary: Mrs. Kent wrote about a dozen children's books and several for adults featuring a Mrs. Appleyard, a thinly disguised projection of her own character and life in small-town New England. She writes fondly of the simpler life and values of her earlier years.

title: It's me, O Lord: the autobiography of Rockwell Kent.
summary: A multi-faceted artist whose talents led him to careers as a painter, writer, explorer, illustrator, farmer, sailor, book designer, architect, orator, lithographer, wood engraver, and political figure tells the story of his life from birth to marriages and his travels and trials (literal and figurative). He describes the places he has been (New York, Newfoundland, Virginia, etc.) and his political work which included Spanish Civil War activities.

title: Of men and mountains: being an account of the European travels of the author and his wife, Sally, following their release from continental imprisonment.
summary: From 1950 to 1958, Kent was confined to the United States by refusal of the State Department to issue a passport because of his Communist sympathies. Vindicated by the Supreme Court in 1958, Kent and his wife traveled to Ireland, Switzerland, and spent several weeks in Russia, where he extolled the joys of the Communist political state and the beauties of the countryside.

title: Great green; a loose memoir of merchant marine life in the middle of the twentieth century with examples of true experience being turned into fiction.
summary: Kentfield reminisces about his adventures as a sailor on merchant ships and tankers. He transformed some of his experiences into fiction; after automation took over many shipboard jobs, he went ashore permanently. The appendix includes samples of his fiction, first published in The New Yorker and Harper's Bazaar.

title: Worldview: the autobiography of a social studies teacher and Quaker.
summary: He reflects on a lifetime of learning and teaching which was dominated by three main concerns: a desire to improve social studies instruction, an interest in international education, and the revitalization of the Religious Society of Friends.

title: Burned to life. As told to Bruce A. Darnall and Mike Christopulos.
summary: Kenyon, a born-again Christian after being badly burned in the 1965 Langhorne 100 US AC championship race, exhibits his resilience, religious faith, and devotion to auto-racing in this book filled with frightening details of wrecks. He was once run over in the Indy 500 while trying to get out of his wrecked car. Midget-car racing, of which he is the four-time U.S. champion, is of particular interest to him.

title: Campfires rekindled: a forester recalls life in the Maine woods of the Twenties. Illustrated.
summary: Kephart, a forester for lumber companies in Maine in the 1920's, before logging became mechanized, describes his expeditions along northern Maine's Allegash and Penobscot rivers, canoeing, camping, hunting, fishing, and scouting the woods for suitable stands of timber for logging.

title: William Allison Kepner: teacher, scientist, philosopher.
summary: A revered professor of biology at the University of Virginia for over forty years, he wrote his life story at his students' request, emphasizing his developing curiosity and scientific education.

title: How thin the veil: a newspaperman's story of his own mental crack-up and recovery.
summary: The story of 45 days in a mental institution after his attempted suicide.

title: Lonesome traveller.
summary: A guru of literature and lifestyle in the 1950's, he describes his book as "a mishmosh of life as lived by an independent educated penniless rake going anywhere."

title: Satori in Paris.
summary: Kerouac, searching for his ancestral roots in Paris, experiences satori, "sudden illumination," in retrospective contemplation of his ten-day trip (c. 1965). The book, written in Kerouac's typically impressionistic, disjunctive mixture of slang and literary allusions, validates Kerouac's self-description as: "this rage and rake and rack of lacks, this 'trunk of humours' as Shakespeare said of Falstaff, this false staff... this fear-of-death tumor, with tumescences in the bathroom . . . this farceur jokester at art galleries in New York and whimperer at police stations and over longdistance telephones . . ."

title: Knife is not enough. Illustrated.
summary: As a young surgeon, Kessler began to be concerned with the major issues of post-operative rehabilitation. Ultimately he spent fifty years on this enterprise, attaining international recognition for his work and special gratification from the founding of the Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation in West Orange, New Jersey.

title: Recollections of Colonel Retread, USAAF 1942-1945.
summary: Ketchum, a colonel in the U.S. Army Air Force, 1942-1945, has collected and privately printed the letters he wrote to his wife about his experiences. They contain detailed interpretations of personnel and military strategy he observed during his duty in New Jersey, the Middle East, and Europe, and are punctuated by accounts of occasional meetings with his son David, also in the service.

title: Scarlett O'Hara's younger sister: my lively life in and out of Hollywood. Illustrated.
summary: Pampered by Cecil B. DeMille and cast as Scarlett O'Hara's younger sister Suellen, Keyes achieved movie stardom in the 1930's. She recounts a dramatic life of marriages, divorces, and Hollywood life.

title: All flags flying: reminiscences of Frances Parkinson Keyes.
summary: This volume covers 1904-1931, the early years of her marriage and career as a novelist and journalist. Because her husband was a U.S. Senator from New Hampshire, her time was filled with social obligations; she also published "Letters from a Senator's Wife" in Good Housekeeping for fourteen years, which started her writing career.

title: The cost of a best seller.
summary: Description of the difficulty of writing, particularly in acquiring authentic backgrounds for her fiction by an author who perseveres despite frequent physical illnesses, achieves fame, and is sustained by her faith in prayer and her dedication to the global human family.

title: Roses in December.
summary: Reflections of her New England childhood in a prominent, aristocratic family, of nineteenth-century elegance and charm, of her poignant struggle to become a writer in spite of her family's wishes, of her brilliant father's untimely death when she was two, and her early devotion and engagement to Harry Keyes, a family friend more than twice her age.

title: Not under oath: recollections and reflections.
summary: Raconteur, naturalist, newspaper man, sportswriter, and scholar, Kieran is also well known as one of the regular panel members on radio's "Information Please," a high-speed genial war of wits. His autobiography reveals his own vivacity and warmth, his love of nature, and his regard for humanity.

title: Inside the endless house: art, people and architecture: a journal.
summary: This personal journal covering 1956 to 1964 touches on the whole range of the author's artistic and intellectual activity, his accounts of travel in Italy and Brazil, descriptions of people and events, and his creation of the Shrine of the Book, the sanctuary for the Dead Sea scrolls.

title: Tell me, Rabbi.
summary: Rabbi Kertzer, a descendant of Sholom Aleichem, writes humorous anecdotes with pungent messages. Kertzer tells of his boyhood in frozen Cochrane, Ontario, but focuses on various aspects of Jewish life, including weddings, Bar Mitzvahs, circumcisions, keeping kosher, Israel, education, and family life.

title: The Kikuchi diary: chronicle from an American concentration camp: the Tanforan journals of Charles Kikuchi. Illustrated.
summary: A Nisei relocated during World War II, Kikuchi recorded events in the camp, his psychological adjustments, and the ambivalence typical of his ethnic group.

title: My life, love, and limericks; an autobiography in verse.
summary: Known principally as the author of Arsenic and Old Lace and other Broadway plays, Kesselring also wrote short stories and sketches, directed and acted in amateur theatricals, and was a singer. His poems trace the progress of his life.

title: Sputnik, scientists, and Eisenhower: a memoir of the First Special Assistant to the President for Science and Technology. Illustrated.
summary: Eisenhower's Special Assistant for Science and Technology articulately discusses America's scientific efforts to surpass Russia in the space race that began in 1957 when the Soviets orbited Sputnik I and continued into the Kennedy administration. Killian also provides a history of the President's scientific advisers.

title: I remember. Foreword by Senator Ralph K. Flanders.
summary: The author, an engineer and educator, looks back at his 87 years and particularly recalls the various jobs he held as well as his close association with Cornell University.

title: Forty plus and fancy free.
summary: In some ways this seems strictly a travel book, but it reflects Kimbrough's style of life and writing, her humor, and her sense of adventure as she describes a European tour with three other grandmothers.

title: The innocents from Indiana.
summary: Humorous account of Emily (11 yrs.) and her brother (4 yrs.) moving from Muncie, Indiana, to Chicago. Good description of family and school experience.

title: It gives me great pleasure.
summary: Three years of lecture tours throughout the country provide many humorous episodes of mishaps, pitfalls, and amusing confusion.

title: May this house be safe from tigers.
summary: His second autobiographical work depends again on humorous anecdotes but focuses more on affectionate recollections of individuals, prominent and unknown, who were significant to his work as a journalist-illustrator.

title: Mine enemy grows older.
summary: A humorous, almost impersonal narrative with moments of emotional depth in which a prominent journalist-illustrator describes his career with Henry Luce, Eugene O'Neill, and others, and, in a subordinate way, his recovery from drug addiction.

title: Billie Jean.
summary: With few references to her personal life, she describes her development as a tennis star and her fight for equality for women athletes.

title: This was ever in my dream.
summary: After her husband's death, she acquired an acre of rural Pennsylvania and gradually converted it to a beautiful garden and cultivated woods surrounding the house she built there.

title: My life with Martin Luther King, Jr.
summary: The story of the remarkable King family, who with faith and courage were heroic in their devotion to justice.

title: Transformations: the Humphrey-Weidman era: a memoir.
summary: Interwoven with this well-written story of four figures of modern dance in America, King provides vivid portraits of the major dancers of the 1930's and interprets the dynamics of the dance climate during this artistically exciting time.

title: Fleet Admiral King: naval record.
summary: This autobiography mainly deals with King's part in World War I and II and his tours of command in between.

title: Main line: fifty years of railroading with the Southern Pacific.
summary: A good narrative of railroad history, from the rough and primitive days in the 1890's through World War II, by a man who began as a telegraph operator and later became a railroad executive.

title: Wranglin' the past: reminiscences of Frank M. King.
summary: The colorful story of a cowboy's life in the Southwest during the last quarter of the nineteenth century includes anecdotes about Billy the Kid and other famous gunfighters but deals primarily with the difficulties of common everyday life.

title: Doctor on a bicycle.
summary: King went straight from high school to medical school, became a general practitioner at 21 and soon established a large practice on Long Island by being the first to arrive at crisis cases (by bicycle, no less). He writes of colorful cases throughout his sixty-year practice and lovingly of the sea.

title: Memories of a Southern woman of letters.
summary: Born into a prominent New Orleans family, King writes about her experiences before and after the Civil War. As in her novels and stories, her major focus is on the development of women in Louisiana and their attempts to preserve social amenities in a climate of disruption.

title: Box man; a professional thief's journey.
summary: For the better part of fifty years, King was a professional thief specializing in safe-cracking. He tells the story of how he became a thief, his time spent in Folsom and San Quentin prisons, and his ultimate decision to 'go straight.'

title: Memoir of an Oklahoma jurist.
summary: He recalls his experience as a soldier in World War I, travel to tourist sites in the U.S. such as Mt. Rushmore, but very little about life in early Oklahoma.

title: ... And other dirty stories.
summary: A contributor of articles and essays to various periodicals has collected some of them for this book which captures the flavor of his life.

title: Confessions of a white racist.
summary: The author, a writer and journalist, traces his steps from boyhood to manhood in order to understand for himself the insanities of racial prejudice and his own involvement in racism as a white growing up among whites.

title: Daddy King: an autobiography.
summary: Born of a poor Southern farming family, King, who witnessed lynchings and beatings as a youth, became a country preacher and laborer.

title: House of a thousand babies: experiences of an American woman physician in China (1922-1940).
summary: A lucid, alternately amusing and suspenseful account of King's experiences as a physician-obstetrician at the Margaret Williamson Hospital in Shanghai.

title: John Martin: entries from an early diary.
summary: Kirstein's fragmentary diary entries cover the summer of 1933, spent largely in Paris learning his craft. He was Director of the American Ballet, which later became the New York City Ballet.

title: The woman warrior: memoirs of a girlhood among ghosts.
summary: She sees her life in the ghosts of female figures from her Chinese family history, in the clash of two cultures growing up in San Francisco's Chinatown.

title: The autobiography of David Kinley.
summary: Memoirs of a college professor of economics who relinquished teaching and research for administrative work and led the growth of the University of Illinois for forty years until his retirement in 1930.

title: I flew a camel.
summary: A nostalgic look at the dramatic days of World War I and the adventuresome fliers who manned single-seater planes for the RAF in air battles with the Red Baron and his countrymen.

title: Kinney journals: Boston to the Sandwich Islands, 1847-1848.
summary: Henry Kinney and his bride Louisa sailed from Boston, November 3, 1847, and arrived in Hawaii, February 26, 1848, to become missionaries.

title: I wonder why?
summary: With urbane wit Kirby relates the highlights of a long, vigorous life as a lawyer devoted to public service and to fun.

title: Fourscore breathless years.
summary: Journalist who has worked on many city newspapers across the country reflects upon the issues of his times.

title: Signal zero: the true story of a professor who became a street cop.
summary: A professor of criminology attempts to reconcile his theoretical training with the professional experience of a particular student who is a full-time police officer.

title: Recollections of a Life photographer.
summary: Chapters are not continuous, but show him in the context of a variety of assignments during his career with Life magazine.

title: Links of life.
summary: Born in Sydney, Australia, Kirkwood established an international reputation as golf's premier trick-shot artist.

title: Thirty years: Lincoln Kirstein's The New York City Ballet.
summary: In discussing the thirty-year history of the New York City Ballet, Kirstein provides a history of modern ballet and demonstrates the powerful artistic influence and innovations of Balanchine and Stravinsky, among others.

title: New light of hope.
summary: In an inspiring but unsentimental account, Kiser, handicapped by cerebral palsy, writes of home schooling, surgery and physical therapy, nursing homes, emotional instability, and frustrated sexuality.

title: White House years.
summary: The highlights of Kissinger's memoir of his first four years as Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs (1969-1973).

title: Scientist at the White House: the private diary of President Eisenhower's special assistant for science and technology.
summary: This diary reveals the U.S. transition from conventional warfare to the missile age, and its increasing Cold War rivalry with Russia over atomic delivery systems and satellite intelligence.

title: Alone with me: a new autobiography.
summary: Kitt, a sensuous singer, dancer, and actress, recounts her impoverished childhood in South Carolina and, after her mother abandoned her, in Harlem with a stern aunt.

title: Thursday's child.
summary: Her first autobiographical book describes the poverty and hardship of her girlhood in New York, her years with the Katherine Dunham Dancers, and her first success as an entertainer.

title: I'm Hey, alive!
summary: In 1963 she and the pilot of a small plane crashed in the Yukon wilderness. For 49 days they lived on melted snow, a few cans of food, some toothpaste, and an amazing will to live in spite of the conditions which daily suggested almost certain death.

title: My girlhood among outlaws.
summary: As a child on the New Mexico frontier, Mrs. Klasner encountered the hardships of migration and settlement in a raw, sparsely populated land.

title: We die at dawn: the true to life story of America's No. 1 radio team, or No. 2, or No. 3, Kiavan and Finch.
summary: With in-group humor designed for his listeners, Kiavan describes typical radio broadcasts, 6-10 a.m. on New York's WNEW, that he and his partner, Dee Finch, conducted daily during the 1950's and early 1960's. He analyzes their comic style (parody, situation humor, nonsense) and identifies their total absorption in their work.

title: Lindsay's promise; the dream that failed; a personal account.
summary: Klein was New York City Mayor Lindsay's press secretary in 1966 and later served as an assistant administrator in the Housing and Development Administration. This is his view of the first year of Lindsay's administration and the nature of the pressures, trials, and crises confronting him.

title: A self portrait.
summary: Kleinholz writes an autobiographical introduction to a volume of reproductions of his paintings, explaining how he became a lawyer somewhat inadvertently and later pursued a career in painting.

title: Love affair; a memoir of Jackson Pollock.
summary: Kligman, an aspiring artist, met painter Jackson Pollock in 1956, resulting in a passionate, mercurial affair which lasted until his fatal accident. Her memoir captures the emotional highs and lows of their relationship.

title: Will everyone please stand still for the picture.
summary: A junior high school teacher recalls her experiences in a small school in the South and argues that teachers are inadequately prepared for their jobs.

title: The Ellen Knauff story.
summary: War bride's account of her three-year fight to be admitted to the United States despite unjust charges that detained her on Ellis Island.

title: Season in hell.
summary: A successful writer, journalist, and editor for over 28 years describes his battle with suicidal depression.

title: My papa's daughter.
summary: Interspersed with anecdotes of her life in Oklahoma Territory, the book provides facts about the area's history and schools.

title: Minister's daughter; a time exposure photograph of the years 1903-04.
summary: A diary capturing the author's observations of family and acquaintances during her youth, providing a picture of American family life at the turn of the century.

title: The story of my psychoanalysis.
summary: An early account by a patient undergoing psychoanalysis, detailing inquiries, dreams, and associations during his search for self-knowledge.

title: Journal of Madam Knight.
summary: Madam Knight's journal provides a lively account of her journey from Boston to New York, depicting New England provincial life in the colonial era.

title: Double vision: American thoughts abroad.
summary: A personal travelogue that explores American attitudes as juxtaposed against foreign lands and cultures.

title: Slave and freeman: the autobiography of George L. Knox.
summary: An autobiographical account divided into three parts describing Knox's life from slavery to freedom and his involvement in politics.

title: As time goes by: memoirs of a writer.
summary: Koch recounts his journey from law to writing, detailing his early radio script success, Hollywood career, and experiences during the McCarthy era.

title: G-2; intelligence for Patton.
summary: Koch, chief of intelligence for General Patton, traces the role of military intelligence in key World War II battles.

title: Fifty-fifty: or, you can't hide a man who is riding on a camel.
summary: Kofoed discusses various life experiences through the topics covered in his newspaper columns.

title: Leg man in seven-league boots.
summary: A prominent reporter and columnist describes his life in journalism with anecdotes about celebrities.

title: Half the house.
summary: Kohl describes his search for better ways to educate young people after directing the Other Ways school.

title: Big city, little boy.
summary: The book describes a writer's childhood in New York City at the turn of the century and his aspiration to become a writer.

title: The David Kopay story: an extraordinary self-revelation.
summary: Kopay gives an account of his life as a homosexual football player, including descriptions of his athletic career and persecution.

title: With two wheels and a camera.
summary: Kopperl, a photographer who became crippled by polio, shares humorous accounts of celebrities and events he photographed.

title: The diary of Elizabeth Koren, 1853-1855.
summary: An account of immigration from Norway to Decorah, Iowa, depicting pioneer life and domestic detail.

title: Journey to a far country: the parish papers.
summary: A collection of essays and letters from Vietnam that provide an autobiographical account of the author's life as a Lutheran clergyman.

title: Born on the Fourth of July.
summary: Kovic recounts his experiences in the Vietnam War and his struggles to reintegrate into society after being paralyzed.

title: On my way to the theatre.
summary: Kraft recounts his journey in the world of Broadway theater and his experiences during the House Hearings on Un-American Activities.

title: Jerry Kramer's farewell to football.
summary: A popular player with the Green Bay Packers recounts his life and values in football, along with a series of medical challenges.

title: The game: my 40 years in tennis.
summary: Kramer discusses tennis strategy and provides history and insights from his long tennis career.

title: Instant replay; The Green Bay diary of Jerry Kramer.
summary: A diary kept during the 1967 football season detailing the experiences of a professional player.

title: Rare book saga: the autobiography of Hans Peter Kraus.
summary: The memoirs of a well-known book collector detailing his experiences and the remarkable items he has acquired.

title: Big ear.
summary: A technical account of the author's career as an astronomer and professor involving the Big Ear radio telescope.

title: So I was a sergeant: memoirs of an occupation soldier.
summary: Krause recounts his experiences as an American army sergeant in charge of a hospital for German prisoners of war post World War II.

title: Horizons circled: reflections on my music.
summary: Krenek discusses his philosophical approach to music composition and his experience with the twelve-tone system.

title: Cabinetmaker's notebook.
summary: Krenov writes about the craft of cabinet making, emphasizing the skill and dedication required for craftsmanship.

title: To race the wind; an autobiography.
summary: A memoir detailing the life of a blind boy who set goals despite his disabilities and went on to graduate from Harvard.

title: S.S. Kresge story.
summary: A biography mainly focused on the author's father and the history of the Kresge Company.

title: Under the blood banner: the story of a Hitler Youth.
summary: A novelistic tale recounting the author's childhood in Germany as a Hitler Youth member.

title: Long walk home.
summary: A moving narrative of recovering from polio and adapting to life with disabilities, later becoming an English professor.

title: Now that you mention it.
summary: An account of Krielewitch's life as a Marine Corps General and his participation in politics.

title: Life, the man who kidnapped Barbara Mackle.
summary: A suspenseful recounting of the author's life and bizarre abduction of heiress Barbara Mackle.

title: Path: autobiography of a Western Yogi.
summary: An account of the author's search for God through yoga under the guidance of his guru, portraying a life dedicated to spiritual practice.

title: Memoirs; sixty years on the firing line.
summary: Krock, a longtime Washington correspondent, shares his experiences with powerful political figures.

title: Professional commodity trader (look over my shoulder)
summary: An over-the-shoulder look at the dealings of a professional commodities trader as he attends meetings and conferences, engages in private maneuvers, lets profits run and cuts losses.

title: No whippings, no gold watches; the saga of a writer and his jobs
summary: Reminiscences of work, the people he worked with, and a variety of jobs he has had — as a reader, reviewer, editor, writer, teacher, and critic at publishing houses, national magazines, universities, and newspapers during his extensive literary career.

title: More lives than one
summary: Drama critic for The Nation (1924-1952), professor of literature at Columbia (1937-1950), naturalist, and author — Krutch led an interesting and gratifying life, qualities beautifully revealed in his book.

title: My iron journey: an autobiography of a life with steam and steel
publisher: Intermountain Chapter, National Railway Historical Society, Inc.
summary: An exciting tale intertwining the design and development of twentieth-century steam and diesel locomotives and trains with the life of their designer.

title: In the arena
summary: After receiving missionary training at Chicago's Moody Bible Institute, the author went to China in 1928 to work among the Chinese peasants. There she married a fellow missionary, John Kuhn, and together they spent nearly twenty years in Yunnan among the Lisu people, until driven out by the Communists after World War II. A compelling, exciting tale, written while Kuhn was dying of cancer.

title: Memoirs of a new American
summary: Real-estate businessman recalls his childhood and adult experiences in Russia and the United States, emphasizing his family responsibilities and his appreciation of freedom.

title: Assignment: wildlife
summary: Whether saving an endangered species in Guatemala, staking out a national wildlife reserve in the Caribbean, or analyzing the Amazonian ecosystem, LaBastille is an award-winning conservationist and a very good writer.

title: Native daughter
summary: His book is both a confession and a love story. A middle-class urban Black, he was well educated, traveled to Africa to understand his heritage, and returned to Chicago to teach in a program for unmarried Black girls.

title: The rise and fall of a proper Negro; an autobiography
summary: Lacy grew up in the United States, became bitter and angry with discrimination and with the draft, and went to Africa searching for a new definition of emotional freedom and a way to be absorbed by the culture.

title: The manner is ordinary
summary: His father a famous artist and friend of Henry Adams, the son became the first priest in the family, attained success in his calling, and became Editor-in-Chief of America, a national Catholic weekly.

title: Adventure in politics: the memoirs of Philip LaFoIIette
summary: A member of the Progressive LaFoIIette family of Wisconsin, the author recounts the part he and his family played in the struggle for creative and vigorous state government and the difficulties they had because of their stand against war.

title: La Follette's autobiography: a personal narrative of political experiences
summary: The political life of a prominent statesman in Wisconsin and national government, who is best remembered as a pioneer in the Progressive movement for more representative government.

title: Making of an insurgent: an autobiography, 1882-1919
summary: Written during the last six months of his life, the book describes LaGuardia's formative years as a statesman, including work for the consular service in Hungary, as a translator on Ellis Island, as Deputy Attorney General for New York State — all preceding his years as congressman and Mayor of New York City.

title: Encounter with an angry god: recollections of my life with John Peabody Harrington
summary: Laird writes an unsparing account of the seven years she spent as the wife of John Peabody Harrington, an eccentric ethnologist who devoted his life to learning as much as possible about the Southwest Indian culture and dialects.

title: Limbo
summary: Laird's personal narrative describes a typical life in the 'Golden Mesa Nursing Home,' which she, as an unwilling patient, detested because of the dreadful food and the dehumanizing effect of treating everyone as senile.

title: The United States vs. William Laite
summary: Convicted of perjury and making false statements in relation to overtime pay for employees of his firm which was working on a government contract, Laite was sentenced to a year and a day in prison. Here he relates his prison experiences and sets forth his indictment of the system.

title: Veronica
summary: An account of Lake's career as a Hollywood actress in the 1940's and early 1950's, when she made The Blue Dahlia, I Married a Witch, and So Proudly We Hail, including her struggles with alcoholism and multiple marriages.

title: Dorothy Lamour: my side of the road
summary: Lamour describes her childhood in Louisiana, her struggles as a beginning actress, and her first success, starring in the motion picture The Jungle Princess.

title: This, too, shall pass
summary: An articulate testament of faith in God, man, and her husband, Bert Lance, detailing their journey from childhood friends to prosperity through Bert's banking activities.

title: Winning the war with ships: land, sea, and air — mostly land
summary: President Roosevelt assigned him to develop a vast program of ship construction for the Navy and Merchant Marine in World War II. His book describes the program and his long working relationship with Roosevelt.
occupations: Navy and Merchant Marine ship constructor

title: won't be so pretty (but you'll know more)
summary: An actress reminisces about her life, loves, and acting, particularly on stage in London and New York.

title: made it myself
summary: A printer in New York, he was kidnapped by the mob and forced to counterfeit twenty-dollar bills. His book emphasizes the ease and temptations of his crime.

title: Washington diaries, 1933-35
summary: Landreth was in Washington from 1933 to 1935 to serve on the Puerto Rican Hurricane Relief Committee. This diary covers political and social activities.

title: G.B.S. and the lunatic; reminiscences of the long, lively, and affectionate friendship between George Bernard Shaw and the author.
summary: Record of Shaw's views on his plays and other subjects from sex to socialism.

title: The magic curtain: the story of a life in two fields, theatre and invention, by the founder of the Theatre Guild.
summary: Describes his activities in art and invention along with notable plays and figures in theater.

title: Poems and letters.
summary: Selections include 25 poems and letters relating to Lanier's professional life in music and literature.

title: Wandering showman, I.
summary: Describes his 78 years as a puppeteer and his unusual view of small-town, rural America.

title: Run Sammy run: sixty-five years a preacher man.
summary: An evangelical preacher characterizes himself as perpetually running and reflecting on his formative years.

title: First and last consul: Thomas Oliver Larkin and the Americanization of California; selection of letters.
summary: Letters concentrate on Larkin's role in the movement to secure California for the United States.

title: Larkin papers: personal, business, and official correspondence of Thomas Oliver Larkin, merchant and U.S. Consul in California.
publisher: University of California Press for the Bancroft Library
summary: A collection of records from one of California's most prominent citizens.

title: Woman surgeon: the autobiography of Else K. LaRoe, M.D.
summary: Details her career as a restorative surgeon.

title: Candle in the sun.
summary: The high points in her life as the wife of film producer Jesse Lasky, with insights into her early and later years.

title: I blow my own horn.
summary: Describes Lasky's career in Hollywood, including partnerships and challenges.

title: Tell it on the mountain.
summary: A personal account detailing Lasky's Jewish ancestry and challenges in life.

title: My life in publishing.
summary: Memoir of the publishing profession from the editor-in-chief of the Macmillan Company.

title: Impressions respecting New Orleans: diary and sketches, 1818-1820.
summary: Latrobe gives details of the growing city and his philosophical comments during his visit.

title: The Virginia journals of Benjamin Henry Latrobe: 1795-1798.
summary: Latrobe's journals feature stories of daily life and watercolor sketches from colonial Virginia.

title: Ordeal by slander.
summary: Account of the author's defense before the Senate subcommittee following accusations of espionage.

title: Sand in my eyes.
summary: Details the life of a bride in the Oklahoma Territory and reflections on her early life.

title: My life with Sydney Laurence.
summary: Chronicles her life with painter Sydney Laurence in Alaska, featuring his work.

title: The papers of Henry Laurens.
publisher: Published for the South Carolina Historical Society by the University of South Carolina Press
summary: A collection of documents from an almost forgotten patriot of the American Revolution.

title: Action priest; the story of Father Joe Lauro.
summary: Chronicles the journey of a World War II bomber pilot who became a priest.

title: Memoirs of my life: to my son during the years 1803 and after.
summary: Laussat's journal chronicles his role in the Louisiana Purchase and daily activities.

title: One man's West.
summary: Narrative describing the life of a modern cowboy.

title: Practice of mountains.
summary: An Olympic skiing champion describes influence of the sport on her life.

title: Memoirs and correspondence.
summary: Narrative of her life portraying her understanding of her nature and relationship with D.H. Lawrence.

title: The captain's best mate: the journal of Mary Chipman Lawrence on the whaler Addison, 1856-1860.
summary: A journal detailing the experiences of a woman on a whaling voyage.

title: My last seventy years.
summary: Life story focusing on associations with notable people.

title: The early advertising scene.
summary: Recollections of experiences in the advertising field.

title: Mission possible.
summary: Offers career guidance in the airline industry while reflecting on personal hardships.

title: A rage for opera; its anatomy as drawn from life.
summary: Composer's views on opera, discussing the audience and the repertoire.

title: Confessions of a hope fiend.
summary: A personal account of Leary's imprisonment and escape after drug charges.

title: Stranger at the party: a memoir.
summary: A quest for self and independence after the author's husband's death.

title: William Hayne Leavell, 1850-1930: an autobiography.
summary: Account from a life in South Carolina during the Civil War and Reconstruction.

title: Whistling girl: candid confessions of a chameleon.
summary: A journalist's candid confessions reflecting on her career and experiences.

title: At that time: with decorations by the author.
summary: A nostalgic recall of the author's New England boyhood.

title: It's time to tell.
summary: Reflects on the author's public service career and safety initiatives.

title: One man show: a personal adventure in American art.
summary: Reflections on life and career as an artist during the Depression.

title: The discoveries of John Lederer: with unpublished letters by and about Lederer to Governor John Winthrop, Jr. and an essay on the Indians of Lederer's Discoveries.
summary: Record of explorations in Virginia and commentary on Indian tribes.

title: N/A
summary: N/A

title: All the ships at sea.
summary: Humorous account of experiences by a naval officer turned public relations specialist.

title: It was a different game; the Elmer Layden story.
summary: Nostalgic account of football and the author's experiences.

title: John Ledyard's journal of Captain Cook's last voyage.
summary: Journal detailing Ledyard's experiences during the voyage exploring the Northwest Passage.

title: Gypsy: a memoir.
summary: Stripteaser Lee, 'the greatest no-talent star' in show business, narrates the story of her life on the vaudeville and burlesque circuits.

title: Payday everyday.
summary: A southern Baptist preacher's story of his life in the church, with comments on selected issues such as smoking and evolution, and notes on some famous people he has known.

title: Man and me, M.D.
summary: Upon retiring from a thirty-year medical practice, he traveled all over the world with an anthropologist's interest in observing how certain peoples have developed. Text includes photographs, charts, and illustrations.

title: Testament of intent.
summary: This book discusses the disbarment proceedings instituted against the author, a nationally prominent attorney who was active in reform of the bar association and in setting up a 'Citizens' Legal Clinic' for the poor.

title: Memoir of the Rev. Jesse Lee; with extracts from his journals.
publisher: Arno Press and The New York Times
summary: A minister in the Church of Christ, Lee traveled between New York and Virginia to strengthen the organizational ties of the church.

title: Morman chronicle: the diaries of John D. Lee, 1848-1876.
summary: Five diaries of a prominent Morman leader describe the Morman settlement of Utah, his devout, uncompromising practice of Morman beliefs, and the details of everyday life on the wilderness frontier.

title: Memories beyond bloomers: 1924-1954.
publisher: American Alliance for Health, Physical Education, and Recreation
summary: Lee discusses her thirty-year career as chairman of Women's Physical Education at the University of Nebraska and her involvement in various organizations.

title: Memories of a bloomer girl: 1894-1924.
publisher: American Alliance for Health, Physical Education, and Recreation
summary: Lee recounts her upbringing and early teaching career, interwoven with a history of women's physical education and women's liberation.

title: The London journal of General Raymond E. Lee, 1940-1941.
summary: As military attache to the American Embassy in London during 1940 and 1941, he had a first-hand experience with British morale and the efforts of British citizens.

title: Lee's dispatches: unpublished letters to Jefferson Davis and the War Department of the Confederate States of America, 1862-65.
summary: An interesting contribution to our understanding of the man, the general, and Civil War history.

title: The story of Robert E. Lee: as told in his own words and those of his contemporaries.
publisher: Eastern National Park and Monument Association
summary: A collection of writings about Robert E. Lee.

title: The happy life of a doctor.
summary: A physician for fifty years describes his life in medicine.

title: Letters of William Lee, 1766-1783.
volume: Eyewitness Accounts of the American Revolution
summary: Lee, brother of Richard Henry Lee, was the only American who served as Alderman of London. His letters reveal his chequered career.

title: A Yankee Jeffersonian: selections from the diary and letters of William Lee of Massachusetts written from 1796-1840.
summary: A candid, perceptive record of his life as a businessman and diplomat.

title: A short biography of John Leeth: with an account of his life among the Indians.
summary: The record of the author's captivity and life among the Indians for over eighteen years, written by Ewel Jeffries from Leeth's recollections.

title: Breakout: from prison to the big leagues.
summary: LeFlore's autobiography is an honest, earthy account of his youth spent stealing and drug-taking, leading up to his rise to the major leagues.

title: Left Handed: a Navajo autobiography.
summary: This book is a sequel to Son of Old Man Hat and focuses on the trials of Left Handed's early marriage, family life, and tribal practice.

title: With a quiet heart.
summary: Written in her fifties, this book begins with the story of her near-fatal accident by fire and her return to success as one of America's most outstanding stage actresses.

title: Midway in my song: the autobiography of Lotte Lehmann.
summary: The famous opera diva's story of her life, her disappointments and triumphs throughout Europe and the United States.

title: My many lives.
summary: Her experiences and conceptions of operatic roles she has performed, focusing on her acting and insight into the characters.

title: In the strong moods: a season alone in the North Country.
summary: Lehmberg spends a summer by himself in the remote Ontario lakes region, contemplating his natural surroundings.

title: "King Lehr" and the gilded age.
summary: Lehr writes of the 'tragic farce of [her] marriage' to a dictator of society and describes the society and women of America's 'gilded age' with humor.

title: The girl who had everything: the story of 'The Fire and Ice Girl.'
summary: Dorian Leigh, a high-fashion model, became known for her tumultuous life and relationships, and her story encompasses her struggles and successes.

title: Man with the white horse: memoirs.
summary: Leistad describes his childhood in Norway and his experiences as an immigrant in Iowa and his career in construction with trick horses.

title: Himself and I: our sea saga; in collaboration with himself.
summary: A socialite-author reminisces about social customs of the early twentieth century and their long sea travels together.

title: The Carolina chronicle of Dr. Francis Le Jau, 1706-1717.
volume: California University Publications in History, Vol. 53
summary: A collection of correspondence and annual reports written by an Anglican missionary in Charleston, South Carolina.

title: Memoirs.
summary: Leland, a prominent journalist, writes of his upbringing, education, journalistic career, abolitionist efforts, and travels in Europe.

title: Golfers gold: an inside view of the pro tour.
summary: A champion player in the 1960's describes tournament life, money, and celebrities.

title: Memories of an old actor.
summary: Leman recalls actors and actresses, theaters, and travel throughout the United States and Europe.

title: Boss cowman: the recollections of Ed Lemmon, 1857-1946.
summary: Lemmon was a cowhand and ranch owner who witnessed the development of the Western Plains and was named among the first South Dakota cowmen in the National Cowboy Hall of Fame.

title: A circle of quiet.
summary: Her first autobiography describes her life in rural Connecticut as wife, mother, grandmother, and writer until the success of A Wrinkle in Time.

title: The irrational season.
summary: L'Engle writes about her family, teaching, and the influence of religious inspiration on her writing, with inspirational poems interspersed.

title: The summer of the great-grandmother.
summary: A study of her maternal ancestry written during the last year of her mother's life.

title: Private lives in the Imperial City.
summary: Leonard's collection of 'Private Lives' columns from the New York Times provides insights into family relationships.

title: Adventures of Zenas Leonard, fur trader.
volume: American Exploration and Travel Series, Number 28
summary: Zenas Leonard recounts his experiences as a fur trader and trapper in the Rocky Mountains.

title: The street where I live.
