summary: An engaging, highly personal biography of three great shows: Camelot, My Fair Lady, and Gigi.

title: Mervyn LeRoy; take one.
summary: LeRoy started out in vaudeville and went to Hollywood where he directed and produced several famous movies.

title: There's a rhino in the rose bed, Mother.
summary: An account of their lives in South Africa and in America, comparing social issues in both countries.

title: All is well.
summary: Black author Lester reveals consistent malaise through an autobiographical narrative interspersed with poetry, letters, diary entries, and excerpts from his essays and reviews.

title: Mover of men and mountains: the autobiography of R.G. LeTourneau.
summary: Self-educated, he invented giant earth-moving machinery and became involved in missionary work in Liberia and Peru.

title: Memoirs of an amnesiac.
summary: Levant's autobiography recounts episodes of his life with typical frenetic and sardonic wit.

title: The unimportance of being Oscar.
summary: Written after his Memoirs of an Amnesiac, this book continues his reminiscences about show business and famous people.

title: Everything but money.
summary: Amid nostalgic stories of his youth, Levenson mixes humorous criticism of today's society and a plea for old-fashioned values.

title: In one era and out the other.
summary: His book describes his childhood and youth in New York, along with the problems common to both.

title: The poet in the world.
summary: A collection of scattered prose pieces that express her thoughts on poetry, writing, politics, and other writers.

title: Pilot.
summary: Describes his career as a stunt flyer, teacher, and barnstormer until 1941, when he became a test pilot.

title: In search: an autobiography by Meyer Levin.
summary: Examines his own sense of being a Jew, discussing the history of the Jews through World War II and the development of Israel.

title: The obsession.
summary: Describes his efforts to come to terms with his conviction that his staging of The Diary of Anne Frank had been unjustly debarred.

title: Eyewitness to history; memoirs and reflections of a foreign correspondent for half a century.
summary: The dramatic peaks in the career of a rebel whose life was influenced by the Russian Revolution and other political events.

title: Memoir.
summary: Levy, a Manhattan art dealer, specialized in work by Dadaists and Surrealists and describes the avant-garde art world of the 1930's.

title: My double life: adventures in law and letters.
summary: Levy writes engagingly about his dual careers as a successful trial lawyer and author.

title: Human island: the story of a woman's dedication to the hopeless.
summary: Lewandowski writes of her years ministering to the infirm and elderly, shaped by her Christian faith.

title: Ramblings.
summary: Entries from a travel journal of trips throughout the U.S.

title: I remember.
summary: Reflections on her life and experiences, particularly in relation to her parents' missionary work.

title: Nothing to make a shadow.
summary: The first woman graduate of the University of South Dakota College of Medicine describes her family's homesteading years.

title: With love from Gracie: Sinclair Lewis: 1912-1925.
summary: The story of her life with the famous author.

title: Bay River.
summary: A folk history of the Delaware Bay area, mixing local legends with personal experiences.

title: The film maker.
summary: A versatile comedian turned filmmaker, Lewis provides an inside look at the film-making process.

title: The strange story of a minister's life.
summary: Recounts his ministry and experiences, including being framed for arson and serving time in prison.

title: Letters from Lloyd Lewis: showing steps in the research for his biography of U.S. Grant.
summary: Historian describes the progress of his research through letters to his publisher.

title: The journals of Lewis and Clark: a new selection.
summary: An exciting account of the Lewis and Clark expedition.

title: From Main Street to Stockholm: letters, 1919-1930.
summary: Letters between Lewis and his publisher detailing their friendship and Lewis's literary ambitions.

title: One man's education.
summary: An account of his education and passion for collecting Walpoliana.

title: The things I love.
summary: Liberace offers an account of his career and personal passions as a flamboyant entertainer.

title: A pharmacist's memoirs: fifty years of Ukrainczyk's Brighton pharmacy.
summary: Recollections of a neighborhood pharmacist in Brooklyn.

title: Desperado.
summary: The author encountered the American West as the first female regional bureau chief of the New York Times.

title: The odyssey of a Jew.
summary: Describes Lichtiger's escape from Poland during World War II and his journey to Palestine and eventually New York.

title: Will: the autobiography of G. Gordon Liddy.
summary: Liddy describes his career, involvement in the Watergate break-in, and experiences as a former Presidential Counsel.

title: Up stream: an American chronicle.
summary: A progressively ironic account of his family's immigration from Prussia to South Carolina.

title: Baseball as I have known it.
summary: The history of major-league baseball through the eyes of a long-time sportswriter.

title: Freak show man: the autobiography of Harry Lewiston.
summary: Describes his life in the circus and his experiences as a barker and showman.

title: My seventy five years along the Mexican border.
summary: Recollections from life along the Mexican border, remembered from his boyhood and adulthood.

title: Picnic in Babylon; a Jesuit priest's journal, 1963-1967.
summary: Records his life before ordination, commenting on the conflict between being a poet and a priest.

title: A doctor's apprenticeship (autobiographical sketches).
summary: Recalls his childhood, medical education, and life in America as a general practitioner.

title: Liberace; an autobiography.
summary: One of the most flamboyant show biz figures, writing to entertain and further his public image.

title: Just Dad: a pioneer history of the Southwest.
summary: A retrospective view of the author's pioneer life in the Southwest, written as an extended letter to his son.

title: The journals of David E. Lilienthal.
summary: Collection of journal entries spanning from 1917 to 1963 including reflections on public service and interests in helping underdeveloped nations.

title: Dear remembered world: childhood memories of an old New Yorker.
summary: Interesting story of middle-class life in Victorian New York.

title: Hawaii's story by Hawaii's queen.
summary: A personal account of the last years of the Hawaiian monarchy that was inevitably and inexorably swept along toward democracy. She believed in the divine right of monarchy but supported efforts to improve health, welfare, and education among her people. She writes of the revolution and annexation by the U.S. and asks for sympathy toward the cause of Hawaiian autonomy.

title: The dyadic cyclone: the autobiography of a couple.
summary: Psychoanalyst Lilly and his wife, an artist, focus on the question to which they have devoted considerable investigation during their five years together: 'Is it possible to merge two centers, cyclones, one male, one female, in such a way that there can be a rising center shared by both?' They discuss their explorations of the question, via meditation, but particularly through hour-long flotations in a dark tank of epsom salts and 93 degrees F. water, to replicate the womb.

title: Abraham Lincoln: an autobiographical narrative.
summary: Two sketches, the second originally written in third person, edited here in first person, describing his life through his presidential campaign in 1856.

title: Abraham Lincoln: his speeches and writings.
summary: A selection of Lincoln's best writings, mostly letters, selected on the basis of 'literary significance, historical importance, human interest,' with long introduction analyzing his development as a writer.

title: Abraham Lincoln's autobiography: with an account of its origin and history and additional biographical material.
summary: A copy of the original manuscript is printed in the context of correspondence between Lincoln and Jesse W. Fell, who persuaded him to write it in 1859. Edited by Fell's grandson.

title: Lincoln: his words and his world.
summary: This handsome volume consists of excerpts from Lincoln's letters and speeches on topics such as the Lincoln-Douglas debates, the Civil War, and his private life. Prints, cartoons, and photographs, many in color, enhance the text.

title: My twelve years with John F. Kennedy.
summary: Secretary to John F. Kennedy for twelve years while he was senator and president, Mrs. Lincoln writes of her experiences on the job and relates anecdotes that are both revealing and heartwarming.

title: Vice-president in charge of revolution.
summary: The story of his successful career as a creative and controversial business executive, who at time of writing was head of Nationwide Insurance and had served as first president of CARE, as president of the Cooperative League of the U.S.A., and in several major positions in the United Nations.

title: Bring me a unicorn: diaries and letters of Anne Morrow Lindbergh, 1922-1928.
summary: Diary entries and letters shaped into a continuous autobiography record the significant impressions and events of her life through 1928.

title: The flower and the nettle.
summary: The fourth collection from her letters and diaries covers 1936-39, when she lived in England and Brittany, moving in European diplomatic circles with her famous husband and beginning to develop her career as a writer.

title: Gift from the sea.
summary: Reflecting on her past during a private retreat on the beach, Lindbergh sees many aspects of her life as representative of American womanhood.

title: Hour of gold, hour of lead: diaries and letters of Anne Morrow Lindbergh, 1929-1932.
summary: This second volume of Anne Morrow Lindbergh's diaries and letters covers her early married life. She learned to fly, to navigate, to live in the glare of publicity. Then came the tragedy of the kidnapping and murder of their young son, which brought the bitterness and despair they overcame by the strength of their love and marriage.

title: Locked rooms and open doors; diaries and letters of Anne Morrow Lindbergh, 1933-1935.
summary: In this volume the author traces her life after the kidnapping of her son and all the attendant publicity. She and her husband undertook a pioneering flight around the North Atlantic to seek air routes to Europe. Her diary and letters reveal some of the hardships they endured — fear, sickness, discomforts — but also the beauty, excitement, and adventure of the trip.

title: Literary works of Abraham Lincoln.
summary: While not strictly autobiography, this volume contains orders, directives, stump and courtroom speeches, letters and telegrams which lend insight into Lincoln's mystical vision of human experience. Materials cover the period 1824-1865.

title: Autobiography of values.
summary: Lindbergh reaches far beyond the notable achievements of his life to discuss many of the values of modern life — advances in science and technology, civilizations of the world, military priorities and weapons, the environment, freedom and responsibility of the individual, life and death, war, and marriage.

title: The living Lincoln: the man, his mind, his times, and the war he fought, reconstructed from his own writings.
summary: This book is reconstructed from Lincoln's own writings, covering significant aspects of his life and thoughts during his presidency and the Civil War.

title: Spirit of St. Louis.
summary: Primarily the story of his planning and execution of the first intercontinental flight, written over a period of fourteen years.

title: The wartime journals of Charles A. Lindbergh.
summary: During the World War II years, 1938-1945, Lindbergh studied European aviation, sought to alert Western leaders to military imbalance, and to lack of preparation, and made a dedicated effort to keep the United States out of a war which threatened to destroy Western civilization. Although his views were controversial and sometimes misunderstood, he maintained his position with sincerity and determination.

title: Montana adventure; the recollections of Frank B. Linderman.
summary: Although he served in the Montana legislature for two terms and was Assistant Secretary of State for Montana as well as a successful insurance agent, Linderman's first love was the great outdoors. He also devoted a large share of his life to the Indians, learning their lore and writing books and articles about them.

title: Journey into politics; some informal observations.
summary: With the exception of the final chapter, written after his mayoralty campaign in 1965, Lindsay's book is devoted mainly to his seven years in Congress. The substance appeared first in articles, book reviews, and speeches he wrote between 1958 and 1965.

title: Memories of Davidson College.
summary: Lingle entered Davidson as a freshman in 1888, was president (1929-1941), and was asked by the trustees to write this memoir in retirement; it describes the life of the college and his own years as a part of its history.

title: The best war at the time.
summary: In 1898, he volunteered for the infantry to serve in the war with Spain, and afterwards served in the Philippines, in Mexico in pursuit of Pancho Villa, and in World War I, working through the ranks to retire as a general.

title: Advocate for God: a lawyer's experience in personal evangelism.
summary: Linsley, a bom-again Christian lawyer with the Judge Advocate General's staff of the U.S. Army, intends each chapter of this book of short, personal religious essays to be used as the basis for a prayer meeting or religious discussion group. They exhibit a belief in the efficacy of faith, prayer, and good works.

title: Fifty years an editor.
summary: As editor of Missions, a Baptist magazine, he participated extensively in the organizational structure of the church and travelled widely to report on social and political, as well as religious events that concerned the church.

title: Haps and mishaps of a tour in Europe.
summary: A minutely detailed account of the author's tour of Europe, 1852-1853. Although she dines with Charles Dickens, Walter Savage Landor, and becomes close friends with Kossuth and Mazzini, this is less the story of a writer's visits to great people than an American tourist's diary of viewing the Queen, Parliament, and traipsing about the seven hills of Rome.

title: David Lipscomb: journalist in Texas, 1872.
summary: Preacher-journalist-educator Lipscomb wrote travel dispatches during his 1872 journey through Texas for the religious journal Gospel Advocate.

title: Memoirs in profile.
summary: Zionist leader Lipsky prefaces this collection of portraits of notable international Jewish leaders and essays on Zionism with a 57-page autobiography of his childhood in Rochester, N.Y., and his first twenty years as a Zionist newspaper editor and organizer in New York City.

title: Industrial voyage: my life as an industrial lieutenant.
summary: In 1900 he moved from Boston to Akron, Ohio, to work as a young supervisor for Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co., then in its second year. Later, as Goodyear's Chairman of the Board, he pioneered in mass production and marketing, labor relations, and export business, his life story becoming emblematic of the rise of modern industry.

title: Russian Hussar.
summary: A colorful, witty account of Littauer's military career in the pre-revolutionary Russian army.

title: The autobiography of Malcolm X.
summary: The remarkable story of Malcolm X, the outspoken, forceful Black Muslim leader who worked for Black separation and secession as the only acceptable way to liberate his people. In 1964, however, his attitude underwent a change and he broke from Elijah Muhammad, recognizing the advantages of Black integration into the American community.

title: The real score.
summary: A golfer writes of 25 years of golfing tournaments; he won the U.S. Open in 1961 and by September 1974, after 487 matches, had won over a million dollars.

title: Solitaire.
summary: A bizarre story of Aimee Liu's self-deluding insistence that she was too 'fat' and her near-starvation, which brought her weight down to the ninety pounds she maintained throughout high school.

title: The story of my life.
summary: Livermore presents a lively, penetrating account of the major social movements in which she participated during her long life: upbringing in intellectual Boston; living in a log cabin in western New York State; tutoring on a Southern plantation, where she became a firm opponent of slavery; working as one of the Commissioners of the U.S. Sanitary Commission during the Civil War; involvement in temperance, Women's Suffrage, and pacifistic activities thereafter.

title: Bostonians and bullion; the journal of Robert Livermore, 1892-1915.
summary: Extracting from lengthy diary entries, Livermore, a mining engineer, wrote this journal covering his life to the termination of his Telluride residence in 1910. Later he added a chapter on Canada.

title: Nancy Shippen, her journal book: the international romance of a young lady of fashion of colonial Philadelphia.
summary: A selection of journal entries and letters provides a record of the life, thought, and background of a family before, during, and after the Revolution.

title: The original letters of Robert R. Livingston, 1801-1803: written during his negotiations of the purchase of Louisiana to which is prefixed a brief history of the Louisiana Purchase from original documents.
summary: Livingston, Minister Plenipotentiary to France, arrived in Paris in December 1801, to pursue for the next eighteen months advocacy of the right of the United States to the free navigation of the Mississippi and the Right of Deposit of merchandise in Louisiana.

title: Belle out of order.
summary: The curious story of a woman who left poverty on a Kansas farm for the stage, worked her way into society life in New York, London, Monte Carlo, and was notorious for her unconventional life.

title: Always the unexpected: a book of reminiscences.
summary: Winner of the Pulitzer Prize in 1939 for distinguished service as a foreign correspondent, he describes his career in journalism, including his long association with the Berlin Bureau of the Associated Press (1924-1942).

title: This world, my home.
summary: Born in a West Virginia log cabin, he spent his boyhood in Nebraska, where he began his career in journalism, and at 51 became editor of the Dayton Daily News.

title: Custer fell first: the adventures of John C. Lockwood.
summary: Lockwood was a soldier at Custer's last stand, then became a stagecoach driver in the Dakota Territory and Idaho, detailing his adventures in this narrative.

title: Early memories. Leisure Class in America Series.
summary: Lodge discusses the first thirty years of his life, focusing on his illustrious ancestors, his Boston upbringing and education at Harvard.

title: The storm has many eyes; a personal narrative.
summary: Lodge has served his country in a variety of posts, discussing the working of politics and government.

title: I remember Detroit.
summary: The former mayor of Detroit recalls his long, active personal and professional life in that city.

title: Movie stars, real people, and me.
summary: Logan discusses his career as a film director and theatrical producer, focusing on personal anecdotes of numerous actors.

title: George, be careful; a Greek florist's kid in the roughhouse world of advertising.
summary: In rapid-fire prose, a self-made millionaire tells how he made it big in the advertising world.

title: Adventures of a ballad hunter.
summary: Recalls life as an avid ballad hunter since boyhood in Texas, including his discovery of Leadbelly in 1934.

title: Auld acquaintance.
summary: A well-written account of Lombardo's career as a bandleader, particularly focused on the demand for melody in dance music during the 1930s and 40s.

title: Jack London, American rebel: a collection of his social writings, together with an extensive study of the man and his times.
summary: Includes fiction, articles, and essays along with autobiographical writings revealing the life and times of Jack London.

title: John Barleycorn: or alcoholic memoirs.
summary: This autobiography presents London's struggle with alcoholism and his literary career, despite his dependency on drink.

title: Letters from Jack London, containing an unpublished correspondence between London and Sinclair Lewis.
summary: A selection of thousands of letters from Jack London, aiming to provide an accurate image of his life and thoughts.

title: No mentor but myself: a collection of articles, essays, reviews, and letters on writing and writers.
summary: This collection features London’s insights on authorship, reader psychology, and the economics of writing.

title: The road.
summary: London recounts his experiences as a hobo in 1894, detailing the culture and experiences of hobos.

title: Strange journey: the vision life of a psychic Indian woman.
summary: Beginning with a discussion of her Mohawk-Delaware heritage, she writes of her early encounters with ghosts and spirits.

title: The war diary of Breckinridge Long; selections from the years 1939-1944.
summary: Long's diary presents a primary source of diplomatic history during an exciting period of American and world history.
occupations: Ambassador, Special Assistant Secretary of State

title: The journal of John D. Long.
summary: Based on his 24-volume journal, this edition gives a portrait of a popular statesman, who was Governor of Massachusetts and Secretary of the Navy.

title: High time to tell it.
summary: Primarily a recollection of her childhood on a plantation in North Carolina and her extended family.

title: Mrs. Longfellow: selected letters and journals of Fanny Appleton Longfellow.
summary: The life records of Mrs. Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, providing a portrait of her experience in Boston's intellectual community.

title: The letters of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow.
publisher: The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press
summary: A collection of letters revealing Longfellow's life before and during his career as a poet.

title: Life of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow: with extracts from his journals and correspondence.
summary: Documents Longfellow's life and career with a mix of correspondence and journal entries.

title: Spoiled priest; the autobiography of an ex-priest.
summary: The story of a priest's journey from his boyhood through his difficult decision to leave the priesthood.

title: I married a priest.
summary: Longo writes about her experience as the wife of a former Catholic priest, detailing the challenges they faced.

title: Boy in the Model-T: a journey in the just gone past.
summary: A vivid and nostalgic account of a cross-country trip in a Model-T at the age of twelve.

title: Mesabi pioneer: reminiscences of Edmund J. Longyear.
summary: Recollections of a mining engineer's exploration for iron ore in Minnesota's Mesabi Range.

title: Cast of thousands.
summary: A celebration of the glamour of Hollywood from silent films to the fifties, filled with photographs and anecdotes.

title: A girl like I.
summary: An amusing story of her climb up the ladder of success in Hollywood, particularly through her character Lorelei Lee.

title: Kiss Hollywood good-by.
summary: The second volume of Loos' autobiography detailing her adventures in and out of Hollywood.

title: The education of a woman golfer.
summary: Professional golfer Nancy Lopez describes her education through golfing, highlighting the physical and psychological aspects of the game.

title: Lopez speaking: an autobiography by Vincent Lopez.
summary: Lopez describes his career as an entertainer, his relationships, and his journey to stability.

title: Played by ear.
summary: A Jesuit priest writes episodes of his life, reflecting on his youthful outlook and literary ambitions.

title: No job for a lady: autobiography.
summary: Lose shares her journey from an exercise boy at a race track to a veterinarian specializing in horses.

title: Throw me a bone: what happens when you marry an archaeologist.
summary: The wife of Samuel Lothrop recounts her experiences traveling with him to various archaeological sites.

title: By the political sea.
summary: As a State Department official, the author provides an insider's view of political campaigns and efforts to include women in political life.

title: Pat Loud; a woman's story.
summary: Pat Loud shares her experiences in a nationally televised series An American Family.

title: The Joe Louis story.
summary: Boxer Joe Louis narrates his rise from poverty to wealth and fame as a heavyweight boxer, including victories over notable opponents. He retired from boxing in 1951.

title: My life story.
summary: World heavyweight-boxing champion writes of his early life, training for the ring, service in World War II, and the championship.

title: From Hollywood with love.
summary: This account of the actress's life emphasizes her career in silent films and her transition to talkies, reflecting on her experiences and the industry.

title: All our years: autobiography.
summary: Richly detailed life of Lovett as a man of letters, professor, and president of a socialist organization, reflecting on his life experiences.

title: Scholar-friends: letters of Francis James Child and James Russell Lowell.
summary: The letters between scholar Francis Child and poet James Russell Lowell discuss topics such as scholarship, literature, and travel.

title: The life and adventures of Nat Love, better known in the cattle country as Deadwood Dick, by himself.
summary: A narrative of Love's life as a cowpuncher and experiences in the post-Civil War West, highlighting his adventures.

title: Until proven guilty: forty years as criminal defense counsel.
summary: Lowenberg describes his experiences as a criminal defense counsel, sharing observations on criminal behavior and significant cases.

title: Lovecraft at last.
summary: Correspondence between Lovecraft and a fan that reveals insights into Lovecraft's literary mind and their interactions.

title: Selected letters, 1911-1924.
summary: A collection of letters revealing Lovecraft's thoughts on various subjects, showcasing his known literary voice.

title: Selected letters, 1925-1929.
summary: The letters during Lovecraft's return to Providence reflecting on his expanding literary and personal life.

title: Ordeal.
summary: Lovelace describes her life in the pornographic film industry, detailing her traumatic experiences and eventual escape.

title: Tomorrow's a holiday (Kesho siku kuu).
summary: A naturalist describes his field work in Africa and his interactions with locals during his explorations.

title: C.S. Lovett, maranatha man: an autobiography.
summary: Lovett's autobiography recounts his journey as a preacher and evangelist, reflecting on his faith and mission.

title: Robert H. Lowie: ethnologist.
summary: A biography of Robert H. Lowie, detailing his contributions to the field of ethnology.

title: Heaven on earth.
summary: Recollections of her childhood summers in Northfield, Massachusetts, as a minister's child with a love of nature.

title: I always wore my topi: the Burma letters of Ethel Mabuce, 1916-1921.
summary: Accepted for an overseas assignment by the Women's Foreign Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church, her letters describe her delight in the people, customs, foods, and country of the Burmese, conveying a sense of adventure in an exotic land.

title: The plague and I.
summary: The story of her recovery from tuberculosis after nearly nine months in a sanatorium.

title: Who, me?
summary: Selections from previously published autobiographical books placed in chronological order: her life on a chicken farm, her conquest of tuberculosis, her career as a writer, and her family life on Vashon Island.

title: Duty, honor, country: a pictorial autobiography.
summary: The vivid life of MacArthur is told in his words and with over 200 photographs.

title: Diaries of Donald Macdonald 1824-1826.
summary: These are the diaries kept during two journeys to New Harmony, often remembered as a romantic figure in the community.

title: Reminiscences.
summary: General MacArthur's life story dedicated to his country, offering insights into World War II, the occupation of Japan, and the Korean War.

title: Undercover girl.
summary: During World War II, she worked for the OSS and was involved in psychological warfare, traveling to India and China.

title: A soldier speaks: public papers and speeches of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur;
summary: This collection demonstrates MacArthur's dedication to West Point and his patriotism, recounting his speeches during two world wars and his insights on Americanism.

title: Don't fall off the mountain.
summary: The author, known for her dancing and acting, shares her journey of discovery, public success, personal odyssey, and her view of fame.

title: You can get there from here.
summary: Covers the author's work for presidential candidate McGovern and her leading role in the first American women's delegation to China.

title: I, Mary MacLane: a diary of human days.
summary: A collection of prose images depicting herself and the world of Butte, Montana.

title: The story of Mary MacLane by herself.
summary: Written at nineteen, it contains her thoughts about her unhappy childhood, her desolate life, and her self-assessment.

title: The journal of William Maclay: United States Senator from Pennsylvania, 1789-1791.
summary: This journal contains Maclay's views on political issues and customs of the day, as well as various topics from religion to menus.

title: Champion of cause; essays and addresses on librarianship.
summary: This collection features essays and speeches from MacLeish's tenure as Librarian of Congress, focusing on modernizing the profession.

title: Green seas and white ice.
summary: Magnes recounts her experiences traveling 40,000 arctic miles as the wife of Arctic explorer Donald MacMillan.

title: The rewarding path: an autobiography.
summary: A self-serving account of his life from rural Nova Scotia to a successful career as a businessman.

title: Paintbrush ambassador.
summary: From acting to painting, the book recounts MacNicol's travels and experiences as a goodwill ambassador.

title: Charles E. Maddry: an autobiography.
summary: Maddry recounts his education and career in church leadership, detailing his work with the Southern Baptist Foreign Mission Board.

title: The orchard children.
summary: Maddux describes her family's experience of moving to Tennessee and adopting a baby girl.

title: My first seventy years.
summary: A lively account of Sister Madeleva's upbringing, education, and presidency at St. Mary's College.
other_places_lived: Wisconsin, Notre Dame, Indiana, California, Oxford

title: Memoirs and letters of Dolley Madison.
summary: Contains letters from 1796 to 1836 with personal matters and views on current events.

title: The papers of James Madison.
summary: Documents revealing Madison's involvement in American politics over nearly sixty years.

title: One step at a time: a young woman's inspiring struggle to walk again.
summary: Madruga's account of her hemipelvectomy and her journey to adjust and lead a normal life.

title: Autobiography of Clara Fisher Maeder.
summary: Recalls her experiences and the world of nineteenth-century theater.

title: Infinite riches; the adventures of a rare book dealer.
summary: A volume about the adventure of selling rare books and the special people in that world.

title: Nila: her story.
summary: The story of her life in Russia and adaptation to life in the United States.

title: Episodes: a memoir.
summary: Recalls memories linked by Judaism, offering warmth and descriptions of local customs.

title: Ring the night bell: the autobiography of a surgeon.
summary: The development of Magnuson's career as a bone and joint surgeon and head of the medical section at the Veterans' Association.

title: Down the Santa Fe Trail and into Mexico. The diary of Susan Shelby Magoffin, 1846-1847.
summary: An edited diary covering her experiences on the Santa Fe Trail and in Mexico.

title: The autobiography of Mrs. Tom Thumb: Some of my life experiences.
summary: Lavinia Warren Stratton reminisces about her travels as a dwarf circus performer, including extensive tours in the U.S. and Great Britain as well as Japan, China, India, and the Mediterranean. Her aristocratic self-image dominates even in meetings with General Grant and Queen Victoria.

title: An American life: one man's road to Watergate.
summary: The author writes mainly of his job in the Nixon administration focusing on the Watergate affair, the coverup, and its causes.

title: From power to peace.
summary: This is a confessional by a convicted Watergate conspirator who describes his participation in the political cover-up and his remorse.

title: From sail to steam: recollections of naval life.
summary: Mahan provides a detailed account of his naval career, including an extensive history of pre-Civil War naval vessels and the American naval penetration of China and Japan in the 1870's.

title: Autobiography: intellectual, moral, and spiritual.
summary: A spiritual autobiography by a Congregational minister includes few particulars of his life except the principles by which he guided his presidencies of Oberlin and Adrian Colleges.

title: Stan Mahoney: the adventures of a working man.
summary: This is a candid, engaging account of Mahoney's varied occupations as a truck driver, ship's fireman, oiler, mechanic, welder, and commercial fisherman.

title: Advertisements for myself.
summary: This is anything but a conventional autobiography; it is an analysis of his life in writing to date, with running commentary or advertisements providing a continuous structure for his development as a writer.

title: A tapestry of memories.
summary: Desiring to share her unusual experiences, the author has recorded episodes from her travels and singing engagements in Italy and Spain.

title: Seventy years on the frontier: Alexander Majors' memoirs of a lifetime on the border.
summary: Drawing upon his broad experiences of hunting, trapping, mining, farming, shipping, and traveling, Majors recalls the Western frontier of the 1800's.

title: Return to my father's house; a charter member of the American Communist Party tells why he joined — and why he later left to fight communism.
summary: Disillusioned with the Communist Party, he shares his experiences before and after communism.

title: Amber gold: an adventure in autobiography.
summary: Born in Trinidad, Maloney traces the development of his personality and character as he became a professor of pharmacology at Howard University.

title: Doctor Pygmalion: the autobiography of a plastic surgeon.
summary: The book recounts the life of a New York plastic surgeon, his patients, and the various operations he performed.

title: I live my life.
summary: A sprawling account of the author's California upbringing, education at Vassar and the University of California, practice of general medicine, and her travels around the world.

title: The nightmare season.
summary: Mandell, a psychiatrist, shares his involvement with the San Francisco Chargers football team and the difficulties encountered during that time.

title: Blood ties: a woman's history.
publisher: Moon Books and Random House, Inc.
summary: A feminist autobiography focusing on the author's early life and her family's escape from Yugoslavia during WWII.

title: Fanfare: the confessions of a press agent.
summary: Raised in Montana, Maney describes his life in the theatrical world over several decades.

title: Conversations with Frederick Manfred.
summary: Taped interviews with Manfred provide insights into his novels and their regional characters.

title: My days in Vietnam.
summary: Mangiolardo kept a diary of his experiences as a soldier in Vietnam, providing a raw account of the war.

title: "My dearest friend": the letters of A. Dudley Mann to Jefferson Davis, 1869-1889.
summary: The correspondence records their long friendship and Mann's experiences as a diplomat.

title: Ant hill odyssey.
summary: The book traces the development of the author's strong interest in insects and animals through his life.

title: Out of my time.
summary: The narrative weaves excerpts from the past with an imaginary dialogue around the author's life.

title: Step right up!
summary: The story of a traveling American carnival and the author's experiences working in various concessions.

title: Trumpet on the wing.
summary: Growing up in the world of jazz, Manone shares his experiences from youth in New Orleans to various cities in the U.S.

title: Personal memories, social, political, and literary, with sketches of many noted people, 1803-1843.
summary: The reminiscences of a lawyer and writer who describes Cincinnati and national events from the early nineteenth century.

title: Jayne Mansfield's wild, wild world.
summary: Movie actress Jayne Mansfield exploits her sexuality in a disjointed account of her life and experiences.

title: The education of a baseball player.
summary: His second book gives a detailed account of his father's influence on his baseball career and the challenges he faced.

title: Mickey Mantle story.
summary: Written after his first two years with the New York Yankees, it explores his early interest in baseball and his rise to stardom.

title: Road to Wimbleton.
summary: A champion at Wimbleton describes her childhood and the responsibilities of success.

title: Minding the store; a memoir.
summary: A memoir highlighting the success of the Nieman-Marcus enterprise and the author's insights on Texas and national politics.

title: Thirty years of army life on the border.
summary: Marcy records his first-hand experiences with the Indian nomads and the wild territories during his service as an army officer.

title: Song of America.
summary: A leading restaurateur shares his story of immigration to California and adaptation to American life.

title: My flag is down: the diary of a New York taxi driver.
summary: A collection of anecdotes reflecting the life of a taxi driver in New York City.

title: Crotchets and quavers: on revelations of an opera manager in America.
summary: An autobiography revealing details of the operatic and musical life in America during the pre-Civil War era.

title: From a political diary: Russia, the Ukraine, and America, 1905-1945.
summary: Political analysis of the author's experiences in Russia and America during and after the Revolution.
occupations: Justice of the Supreme Court of Appeals

title: The selected writings of John Marin.
summary: Includes letters and writings from various periods of the artist's life, addressing his friendships and artistic endeavors.

title: Roger Maris at bat.
summary: The story of his successful season in 1961 when he broke Babe Ruth's home-run record.

title: Old man trouble.
summary: Marke shares his life experiences as a seaman amidst various troubles and the challenges of racial prejudice.

title: Autobiography of William Colfax Markham.
summary: Markham recounts his experiences as an editor and his increasing involvement in local and national politics.

title: The letters of PFC Richard E. Marks, USMC.
summary: During fifteen months in the Marine Corps, Pfc. Marks wrote almost one hundred letters home, revealing his experiences in training and combat up until a few days before his death.

title: Julia Marlowe's story. As told to E.H. Sothern.
summary: Recorded by her husband and co-star, the narrative depicts her career as an outstanding stage actress until their retirement in 1924.

title: An auto worker's journal: the LAW from crusade to one-party union.
summary: Marquart discusses his life as an auto worker, focusing on his radical activities as a labor leader in the 1920's and 30's, providing an intimate view of the American labor movement.

title: Life and history of the Rev. Elijah P. Marrs.
summary: His experiences as a slave, in the U.S. Colored Artillery, and as a school teacher and Baptist minister.

title: The papers of John Marshall.
summary: The papers of Supreme Court Chief Justice Marshall include correspondence, account books, and other documents.

title: Together: annals of an Army wife.
summary: Recollections of her marriage to General George C. Marshall from 1930 through 1945.

title: Journeyman machinist en route to the stars: Stellafane to Palomar.
summary: An inspiring account of Marshall's career as a machinist and his interest in astronomy.

title: Lobbyist for the people: a record of fifty years.
summary: For over thirty years he organized and ran The People's Lobby in Washington.

title: Memories of a G.P.
summary: He describes his career as a doctor and his adaptation to advances in the medical profession.

title: Journey
summary: A moving, sensitive account of their family life which focuses on their son's struggle to survive hemophilia.

title: Across Spoon River: an autobiography
summary: Masters' gloomy cast of mind imposes a pessimistic interpretation on most of the events of his unhappy life.

title: Diary of Cotton Mather D.D., FR.S. for the year 1712
summary: This year of Mather's diary, written for his children, notes his proposed good deeds for each day and his achievements and shortcomings.

title: Selected letters of Cotton Mather
summary: Mather's letters touch on virtually every aspect of colonial American life and delineate the life and habits of one of colonial New England's most famous families.

title: First Lady of the Lighthouse: a biography of Winifred Holt Mather
publisher: The Lighthouse/New York Association for the Blind
summary: For forty years Winifred Holt worked tirelessly to establish lighthouses for rehabilitation, education, and employment of the blind.

title: From gun to gavel: the courtroom recollections of James Mathers of Oklahoma
summary: Mathers describes his experiences practicing law specializing in cases involving the death penalty in Oklahoma.

title: Talking to the moon
summary: An Osage Indian reflects on his years of retreat in the Oklahoma hills, recalling Osage myth and history.

title: Pitching in a pinch: or, baseball from the inside
summary: This book offers thoughtful advice on understanding and playing baseball from a legendary pitcher.

title: Master of the moving sea: the life of Captain Peter John Riber Mathieson
summary: An account of a ship's boy who rose to command fourteen vessels through his adventurous life at sea.

title: Education of a correspondent
summary: An experienced journalist reflects on his philosophy of liberalism through observations of totalitarian states.

title: A world in revolution; a newspaperman's memoir
summary: A memoir organized by countries where the author worked, including passages from his newspaper articles.

title: Under the influence: recollections of Robert Graves, Laura Riding, and friends
summary: The poet composes his autobiography by describing significant people in his life.

title: Born rebel; an autobiography
summary: Mays reflects on his upbringing in rural Black poverty and discusses his contributions to race relations.

title: The memoirs of Father Samuel Mazzuchelli, O.P.
name_of_translator: Maria Michele Armato, OP., and Mary Jeremy Finnegan, OP.
summary: Mazzuchelli's memoirs relate to his missions among various Indian tribes and his observations on Protestantism and Catholicism in the U.S.

title: The Civil War letters
publisher: Rutgers University Press for New Jersey Civil War Centennial Commission
summary: A collection of 637 letters by Colonel McAllister from the Civil War, providing an intimate view of battles and military life.

title: Society as I have found it
summary: McAllister describes his rise to social arbiter of America and provides insights on entering high society.

title: Between us and the dark.
summary: A moving account of her mental illness, of the painful discovery that she was not in control of her life, and of nearly five years spent in mental hospitals struggling for her recovery.

title: 1913Tom McCall, maverick: an autobiography.
summary: McCall's engaging life story depicts a dynamic person actively committed to Oregon, the state he governed, 1966-1974. Among his accomplishments were tax reforms, an anti-litter bottle-return drive, cleaning up the Willamette River, an energy-saving edict requiring businesses to dim their advertising signs, and the initiation of the campaign 'Visit Oregon, But Don't Stay.'

title: The two of us.
summary: Actress McCambridge describes her year of travel (1947) with her five-year-old son, John, to recover from a painful divorce. The trip to the Caribbean, England, Ireland, and Italy proved hectic, exhilarating, and therapeutic.

title: Private faces/public places.
summary: Abigail McCarthy relates her experiences with her husband as they began life together teaching and working for Christian renewal and then moved into the political scene. She evaluates the traditional role of political wives and of women in politics, telling also of important people and events including the 1968 campaign with its new constituency and tragic violence.

title: The year of the people.
summary: The story of one year, 1968 — his year as presidential candidate, when McCarthy challenged the traditional system in his attempt to run his campaign on issues rather than personalities, to restore power to the people, and to engender a new vitality in politics.

title: Memories of a Catholic girlhood.
summary: The story of a well-known writer's traumatic but often humorous childhood, spent with various relatives and in a Catholic girls' school, after the early death of her parents.

title: Nobody's perfect.
summary: A story, both funny and sad, of the Detroit Tigers pitcher who was ostensibly a highly successful athlete and businessman, but was also hopelessly indebt and seriously debilitated by gambling, doctors, drugs, and sex.

title: Her father's partner: the story of a lady lawyer.
summary: McClanahan recounts amusing, poignant, and otherwise memorable cases from her law practice in Chicago, 1915-1918, with the Legal Aid Society, and thereafter as her father's partner until he died in 1940. She is proud of women in the legal profession and champions their professional.

title: My eight presidents.
summary: McClendon, a White House press correspondent since Franklin Roosevelt's day, claims she asks some of the toughest questions at press conferences. Here she discusses her relationship with eight presidents but specifically deals with Eisenhower through Carter. Her closing chapters concern her fight against secrecy in the government.

title: Me and Kit.
summary: The story of his life in the theater, as a drama student, young actor, director, producer, and his long and interesting marriage to Katharine Cornell.

title: Potpourri: an autobiography.
summary: In her second autobiographical volume, she describes her girlhood in the Allegheny Mountains and her happiness with husband, daughter, and her art.

title: So dear to my heart.
summary: A Pennsylvania artist and poet reminisces about her childhood and early career.

title: Hey! Major, look who's here.
summary: He joined the U.S. Army at the age of fifteen and did a year and a half of overseas service during World War I. After the armistice, he remained in Germany as part of the Army of Occupation.

title: My autobiography.
summary: The founder and editor of McClure's Magazine writes of his Irish boyhood, his immigration to New York, the hardships of establishing a career as an editor, and the rewarding years of success. He was a friend and editor of many now famous writers, including Willa Cather, Robert Louis Stevenson, Ida Tarbell, and Stephen Crane.

title: We flew with one wing.
summary: McCollough wrote for his great-grandsons this account of his childhood near Oil City, Pennsylvania, and of his service as a machine gunner during World War I with the 168th Squadron, U.S. Air Service. He learned early to work hard, especially to keep the pump on the family's oil well running, even during blizzards. He taught in a one-room country school for two years before entering Gettysburg College at twenty. At the end of his junior year he joined the service and thoroughly enjoyed the excitement and danger of his air battles over France and Germany.

title: From Kansas farm boy to scientist: the autobiography of Elmer Verner McCollum.
summary: A fascinating account of McCollum's childhood on a Kansas farm; his education as a biochemist at the University of Kansas and at Yale; and his biochemical research in nutrition at the University of Wisconsin and at Johns Hopkins. McCollum speaks modestly about his discoveries of Vitamins A and D and international awards in nutrition and biochemistry.

title: By the way: an autobiography.
summary: The vivid recollections of a crusading Methodist bishop who lived at the center of social reform movements from the 1890's. After the Great Steel Striker of 1919, he led a vigorous campaign for labor reforms.

title: The gentleman and the tiger: the autobiography of George B. McClellan, Jr.
summary: The boyhood, political career, and professional life of a man who was associated with Tammany Hall as Mayor of New York (1903-09) and a professor of economic history at Princeton for over twenty years.

title: Faith victorious in the Kentucky mountains: the story of twenty-two years of spirit-filled ministry.
publisher: The author, by Light and Life Press
summary: Spiritual autobiography describing the education and work of a fundamentalist minister.

title: G.P.
summary: A physician describes his childhood in Egypt with his missionary parents, his education in the U.S., and experiences in medical school, in World War II, and in practice in Chestnut Hill, Pennsylvania.

title: The autobiography of Robert Earll McConnell.
summary: McConnell's autobiography depicts a successful fulfillment of the American dream. Born in Durango, Colorado, McConnell worked during school vacations in mines and on ranches. He graduated from the Columbia University School of Mines in 1910 and was employed in Mexico, Texas, and California as a mining engineer. In the 1920's as a partner of Foster, McConnell, Inc., a Wall Street brokerage specializing in mining-related businesses, he made a fortune. At 49 he retired and enjoyed living in Virginia and Florida while performing public service, especially on energy-related matters as Chairman of the National Engineers' Committee during World War II.

title: My patients were Zulus.
summary: Medical missionary describes forty years of work with the Zulus, including opening a dispensary and hospital and forming a medical school and nurses' training school.

title: A piece of tape: the Watergate story; fact and fiction.
summary: A key participant in the Watergate affair, McCord writes his account of that historic series of events. The book is divided into 'The break-in and its aftermath,' 'Key testimony before the Senate Watergate Committee,' and 'Summation and the future.'

title: Lady bullfighter: the autobiography of the North American matador.
summary: After seeing her first bullfight at seven, she dreamed of becoming a bullfighter and at 21 made her debut in the bull ring of Juarez. Her story is of the art, its discipline, sacrifice, and rewards.

title: Memoirs: broadcast over WGN, WGNB and the Mutual Broadcasting System.
summary: A brief, superficial sketch of autobiographical incidents from the youth of publisher McCormick, reflecting social and political events from the perspective of a wealthy and politically powerful scion. He briefly mentions the Spanish-American War, President McKinley, Mark Hanna, and other people and phenomena.

title: Tim McCoy remembers the West: an autobiography.
summary: An exceptionally well-written account of McCoy's varied life as a cowboy, rancher, movie star, and director of a circus cowboy-and-Indian show. McCoy became intimately acquainted with the last denizens of the open range, the Cheyenne, Blackfeet, and Sioux Indians, and was adopted into the Arapaho tribe. He brought hundreds of Indians from Wyoming, where his ranch was, to Hollywood to act in The Covered Wagon.

title: Roughnecks and gentlemen: memoirs of a maverick.
summary: Kicked out of high school, he earned money for a train ticket to British Columbia where he stayed with an aunt and uncle and began to learn the ways of the woods and wilderness. His life became a series of adventures—exploring Alaska; becoming a self-taught archaeologist, naturalist, and movie producer; becoming recognized as an expert on Frederic Remington and Charles Russell.

title: A star in the family; an autobiography in diary form.
summary: Tenor McCracken and his wife, mezzo-soprano Sandra Warfield, both opera singers, together tell the story of their careers, the discouragement, auditions, successes, and amusing incidents. One of their happiest experiences was singing together in the title roles of Samson and Delilah.

title: Dear Belle: letters from a cadet and officer to his sweetheart, 1858-1865.
summary: A narrative constructed from parts of McCrea's letters to Belle which were connected by Catton to tell the story of McCrea's experience at West Point and with the Army of the Potomac. The Civil War has been called the 'West Point War' since so many of the officers on both sides were Academy graduates (over 800 out of 1,000 at the beginning of the war). McCrea represents those well-trained graduates.

title: The mortgaged heart.
summary: A collection of essays, some previously unpublished, depicts her childhood in Georgia, her later life in New York, and the development of themes in her writing from personal moments to larger social commitments.

title: The autobiography of Billy McCune.
summary: In 1950 he was convicted of raping a Fort Worth suburban housewife, which sent him to Death Row. He was misclassified as psychotic, which placed him in a section reserved for lunatics and homosexuals; he spent much of his time in isolation wards and has never been seriously considered for parole. Lyon managed with great difficulty to get his manuscript approved and let out of prison.

title: With unabated trust: Major Henry McDaniel's love letters from Confederate battlefields as treasured in Hester McDaniel's bonnet box.
summary: Major McDaniel's letters to his fiancee Hester Felker reflect life in a Confederate Army unit as it fought and traveled throughout the South, particularly in Virginia. The letters are courtly and provide an understanding of military strategy as well as of events.

title: Union man.
summary: McDonald, who was president of the United Steelworkers of America for thirteen years, tells the story of the steel strikes of the postwar years, of John L. Lewis and the union movement, of the battle between the AFL and CIO, of industrial and political leaders, and of his own involvement in the union movement.
occupations: President of United Steelworkers of America

title: My mission in Israel, 1948-1951.
summary: Experiences and impressions of the first U.S. Ambassador to Israel during its early years by a man active in international affairs, particularly with refugees.

title: Mac: the autobiography of Ernest W. McFarland.
summary: The book, abundantly illustrated with photographs and anecdotes, reveals the essence of a politician's life and relations with constituents and colleagues. His expertise on water law was helpful in his local political offices. Elected to the U.S. Senate in 1942, he served as majority leader in the 82nd Congress and sponsored the G.I. Bill of Rights before returning to Arizona as governor, and then as Chief Justice of the Arizona Supreme Court.

title: Memoirs of a rose man: tales from Breeze Hill.
summary: Charming story of a well-known Pennsylvanian horticulturist and his garden.

title: The autobiography of J.W. McGarvey.
summary: Written as notes for a biography he intended his son to write, the book has curious switches from first to third person. It is the record of a Baptist minister and college professor who taught for 46 years at College of the Bible in Lexington, Kentucky.

title: My 66 years in the big leagues: the great story of America's national game by Connie Mack.
summary: Memoirs of both the man and the game to which he gave his life, written in commemoration of seventy-five years of the National League and fifty years of the American League. Connie Mack's recollections of his career as player, manager, and businessman include baseball lore and anecdotes about famous players.

title: A Trappist writes home: letters of Abbot Gerard McGinley, O.C.S.O. to his family.
summary: A collection of letters written 1926-55 by a Trappist-Cistercian monk at Our Lady of Gethseminai, Trappist, Kentucky, and Our Lady of the Genesee, Piffard, New York. The Trappist vows of silence and austerity are congenial to this devout ascetic whose correspondence continually proclaims: 'The Trappist life when lived to the core is so sweet; the core of Trappist life is Jesus, He is in me and I in Him, with Mary. Love is sweet and love is joy-giving. That is just what our life is if it be anything at all — love. All for Jesus, all for Jesus.'

title: Sixpence in her shoe.
summary: Written as a rebuttal to Betty Friedan's Feminine Mystique, this is a celebration of housewifery by the author of light verse and 17 books for children.

title: Heroes.
summary: McGinnis laments the loss of American heroes, describing such men as Eugene McCarthy, George McGovern, William Westmoreland, Daniel Berrigan, and expresses his sense of personal failure and depression.

title: Rodeo road; my life as a pioneer cowgirl.
summary: From age three when she jumped her burro over an irrigation ditch, the author rode horses — racing, jumping, trick riding, and rodeo riding all over the United States, in Europe, and the Orient.

title: Uphill; a personal story.
summary: Mrs. McGovern recalls what it was like to be the wife and partner of a politician — the official duties, the family decisions, the campaigning, especially presidential conventions and campaigning, the adversity and the rewards.

title: Grassroots: the autobiography of George McGovern.
summary: McGovern analyzes his career as a grassroots politician (trained first as a Methodist minister), serving as a South Dakota Congressman, 1957-62, and as a U.S. Senator for the next decade. As a liberal dove during the hawkish Vietnam War years, McGovern lost a Presidential campaign in 1972; he comments with insightful detail on both the war and the state of American politics.

title: The kitchen sink papers: my life as a househusband.
summary: With humor and insight, McGrady narrates the highs, the lows, and the humdrum moments of the year (1973-74) he stayed home to care for the house and three school-age children while his wife worked full-time to establish her plastics business. He learned firsthand the meaning of the women's movement as he experienced a life of caring for others, grocery shopping, cooking, running errands, and financial dependence.

title: Fighting back: one woman's struggle against cancer.
summary: The author tells the story of the difficult treatment for lung cancer in the United States and in Germany that enabled her to live three years more than expected, but with great physical pain and difficulty. Her valiant spirit to fight cancer, and her husband's help, are pervasive; various therapies (diet, medicine) help intermittently, but McGrail's condition eventually deteriorated.

title: I'd go back.
summary: Recollections of childhood escapades in a large, loving family in Brooklyn from the perspective of middle age, by a Catholic priest.

title: Up from the walking dead: the Charles McGregor story.
summary: Most of McGregor's first forty years were spent either as an armed robber or in prison (27 years, mostly in Sing Sing) for robbery or for murder, of which he claims he was wrongfully convicted. Released in 1968 for the third time, McGregor found friendship and a constructive purpose in life through Reality House and the Fortune Society for ex-convicts in New York. He achieved movie stardom in Blazing Saddles and Superfly.

title: Called for travelling.
summary: McGregor writes about coaching basketball all over the world, in countries as diverse as the Soviet Union and Peru. His book concerns his adventures teaching basketball clinics in European countries as well as supervising his American team worldwide.

title: White House physician.
summary: This is the story of FDR's health, his battle against the effects of infantile paralysis, his efforts to overcome the fatigue of his wartime exertions, and the final moments of cerebral hemorrhage brought on by overwork, as told by his friend and official physician, who denies the rumors that Roosevelt ever had cancer, stroke, or various operations.

title: A long way from home: an autobiography.
summary: The sensitive story of a Black poet from Jamaica who came to the United States in search of education and expression as a writer. Aided by editors Frank Harris, Max Eastman, and others, McKay published and joined radical literary circles, including the "Harlem Renaissance." He traveled to Russia but returned, repelled by communism. His prose work, including Home to Harlem and Banjo, won international acclaim.

title: The passion of Claude McKay; selected poetry and prose, 1912-1948.
summary: Although primarily a collection of his poetry and prose, this volume includes a selection of his letters. Of special interest are letters written to Max Eastman, which include comments on social problems in Harlem, his struggles to survive as a Black writer, and his later conversion to Catholicism.

title: My wide world.
summary: McKay had been featured on ABC's Wide World of Sports for a dozen years before the Munich Olympics in 1972. He uses his experience of that summer season to frame the story of his life as a sportscaster, though half the book is a detailed dramatic account of terrorism, death, and survival at Munich.

title: McKay: a coach's story.
summary: He began coaching the University of Southern California Trojans in 1969. He produced three national championships, seven Rose Bowl teams, and Heisman Trophy winners Mike Garrett and O.J. Simpson. His book tells that story.

title: All about Eileen.
summary: A collection of essays, many previously published, about her life with her sister. Eileen and her husband, Nathaniel West, were killed in an automobile accident in 1941; the volume serves as memorial to her.

title: Far, far from home.
summary: In 1947 the author and her husband, both writers, moved to Belgium for two years, ostensibly to write screenplays on European locations. The book tells the humorous story of their adapting to life with their three small children in a country foreign to them in every way, including the language.

title: Love story.
summary: The author of My Sister Eileen describes her life in Greenwich Village after her secret marriage to Mike Lyman, editor of the left-wing publication, New Masses. Both became screenwriters in Hollywood, where they were divorced. The book satirizes many groups, from labor organizers to avant-garde writers.

title: Sgt. Mickey and General Ike.
summary: Assigned as an orderly to Colonel Eisenhower when he was at Fort Sam Houston, he stayed with him through the duration of the war. His book provides an informal, behind-the-scenes picture of Eisenhower and a rather shy, simple self-portrait.

title: Finding my father: one man's search for identity.
summary: This is the story of the poet's exhaustive search for his father who had abandoned his mother before McKuen's birth. He describes his youth, the shock of discovering he was illegitimate, and the reasons for his decision to find his father. Interspersed throughout the book are McKuen's poems.

title: Reminiscences, 1827-1897.
summary: Since his father was a senator from Delaware and U.S. Minister to London, McLane was from an early age aware of political and diplomatic affairs. Here he writes of his youth and his own career as lawyer, state legislator, congressman, commissioner to China, and governor of Maryland.

title: Father struck it rich.
summary: A salty tale of her flamboyant, outrageous progression through Eastern high society. A good-hearted, hard-drinking, high-living free spender, owner of the Hope Diamond, and friend of President Harding, McLean was sobered by her son's death and her husband's permanent hospitalization for alcoholism.

title: People's Padre: an autobiography.
summary: After 25 years in a Franciscan seminary and priesthood, he left the church to become a hospital administrator. His book includes an account of his persecution and harassment by Catholic priests and lay people.

title: John McLoughlin's business correspondence, 1847-48.
summary: An important pioneer businessman in Oregon, McLoughlin worked for Hudson's Bay Company and played a major part in the problems and struggles of the frontier community of Oregon City. Appendixes provide shipping data, biographical notes, and a bibliography.

title: Letters of Dr. John McLoughlin: written at Fort Vancouver 1829-1832.
publisher: Binford and Mort for the Oregon Historical Society
summary: Letters copied in a book by an assistant from the head of the Columbia District of the Hudson's Bay Company in Fort Vancouver, Washington, provide a remarkable view of the work and living conditions in the Northwest. Well-written appendixes give useful information and details.

title: What, you a priest!: Father Tom, pastor.
summary: McMahon, pastor of St. Jude the Apostle Church in South Holland, Illinois, recalls special masses, a visit from Pope Paul VI, athletic contests, banquets, communions, and other activities within his parish.

title: This is my life.
summary: With obvious pride in family, accomplishments, and material wealth, McNary discusses his career as a banker in El Paso, Texas, and lumber company president in Arizona and Louisiana. Active in business (lumber), fraternal and political organizations, McNary was almost rewarded in 1924 when President Harding nominated him for Comptroller of the Currency, but the Senate refused to confirm the appointment.

title: Four white horses and a brass band.
summary: A plainly told but rather grisly story of a young girl from Minnesota, addicted to opium at 18 by a medicine show operator who pretended to marry her, then trained her in the "arts" of his profession.

title: Lord, give me this mountain.
summary: With zealous thanksgiving to God, McNeil provides an account of the Mwingi Mission she helped establish in Kenya. Bible verses and testimonies are the backdrop for the building of Christian faith among the natives there and the missionaries' efforts to receive a land grant from the Kenyan government for their mission and hospital.

title: Forest McNeir of Texas.
summary: A garrulous account of McNeir's life, including several courtships, a fifty-year marriage to Stella, mother of his five adored children, and an occupation as a building contractor. McNeir was a member of the 1920 U.S. Olympic trapshooting team and recounts innumerable trapshooting meets in which he won many championships.

title: My son Johnny.
summary: A journalist best known for his work in the New Yorker describes his delight in being a father and his warm affection for his son.

title: The story of my life.
summary: The manuscript on which this book is based was written before her death; in addition, sermon notes, publications, and other documents furnished material which the editor has arranged to make a continuous narrative of her ministry.

title: Running a message parlor: a librarian's medium-rare memoir about censorship.
summary: McShean writes in anecdotal form about his constant battle against censorship of library books and records in Roswell, New Mexico, home of the John Birch Society.

title: The education of Carey McWilliams.
summary: A highly analytic, thoroughly detailed account of author's liberal political education for 25 years as editor of The Nation and long as a writer of numerous books, including four on victimized minorities — Jews, Japanese-Americans, Hispanics, and migrant workers. A highly principled man, he used his talents to crusade against the Cold War and the Vietnam War, to which he devotes considerable space here.

title: Parish priest.
summary: Father McWilliams describes his 25-year career as priest of St. Michael's parish in the tough horseshoe district of Jersey City, New Jersey. His parishioners, Irish, Polish, Italian, experienced the joys and traumas of birth and death, sin and salvation, material hardship and sometimes spiritual wealth, all of which McWilliams willingly shared.

title: Blackberry winter; my earlier years.
summary: Anthropologist Mead writes of her life up to World War II, including her schooling, the influence of professors on her choice of career, her family, friends, three marriages, pioneering early field trips to Samoa, New Guinea, and Bali, and the opposition she overcame as a young woman studying primitive peoples in the South Seas.

title: Letters from the field, 1925-1975.
summary: Mead's collected letters discuss her field work in Samoa, Manus, the Admiralty Islands, New Guinea, Bali, and on an Omala Indian Reservation in 1930. She describes the anthropological methodology she was developing and her immersion in the ongoing life of other peoples, other cultures.

title: Margaret Mead: some personal views.
summary: This collection of Mead's columns from Redbook Magazine, 1963-1979, contains her forthright views on cultures around the world. Her topics include the relations among men, women, and children; primitive and more "civilized" societies; government and politics; religion; education; and "personal choices" — places she would like to live, her daydreams, her views on the proper balance between solitude and sociality, and sketches of her female role models.

title: Diary for 1861.
summary: The diary recalls events in the life and work of a prominent Georgia citizen.

title: see Franklin, Benjamin.
summary: N/A

title: Come and see.
summary: Medema, a Christian composer and pianist, describes his musical ministry and his happy marriage to Joyce, a music therapist and student at Union Theological Seminary. Blind from birth, Medema nevertheless leads an energetic life of concert tours. His book is intended to provide an inspiring example of faith, optimism, and love.

title: Klondike diary: true account of the Klondike Rush, 1897-1898.
summary: Written in his seventies on the basis of letters, notes, and his diary, the book describes his adventures in the Alaskan Gold Rush.

title: Autobiography of a mountain man, 1805-1889.
summary: Brief narrative of the fortunes and failures of a trapper, prospector, and guide in the Western frontier.

title: Chicago, with love: a polite and personal history.
summary: He grew up in Chicago society of the rich and famous, capturing the essence of an era now vanished.

title: We are your sons; the legacy of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg; written by their children. And Michael Meeropol.
summary: The sons of the Rosenbergs tell their own story of the trial, appeals, and execution of their parents.

title: Out of their league.
summary: The author, a former linebacker, explains why he quit football, viewing the game as vicious and dehumanizing.

title: Apron full of gold: the letters of Mary Jane Megquier from San Francisco, 1849-1856.
summary: Vivid description of her journey from Maine through the Panama Canal to California during the Gold Rush.

title: From pillar to post.
summary: Cultural conflicts as her family moves through Mexico, the U.S., and Europe.

title: Persia revisited.
summary: Describes their return to Iran, emphasizing cultural differences.

title: Persian adventure.
summary: A record of her marriage to Mohammed Mehdevi and their journey to Iran reflecting cultural clashes.

title: My life.
summary: The remarkable story of the woman who became Prime Minister of Israel.

title: Philippine diary, 1939-1945.
summary: Records the agony and humiliation of life in a Japanese penal colony and the heroism of survival.

title: On being a missionary.
summary: Describes his years between World Wars I and II as a missionary in China.

title: Journal of a visit to Europe and the Levant, October 11, 1856-May 6, 1857.
volume: Princeton University Studies in English, no. 35
summary: A record of his observations during a crucial period of his literary career.

title: Journal of a visit to London and the continent, 1849-1850.
summary: Unpublished journal of Melville's first trip abroad, reflecting his thoughts during the journey.

title: The letters of Herman Melville.
summary: A collection of 271 letters, revealing insights into Melville's life and relationships.

title: Letters from Attica. Profiles of the author by Jane Alpert and John Cohen.
summary: Melville's letters reveal his struggles and leadership during the Attica Prison riots.

title: Whose heaven, whose earth? And Marjorie Melville.
summary: A narrative of a young priest and a nun forming a guerrilla band to champion the cause of the poor.

title: A choice of days: essays from Happy Days, Newspaper Days and Heathen Days.
summary: Essays reflecting Mencken's happy childhood and early newspaper days.

title: Days of H.L. Mencken: happy days, newspaper days, heathen days.
summary: Random reminiscences from a busy journalist's life.

title: Letters of H.L. Mencken.
summary: A selection of Mencken's correspondence with his contemporaries.

title: The new Mencken letters.
summary: A representative selection of Mencken's extensive correspondence.

title: I lost a king.
summary: An account of the author’s overseas service as a physician during World War I and beyond.

title: It took nine tailors.
summary: Describes boyhood in Cleveland and New York, emphasizing his film acting career.

title: Sparks.
summary: Compilation of notes, articles, speeches, and letters reflecting the mind of Dr. Menninger.

title: Unfinished journey.
summary: Menuhin writes of his musical career and humanistic concerns.

title: Three years in Mississippi.
summary: Meredith's story of his struggle to attend the University of Mississippi, marking a historic moment.

title: My life on the mountains and on the plains; the newly discovered autobiography.
summary: Dictated account of Meriwhether's experiences as an Indian trader and territorial governor.

title: Merman: an autobiography.
summary: An account of Merman's theatrical career and personal life.

title: Who could ask for anything more.
summary: Merman reflects on her theatrical career and personal life.

title: Green Mountain farm.
summary: Describes life on a small Vermont farm during the Great Depression.

title: Son of Salem: the autobiography of John Merrill.
summary: Merrill emphasizes his formative years and education in Salem, and a brief acting career.

title: Between acts: an irreverent look at opera and other madness.
summary: Merrill shares tales from over 40 years in the performing arts, including opera.

title: An American child: the beginning of an autobiography, by Mary Weston (pseud.).
summary: An author recalls her girlhood in New York and her English boarding school experience.

title: Merritt and the Indian wars; three Indian campaigns.
summary: General Merritt describes his attitudes toward war-making against the Indians post-Civil War.

title: My twenty years in Congress.
publisher: Society for the Publication of New Hampshire Biographies
summary: A summary of his major votes and philosophy of government.

title: A catch of anti-letters: Thomas Merton and Robert Lax.
summary: The friendship between Merton and Lax, both of whom retreated from the world post-conversion.

title: The secular journal of Thomas Merton.
summary: Covers his life at Columbia and early struggles before becoming a monk.

title: The seven storey mountain.
summary: Explores Merton's dual life as a monk and poet.

title: Hope: a loss survived.
summary: Details Meryman's experience of his wife's cancer and subsequent life as a widower.

title: Perle: my story.
summary: A society leader discusses her life among the elite and her experiences as an ambassador.

title: Random recollections of an anachronism; or seventy-five years of library work.
summary: Recollections spanning Metcalf's library career, highlighting achievements in public and academic libraries.

title: Out of these roots: the autobiography of an American woman.
summary: An autobiography reflecting on her roots and experiences as an American woman.

title: Assignment Tokyo; an ambassador's journal.
summary: A career diplomat, Meyer became Ambassador to Japan in 1969, when Japan had become one of the world's three leading industrial powers. His book concentrates on his diplomatic role, emphasizing the significance and gravity of America's relationship with Japan.

title: For goodness sake! Growing up in a New England parsonage.
summary: One of five children in a Methodist minister's family, she writes of the lively mischievous days of her childhood in a home ruled by codes of physical and spiritual economy.

title: Hey! Yellowbacks; the war diary of a conscientious objector.
summary: Expelled from the University of Wisconsin for his refusal to serve in World War I, imprisoned, tried three times, and finally released after the armistice, Meyer described his experiences in various military camps. Despite his unpleasant treatment, he feels that "the American government, officially, dealt more humanely and generously with war objectors than did any other nation."

title: Goodbye Columbus, hello medicine.
summary: Meyers writes of becoming a family practitioner, beginning with medical school, through internship and residency. He includes anecdotes about typical cases, ranging from obstetrical to alcoholic to pediatric. While in medical school, Meyers played a role in Goodbye, Columbus and other films and was on various television talk shows.

title: A term to remember.
summary: Mezvinsky was elected to Congress in 1972 as a Democrat from Iowa's first district, just as the taint of the Watergate scandal was about to reach the Oval Office. He joins an account of the Congressional hearings, which he attended as a member of the House Judiciary Committee, with fragments of his disintegrating family life and ultimate divorce, another consequence of the stress of politics.

title: Really the blues.
summary: The world of jazz by one who knew it well, including translations and a glossary of jive talk, discussions of what is jazz, and the ways in which Chicago style differs from that of New Orleans.

title: Inside Tin Pan Alley.
summary: Her experience trying to make a career as a songwriter, with one song that did become a hit, "Strange and Sweet," focuses on the difficulty a woman had breaking into the business world.

title: These things are mine: the autobiography of a journeyman playwright.
summary: Well-written narrative of his life in the theater — stage and screen — with interesting details about his literary friends and famous contemporaries.

title: Memoirs of a pioneer surgeon.
