summary: This book, written in 1936, is a straightforward account of Middleton's experiences as a Mormon farm youth in Utah, his medical education in Baltimore and London, and his pioneering surgical practice in Cedar City, Utah, 1895-1932. The surgeon loves his work, his Mormon heritage, the hardiness of the Western pioneers, and the rocky terrain of Utah and the Colorado River area.

title: A view from a broad.
summary: A series of one-liners that describe a comic entertainer's tour of Europe, including England, Scandinavia, France, and Australia. She calls it a "monumental schlep."

title: The laughter and the tears.
summary: In a style highlighted by underlinings, ellipses, and Bible quotations, gospel musician Mieir recounts her musical ministry to the United States and the Orient. She intersperses her story with lyrics and music she has written. Her work has included support of Korean orphans and mixed-blood offspring of American servicemen in Korea and placement with foster parents in America. Two of her own children are adopted.

title: The trouble bush.
summary: Miers explains his metamorphosis from a scrawny Brooklyn child with cerebral palsy through training as a journalist, first as a high school stringer and later at Rutgers. His editorial positions at Rutgers University Press and Alfred A. Knopf are proof that a handicapped person can lead a useful and enjoyable life.

title: The autobiography of Robert A. Millikan.
summary: Research physicist with international administrative responsibilities reflects upon the events of his life and career, including philosophic observations about the prolific growth of scientific knowledge during the past hundred years.

title: The lady driller: the autobiography of N. Elizabeth Mills.
summary: Mills chronicles a varied life from near poverty and warring over homestead claims in Nebraska to eventual success as 'The Lady Driller' of oil wells in Oklahoma and Texas.

title: Education of an American liberal.
summary: A social worker from Missouri describes her work as a secretary for the American Civil Liberties Union in New York City from the time the organization began.

title: Beneath the underdog; his world as composed by Mingus.
summary: A self-portrait of a musician and jazz composer confronts his experiences in poverty-stricken childhood, outcast adolescence, and an adulthood haunted by guilt and self-hatred.

title: Maria Mitchell, life, letters, and journals.
summary: Selections from the astronomer's letters and journals from 1847 to her death are bound together by the compiler's commentary.

title: My own diary: the diary of an analysis.
summary: Diary entries during the six years in which she consulted an analyst reveal her struggle to overcome depression and develop an independent identity.

title: Mitchell of California: the memoirs of Sydney B. Mitchell, librarian, teacher and gardener.
summary: Mitchell describes the places he lived and worked during the first half of his life — Montreal, Albany, and Palo Alto.

title: I remember it well.
summary: A remarkable narrative of Hollywood in the Forties, Fifties, and Sixties, written by an outstanding director of musicals.

title: A fine old conflict.
summary: The author describes her membership in the American Communist Party and her disenchantment and resignation.

title: The road I came: the memoirs of a Russian-American forester.
summary: A well-written, richly descriptive story of the author's life in pre-revolutionary Russia where he studied forestry.

title: Hons and rebels.
summary: N/A

title: Anchored to the rock.
publisher: Printed for the author by Gospel Trumpet Co.
summary: A third person narrative of her lifelong devotion to the church, as a minister and minister's wife in the rural South.

title: Navajo Blessingway singer: the autobiography of Frank Mitchell.
summary: One of the first Navajo children to attend the Fort Defiance boarding school, his book describes the Blessingway rites he practices.

title: Two lives: the story of Wesley Clair Mitchell and myself.
summary: The story of a remarkable marriage and notable careers.

title: Margaret Mitchell's Gone with the Wind letters: 1936-1949.
summary: Mitchell's correspondence concerning her only book, Gone With the Wind.

title: Violent innocence.
summary: Account of privileged and precious childhood in Mexico (1911-1921), including experiences with tutors and travel to the United States during the Mexican Revolution.

title: Mockridge, you're slipping!
summary: He writes of his life in journalism with humorous nostalgia.

title: Memories and impressions; an autobiography.
summary: A magnificent actress in her time writes of her early life and theatrical experience in Poland and her career in San Francisco and New York.

title: Moffat papers: selections from the diplomatic journals of Jay Pierrepont Moffat, 1919-1943.
summary: The diaries of a prominent diplomat provide detailed accounts of his personal, family, and professional interests.

title: Diary of a journey from the Mississippi to the coasts of the Pacific: with a United States Government expedition.
summary: Mollhausen, a German artist and naturalist, accompanied an American expedition emphasizing the relationship of geography, landscape, history, and populations.

title: And then there were eight.
summary: A journalist writes of his pride and pleasure in his eight children and the importance of family-centered values.

title: Names: a memoir.
summary: Momaday pays homage to his Cherokee and Kiowa ancestors in this warm memoir.

title: The way to Rainy Mountain.
summary: At the center of this book is his journey to his birthplace in the heartland of the Kiowa Indians.

title: A poet's life: seventy years in a changing world.
summary: Poet, dramatist, and critic tells of her Chicago childhood and her literary and artistic careers.

title: The autobiography of James Monroe.
summary: Focuses on the years 1776-1807, in which his political career prepared him for the Presidency.

title: The writings of James Monroe, including a collection of his public and private papers and correspondence.
summary: Distinguished by more than fifty years of public service and includes his experience as a soldier, legislator, member of Congress, and President.
occupations: Soldier, legislator, member of Congress, President

title: My story.
summary: She tells her own version of her sad, loveless childhood and the difficulties in breaking into Hollywood's charmed circle.

title: It was fun while it lasted: the memories and musings of a real American 'Old-Timer.'
summary: A narrative of an army lieutenant's life and philosophy written during a tour of duty in Panama.

title: Memories: an autobiography.
summary: Montana describes his childhood in Italy, his emigration to New York, and his studies at Cooper Union.

title: Hail to the chiefs; my life and times with six presidents.
summary: On the Washington scene for 25 years, she writes about White House anecdotes and how she became involved with psychic personalities.

title: Coming of age in Mississippi.
summary: Her childhood, education, and involvement in the Civil Rights movement in Mississippi.

title: Home ranch.
summary: Recollections of his boyhood in the cattle country of Colorado.

title: Little britches: father and I were ranchers.
summary: His book tells of his delight in ranch life, the values of country living, and the close ties with his father.

title: Man of the family.
summary: A restaurateur and author recalls his experience in Colorado after his father's death.

title: Mary Emma & company.
summary: This book describes their struggle to make a living with a sense of spirit and love after his father's death.

title: Reprieve from hell.
summary: A dramatic account of Moody's participation as a soldier in the American defeat at Corregidor and in the Bataan Death March.

title: Some letters of William Vaughn Moody.
summary: Moody's letters are doubly interesting for their literary charm and revelations.

title: Mustard plasters and printer's ink: a kaleidoscope of a country doctor's observations about people, places, and things.
summary: A sentimental, folksy account of Moore's life, education, and medical practice.

title: The Archie Moore story.
summary: His book describes his life in the ring, emphasizing boxing's common prejudices.

title: Bishop to all peoples.
summary: N/A

title: Heritage of freedom.
summary: Moore emphasizes the backwoods Methodist and Baptist religions of his childhood in Kentucky, his rural schooling, and his judicial career, with his landmark ruling to uphold the Turnpike Act authorizing construction of the West Virginia Turnpike.

title: Silent star.
summary: She started playing in silent movies in 1917. In the early Twenties she bobbed her hair and became the first flapper in the movies. Her memoir is well-stocked with the glitter of Hollywood's golden era.

title: Roman collar.
summary: Written in response to the frequent question 'what does a priest do with his time?' by a priest who ministered at St. Peter's in New York and worked for years at Catholic charities.

title: Lead me to the exit.
summary: Born in poverty, she writes of her unconventional career as domestic servant, social worker, and college teacher.
occupations: Domestic servant, social worker, college teacher

title: Souls and saddlebags: the diaries and correspondence of Frank L. Moore, western missionary, 1888-1896.
summary: His letters and diary entries provide an interesting view of frontier life in Wyoming and northern Colorado during territorial days.

title: A special rage.
summary: As a Black journalist assigned to write about the Black Panther Party for Life Magazine, Moore came to know its leaders and followed closely the Huey Newton affair.

title: Unmasked; the story of my life on both sides of the barrier.
summary: Speaking out for equality of women of minority groups, she recalls her youth and later life and her struggles against prejudice.

title: I'll meet you in the lobby.
summary: Lively, energetic story of her work as a lobbyist in Washington, D.C., and as a staff writer for the U.S. Office of War Information in England during World War II.

title: Diary: a trip from New York to the Falls of St. Anthony in 1845.
summary: A travel diary depicting the conditions of river and coach travel and an interesting view of the times.

title: Shepherd of Times Square.
summary: An account of the leadership of the Manhattan Church of the Nazarene, where he ministered to a dynamic congregation of diverse backgrounds.

title: Dateline Chicago; a veteran newsman recalls its heyday.
summary: Moore recreates the 'Front Page' era of Chicago journalism when gangsters, dance marathons, and spicy divorces were of more interest than Washington or world news.

title: Pioneer doctor.
summary: Physician reflects upon his medical practice during a fifty-year period of growth and change in scientific knowledge.

title: Journal of Madison Berryman Moorman, 1850-1851.
summary: Well-written narrative of his travels west over part of the Oregon Trail, then through Utah and the California Plains.

title: The journal of Benjamin Moran, 1857-1865.
summary: An assistant secretary of the U.S. legation in London records the friction between the two countries and describes people and incidents in his daily life.

title: Home-thoughts, from afar: letters of Thomas Moran to Mary Nimmo Moran.
summary: A collection of letters Moran wrote to his wife during various trips, providing insights into his travels and artistic experience.

title: Moreau de St. Mery's American journey: 1793-1798.
summary: A frank and detailed commentary on American life in the late eighteenth century, including observations on various aspects of society.

title: The saving grace.
summary: The author's sense of humor is manifested in anecdotes from her years in nursing, detailing her extensive travels and various jobs.

title: Just the other day: from Yellow Pines to Broadway.
summary: The story of his boyhood in rural Georgia, his early years in journalism, and his success as a drama critic for the New York Sun.

title: Mountains of the mind.
summary: Morelock describes his upbringing in Appalachian Tennessee and major accomplishments including the presidency of Sul Ross State College.

title: Magic city doctor.
summary: Morey focuses on his career in Millinocket, Maine, describing his invention and various medical cases.

title: One man, one voice.
summary: Morgan concerns himself with Civil Rights and the injustices Blacks have suffered in America, including accounts of the Watergate scandal.

title: Time to speak.
summary: Morgan's account following a bomb attack on a Black Baptist church in Birmingham, detailing his life and commitment to improve conditions there.

title: The making of a woman surgeon.
summary: Morgan relates her odyssey through medical school and surgery, detailing the challenges faced by women in the field.

title: Gift from the hills; Miss Lucy Morgan's story of her unique Penland School.
summary: Miss Lucy directed the Penland Craft School, teaching and preserving old-time craft skills.

title: Personal reminiscences of the war of 1861-5; in camp, en bivouac, on the march, on picket, on the skirmish line, on the battlefield and in prison.
summary: Morgan recorded memories of his experiences as a Confederate soldier during the Civil War.

title: I have considered my days.
summary: Morgenstern describes his early life in Lithuania, his voyage to the United States, and his activities within the Jewish community.

title: By sea to San Francisco, 1849-1850.
summary: Morison writes about his six-month journey by ship from New England to San Francisco, including observations on flora and fauna.

title: One boy's Boston: 1887-1901.
summary: A prominent historian recalls his childhood in a prominent Boston family.

title: The papers of Robert Morris, 1781-1784.
summary: This edition includes the official diary, correspondence, and other documents of Robert Morris during his administration as Superintendent of Finance, 1781-1784.

title: North toward home.
summary: Raised on the Mississippi Delta, educated at the University of Texas and Oxford, and then transplanted to New York City, the editor of Harper's Magazine tells of his growth and maturation in this probing and sometimes funny book.

title: As the river flows: the autobiography of John A. Morrison.
summary: Raised in a large, poor family in the Missouri Ozarks, educated only through the eighth grade, he trained himself for the ministry of the Church of God, founded and became president of Anderson College in Indiana.

title: My ten years as a counterspy.
summary: During 1948-58 Russian-born film producer Morros was an F.B.I. counterspy to track down Jack and Myra Soble and others in league with the Russians during the Cold War.

title: The Mexican years: leaves from the diary of Elizabeth Cutter Morrow.
publisher: Elizabeth Cutter Morrow, The Spiral Press
summary: Selections from Mrs. Morrow's diary during the time her husband was U.S. Ambassador to Mexico, 1927-30.

title: Scientist with Perry in Japan: the journal of Dr. James Morrow.
summary: A record of his agricultural work and travels with the Perry Expedition in Japan and China (1853-1854), as a representative of the Department of Agriculture.

title: First American Ambassador to Guinea.
summary: Morrow's tenure as U.S. Ambassador to the newly independent country of Guinea lasted from 1959 to 1961.

title: Civil War diaries of Bliss Morse.
summary: Diaries for the years 1858, 1860, and 1862 through 1866 provide a view of an infantry corporal from Ohio who fought through the South on Sherman's march to the sea.

title: Organize! my life as a union man.
summary: Mortimer was close to the center of labor union activities in the 1930's.

title: It has its charms ....
summary: A newspaperman and editor, he worked on the Boston Evening Transcript, then for the government Social Security Board, and finally for The Atlantic Monthly.

title: My first sixty years; passion for wisdom.
summary: Her struggles to win her education and to overcome discrimination have shaped her life. She became the first Negro to receive a doctorate in English at Western Reserve and thereafter devoted herself to educating young people.

title: Seventy years a preacher: the life story of the Rev. William H. Moser, Ph.D., militant Methodist preacher.
publisher: The Historical Society of the New York Annual Conference of the Methodist Church
summary: Moser, a militant, itinerant Methodist preacher, crusaded for fifty years throughout New York State for God and for temperance.

title: The art and life of Grandma Moses.
summary: This edition contains reproductions of her pictures, essays about her by Louis Bromfield, and comments on her art by European papers.

title: Grandma Moses: my life's history.
summary: Recollections of her childhood in New York state, her young married life in Virginia, her return to New York state, and her development as a painter.

title: Jimmy Moss.
summary: The story of a Mormon teacher who devoted his life to education, sports, and the church.

title: Rough and tumble: the autobiography of a West Texas judge.
summary: Moss describes his fifty years as a lawyer and cattle rancher, mostly in his beloved Odessa, Texas.

title: The correspondence of John Lothrop Motley.
summary: An historian and diplomat, Motley studied and wrote about the history of the Dutch Republic and of the United Netherlands.

title: The diaries of Willard Motley.
summary: Covering the years 1926 to 1943, a Black writer's diary contains personal notes about friends and jobs.

title: Time enough: essays in autobiography.
publisher: The University of North Carolina Press
summary: In essays about his life in the business and profession of journalism, he emphasizes the need to avoid the tyranny of time.

title: Slavery and 'The Woman Question': Lucretia Mott's diary of her visit to Great Britain to attend the World's Anti-Slavery Convention of 1840.
summary: A revealing picture of the convention Mott attended as a delegate, but refused official recognition and participation because she was a woman.

title: Stuff it: the story of Dick Motta, toughest little coach in the NBA.
summary: A controversial coach in the NBA, Motta was named Coach of the Year in 1971.

title: Memoir of the American Revolution: so far as it related to the states of North and South Carolina and Georgia.
summary: Moultrie, a major general in the U.S. Army during the Revolutionary War, has compiled his correspondence about military matters in the American Revolution.

title: Mountain Wolf Woman, Sister of Crashing Thunder: the autobiography of a Winnebago Indian.
summary: Written from taped interviews, the book describes growing up in and between two cultures in Wisconsin.

title: Journalist's wife.
summary: She married Edgar Mowrer, the Paris correspondent of the Chicago Daily News, in 1916 and spent her life involved in large history-making events.

title: Mormon Democrat: the religious and political memoirs of James Henry Moyle.
publisher: Historical Department of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
summary: A lawyer and Assistant Secretary of the Treasury under Henry Morgenthau until 1940, Moyle was also a leader in the Mormon church.

title: A dangerous place.
summary: A journal and commonplace book, this volume describes the author's part in recent ideas and events that contributed to the emergence of human rights as an issue of American foreign policy.

title: Skin deep: the making of a plastic surgeon.
summary: A vigorous, engrossing narrative of Dr. Moynihan's two-year residency in plastic surgery at a university hospital in southern California.

title: Bell in the heart: the autobiography of Patty Gardenseed, America's ambassador of goodwill.
summary: The adventures of a U.S. Navy boxer who became the Navy welterweight champion during World War I.

title: At General Howe's side, 1776-1778; the diary of General William Howe's aide de camp.
summary: Muenchhausen's command of German, French, and English made him a valuable aide to Howe and an intermediary during the American Revolution.

title: The journals of Henry Melchior Muhlenberg.
summary: An important religious leader of eighteenth-century America, Muhlenberg acted as a missionary bishop.

title: The notebook of a colonial clergyman: condensed from the journals of Henry Melchior Muhlenberg.
summary: The record of a German Lutheran minister in southeastern Pennsylvania, selected from their three-volume edition.

title: Headline happy.
summary: Primarily the work experience of a journalist who was an outstanding reporter for the New York Daily News and the Los Angeles Mirror.

title: John of the mountains: the unpublished journals of John Muir.
summary: These journals, starting with 1869, are some of the most noteworthy of the sixty written by Muir covering his career as a naturalist.

title: I was a country girl.
summary: Life in rural Texas and Louisiana by a woman who was brought up to the teaching of the Good Book during the late nineteenth century.

title: White coat, clenched fist: the political education of an American physician.
summary: Mullan dramatically recounts his years of social and political activism as a medical student and intern at Lincoln Hospital.

title: Let justice be done.
summary: Partially intended as a model for young lawyers, the book focuses on his life in the law.

title: I, pig, or how the world's most famous cop, me, is fighting City Hall.
summary: A tough Chicago cop who has spent his life enforcing the letter of the law and taken much abuse for doing it.

title: My pilgrim journey: the making of an evangelist.
summary: Housewife evangelist Mullings has written an account of her childhood and Presbyterian schooling in Jamaica.

title: The will to win: An inside view of the world of tennis.
summary: A tennis champ tells the story of his notable athletic achievements, particularly at Wimbledon.

title: Star to steer by.
summary: The adventures of a U.S. Navy boxer who became the Navy welterweight champion during World War I.

title: The letters of Lewis Mumford and Frederic J. Osborn: a transatlantic dialogue 1938-70.
summary: The letters detail the friendship between Mumford and Osborn, focusing on their common interests and contributions to city planning.

title: My works and days: a personal chronicle.
summary: A collection of discussions on various topics from the perspective of a social critic, poet, and historian.
occupations: social and literary critic, poet, historian

title: Mister Charlie: memoir of a Texas lawman, 1902-1910.
summary: Describes life at the turn of the century in Lavaca County, Texas, as seen through the eyes of a lawman.

title: Thurman Munson: an autobiography.
summary: An autobiography of the famous New York Yankees player detailing his life and career.

title: Journey into truth: The autobiography of a Catholic convert.
summary: Focuses on Murdick's journey through education and eventual conversion to Catholicism.

title: Journeys to the far North.
publisher: The Wilderness Society and American West Publishing Co.
summary: Chronicles Murie's experiences as a field biologist studying the environment and its inhabitants.

title: But God has promised.
summary: A memoir detailing Murphey's path to becoming a missionary and his experiences in Kenya.

title: The Frank Murphy story: his years in Florida prisons, his rehabilitation, and his conquest of alcoholism.
summary: Murphy details his experiences within the prison system and his journey to recovery from alcoholism.

title: Say . . . didn't you used to be George Murphy?
summary: A biography detailing Murphy's multi-faceted career from stage to politics.
occupations: entertainer, public relations officer, U.S. Senator

title: There's always adventure: the story of a naturalist's wife.
summary: Recollections from the wife of a naturalist, reflecting on their life and travels.

title: Glow of candlelight: the story of Patricia Murphy.
summary: Patricia Murphy narrates her life story from her arrival in New York to her success.

title: In the morning of my life.
summary: Netherton's good-natured narrative focuses on his childhood in a peripatetic family, his advancement in the U.S. Army, the experience of being a born-again Christian, and its impact on his career as a popular singer.

title: Drawn from memory: a self portrait.
summary: Because German-born Neuhaus was forbidden by a harsh guardian uncle to study art, he became a house painter until he won a scholarship to art school in Berlin at the Royal Museum of Decorative Art. Later Neuhaus emigrated to America and eventually settled on the Monterey Peninsula.

title: In the arena: an autobiographical memoir.
summary: Neumann narrates the story of a life devoted to Zionism with its central goal the establishment of the State of Israel, accomplished in 1947. Neumann was an outstanding leader in American and international Zionist organizations.

title: Life and shape.
summary: A respected Austro-American architect, he tells of the forces that shaped him and his awareness of the intricate relationship between physical surroundings and the creative mind and spirit.

title: Dawn & dusks: taped conversations with Diana MacKown.
summary: In a series of candid conversations with her longtime assistant, Nevelson describes the metamorphosis of her life from unconventional wife and mother to one of America's foremost innovative sculptors.

title: Julia Newberry's diary.
summary: The journal of two years of the life of a young girl whose travels in Europe are overlaid with nostalgia for her home. The Newberry family was important in Chicago history.

title: Revolutionary suicide.
summary: Newton writes of his youth and development, the emergence and strategy of the Black Panther Party, his imprisonment and associates.

title: River of years: an autobiography.
summary: Fully detailed narrative of the life and development of an Episcopal minister, famous for his syndicated feature in the American Press (1933-1944).

title: Why I am a Baptist.
summary: Written at the request of the publisher for its 'Why I Am' series, the book places his personal history in the context of his Baptist faith.

title: Sursum!: Elisabet Ney in Texas.
summary: All but the last twenty pages of this book are letters to or from the German-American artist concerning various commissions for sculptures, mostly in Texas.

title: Frederick G. Nichols' memoirs, 1878-1954: the early view of business education.
summary: Nichols' memoirs comprise a 'written photograph' of one of the great personalities in business education during the first half of the twentieth century.

title: If mountains die: a New Mexico memoir.
summary: With lyricism and humor, a novelist describes his first eight years in Taos, New Mexico.

title: The diary of Anai's Nin.
publisher: The Swallow Press and Harcourt, Brace & World, Inc.
summary: Nin's diary, including a supplementary photographic volume, discusses art, drugs, beauty, and psychology, with comments on plays, books, and films.

title: A sculptor's world. Illustrated.
summary: A sculptor and designer of remarkable intellect and originality, Noguchi writes of his life and work, emphasizing the importance of his Japanese heritage and the conceptual development of his art.

title: The making of a surgeon.
summary: A surgeon writes of his five years of training at New York's Bellevue Hospital — his success, mistakes, disasters, and a description of how surgeons work, think and feel.

title: Last of the Scottsboro boys: an autobiography.
summary: The state of Alabama granted him an unconditional pardon after reviewing evidence that had convicted him for rape three times. He recalls his five years on death row, ten in the penitentiary, and life as a fugitive after breaking parole in 1946.

title: Dreamers, dynamiters and demagogues; reminiscences.
summary: Sketches of many 'heroes and non-heroes' he has admired during his lifetime of alternating attraction to and disenchantment with anarchism, various revolutionary causes, and violent acts of protest.

title: Journals of Eric Norelius, a Swedish missionary on the American frontier.
summary: Drawn to America for economic reasons, Norelius left Sweden and became a clergyman, missionary, and educator attempting to establish schools and children's homes, publish a Swedish newspaper, and carry out other humanitarian endeavors.

title: My fifty years with the angels.
summary: Norman, an elementary school teacher for over fifty years in Minnesota, Iowa, and Washington, D.C., describes each position in minute detail.

title: Last of the Scottsboro boys: an autobiography.
summary: The state of Alabama granted him an unconditional pardon after reviewing evidence that had convicted him for rape three times.

title: Letters.
summary: Fewer than a hundred letters have survived the author of McTeague, who died at the age of 31. Those that have been preserved almost always have his writing as their subject.

title: Gleanings from a doctor's eye. Illustrated.
summary: These 'gleanings' include stories and fragments of a philosophy of life, among them observations on grandfatherhood, television addiction, alcoholism, the maintenance of health after forty, and a religious creed.

title: Family gathering.
summary: Author of about eighty popular novels, Norris writes her life story as a family memoir, focusing on family events, members, and activities, mostly in the San Francisco area.

title: No men are strangers.
summary: A fast-moving account of the development of North's liberal ideals and principles as a Jewish immigrant's child in Pennsylvania.

title: Man of the Plains: recollections of Luther North, 1856-1882.
volume: The Pioneer Heritage Series, Vol. IV
summary: In 1864 North and his brother Frank joined the Pawnee Scouts, a unit of the U.S. Army which played a significant role in the long wars for control of the Great Plains.

title: Twelve years a slave. Illustrated.
summary: Born a free Negro in the North, Northrop was kidnapped at age 33 and enslaved in the South, but finally was rescued twelve years later.

title: The Dean speaks again: giving hitherto unpublished excerpts from personal papers, diaries, and letters; together with portions of previously published speeches.
summary: With love, faith, and gentle humor, Norton tells about his youth and early education in Minnesota and focuses on his career as the first Dean of Pomona College.

title: A goodly heritage.
summary: This volume begins in 1879, the year the Community was dissolved, describing his shock in having to contend with the outside world, and his long career as a community leader and pacifist.

title: My father's house: an Oneida boyhood.
summary: Noyes analyzes the first sixteen years of his life, growing up in a Utopian society, a communal religious sect.

title: Events leading up to the comedy; an autobiography.
summary: The story of Nugent's life is full of anecdotes about his careers as an actor in theater and as a writer of successful comedies.

title: My dear Nellie: Civil War letters to Eleanor Smith Nugent.
summary: In his effusively romantic letters to his betrothed, Nugent frequently upbraids her for her gaiety, while detailing the progression of the war in Mississippi and Tennessee.

title: The spirit woman: the diaries and paintings of Bonita Wa Wa Calachaw Nunez.
summary: Nunez became a painter in Greenwich Village and spent much of her adult life trying to discover her parents and working for Indian rights.

title: Whole man goes to work: the life story of a businessman.
summary: As President of the Nunn-Bush Shoe Company in St. Louis, he encouraged unionization and many forms of labor-management cooperation.

title: My diary. Drawings by the author.
summary: Her diary for 1947, written after she had been a child actress for five years.

title: Nuttall's travels into the Old Northwest: an unpublished 1810 diary.
summary: A botanist's record of his explorations in the Northwest (now Michigan and Minnesota) collecting specimens of flora.

title: Bill Nye, his own life story.
summary: This volume is compiled largely from his letters and articles, with connecting comments written by his son.

title: Letters now in the University of Wyoming Library.
summary: Thirty-three letters written by a popular frontier humorist and historian.

title: Jack Oakie's double takes.
summary: This book focuses on Oakie's particular friends among the hordes of Hollywood stars he worked with, arranged topically.

title: Outwitting the Hun; my escape from a German prison camp.
summary: An Irish Canadian, he enlisted in the British Royal Air Corps during World War I, was captured by the Germans, escaped through Belgium.

title: The habit of being: letters.
summary: O'Connor's warm personal letters reveal her notions about the writing of good fiction, her attitude toward racial problems in the South, and many practical matters.

title: One summer in Israel.
summary: O'Connor and Cole spent six weeks in Israel, partly on a kibbutz, partly touring the country.

title: Eskimo parish.
summary: A Catholic missionary in Alaska describes his parish, the people, their work and society.

title: The angel of Hell's Kitchen.
summary: At 21 she was working as an investigator for the New York Welfare Department, her cases involving the poor, the derelict, and hardened mobsters.

title: An autobiographical sketch.
summary: Oberndorf's narrative tells of his early life, his medical training, and his decision to enter psychiatry.

title: Liberty to the captives: the struggle against oppression in South Korea.
summary: This Methodist missionary in Korea worked along with the urban poor seeking to change the terrible working conditions.

title: The memoirs of Serge Obolensky.
summary: Born a Russian prince, he grew up in the midst of elegant aristocracy and court life.

title: O'Grady: the life and times of Hollywood's no. 1 private eye.
summary: After twenty years as an L.A. policeman, the author opened his own investigative agency catering to various clients.

title: All things considered: memories, experiences, and observations of a Chicagoan.
summary: His book bears the name of his daily column, characterized by humor and searching honesty.

title: No final victories; a life in politics— from John F. Kennedy to Watergate.
summary: The author's life in politics covering his work as a Democratic Party strategist.

title: Heaven was not enough.
summary: O'Hara details her development as a Catholic and her continual association with the Catholic faith.

title: Novel in the making, by Mary O'Hara (pseud.)
summary: The journal of a job, based on her diaries while writing a novel, revealing the progress of her thoughts and craft.

title: Georgia O'Keeffe. Illustrated.
summary: N/A

title: Old Mexican Navaho autobiography.
summary: The themes of acculturation, the difficulties of farming, and the troubles of married life run through this story of a Navaho's life revealing the sufferings and frustrations of his own complex personality and society's imposition on him of expectations, attitudes, ideals and reactions.

title: Twenty miles from a match: homesteading in western Nevada.
summary: Olds explains her life as a homesteader and rancher in western Nevada for the first half of the twentieth century. There she reared five children; raised a garden, mules, and lambs; trapped and skinned coyotes; and at times ran a dude ranch and a boardinghouse.

title: The making of an ex-astronaut.
summary: A scientist-astronaut who left the program a year before the first manned moon landing writes of his desire to become an astronaut, the applications, tests, interviews, training, flight school, and studies involved. He discusses his agonizing decision to quit and offers his views about the future of the space program.

title: For the prosecution: Miss Deputy D.A.
summary: A lively account of her legal education and career as a Deputy District Attorney in California. In spite of continuous opposition from male colleagues, she placed high in her class and began a difficult but successful career as a trial lawyer.

title: Wisconsin, my home: [her] story.
summary: Oleson recounts the history of her parents, Norwegian immigrants to Wisconsin in 1866, as well as the life stories of herself, her mother-in-law, her husband, and her children. She provides a history of the Norwegian-American community of Winchester, Wisconsin, in which she lived most of her long life.

title: The bench is a hard seat: an autobiography.
summary: Employing the experience gained in 62 years as a lawyer and judge, Oliver gives practical information and advice on successful conduct of a law practice. He also relates his own progress from a young, naive lawyer to a seasoned, competent jurist.

title: A journey through Texas; or a saddle-trip on the southwestern frontier.
summary: This narrative, undertaken to describe 'the great extent and capacities of Texas, as well as its distinct position and history,' was compiled from the author's record of the journey he took in order to improve his health with invigorating outdoor life.

title: Papers: Vol. 1: The Formative Years, 1822 to 1852.
summary: This splendidly printed, edited, and annotated edition of Olmsted's letters focuses on a voyage to China (1843), 'Connecticut Interlude' (1844-1845), 'The Search for Love and Certitude' (1846), and Olmsted's years as a 'Gentleman Farmer' (1847-49). They are eclectic, vibrant, and witty.

title: Journal of a famed bureaucrat: Nils A. Olsen and the BAE, 1925-1935.
summary: Olsen's diaries cover the years 1925 to 1935 and concern his meetings with various Department of Agriculture bureaucrats to discuss farming policy, politics, and programs — among them, taking farmland out of circulation to cut farm surplus.

title: Squarelv behind the beavers. Illustrated by Larry Lurin.
summary: After eighteen years as a public relations man in Boston, he went 'back to the land,' became a columnist and feature writer in New Hampshire, began renovating the family homestead near Durham, and immersed himself in the curious and independent lifestyle of rural New England.
occupations: Public Relations Man, Columnist, Feature Writer

title: Confession from the Malaga Madhouse: A Christmas diary.
summary: A widowed writer travels to Spain with her six-year-old son, struggling to find some sense of sanity and self in a world gone mad.

title: 'Atsa Louie, I'ma Phil. And Phil Palermo with Bernard Palmer.
summary: Gospel musicians Phil and Louie Palermo describe their conversion from lukewarm Roman Catholicism to fervent evangelical Christianity as a consequence of their mother's miraculous 'cure' from cancer in 1926.

title: As it happened: a memoir.
summary: Founder and chairman of CBS, Paley describes his experience in transforming the small, struggling United Independent Broadcasting into the giant communications empire CBS.

title: Autobiography of a philosopher.
summary: His memories of the intellectual growth and struggles in reaching his convictions 'about ultimate things on which he now relies.' He and his colleagues at Harvard composed the outstanding group of philosophers of their day.

title: Gringo lawyer.
summary: In 1919, after studying law at Harvard and in Spain, he began to practice law in Chile. His book describes his experience as a lawyer in Latin America during the next thirty years.

title: Miracle at City Hall.
summary: The author felt a God-given directive to help drug addicts in Minneapolis. He became a policeman and learned first-hand about violence and lawlessness, which he sought to overcome through his distinctive Christian ministry.

title: The crucible: an autobiography.
summary: Courageous narrative of experience as a guerrilla fighter in Luzon during the Japanese occupation, 1942-1945, by a journalist.

title: God's spy.
summary: An exuberant account of Panos's life as a teenage hoodlum and hustler, followed by success as a businessman selling houses, clothing, and boots in Houston. His transformation to evangelical Christianity is highlighted.

title: Out of the fire.
summary: In 1938 Papanek became director of a group of castles in southern France which served as shelters for refugee Jewish children, providing a normal life using progressive educational theories.

title: Anything can happen.
summary: The story of his immigration to the U.S. from Georgia in Russia includes his first impression of Ellis Island and early attempts at farming.

title: Home, and home again.
summary: This volume tells of his return visit forty years later to the village he grew up in, with recollections of childhood at the center of his narrative.

title: My book.
summary: A whimsical and anecdotal review of her adult life during which she found satisfaction in nursing and journalism.

title: Beltran: Basque sheepman of the American West.
summary: This unusual book provides an oral history of Basque sheepherders in Wyoming and Nevada as epitomized in the experiences of Paris, who immigrated from French Basque country in 1912.

title: A story for my children.
summary: The author intended these recollections of farm life in Michigan and upstate New York for her fourteen children and families, detailing daily activities of a farm family.

title: Front door lobby.
summary: A settlement worker describes her experience in the suffrage movement, 1916-1919, as part of the National American Woman Suffrage Association.

title: The world expands: recollections of a zoologist.
summary: Primarily recollections of his professional life, the book describes some boyhood memories, his Harvard College days, his field work on the Pacific Gold Coast, Japan and China, and his career on the Harvard faculty.

title: Mules, mines and me in Mexico, 1895-1932.
summary: At the age of 24 he became manager of an ore-buying agency in Mexico. He witnessed one of Mexico's most turbulent periods of history.

title: The trial of Theodore Parker, with the defence by Theodore Parker.
summary: In 1854 Parker gave a speech in Boston's Faneuil Hall objecting to the activities of slave hunters, and the book records the arguments for his defense.

title: Halt! I'm a Federal Game Warden: the amazing career of 'the toughest warden of them all.'
summary: A straightforward account of Parker's 25-year career as an agent for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, dedicated to protecting endangered species.

title: Journals of Francis Parkman.
summary: Journals of explorer-historian's travels in New York, Maine, Canada, Europe, and on the Oregon Trail.

title: Untold friendships.
summary: As a member of one of New York's oldest families, he inherited traditions of wealth, style and entertainment that prepared him for his own position as a professional host.

title: Letters of Francis Parkman.
summary: The letters of a famous nineteenth-century explorer and historian record the history of his ambitions, frustrations, attainments, and his struggles against illness.

title: Born.
summary: N/A

title: Journey through a lighted room.
summary: A journalist recounts her personal struggles with love, marriage, divorce, and her son's death, affirming her will to live and endure.

title: A choice of weapons.
summary: Parks has been a correspondent, professional basketball player, composer, novelist, and photographer, receiving awards for his photojournalism.
occupations: Correspondent, Basketball Player, Composer, Novelist, Photographer

title: To smile in autumn: a memoir.
summary: Parks details his career as a photographer during the 1940s and 50s, focusing on civil rights and his personal life.

title: It was fun working at the White House.
summary: An engaging account of Parks's forty-year career as a maid and seamstress in the White House.

title: My thirty years backstairs at the White House.
summary: Parks recounts her service as a maid and seamstress at the White House and her impressions of the Roosevelts.

title: The leaf and the flame.
summary: The book distills her diaries of five years during which she lived in India, providing colorful and precise accounts of Eastern culture.

title: Easy the hard way.
summary: A Hollywood producer writes of his boyhood in Hungary and his career in the movies.

title: George Thomas White Patrick: an autobiography.
summary: Writing at age 90, Patrick describes his long and productive life as a student, teacher, and philosopher.

title: Inside Lincoln's army: the diary of Marsena Rudolph Patrick, Provost Marshall General, Army of the Potomac.
summary: A record of the day-to-day operation of staff departments during the Civil War and social life in Washington.

title: Penn State Yankee: the autobiography of Fred Lewis Pattee.
summary: Raised in New Hampshire, Pattee describes his life as a professor at Pennsylvania State College and the introduction of American Literature studies.

title: Frank MerriwelPs 'father': an autobiography by Gilbert Patten ('Burt L. Standish').
summary: Patten, author of the Frank and Dick Merriwell books, shares his life story in an unfinished autobiography reconstructed by the editor.

title: Yankee rebel: the Civil War journal of Edmund DeWitt Patterson.
summary: Patterson's detailed account of Civil War battles is capable of vivid language and humor.

title: I like people: the autobiography of Grove Patterson.
summary: Patterson recounts his childhood upbringing in Carlyle, Ohio, but concentrates on his career as a newspaper editor, primarily of the Toledo Blade. During travels abroad, he interviewed Mussolini, Winston Churchill, and Eva Peron, among other notables. Patterson concludes with paeans to his faith in God and faith in people.

title: To be young was very heaven.
summary: N/A

title: Afield with plant lovers and collectors: botanical correspondence of the late Harry N. Patterson with the great botanical collectors and distributors of America from 1870 to 1919.
publisher: Alice M. Kibbe, Carthage College, and Gem City Business College
summary: Correspondence, 1870-1915, between botanist and printer Harry N. Patterson and a host of other botanical collectors, including Samuel Barnum Mead, H.G. Jessup, and Edwin Hunt, is mostly concerned with the exchange, location, and identification of various plant specimens in the West and Midwest.

title: Scottsboro boy.
summary: One of the central figures in the Scottsboro case tells the story of his arrest, his trial, the harrowing life in Alabama jails and prisons, and his escape.

title: Personal narrative of James O. Pattie.
summary: A fur trapper's formal but classic account of his journeys of trade and exploration to New Mexico and Mexico, with forays along the Platte and Colorado rivers.

title: War as I knew it.
summary: Essentially a study of Patton in the West-European campaign of 1944-45, the book is based heavily on his unpublished war diary and includes letters written to his wife from Africa and Sicily.

title: Desperate scenery.
summary: The last in his autobiographical series, Items on the Grand Account, which describes his youthful experience working on construction crews in Wyoming and Idaho around 1910.

title: Ghost town on the Yellowstone.
summary: Youthful adventures on a project of the U.S. Reclamation Service in Montana (1907-08), with good details of Western frontier life.

title: Linden on the Saugus Branch.
summary: The third volume in his autobiographical series, Items on the Grand Account, describing his early years growing up in a suburb of Boston.

title: My old Kentucky home.
summary: Another in his autobiographical series, Items on the Grand Account, describing his life in Louisville around 1910.

title: A narrow street.
summary: A journalist's well-written account of his experience in Paris during the Twenties and Thirties until the Nazi takeover of the city, with powerful and precise details of personal and political struggles.

title: Civil War letters of General Frank "Bull" Paxton, CSA: a lieutenant of Lee & Jackson.
summary: Paxton's letters to his wife and an occasional speech to his troops are embedded in an interpretive matrix that provides a much larger picture of the Civil War as fought primarily in Virginia 1861-63.

title: Minnie Pearl: an autobiography.
summary: This fast and funny narrative moves from early family life to road shows to the Grand Ole Opry. Ophelia Colley traces the development of character Minnie Pearl with humorous anecdotes and witty insight.

title: Never look back: the autobiography of a jockey.
summary: An exciting, fast-moving account of Pearson's career around horses. He began as a stable boy and continued into his thirties as a jockey, racing primarily in California. As a sailor in the Pacific during World War II, he added to his art collection.

title: Diaries, 1949-1959.
summary: Pearson lived to communicate. His diaries extend his view of the history of his time — a record of the people and events that made history during the decade of the 50's.

title: Country flavor.
summary: In this collection of essays which originally appeared on the editorial pages of the New York Times, Pearson writes of the charm of rural life.

title: Countryman's year.
summary: Reprinted from the Boston Herald, the Providence Journal, the New York Times...

title: New England flavor: memories of a country boyhood.
summary: A nostalgic recollection of life in a New Hampshire farming community includes stories of Fogg's General Store, covered bridges, fringe-top surreys, the tin peddlar, homemade ice cream, and other happy memories.

title: Sea flavor.
summary: A collection of editorials, articles, and essays reprinted from various newspapers, this volume contains Pearson's impressions and observations of life in a small New England fishing village.

title: Everything but elephants.
summary: Lively, well-written narrative by a doctor's wife during a two-year assignment in the jungle of Colombia.

title: My Arctic journal, a year among ice-fields and Eskimos: with an account of The Great White Journey across Greenland by Robert E. Peary.
summary: This is the plain and simple narrative of a white woman's year on the shores between the Arctic Circle and North Pole. It includes observations of a small band of Eskimos as well as a frank account of the hardships of existence.

title: Sequestered vales of life.
summary: Charming sketches of his relatives, friends, neighbors, and surroundings by a keen, thoughtful observer of nature and human nature.

title: Forty years of pioneer life: memoir of John Mason Peck, D.D.
summary: Peck's memoir reveals an energetic, perceptive Baptist-pioneer clergyman dedicated to observing frontier civilization throughout the Midwest as well as to proselytizing.

title: Fifty years with the Golden Rule.
summary: Successful businessman recounts his adherence to Christian principles in his working and family life.

title: What next, Doctor Peck?
summary: In 1916-18 he was a doctor for the Utah Construction Company in a bleak, isolated area in the western part of the state. His book tells of the rough, uncivilized but pleasant life on this twentieth-century frontier.

title: The unprejudiced palate.
summary: A university professor describes his family's immigration from Italy to the United States, his culinary philosophy, and some practical suggestions about his culinary craft.

title: Not in my time: the story of a doctor.
summary: In gruesome detail Peller writes about his life as a doctor. He describes various diseases and symptoms in terms difficult for a layman to understand.

title: Starlight nights: the adventures of a star-gazer.
summary: A unique autobiography in which the simple, clear style of an amateur astronomer transports the reader into the starry skies above rural Delphos, Ohio.

title: General to his lady: the Civil War letters of William Dorsey Pender to Fanny Pender.
summary: Pender's letters combine general news of the war's progress (1861-1863) with domestic concerns — inquiries after health, his need for new undershirts, and accounts of flirtations, which draw swift responses from his young wife.

title: The letters and papers of Edmund Pendleton, 1734-1803.
publisher: Published for The Virginia Historical Society by The University Press of Virginia
summary: Prominent as a lawyer, judge, and politician in Virginia, he worked with the major figures in colonial history. His letters document his political activity and the times.

title: No man alone; a neurosurgeon's life.
summary: Dr. Penfield recounts his studies at Princeton and Oxford during World War I, followed by medical practice in New York City and his founding of the Montreal Neurological Institute.

title: My wonderful world of golf.
summary: Penna, winner of various middle-level golf tournaments in the 1930's, discusses his career as a golfer and offers tips on how to play pro.

title: View from the ninth decade: jottings from a merchant's daybook.
summary: With self-congratulatory good humor, multimillionaire Penney expounds on the religiously-oriented philosophy that governed his business dealings.

title: Rambling recollections of ninety happy years.
summary: Pennington, a lifelong Quaker clergyman, reminisces about significant aspects of his life and notable Quaker friends.

title: Straight life: the story of Art Pepper.
summary: The story of Art Pepper's life as musician, drug abuser, and prisoner, as reflected by taped interviews with Pepper and others who know him.

title: Uncollected letters of James Gates Percival: poet and geologist, 1795-1856.
summary: Fifty-two letters previously unpublished confirm the impression that Percival was a romantic, melancholic recluse, usually dissatisfied with his place in the world.

title: Lanterns on the levee; recollections of a planter's son.
summary: He writes of his noble and tragic view of life, his gloomy assessment of the spiritual health of Western civilization, and life in the Southern aristocracy.

title: More was lost.
summary: Most of the book describes the war years in Hungary, 1937-1940, when she fell in love, married, and had a child before fleeing the coming war.

title: El coyote: the rebel.
summary: Orphaned at birth, Perez lived with an uncle until he was eleven, when he joined the Mexican rebel army.

title: Gold rush diary; being the journal of Elisha Douglass Perkins on the Overland Trail in the spring and summer of 1849.
summary: Perkins' diary records his enthusiastic observations of people, the countryside, the Indians, and animal life on the rugged overland trail during the California gold rush.

title: Letters of Capt. Geo. Hamilton Perkins, U.S.N.
summary: Perkins, a naval lieutenant aboard the U.S.S. Cayuga and the Chickasaw, documented his naval service and experiences in the letters collected in this volume.

title: Editor to author: the letters of Maxwell E. Perkins. Selected and edited with commentary and introduction by John Hall Wheelock.
summary: In these letters to authors written from 1914 to 1947, the editor of Scribner's reveals his personality and his interest in the development of American literary talent, especially in fiction.

title: In and out the garbage pail.
summary: Psychiatrist and founder of gestalt therapy, Perls uses writing as a means to explore his own struggle with self-esteem, self-love, and self-image.

title: Forty cords of wood: memoirs of a medical doctor.
summary: Well-written, dramatic story of a Black man who wanted as a young boy to become a doctor and who succeeded in an extraordinary way as a surgeon, medical educator, and founder of hospitals in Missouri.

title: The Japan expedition, 1852-1854: the personal journal of Commodore Matthew C. Perry.
summary: Enhanced by numerous water colors and pen or pencil sketches, this handsome volume describes Perry's 1852-1854 journey to Japan and includes material omitted from the official narrative such as personal observations, correspondence, and many of the paintings.

title: Selections from the letters of Thomas Sergeant Perry.
summary: An aristocrat by birth, instinct, and environment, Perry was editor of the North American Review and a literary critic. He published several volumes of translations from Russian literature and collections of critical articles. This edition of his letters includes many to the contributors of his journal, notably Henry James.

title: Chautauqua to opera: an autobiography of a voice teacher and daughter of a Chautauqua pioneer.
summary: Perry-Cowen focuses on her musical career, including nine years performing with her singer father on road tours with Ye Olde New England Choir and a year's voice lessons in Paris. After marriage she performed 'Scenes from the Operas,' gave music lessons, and sang in church choirs in New Jersey.

title: Bread upon the waters.
summary: As a union organizer, the author traveled throughout the U.S. helping to reshape the lot of workers in many industries. With great spirit and energy she pursued her goal of helping workers through World War I, the disturbances after the War, the despairing times during the Depression, and the resurgence when the New Deal sanctioned the right of workers to organize and bargain collectively.

title: Boyhood with Gurdjieff.
summary: An intense and remarkable study of his early education in Paris at the school of Georges Gurdjieff, a well-known educator and theologian, which pays high tribute to the significant influence Gurdjieff had on his life.

title: The correspondence of Captain Nathan and Lois Peters: April 25, 1775-February 5, 1777.
summary: The letters exchanged between an officer in the Continental Army serving in Massachusetts and his wife, who was raising their four children and running the family business, a saddle shop in Preston, Connecticut, provide a striking glimpse of the Revolutionary Era.

title: debut at the Met.
summary: At age ten she went with a friend to her singing lesson. At twenty she made her debut at the Metropolitan Opera as Zerlina in Mozart's Don Giovanni. Her book describes the years of study, excitement, and hard work in between that sustained her dream to become a successful musician.

title: Desert pioneer doctor: and, experiences in obstetrics.
summary: Two separate volumes published together, the first being autobiographical experiences of medical practice in poor and primitive conditions in Southern California, early twentieth century.

title: A matter of life and death.
summary: Written in the form of a letter to her mother, the book is a haunting quest for life's meaning, for reconciliation with her mother and the Catholic faith, for self-justification.

title: My story.
summary: In this quiet, charming autobiography, Pettengill tells of his childhood and traces his ancestry, college and law school years, his stint as a lawyer, professor at Middlebury College, and Congressman, ending with the purchase of his home, Robin Lawn.

title: Jubilee!: autobiography of Hermon Pettit.
summary: Pettit, religious all his life, graduated from Occidental College and became an evangelical Presbyterian preacher. His vows of abstinence from worldly pleasures strained his marriage and precipitated both his divorce and his expulsion from the pulpit. Often penniless and for a time hospitalized as a consequence of mental illness and a suicide attempt, Pettit found a new congregation, tranquility, reunion with his children, and peace in nature in old age.

title: Diary of a dead man: letters and diary of Private Ira S. Pettit, Wilson, Niagara County, N.Y. who served . . . U.S. Army during the War Between the States.
publisher: Privately printed in Waverly, Iowa (by) Ray
summary: The first half of this book consists of brief diary entries and some letters by Pettit, a private in the Union Army, 11th Regiment, 2nd Brigade, 2nd Division, 5th Army Corps, written June 1862-June 1863, when he was captured by the Confederates. He died in the notorious Andersonville (Georgia) Prison of scurvy and diarrhea, without medical care. The rest of the book consists of fragmentary eulogistic biographies of people who may have known Pettit while he was in the army.

title: Bob Pettit: the drive with me.
summary: Along with the story of his rise to success as a basketball player, Pettit presents anecdotes of player high jinks, the serious side of competition, and tips on training, playing, and winning.

title: King of the road.
summary: This description of stock car racer Petty's technique, philosophy, and major races is particularly compelling because of the photographs and drawings of life in the machine shop, at the track, and on the road. Petty has won the Daytona 500 five times, surpassing all other winners.

title: AU for her: the autobiography of Father Patrick Peyton, C.S.C.
summary: The progress of his career as a priest — seminary days, his work with the network radio program, 'Family Theater of the Air,' his crusades world-wide in behalf of the Family Rosary concept, and further efforts to strengthen family ties through prayer.

title: Quest for dignity: an autobiography of a Negro doctor.
summary: Raised in Long Island, he supported his medical education as a jazz pianist in New York, London, and Paris. In a constant battle with racial prejudice, he moved his practice to several American cities, to Brazil, and finally back to New York, with hopes of racial reconciliation.

title: For more than bread: an autobiographical account of twenty-two years' work with the American Friends Service Committee.
summary: A Quaker relief worker details his experience with a Quaker organization, the American Friends Service Committee. He recalls the war relief given to Germany, Spain, and Japan, the aid to conscientious objectors, and the help to poor Americans.

title: Prodigal shepherd.
summary: Father Pfau tells the interrelated stories of his career in the priesthood, mostly in Indianapolis; his incessant neuroticism, which led to twenty years of alcoholism and intermittent hospitalization for his mental state; and his 25-year maintenance of sobriety through Alcoholics Anonymous.

title: Soldier of the South: General Pickett's war letters to his wife.
summary: An unusual collection of letters to LaSalle Corbett Pickett portraying their courtship, marriage, and the birth of their first son during the Civil War. The letters are rich in details of his emotional reactions to love.

title: When I was a girl in the martin box.
summary: A charming account of her girlhood in nineteenth-century rural Connecticut, with detailed descriptions of games, daily activities, education, and household chores.

title: Sunshine and shadow.
summary: Her story as a child star of stage and screen, her fame as 'America's Sweetheart,' her marriages to Douglas Fairbanks, Jr. and Buddy Rogers told in a style that conveys gentle serenity.

title: Coach's world.
summary: The author was basketball coach of Notre Dame University in 1974 when his team beat UCLA, breaking its string of 88 straight college basketball wins. Phelps tells of the pressures and rewards he faced as he built up the winning team and how the efforts affected his family, the players, and himself.

title: So laugh a little.
summary: A popular actress in the Yiddish theater describes growing up in Philadelphia and New York's Lower East Side, focusing on the character of her grandmother, a lively, loving, humorous Russian immigrant.

title: Fifty years of public school teaching: from rural school teacher to university professor.
summary: Beginning with his early rural education in Missouri, he describes his life in the context of the development of public education in the state. A good source book for history of education.

title: Mushroom: the story of the A-bomb kid.
summary: An average physics student at Princeton, he received national publicity after he designed an atomic bomb for a physics project, drawing entirely on available, unclassified data. His experiences in college, in Hollywood, with the FBI, and with reporters provide entertaining reading while he presents his concerns for nuclear safety.

title: My room in the world: a memoir.
summary: She grew up in western Kansas where her father was a minister. Educated at Ohio Wesleyan and Columbia Teachers College, she was active in education and church work throughout her life, including her years as a college dean, as first president of the American Association of Women Deans and Counselors, and with her husband, Ellis Phillips, a major supporter of Christ Church in New York.

title: Grow old along with me: the autobiography of Marie Tello Phillips (February 23, 1874-).
summary: Author of two novels and six books of poetry and a great promoter of contemporary poetry societies, she writes of her life as a writer and member of polite society, chiefly in Pittsburgh.

title: Ventures in diplomacy.
summary: A personal record of his long career as a diplomat, including his assignment to Peking (1905-07), as Undersecretary of State (1922-24), and assignments in Canada, Italy, India, and Palestine. Detailed recollections of major events during almost fifty years of service.

title: A rebel in sports: the autobiography of the father of the colorful Blue-Gray football game.
summary: Sports-promoter Pickens reminisces about his rural Alabama childhood, business ventures in New York, his penchant for betting on horses, and particularly his promotion of the Blue-Gray football games, 1939-1955.

title: Fear strikes out: the Jim Piersall story.
summary: During his first season with the Red Sox, he had a mental breakdown which hospitalized him for months. Here he tells of his boyhood, his early career, his breakdown, his amazing recovery, and renewal of an outstanding baseball career.

title: Roughly speaking.
summary: Her well-off family was left with little money when her father died, but she set out to be a self-made woman. During all her ups and downs she met life head-on with humor and resilience.

title: Life is victorious!: how to grow through grief; a personal experience.
summary: Diane Pike analyzes her grief when her new husband, Episcopal Bishop James A. Pike, was lost and died in the Judean wilderness in 1969. She moved from shock to suffering to recovery to building a new life. She and a partner have founded 'The Love Project' to intensify union with God. She maintains psychic communion with Pike.

title: My journey into self: Phase one.
summary: Pike, widow of Bishop James Pike, explains in mystical language her quest for an expansion of her consciousness and self-knowledge.

title: Search; the personal story of a wilderness journey.
summary: The story of her husband, Bishop James A. Pike, his trip into the Judean wilderness, and the tragic missteps that turned it into his last journey.

title: Scout and Ranger; being the personal adventures of James Pike of the Texas Rangers in 1859-60.
summary: A grandnephew of the discoverer of Pike's Peak, the author tells the story of his adventures in the Indian Campaigns with the Texas Rangers. Courageous and forthright, he was curious about the customs and habits of the Indians and describes them, the battles, and other events with unusual attention to detail.

title: The other side; an account of my experiences with psychic phenomena.
summary: The controversial bishop writes of events preceding and following his son's death: his attempts to save his son from psychedelic drugs, the son's death, poltergeist occurrences, communications with the son, and other psychic phenomena. Includes a bibliography of works on psychical research.

title: Southwestern expedition of Zebulon M. Pike. Edited by Milo Milton Quaife.
summary: At the age of 27, Pike was sent by President Jefferson to discover the headwaters of the Red and Arkansas rivers. This journal records the perseverance and suffering experienced as he and his party blazed the trail which later became the main route for the 'forty-niners.'

title: Notes from the other side of night.
summary: This poetic account of the author's return to her native Romania seventeen years after emigrating to the United States to escape communism and anti-Semitism presents vignettes alternating between past and present.

title: Breaking new ground.
summary: His 'personal story of how Forestry and Conservation came to America' begins with his early training under Louis Brandeis and then describes his political career, especially during his years as U.S. Forester under Teddy Roosevelt, when many of the major policies affecting national forests and reserves were enacted.

title: The letterbook of Eliza Lucas Pinckney, 1739-1762.
summary: An energetic, intelligent eighteenth-century woman, Eliza Pinckney managed three plantations while her father was away on military duty. She experimented successfully with raising and processing indigo and her letters reveal part of her remarkable life and have been quoted in numerous other places.

title: Maurice C. Pincoffs, M.D.: letters from two world wars and a sketch of his life by his wife.
summary: Pincoffs, a professor of medicine and preventive medicine at the University of Maryland, served as a U.S. Army physician in France during World War I and as the Chief Consultant in Medicine to the U.S. Army, Far East, during World War II. The bulk of this volume is comprised of eloquent letters to his wife, Katharine, written while on military duty.

title: Letters of Arthur W. Pink.
summary: A collection of 44 letters by Pink, editor of an obscure magazine of biblical exposition, on various religious subjects: God, premillenialism, Satan's devices, books, baptism, worship services, and glorifying the Lord.

title: The Maimie papers.
publisher: Feminist Press in cooperation with Schlesinger Library of Radcliffe College
summary: A collection of 119 of the 143 letters that Maimie, a reformed prostitute, wrote to her proper Bostonian mentor, which reveal a great deal about the poverty and degradation that accompanied turn-of-the-century prostitution.

title: Letters home: correspondence 1950-1963.
summary: A selection of 396 letters by the poet arranged chronologically, beginning with her freshman year at Smith College, continuing with her marriage to poet Ted Hughes, until her death in London.

title: The autobiography of Thomas Collier Piatt.
summary: Throughout a 53-year political career Senator Piatt became virtually an absolute dictator of the Republican Party in the East and 'made' four presidents of the United States and four governors of New York.

title: Doctor in the house.
summary: A detailed account of the practical problems occurring in his daily life as a doctor, including a section describing his service as an army doctor in World War I and problems of his patients.

title: Narrative of the capture and subsequent sufferings of Mrs. Rachel Hummer during a captivity of twenty-one months among the Comanche Indians: written by herself, 1839.
summary: This is the story of the author's capture and captivity by Comanche Indians in 1836, with observations about their culture and environment.

title: My first eighty years.
publisher: The University of North Carolina Press
summary: At 18 he became editor of The Progressive Farmer, which grew from 5,000 to 1,000,000 circulation in 1930. His book conveys his loyalty to the South and rural values and to North Carolina.

title: Letters of Edgar Allan Poe.
summary: Includes authentic versions of all accessible letters and 'offers what seem to be the best texts of lost or unavailable originals, accessible now only in printed form or in typescript.'

title: The way the future was: a memoir.
summary: Winner of the first Skylark Award for science fiction in 1966 and later the Hugo Award, he writes of his early education, his work as a writer and as editor of Galaxy magazine.

title: The selected letters of Ezra Pound, 1907-1941.
summary: The poet's letters include arguments about the art of poetry, his search for perfection, his critical opinions, his interest in problems of language. His correspondents, T.S. Eliot, James Joyce, William Carlos Williams, and others, were among the most outstanding poets, writers, and artists of his time.

title: Stranger and friend; the way of an anthropologist.
summary: A trained anthropologist must be immersed in a culture as well as a detached observer. The author tells of four field-work experiences she had: a late Stone-Age Melanesian society in the southwest Pacific — Lesu in New Ireland (1929-30); a rural Mississippi community — half Negro and half white (1933-34); Hollywood, California (1946-47); and an African mining township in northern Rhodesia (1953-54).

title: Personal reminiscences of the anti-slavery and other reforms and reformers.
summary: Among the youngest of the radical anti-slavery workers, Powell was a faithful and energetic worker for the cause of abolition just preceding the Civil War. Afterward he continued to support good causes, helping Blacks and Indians, working for peace, temperance, education, and the personal purity movement.

title: Adam by Adam; the autobiography of Adam Clayton Powell.
summary: A rich, detailed account of the author's middle-class childhood, his education, and his calling to the ministry serves as preface to the story of his rise in politics, his controversial tenure as congressman, and his subsequent expulsion from the U.S. House. This intelligent and sometimes combative autobiography closes with a manifesto of sorts in which Powell presents his outlook on the future of Black Americans.

title: Spy wife.
summary: The wife of Francis Gary Powers (U-2 spy pilot shot down over Russia in 1960) tells of her cloak-and-dagger life as the wife of a CIA spy, including his letters to her from Russia and his appearance before the Senate Armed Services Committee, as well as their divorce proceedings, which are reproduced in detail. The purpose of the book is to tell the 'true story' of their relationship, i.e., to refute Powers' charge of his wife's drunkenness and cruelty and to vindicate her character.

title: Operation overflight; the U-2 spy pilot tells his story for the first time.
summary: Flying over Russia on a reconnaissance mission in a U-2 'spy' plane on May 1, 1960, Powers was shot down and captured by the Soviets, thereby precipitating a serious incident and the official admission that authorized espionage had been occurring. Powers here discloses the details of his recruitment by the CIA, his training, the mission, his trial and imprisonment, his exchange for Soviet spy, Rudolph Abel, and the aftermath when he was made a scapegoat and discouraged from publishing his account of the incident.

title: Overtime! an uninhibited account of a referee's life in the NBA.
summary: In his diary of the 1974 basketball season, referee Powers explains how he keeps control of the game and strives to be aware of every aspect of the action. He has open, controversial opinions about pro basketball, players, coaches, officiating, and owners and still loves the game after over sixteen years of experience.

title: Prairie preacher: a tale of our yesterdays along the middle border; memoirs.
summary: Born of second-generation homesteaders, he tells a story of human tragedy and spiritual triumph during the great Depression and drought years. He holds two honorary degrees of Doctor of Divinity and has conducted his pulpit ministry for over 42 years.

title: Adventure road.
summary: Powell, a world traveler and prolific author, has assembled an eclectic series of travel anecdotes from memory and his earlier books; he discusses his travels ranging from British Columbia to Mexico, India to Zanzibar, Egypt to Malaysia. The incidents themselves are high-spirited and well-told, but their sequence is arbitrary and confusing.

title: The gift is already yours.
summary: After his wartime stint as a pilot, Prange returned to school to become a Lutheran clergyman. His first pastorate was in a tough area of New York City. His calls took him to Montana, Maryland, and other places where he and his parishoners experienced charismatic faith healing.

title: My twenty-five years in China. China in the 20th Century Series.
summary: An old China hand describes the political intrigues and alliances in the Orient between World Wars I and II. He went to Shanghai in 1917 as a journalist and to South China, Russia, and Japan as an editor. Captured in Shanghai by the Japanese in December 1941, he suffered from extreme malnutrition, and though eventually hospitalized and repatriated early in 1943, his gangrenous feet had deteriorated to the extent that he had required over two and a half years of surgical restoration at the time he wrote the book.

title: Orson Pratt journals.
summary: The journals, which cover a period prior to 1848, chronicle Pratt's leadership in the early Mormon church. In 1830 he was ordained an elder by Joseph Smith. He went on numerous missions in America and Great Britain, experienced the persecution leveled against the early church, and was finally created an apostle in the Church of the Latter-day Saints. He was in the party that found the site where Salt Lake City was to be built.

title: Down the Colorado; diary of the first trip through the Grand Canyon, 1869.
summary: This journal of a dramatic trip down the wild Colorado River by ten men in four boats recaptures the excitement and wonder of their adventure. Contemporary photographs and drawings in addition to modern color photos beautifully illustrate the vivid descriptions.

title: Fortune & friendship: an autobiography.
summary: A bookman from his earliest years, the author has been a reader, seller, librarian, and writer. He writes of his teachers, pupils, colleagues, family, and friends, and of the fortune which led him to travel widely and to achieve his current status.

title: Surgeon in wartime China.
summary: Although this is essentially a wartime memoir, it includes interesting accounts of medical practices and experiences during wartime in China.

title: Preminger: an autobiography.
summary: Preminger's exciting account of his career as a motion-picture director and producer focuses on his years in Hollywood (after immigrating from Austria in 1935), where he made such films as Carmen Jones and Advise and Consent. Preminger speaks forthrightly about his work, his marriages, his defiance of segregation, anti-Semitism, and other violations of human rights.

title: Five-dollar gold piece: the development of a point of view.
summary: The engaging life story of a man who became a prominent literary critic for the New York Times, his unconventional education, prosperous family background, and career in literary journalism.

title: A darkening green; notes from the silent generation.
summary: In diary entries joined by narrative passages, the author describes the raw, half-understood experience of late adolescence — the rivalry, the searching for purpose, the bull sessions, the anxieties. The record of his freshman year in college captures the emotions, customs, and rites of passage to present a portrait of the Fifties.

title: The recollections of Philander Prescott; frontiersman of the Old Northwest, 1819-1862.
summary: His position as sutler's clerk in Detroit, and later Fort Snelling, helping with the supply of goods for military communities in the Northwest Territory was the starting point for his participation in the events that shaped the history of the Northwest frontier from 1819 to 1862. He worked as Indian trader, riverman, interpreter, innkeeper, and supervisor of Indian farmers.

title: The correspondence of William Hickling Prescott, 1833-1847.
