summary: At a time when documented accuracy was a rare virtue in a historian, Prescott wrote with painstaking care. Despite continued trouble with his eyes, he pursued his research and wrote several monumental works on Spanish history. This volume contains a large portion of his most significant correspondence.

title: The papers of William Hickling Prescott.
summary: This selection, consisting mainly of letters, covers the years 1808 to 1858 of historian Prescott's life. The earlier letters are to family members, then come those concerning his career choice and scholarly interest. Later letters focus on research and publications; others are to friends and family. He had an international reputation as a writer of very readable history, especially his works on the conquests of Mexico and Peru.

title: I like what I know: a visual autobiography.
summary: Well-known as an actor, he has since childhood had a major interest in art. Here he describes his first awareness of art around him, his first acquisitions, and many experiences as a student, a collector, and a dealer of art.

title: Vincent Price: his movies, his plays, his life.
summary: Price provides for children a simple, engaging account of his lifelong career as an actor in theater, films, and on radio and television. Among his most famous films are Laura, The Masque of the Red Death, and The Abominable Dr. Phibes. Price is a devotee of art and cooking and has written books on both subjects.

title: I cannot rest from travel: an autobiography of adventure in seventy lands.
summary: An inveterate adventurer describes his experience as a roving correspondent and field worker for a museum and a geographic society.

title: Green grows Ivy.
summary: The story of her childhood in a small Utah town where her father was a miner and her mother ran a boardinghouse, her marriage and early experience in state politics, and her prominent career as Treasurer of the United States in the Eisenhower administration.

title: Elvis: we love you tender.
summary: Elvis Presley's stepmother tells of her marriage to Vernon Presley, the rise of Elvis' popularity and the 'Elvis craze,' his close relationship with her three sons, and the events and abuses which led to Elvis' death and her failed marriage to his father.

title: Contradictions; notes on twenty-six years in the theatre.
summary: Prince, who has directed and produced some of the most successful Broadway shows, especially musicals, answers a number of questions about his work and twenty shows he has worked on in a quarter of a century.

title: Exploring with Fremont: the private diaries of Charles Preuss, cartographer for John C. Fremont on his first, second, and fourth expeditions to the Far West.
summary: Diaries of his overland explorations as Fremont's right-hand man (1842, 1843-44, 1848-49).

title: Journals of Hezekiah Prince, Jr.: 1822-1828.
summary: These plainspoken journals of a customs official in Thomaston, Maine, offer a day-to-day glimpse of small-town life in Maine in the 1820's from the viewpoint of a young upper-middle-class bachelor. His involvement in the town's social life and his knowledge of the numerous small workaday ships (packets) vital to nineteenth-century transportation provide useful information about both.

title: Bog-trotter: an autobiography with lyrics.
summary: "I am a freak. Fragmented as this book, a monstrous hydraheaded woman-man dwarf-soul girl-child," an apt description of lyricist Previn, who writes of her career in Hollywood, her several marriages, two abortions, and mental breakdowns. Two-thirds of the book is composed of examples of her lyrics.

title: Midnight baby: an autobiography.
summary: In poetry and oblique, angry prose composer Dory Previn relates her childhood aspirations of social status and theatrical success, overshadowed by poverty and her crazed father's fear of sterility, which culminated in nightmare when he entombed Dory, her mother, and the newborn baby in a boarded-up room for several months.

title: Memories of old Montana.
summary: Well-written story of a cowboy's life in the Old West; no romance, but interesting and realistic narrative of the times with some references to the author's close friend, Charles M. Russell.

title: Trails I rode.
summary: A well-written memoir of hard life in the Old West; capturing the humor and pathos of cowboy life in Montana and South Dakota.

title: With Nixon.
summary: A staunch supporter of former President Richard Nixon, presidential speechwriter Price offers a view of his administration and Watergate which focuses on the triumphs as well as the downfalls. Price emphasizes his respect for Nixon the man.

title: Pencil shavings: memoirs.
summary: The author of Stella Dallas describes the history of her New England family in Worcester, Massachusetts. Her story includes details of daily life and manners set in the context of her own development and that of her town and family.

title: Window on Washington.
summary: A minister of the First Baptist Church in Washington, DC, 1935-1960, recounts his experiences with presidents from Roosevelt to Johnson. Pruden gave the invocation at the inauguration of Harry Truman who was a member of the church. He was an effective fund raiser for an imposing church building.

title: Wyoming scientist, horses to spaceships: memoirs.
summary: Pugh, for many years a physics professor at Carnegie Institute of Technology, devotes extraordinary detail to an account of his childhood in Evanston, Wyoming, and to his work as a banker (1919-21) in Mountain View, Wyoming. He briefly summarizes his teaching career, work on magnetism and electricity, family illnesses, love of sailing, and travel to Europe.

title: Navy surgeon.
summary: The former Surgeon General of the Navy (1951-55) describes his 33 years in the military, mostly as a Navy surgeon and hospital administrator. He discusses a variety of administrative issues and medical cases with which he dealt and devotes about half the book to colorful descriptions of his worldwide travels.

title: Uri; a journal of the mystery of Uri Geller.
summary: Trained in internal medicine at Northwestern, he later set up his own laboratory in Maine for the study of extrasensory perception. He met Uri Geller, an Israeli psychic, in 1971, brought him to the U.S. to be studied, and established a friendship that led to extensive psychic research. They believe they have made contact with non-earthly beings.

title: A Yankee in the yellow robe: an American Buddhist monk's role in East-West cultural exchange.
summary: This is the autobiography of an American whose spiritual journey into Buddhism is reflected in his literal journey from San Francisco to Rangoon, Burma, in 1956. Pulley explains his experiences in Buddhist meditation, ordination, begging, and other religious practices.

title: James Jackson Putnam and psychoanalysis; letters between Putnam and Sigmund Freud (and others).
summary: Putnam took up the cause of psychoanalysis at age 63, having previously been recognized as a distinguished specialist in nervous diseases. In 1908 and 1909 he met Ernest Jones and Sigmund Freud, thereafter corresponding with them and others. The letters reveal their patients' and their own symptoms, dreams, and feelings with candor.

title: Cast off the darkness.
summary: The courageous recovery of a man who was blinded by his attempted suicide, became an author-historian and promoter of various activities for the blind, including 'talking books.'

title: Paris was our mistress: memoirs of a lost and found generation.
summary: Set in the context of a social and intellectual history of American expatriates (1926-1933), the editor of The New Review describes his own development before and after World War I. Well-written, nearly a collective autobiography of the times.

title: Last chapter.
summary: In this the final book of Pyle's war reporting, he tells of the war in the Pacific, writing as before with honesty and no pretensions.

title: Yankee on the Yangtze: one missionary's saga in Revolutionary China.
summary: Seventh-Day Adventist missionary Quimby describes his attempts to administer the China Training Institute in Peking and to perform other teaching duties for the church during the military and social upheaval in China between 1927 and 1946.

title: Memoir of the life of Josiah Quincy, Jr.
summary: Josiah Quincy, Jr., was active in politics before the Revolutionary War. He made a deep impression on his contemporaries through his eloquence in political debates at Faneuil Hall and his zeal in upholding freedom and rights of the Colonies. This collection edited by his son includes extracts from his writings, journals, letters to and from distinguished contemporaries, and his pamphlet on the Boston Port Bill.

title: Karen Ann: the Quinlans tell their story.
summary: A sensitive account of the parents' struggle with the court system, their own religious beliefs, and their love for their comatose daughter, who they believed was being kept alive by medical machinery despite apparent brain death.

title: Original sin; a self-portrait.
summary: Born in Mexico, Quinn worked at a variety of jobs before becoming a movie actor. His career includes over a hundred movie and stage roles. Here he examines his personal triumphs and failures, his self-doubts and his search for self-understanding.

title: Love letters to Mike: forty months as a Japanese prisoner of war: April 9, 1942 to September 17, 1945.
summary: Quinn's diary, written in the form of letters to his wife, covers the period of his imprisonment by the Japanese in the Philippines, on Formosa, and in Mukden, Manchuria. Quinn's account focuses on the minutiae of daily life; the special days of the Catholic year; and on the activities of his family at home.

title: Reflections of field work in Morocco.
summary: A series of reflections about the author's two years of fieldwork in rural Morocco. These contain interesting character sketches of his chief informants in various stages of the work and observations by the author on self and culture.

title: Discretions.
summary: Brought up by the Sama family in Gais in the mountains of Italy, the daughter of Ezra Pound gained 'pleasure in counterpoint' in 'looking back on things at their beginning.' She writes of her father's views, her own situation during World War II, and the despair that overcame her then, as well as of happier pre- and postwar times.

title: Voyages of Peter Esprit Radisson, being an account of his travels and experiences among the North American Indians, from 1652 to 1684; transcribed from original mss. in the Bodleian Library and the British Museum.
summary: Radisson's papers, which remained in manuscript for more than two hundred years, were first published in 1885. They tell of his voyages and expeditions in Canada and the United States, including his captivity by the Iroquois.

title: The Rallo family: the great American saga.
summary: Rallo, a success in the construction business, happily describes the immigrant's dream become reality. His parents were reared in Sicily, immigrated to St. Louis, married, and reared ten children in an unusually loving, materially prosperous extended family, of which Rallo is proud.

title: Autobiography and letters.
summary: An aristocrat of the Old South, he was a practicing physician and prominent citizen of Tennessee, as well as a respected historian of his life and times.

title: Over my shoulder: a reminiscence.
summary: The story of his boyhood and early career as a lawyer in Michigan, his presidency of Inland Steel Co., and his life in public service where he served as Iron and Steel Consultant for the Marshall Plan under President Eisenhower.

title: Sixty-five plus: the joy and challenge of the years of retirement.
summary: A philosophical and practical exploration of his retirement years, his recovery from a heart attack, and his return to a pleasant routine of leisure and activity.

title: Dukedom large enough: reminiscences of a rare-book dealer, 1929-1956.
summary: A book collector and bookseller for forty years, Randall managed the rare book department at Scribner's, 1935-1956, afterward becoming librarian of the Lilly Library, Indiana University. Here he relates his adventures with books, manuscripts, collections, and authors.

title: Correspondence between Henry Stephens Randall and Hugh Blair Grigsby, 1856-1861.
summary: An edition of the Huntington Library collection of letters between Randall, the New York biographer of Thomas Jefferson, and Grigsby, the leading Virginia historian of his generation. Their letters reveal an intense common interest in Jefferson and depict a wide range of intellectual and cultural interests as well.

title: Part of the solution: portrait of a revolutionary.
summary: A poet, writer, and social activist, she became dedicated to socialist revolution during the late Sixties when she went to Cuba to work, live, and write. Included here are diary entries, prose pieces, and poetry.

title: I Ruth; autobiography of a marriage.
summary: The wife of prominent Lincoln scholar, James G. Randall, tells the story of her marriage and the way her interest in her husband's work shaped her own work as an author.

title: Pilgrimage of Harriet Ransom's son.
summary: The life and career of a Black minister who became a bishop in the African Methodist Episcopal Church, serving in Ohio and Pennsylvania.

title: We were interrupted.
summary: Richly detailed description of his life in the Roaring Twenties by an editor and critic who was at the center of literary and intellectual activity.

title: It takes time: an autobiography of the teaching profession.
summary: A third person narrative describing the events which motivated her to become a teacher and shaped her life in that career.

title: There was once a time; of islands, illusions and Rockefellers.
summary: Born the daughter of a Norwegian fisherman, she was married to Steven Clark Rockefeller for ten years. Her book describes her Cinderella marriage, the pain and happiness of living in the Rockefeller family, and her desire to reshape her life after their divorce.

title: In and out of character.
summary: Written in the restrained style and studied perfection that characterized his theatrical roles, his book traces his career, the drama of his life on and off stage or camera, his long and happy marriage, and many of his famous friends.

title: The camera never blinks: adventures of a TV journalist.
summary: Rather describes the hectic world of a television newsman. Through Watergate, Vietnam, the Kennedy and King assassinations, and his daring coverage of the People's Republic of China's army, Rather's incentive has been a lesson from his obscure Texas college: 'Don't let the bastards scare you.'

title: The private journal of Henry William Ravenel, 1859-1887.
summary: In selections from the original notebooks on deposit in the South Carolinian Library, this edition provides a remarkable view of Southern life during the Civil War and Reconstruction. An outstanding botanist, Ravenel's record of detail and his compassionate will to survive result in an unusual account of the man and his times.

title: Self-portrait.
summary: Pioneer Dadaist and Surrealist Ray has written a word portrait of his career in America and Paris, with anecdotes and vignettes of expatriate artists and writers.

title: Forty years behind the wall.
summary: Having lived forty years within the silent Trappist monastery of Gethsemane in Kentucky, Father Raymond provides a detailed account of the life there. His is a lively, witty, intelligent account of daily routines, friends, faith, philosophy, publishing, cancer, and the many ex-GIs who flocked to American monasteries after the World Wars.

title: A Yank in bomber command.
summary: Raymond flew with the Royal Air Force Bomber Command during England's darkest hours, 1940-1943. His accounts of bombing missions to various target sites in Germany and Italy are exciting but understated; only three bombing crews in ten could hope to survive.

title: Confessions of a future Scotsman.
summary: As a young man he discovered he was Scottish instead of Irish. He uses this discovery to explore his sense of his identity and heritage, to dramatize how we become what we think we are.

title: The memoirs of Chief Red Fox.
summary: Chief Red Fox records his own life spanning the early days when he hunted on foot with bow and arrow, traveled with the Buffalo Bill Wild West Show, fought at the battles of Little Big Horn and Wounded Knee, and watched the sad decline of his once-proud race.

title: Letters from an actor.
summary: Written to Robert Mills between January and August 1964, this series of letters describes daily events during the rehearsals, tryouts and opening of the Gielgud-Burton production of Hamlet. The writer, who played Guildenstern, conveys lively observations and impressions of the workings of the theater and the performers involved.

title: The life of Texas Jack; eight years a criminal — 41 years trusting in God.
summary: Texas Jack was an outlaw who claimed credit for numerous bank and train robberies. After a prison sentence and parole he turned evangelist, wrote accounts of his exciting life, sold the pamphlets, and preached about moral and respectable living.

title: Army brat: life story of a West Pointer.
summary: Reeder colorfully describes his lifelong Army career. He was an 'army brat' and lived all over the United States, first with his army-officer father and Southern mother and later as an officer himself, with his wife, four children, and eleven hunting dogs. He was expelled from West Point twice for academic failure, eventually graduated, and performed various duties at U.S. Army posts before World War II. He wrote the training manual, fought in Guadalcanal, was wounded in the Battle of Normandy, had his leg amputated, and then taught at West Point.

title: Memoirs; in cahoots with Lynn Haney.
summary: Best known for his work in TV commercials, the moppet-haired, gravel-voiced third-grader tells about his life and work through pictures and anecdotes.

title: Notes of a processed brother.
summary: In clipped, reportorial style, the author traces his education from Detroit to the West Indies — sent away from American racism — to the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, where he became one of the leaders in a struggle for a student Bill of Rights. The student struggle is the focus, but what is central to this account is the story of a young Black man coming of age and not yet coming to terms with a racist society.

title: Memoirs, with special reference to secession and the Civil War.
summary: As a top statesman of the Confederacy, Regan served as its Postmaster General and Secretary of the Treasury. Imprisoned after the war with Jefferson Davis and other Confederate Cabinet members, he was in solitary confinement for nearly a year. After release he helped the South in its struggle to overcome the ills of the Reconstruction.

title: Memoirs of a dissident publisher.
summary: After a brief resume of his life prior to 1948, a political conservative.

title: A book of dreams.
summary: Reminiscences and dreams contribute to the story of his relationships with his mother and father and his experience with Orgone Energy, the cloudbuster, and the accumulator, all part of the experiments of his father, Wilhelm Reich.

title: Reilly of the White House.
summary: Shortly after Pearl Harbor was bombed, Reilly was made Supervising Agent of the White House Secret Service, charged with protecting President Roosevelt. Here he describes that work (1941-1945) from a personal and professional point of view.

title: The autobiography of Father Reinhold.
summary: A simple, compelling narrative of Father Reinhold's lifetime of religious struggles, which began in Nazi Germany after World War I and led to his persecution and ultimate exile in America in 1936.

title: Shelanu: an Israel journal.
summary: Rennert, an American widow, decided to live in the Israeli frontier city of Beersheba in the 1970's, to be near her son and his family and to explore the country.

title: The money player; the confessions of America's greatest table tennis champion and hustler.
summary: Addicted to the sport at age thirteen, he played and hustled table tennis all over the world, winning seventeen singles or doubles championships. His tense, aggressive playing style is reflected in his writing.

title: Afterglow: memories of a happy ministry.
summary: Renison tells anecdotes about selected moments during his lifelong career as an Episcopal clergyman.

title: Speed with style: the autobiography of Peter Revson.
summary: The book is confined to his life on and off the grand prix circuit in 1973, his last year of racing. It is a tense, realistic, and critical description of life in a dangerous game.

title: Of woman born: motherhood as experience and institution.
summary: Contending that her life is representative, a feminist poet writes of her experience of motherhood and the history of that institution.

title: Reminiscences of Linda Richards: America's first trained nurse.
summary: Brief descriptions of her training in Massachusetts and England, her work at Boston City Hospital, and her medical consulting work in Japan.

title: Court hustler
summary: His second autobiographical book, this one spurred by his well-publicized matches in 1973 against Margaret Court and Billie Jean King.

title: Tennis is my racket
summary: In 1946 Riggs won the world championship in tennis. Here he writes of his tennis life from early years of play, sketches several famous players, and gives pointers on the game.

title: Soldier from Texas
summary: Roberts' account of his life focuses with pride on his years as an army captain in World War II, where he successfully commanded American troops in the Battle of the Bulge and the Battle of Remagen.

title: Letters of James Whitcomb Riley
summary: Riley's poems, many in dialect and many about children, won for him the title of 'The Hoosier Poet.' His simple, affectionate humor, careful technique, and enthusiasm for the works of his contemporaries shine through in these letters to personal friends and literary acquaintances.

title: My story: a new edition and seventeen new years
summary: Remembered mainly for her mystery novels, Rinehart engaged in an amazing variety of social and literary activity. Always ambivalent about her successful career, she stresses the importance of her husband and family while describing her life as writer, literary socialite, war correspondent, and adventuresome traveler.

title: Sixty years of psychical research: Houdini and I among the spiritualists
summary: A stockbroker who investigated psychic phenomena as an avocation describes his hope of discovering empirical evidence of a future life and the widespread fraud among most who claimed to have found it.

title: Taking out my bucketful
summary: Schoolteacher Ritchie describes her whirlwind retirement years of industry and Christian love.

title: Lucy's twentieth century
summary: The author recalls her childhood in Hong Kong, followed by high school and college in California. Later she became an insurance executive and a delegate to two Democratic National Conventions.

title: Survival: my life in love and war
summary: Rivas's autobiography describes his loves and disillusionments, his alternate wealth and poverty.

title: Aphrodite at mid-century: growing up Catholic and female in post-war America
summary: Memoirs of an upper-middle-class Catholic girlhood in and around Washington emphasizing the mild and mundane conventionality of the 1950's.

title: Essays of a Louisiana surgeon
summary: Rives' essays on medical education, doctors, and the practice and frustrations of surgery are wise, witty, and elegantly written.

title: Woody Guthrie and me: an intimate reminiscence
summary: This is a nostalgic account of the friendship between Robbin and Woody Guthrie.

title: His darling wife, Evelyn: The autobiography of Mrs. Oral Roberts
summary: Evelyn Roberts emphasizes the Christian joy of their marriage and the many roles she has played as his inspiration, helpmate, and mother.

title: Autobiography of a farm boy
summary: The author, for thirty years Dean of the College of Agriculture at Cornell University, recalls his boyhood in rural New York and his life and work at Cornell.

title: Never alone
summary: Roberts writes about her love for the theatrical venue and the factors that contributed to her success as a Broadway star.

title: I wanted to write
summary: Roberts analyzes the experience of being a writer, detailing the frustrations and the satisfaction of writing well.

title: My story
summary: Oklahoman Roberts describes his evangelistic career and the impact of his faith healing.

title: Oral Roberts' life story: as told by himself
summary: Evangelist Roberts focuses on his career as a faith healer and describes his experiences.

title: Them were the days
summary: Roberts recounts his experiences with the U.S. Forestry Service and his role in forest firefighting.

title: And they went down into the water: a story about two young hoodlums written by one of them
summary: A witty, tongue-in-cheek account of growing up in Tilmon, Texas.

title: p. in the thicket: an autobiography
summary: The story of his difficult life on the Idaho frontier, a boyhood of poverty and hardship, changed in later life only by his developing career as a popular Western writer during the Thirties.

title: Paul Robeson speaks: writings, speeches, interviews, 1918-1974
summary: A compilation of speeches, articles, editorials, and interviews by and about singer Paul Robeson.

title: As Robie remembers
summary: A collection of brief narratives that go back to the start of the automobile business and carry the author through the city of Chicago.

title: Raymond and I
summary: A gripping journey to Alaska during the Gold Rush to find her brother.

title: Our island lighthouse
summary: The author and her husband spent summers in a lighthouse on a Maine island, describing their life and interests.

title: Third base is my home
summary: Personal glimpses into the life of a Baltimore Orioles' third baseman.

title: The bell rings at four: a Black teacher's chronicle of change
summary: Robinson has had an effective career as a classroom teacher and emphasizes the racial discrimination prevalent in Texas.

title: Duncan Robinson, Texas teacher and humanist: collected writings of Duncan Robinson
publisher: English Department, University of Texas at Arlington
summary: A selection of Robinson's published and unpublished writings covering more than a half century.

title: All my yesterdays; an autobiography
summary: Robinson discusses his career in the entertainment industry and his support for liberal political and social causes.

title: Edwin Arlington Robinson's letters to Edith Brower
publisher: The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press
summary: A collection of letters documenting the poet's development and correspondence with Edith Brower.

title: Frank: the first year
summary: Robinson recounts his first year as the first Black manager of a major league baseball team.

title: My life is baseball
summary: Traded by the Cincinnati Reds to the Baltimore Orioles, he became a crucial player and won the triple crown.

title: Autobiography of George L. Robinson: a short story of a long life
summary: A recollection of a long career as a religious educator and researcher in the Holy Land.

title: A wall to paint on
summary: Her letters reflect deep love and family ties, details of her career as an artist, and her experiences during the Civil War.

title: Road without turning: the story of Reverend James H. Robinson, an autobiography
summary: A frank account of a Black man's struggle to overcome racial discrimination.

title: The making of a man; an autobiography.
summary: Robinson helped form the Freedom Fighters in Cleveland and became vitally involved in demonstrations and actions for racial equality. He describes the summer of 1964, the formation of the Jomo 'Freedom' Kenyatta House, the 1966 riots in Hough, and problems connected with race relations.

title: A boom town lawyer in the Osage, 1919-1927.
summary: Fresh out of law school, Roff set out to establish a practice in an Oklahoma boom town during the 1920's. In those exciting and rough times he encountered big-time operators, bank robbers, murderers, bootleggers, and all kinds of crooks and petty outlaws.

title: Sugar Ray.
summary: He grew up in the ghettos of Detroit and New York to become a world championship boxer, made and spent four million dollars, and retired to enjoy his wife, family, and personal religion.

title: This time the world.
summary: Rockwell documents his development from a bright, independent-minded, and puritanical youth into fanatic leader of the American Nazi Party. Experiences at Brown University and as a wartime Navy pilot led him to hate Jews, Communists, and Blacks.

title: Norman Rockwell, my adventures as an illustrator.
summary: Rockwell is one of America's best-known illustrators, famous for his Saturday Evening Post covers portraying down-home America in a warm and entertaining style. Here he relates his frustrations, failures, and triumphs as well as serious reflections on his art and the state of the country.

title: A personal book.
summary: The story of her pampered and privileged upbringing. Married at twenty to composer Richard Rodgers, who at 27 was already a celebrity, she enjoyed a delightful marriage of maternity, travel, notable and loving friends, and wealth augmented by her invention of the 'johnny mop' and her authorship of books on decorating and entertaining.

title: Pepper!: the autobiography of an unconventional coach.
summary: A low-keyed, good-humored account of Rodgers's life, focused primarily on football. He was a quarterback for the Georgia Tech team that won the 1951 Orange Bowl game; he was a pilot and football coach in the Air Force; he coached the UCLA Bruins and in 1973 returned to his alma mater as head football coach.

title: Diary of Captain Thomas Rodney, 1776-1777.
summary: Captain Rodney was in command of a company of Kent County militia, the only Delaware troops engaged in the battles of Trenton and Princeton. His company left Dover on December 14, 1776, and he recorded in his diary the events of the next six weeks.

title: Roosevelt and Churchill, their secret wartime correspondence.
publisher: Saturday Review Press/E.P. Dutton & Co., Inc.
summary: A collection of some of the World War II messages between the two leaders revealing the cooperation, understanding, and growing friendship in their working together toward common goals.

title: Roosevelt and Daniels: a friendship in politics.
summary: Thirty-year correspondence on career and personal matters between Roosevelt and Josephus Daniels, both politically active in the Democratic Party.

title: Roosevelt and Frankfurter; their correspondence 1928-1945.
summary: The correspondence between Roosevelt and Frankfurter furnishes a record of friendship and insights into the New Deal.

title: Wartime correspondence between President Roosevelt and Pope Pius XII.
summary: Messages emphasizing both leaders' endeavors to alleviate suffering and establish enduring peace.

title: My parents: a differing view.
summary: James Roosevelt discusses his life with his parents and their parenting styles alongside his own public life.

title: Front row seat.
summary: A journalist recounts his observations of major figures and events during his career.

title: Autobiography: condensed from the original edition; supplemented by letters, speeches, and other writings.
summary: A discussion of significant reforms, diplomatic moves, and personal anecdotes from his life.

title: Hunting and exploring adventures of Theodore Roosevelt.
summary: Chronicles President Theodore Roosevelt's hunting and exploring exploits.

title: Fifty years of public life.
summary: An account of Roper's career covering significant posts held during his public service.

title: Beyond my reach.
summary: N/A

title: I'll cry tomorrow.
summary: An actress who worked primarily in New York and Hollywood describes her experience as a child actor and her later career, but the main focus is her struggle against alcoholism and mental illness.

title: And other foolish questions I have answered.
summary: With insight, compassion, and humor Rothstein narrates the story of her repeated initiation into teaching for a decade after her graduation from the University of Michigan.

title: Adventures in Christian journalism.
summary: An editor for the Baptist Standard (Texas) and the Baptist Messenger (Oklahoma) depicts his work as a missionary in journalism.

title: Arrivals and departures: a journalist's memoirs.
summary: A journalist has compiled his autobiography from previously published articles covering various personal and historical events.

title: Under my wings.
summary: He started learning how to fly in 1914 and by 1955 had made a Ripley's record by logging 35,000 air hours.

title: The narrative of the captivity and restoration of Mrs. Mary Rowlandson.
summary: Captured by the Indians at Lancaster, Massachusetts, in 1675, she was forced to live with them until redeemed for twenty pounds. Her narrative describes vividly the battle and her suffering.

title: Letters from Alabama: 1817-1822.
summary: In eighteenth-century novelistic style, a widow writes of her travels and experiences during a time of personal difficulty.

title: The letters of Josiah Royce.
summary: Letters selected for the light they shed on Royce's life, his character, and the period in which he lived.

title: Unquiet pilgrimage: the journal of Robert Stewart Royster.
summary: The diary covers Royster's years spent among the Colombian Indians, focusing on his experiences and contributions.

title: Old man and the boy.
summary: The story of his boyhood in rural North Carolina and his relationship with his grandfather.

title: The man's grows older.
summary: More about his unusual grandfather's influence on his life and values during his boyhood and adult years.

title: Bread and rice.
summary: A journalist caught in the Philippines when the Japanese took over describes her capture, escape, and subsequent survival.

title: My many years.
summary: His second volume is an astonishing record of the pianist's long and active life after World War I.

title: My young years.
summary: Beginning with his childhood in Poland, he writes of the struggles, mistakes, adventures, and miraculous beauty of his first thirty years.

title: Growing (up) at thirty-seven.
summary: Rubin, a Sixties radical yippie leader, writes about trying various popular ideas and therapies in search of maturity and consciousness.

title: Emergency room diary.
summary: The journal of an intern's four-month duty in the E.R. of a large city hospital, detailing various patient interactions and experiences.

title: My life for beauty.
summary: An eventful and successful long life is the subject of the first half of this book, detailing her rise in the beauty industry.

title: Ruby in rough.
summary: Ruby describes his rough-and-tumble childhood and his career attempts, including a stint on Broadway and talk show radio.

title: Father's footsteps.
summary: This book is a combination biography-autobiography chronicling growing up and the relationship with his famous father.

title: Autobiography of Benjamin Rush: his travels through life together with his Commonplace Book for 1789-1813.
summary: Originally written only for his family, this book describes Rush's early life, medical training, and career.

title: Letters of Benjamin Rush.
summary: A prominent physician's letters cover a wide range of interests, sent to leaders in science, philosophy, and family.

title: My dearest Julia: the love-letters of Dr. Benjamin Rush to Julia Stockton.
publisher: Neale Watson Academic Publications in association with the Philip H. & A.S.W. Rosenbach Foundation
summary: These letters to his fiancee detail his affections and thoughts prior to their marriage.

title: Tales of a Western mountaineer: a record of mountain experiences on the Pacific Coast.
summary: This book describes his climbing experiences and the terrain in Washington and Oregon.

title: A world to care for: the autobiography of Howard A. Rusk, M.D.
summary: Dr. Rusk recounts his experiences in rehabilitating patients with disabilities.

title: Horse cars and cobblestones.
summary: Recalls the life of an immigrant family during the early 1900s.

title: A doctor looks at life.
summary: A collection of essays depicting the medical and political philosophy of a prominent surgeon in San Antonio.

title: Elbert Russell, Quaker: an autobiography.
summary: This autobiography recalls his boyhood and career as a professor of religion.

title: Bury me in an old press box: good times and life of a sportswriter.
summary: Russell writes joyfully about his lifelong career as a sportswriter.

title: Victory in my hands.
summary: Russell describes his mental and physical adjustment after losing his hands as a paratrooper.

title: Life is a banquet.
summary: A witty, entertaining account of Russell's career in acting, married life, and various productions.

title: Go up for glory.
summary: The basketball success story of Bill Russell, detailing his achievements and his plea for human dignity.

title: Second wind: the memoirs of an opinionated man.
summary: Russell's lively memoirs detail his life and experiences both on and off the basketball court.

title: Babe Ruth story.
summary: Babe Ruth shares insights about his life in baseball, detailing his long career with the Yankees.

title: Naturalist in two worlds: random recollections of a university president.
summary: Recollections of experiences influencing his thinking as President of the University of Michigan.

title: A private battle.
summary: Ryan's account of his battle against cancer, accompanied by entries from his wife's diary.

title: The game.
summary: Major-league pitcher Ryan covers the high and low points of his career, interspersed with insights from his wife.

title: The letters of Sacco and Vanzetti.
summary: A collection of letters reflecting their beliefs and long struggle for freedom, culminating in execution.

title: Fifty years of neurosurgery: a personal story.
summary: Dr. Sachs recounts his pioneering work in the field of neurosurgery.

title: My first 65 years in advertising.
summary: One of the giants of mail-order, direct-response advertising, Sackheim writes of his beginnings and later career as well as demonstrating how to write ads.

title: I'm a lucky one.
summary: The composer of 'The Ballad of the Green Berets' and other songs writes of his nine-year career, much of it spent as a member of the Special Forces, known as the Green Berets, in Vietnam.

title: The emancipation of Robert Sadler.
summary: In 1916 his widowed father sold him and two of his sisters as slaves. When he was fourteen he ran away to Greenville, North Carolina, not knowing how to read, write, or eat with utensils.

title: Heartland.
summary: Satiric, intellectual comedian writes a chaotic account of his life as an entertainer, intermingled with his social and political views.

title: An unfinished life: an autobiography.
summary: Her life as dancer and the spiritual philosophies that shaped her dance.

title: An unfinished life: an autobiography.
summary: Her life as dancer and the spiritual philosophies that shaped her dance.

title: With Kennedy.
summary: After joining Robert Kennedy's staff in 1957 as an investigator, Salinger became John Kennedy's press secretary in 1959 and worked with him during the election campaign and presidency.

title: Pages from the diaries of DeWitt Clinton Salisbury, 19th century Wisconsin citizen and Civil War soldier.
summary: In his diaries, Salisbury writes of his education, the Civil War and his part in it, and his postwar return to farming and family life.

title: Words of Maurice Samuel: selected writings.
summary: This compilation of extracts from Samuel's voluminous writings offers a polemicist's view of what it means to be Jewish.

title: From the forecastle to the cabin.
summary: Captivated by romantic ideas of life at sea, Samuels ran away from home at eleven years and signed on as cook and cabin boy.

title: Recollections of seventy years.
summary: After discussing his rural childhood and adolescence, Sanborn focuses on his increasing involvement in politics and the abolitionist movement.

title: Letters of Carl Sandburg.
summary: Letters from 1898 to 1963 tell the life story of this great poet.

title: The middle span: Vol. II of Persons and Places.
summary: The second volume of his autobiography begins in 1866 with his student days in Germany.

title: Sons come and go, mothers hang in forever
summary: This is a collection of 67 essays in which Saroyan offers vignettes of his meetings with celebrities, his views on other celebrities, and a portrait of his life.

title: I knew a phoenix: sketches for an autobiography
summary: A poet and novelist analyzes her search for a world of her own and her influence of her family and early education.

title: In search of complications: an autobiography
summary: A personal account of his journey and experiences after immigrating to the U.S. and his career in medical research.

title: My own particular screwball: an informal autobiography
summary: Humorous recounting of his childhood, baseball career, and restaurant ownership.

title: A collection of speeches, essays, poems, letters, and journal entries by a physician-minister who was active in the abolitionist movement before the Civil War.
summary: A collection of various writings from a physician-minister involved in the abolitionist movement.

title: Cleaning the air.
summary: A personal account of the author's confrontation with significant organizations due to his reporting.

title: Ten thousand working days.
summary: Describes various jobs and careers pursued over 42 years, capturing the humanity of workers.
occupations: Plumber, Coal Miner, Farm Hand, Union Organizer, Politician, Sociologist

title: The four seasons of success.
summary: Assesses the effects of success on American writers through the lives of six authors.

title: My life as an Indian.
summary: Chronicles adventures in Montana Territory and experiences with the Piegan Blackfeet.

title: Peanuts jubilee: my life and art with Charlie Brown and others.
summary: A mix of comic strip collection and the author's personal life story.

title: Knee pants.
summary: A nostalgic look at a journalist's middle-class boyhood.

title: Nothing's sacred on Sunday.
summary: A self-critical analysis of journalism experience.

title: The autobiography of Carl Schurz.
summary: Reflects on his political fervor, career in politics, and influential contemporaries.
occupations: Politician, Secretary of the Interior, Senator

title: Intimate letters of Carl Schurz, 1841-1869.
summary: Letters provide commentary on political events during Schurz's leadership.

title: My share of wine: the memoirs of Anton Schutz.
summary: Memoirs detailing life as an artist and etcher after World War I.

title: Black and conservative: the autobiography of George S. Schuyler.
summary: Reflects on his journalistic career and a conservative stance on overcoming prejudice.

title: The captivity of Mary Schwandt.
summary: Recounts the author's capture by Sioux Indians and her experiences.

title: Lawyering.
summary: Details her legal career defending high-profile cases.

title: Tell thy children: the autobiography of an American rabbi.
summary: Describes his Jewish childhood and rabbinical career in the U.S.

title: God bless pawnbrokers.
summary: Shares stories from his tenure at the Provident Loan Society.

title: Diary of a pigeon watcher.
summary: An introspective exploration of the author's life and talents.

title: Farewell to Salonica: portrait of an era.
summary: A narrative of the author's boyhood in Turkey and the societal changes he witnessed.

title: Challenge and crisis in missionary medicine. Illustrated.
summary: This articulate, well-organized book presents Dr. Seel's ideas on both the practical and theological aspects of organizing and maintaining appropriate health-care facilities and health education among primitive Korean villagers.

title: Sego. Preface by Robert Paul Lamb. Foreword by Jim Bakker. Illustrated.
summary: Born of a poor evangelist family in Enigma, Georgia, he grew up amid poor but fervently religious folk. Married young to Naomi Easter, he struggled for years to establish himself, his brothers, and eventually Naomi as a financially solvent gospel-singing group.

title: Me and mine: the life story of Helen Sekaquaptewa. As told to Louise Udall.
summary: The life of a Hopi Indian woman who tells with beautiful simplicity of the old customs and mores of the tribe. She learned new ways of doing things, such as canning food rather than drying it and having preventative shots for her children, but kept some of the best parts of her Indian culture as well.

title: Tell the truth and run.
summary: A journalist recalls the beginning of his career in Pittsburgh with its corrupt press, his later experiences as a World War II foreign correspondent, and then his work as a peacetime foreign correspondent in places such as England, France, Europe, and Russia.

title: The bright lights: a theatre life. Illustrated.
summary: The author examines the serious business of acting as a profession and the joys, the discipline, the technique of her craft.

title: Over 50 — so what.
summary: A chatty memoir of her life as an entertainer by a singer popular in the Forties.

title: The river of no return; the autobiography of a Black militant and the life and death of SNCC. With Robert Terrell.
summary: A Black leader writes of his part in the struggle for equality in the 1960's, the beginnings of SNCC, his work in the Civil Rights Movement in Mississippi, Alabama, and South Carolina.

title: Years were good.
summary: At thirteen he left school to become a cub reporter. Editor of the Cleveland Press since 1928, he describes his long career as a journalist.

title: A tale of two valleys: an autobiography.
summary: Born and raised on a Minnesota farm, he became central in the development of the University of Minnesota's Northwest School of Agriculture and served as U.S. congressman for Minnesota (1927-1933).

title: Memo from David O. Selznick. Illustrated.
summary: The legendary producer of such films as Rebecca and Gone with the Wind, Selznick was an inveterate and prolific writer of telegrams, letters, and especially memos.

title: Rebel raider: being an account of Raphael Semmes's cruise in the C.S.S. Sumter; composed in large part of extracts from Semmes's Memoirs of Service Afloat written in the year 1869.
summary: Journal entries describing Semmes' command of the Sumter (April 18, 1861 — April 1, 1862), while assigned to drive enemy commerce from the Southern seas. Includes detailed comments on international law during wartime.

title: King of comedy. As told to Cameron Shipp.
summary: His life in show business, from New York burlesque to Hollywood film, with a major focus on Mabel Normand, his great love and one of his major comedians.

title: Memoirs of a dancer: shadows of the past, dreams that came true, memories of yesterdays. Illustrated.
summary: The first third of the book concerns the author's upbringing in the luxury of pre-revolutionary Odessa and the poverty of Kiev after the revolution and his parents' divorce. The middle section focuses on Sergievsky's emigration to the United States as the son of a famous test pilot and on his education and career as a dancer with the Metropolitan Opera Company.

title: Letters of Mother Seton to Mrs. Julianna Scott.
publisher: Father Salvator M. Burgio Memorial Foundation in Honor of Mother Seton
summary: Letters written from 1798 until Mother Seton's death in 1821 exhibit a thoughtful, tender spirit, ever devout through childbirth, a happy marriage terminated by her husband's death in 1803, and ostracism by many relatives and friends when she converted to Catholicism in 1805.

title: Trail of an artist-naturalist: the autobiography of Ernest Thompson Seton. Illustrated by author.
summary: A naturalist, illustrator, and popular writer about wildlife writes of his youth in northern England, emigration to Canada, and subsequent travels throughout the Canadian Northwest, Alaska, and the American Southwest.

title: The worlds of Ernest Thompson Seton. Edited, with introduction and commentary by John G. Samson.
summary: A beautifully illustrated compilation of Seton's writings in the habits of animals and birds he has encountered in the Canadian and American North, East, and West, prefaced by a brief biography by John Samson.

title: All the brave promises: memories of Aircraftwoman 2nd class-2146391.
summary: An American, the author volunteered for the WAAF (Women's Auxiliary Air Force) of the British Royal Air Force during World War II. Her moving story of that experience makes vivid the difficulty of adjustment to wartime Britain.

title: Not so wild a dream.
summary: A strong, well-written commentary on his early years in South Dakota and Minnesota, the formation of his liberal philosophy, and a moving account of his experience as a foreign correspondent in World War II.

title: Diary of Samuel Sewall. Edited with introduction by Harvey Wish.
summary: This abridgment of Sewall's diary records New England witch trials, Indian massacres, 'small pocks' epidemics, and other acts of God with pious musings on the significance of all.

title: Diary of Samuel Sewall, 1674-1729. Edited by M. Halsey Thomas.
summary: A full diary kept for 56 years by an important and respected man of learning who knew and kept contact with notable people of his place and time. It provides a panorama of life and events in early Boston.

title: Anne Sexton: a self-portrait in letters.
summary: In this selection from her private letters, the character of the poet is revealed — her struggle with mental illness, her gift for friendship, craving for love, search for faith, and fascination with death.

title: United States attorney: an inside view of 'Justice' in America under the Nixon Administration.
summary: In his key role as U.S. Attorney during the early 1970's he observed or participated in important events including Watergate, FBI operations, the Agnew payoffs, and national-security paranoia.

title: Crusading doctor: my fight for cooperative medicine.
summary: Born in Syria, he immigrated to America in 1898, finished his education and became a doctor, spending most of his career in Oklahoma where he worked seriously to organize cooperative medicine.

title: The story of Bobby Shantz. As told to Ralph Bernstein.
summary: Shantz proudly recounts the story of his career in baseball as a left-handed pitcher, emphasizing his two years pitching for the Philadelphia Athletics, 1951 and 1952.

title: Witness to the truth.
summary: A moving and dramatic account of the destruction of Polish Jews, written by one who survived and worked to help others who lived through concentration camps in post-war Germany until 1951.

title: Old priest remembers, 1892-1978. 2nd. Edition, enlarged.
summary: Father Sharp writes evocatively and lovingly of his youth in turn-of-the-century New York City, of his seminarian training in Baltimore and Washington, DC, and of his career as a priest which ranged from being a parish priest to a hospital chaplin to a priest on a cruise ship.

title: Brain surgeon: autobiography of William Sharpe. Foreword by John Haynes Holmes.
summary: A brain surgeon who practiced in New York and China recounts his schooling and career while reminiscing about his colleagues and patients.

title: All in a day's work.
summary: A journalist writes of his early training on the job for small-town papers in the South and Midwest, followed by fifteen years as a feature writer for Universal Service for the Hearst papers and others.

title: A Pima past.
summary: An Indian family saga unfolding the twentieth-century cultural assimilation of her generation, the inevitable changes in lifestyle, the impact of Anglo culture without loss of proud Pima identity.

title: The trouble with Cinderella: an outline of identity.
summary: A narrative of discovery, written after he had achieved success as a band leader and jazz musician but was still searching for a meaningful life.

title: This house against this house.
summary: His fourth book of personal experience in important historical events with a liberal analysis of international affairs. This volume deals with World War II, its causes, and the making of peace.

title: The parson takes a wife.
summary: Raised in Richmond, Virginia, to be a lady, she had some difficult and humorous experiences learning the conventional behavior of a parson's wife. Her book reflects the mores of a ministry and her own wit and common sense which helped her survive.

title: Cobra story.
summary: Racing-driver Shelby's courageous, colorful American individualism won him the admiration and respect of his European counterparts at Le Mans and in the Gran Turismo picture. He came close to snatching the laurels from the long-dominant Ferrari with his American-designed and built Cobras.

title: Personal memoirs of P.H. Sheridan: General United States Army.
summary: Volume I details Sheridan's military career from West Point to midway through the Civil War. He recounts his experiences with 'the savages,' Indians in California and Vancouver, and traces the military maneuvers of Generals Granger Nelson, Sill, Grant Wilson, Rosecrans, Bragg, Hunter, and Early. Volume II chronicles his career as general through the Civil War, Reconstruction, and the Franco-German war, with extensive descriptions of battles.

title: Soaring: the diary and letters of a Denishawn dancer in the Far East, 1925-1926.
summary: As the youngest member of the famed Denishawn Company during their fifteen-month Far Eastern tour in 1925-26, Sherman wrote these letters and diary entries detailing her adventures, impressions, and thoughts. They reveal not only the conditions of travel and performance in exotic places but also her own maturation and growth.

title: Letters to a lady in the country, together with her replies.
summary: Letters between 'Paul,' a Kentuckian living in New York, and 'Caroline,' a New Yorker living in Kentucky, were published serially in Books, 1924-1925. At the beginning of the correspondence each wished to be back home, but gradually their desires changed as did their relationship to each other.

title: How to succeed in business without being a man!
summary: Shelton illustrates her theory that women can be wives and mothers and millionaires, too, with the saga of her divorces, debts, single parenthood, and ventures into the 'man's world' of life insurance and real estate. Interspersed (and summarized at the end) are tips on personal and professional motivation.

title: Memoirs.
summary: Although chiefly a Civil War memoir, his book includes recollections of California (1846-1859), Missouri, Louisiana, Kansas, and New York. The detailed account of his war experience is deftly told, revealing the great military strategist in the vivid context of war.

title: War is Hell! William T. Sherman's personal narrative of his march through Georgia.
summary: Sherman's account of his famed march through Georgia provides a fascinating look at history, highlighted here by striking photographs and drawings and touching correspondence, much of it with his wife, Ellen. ('Taken principally from the second volume of the Memoirs of General William T. Sherman, by himself')

title: Forgive us our press passes.
summary: As an international correspondent she achieved a spectacular career, covering stories on heads of state, on major political events, on the social scene of Washington.

title: Memoirs of a defrocked psychoanalyst.
summary: Shepard published this pornographic account of his experiences with group sex, homosexuality, voyeurism, and other orgiastic variations in 1972. Five years later, as a consequence, his medical license was revoked.

title: Endure and conquer.
summary: On July 4, 1954, Dr. Sheppard's wife was murdered. Everything connected with that and subsequent events was endlessly and sensationally debated: his accusation, trial, conviction, appeals, and then imprisonment. Finally in 1966 the Supreme Court voted to set aside the conviction. This is his own story of the efforts to prove his innocence from the time of the murder and his conviction through the retrial and his vindication.

title: Shero: the man behind the system.
summary: A hockey enthusiast from an early age, he was spotted by a New York Rangers scout when he was seventeen. Later, thanks to his special system, he coached the Philadelphia Flyers to their Stanley Cup championship.

title: Among friends: an autobiography.
summary: An Episcopal bishop, well known and loved by many friends and colleagues, writes of his ministry. Rector of Trinity Church, Boston, he served as Bishop of Massachusetts for twelve years.

title: From the diary of Dr. Philip Sher: a physician who has reflected on life — with a point of view on volunteer social service.
summary: Memoirs, human-interest stories, contributions to newspapers, correspondence, and community testimonials comprise this diary of a rabbi-physician whose primary interest was social welfare. As founder of the Jewish Welfare Federation, Sher was instrumental in the promotion of Jewish education and various medical and social services in Omaha, Nebraska, during the first half of the twentieth century.

title: Brooke book.
summary: Twelve-year-old Brooke Shields collects her school essays, press clippings, poems, and six-page autobiography in a slick, lavishly illustrated book. The child of an ex-model and a cosmetics executive, she began her modeling career as Ivory soap baby at eight months and has probably been one of the most photographed pre-teens in America. She touches on her emerging film career, but only mentions briefly 'Pretty Baby,' a film in which she plays a child prostitute.

title: Memoirs of Andrew Sherburne: a pensioner of the navy of the Revolution.
summary: Sherburne served on the Continental ship-of-war Ranger from the age of thirteen and later on other ships, including privateers. He was captured by the British three times during the Revolution. After the war he became a Baptist minister.

title: Always a winner: on Route 66.
summary: Shinnick intermingles the story of his career as a linebacker for the Baltimore Colts, 1959-1969, with commentary on the importance of the Christian faith and a discussion of his off-season speaking tours for the Fellowship of Christian Athletes.

title: A vagabond newsman.
summary: Raised in Georgia during the depression of the 1890's, he left college at nineteen to edit a weekly newspaper and then traveled about working at various newspaper and other jobs in the South and Midwest. Later he was a reporter and editor in Savannah and Macon, became involved in art and politics, and editorialized against the Ku Klux Klan.

title: Luckiest man alive: being the author's own story, with certain omissions, but including hitherto unpublished sidelights on some famous persons and incidents.
summary: Blinded when a teenage aspiring journalist, Shippey nevertheless succeeded in his chosen career, writing for the Kansas City Star and the Los Angeles Times. In between, he covered World War I in France, where he met and married Madeleine Babin and worked in Tampico, Mexico.

title: Berlin diary: the journal of a foreign correspondent 1934-1941.
summary: Shirer's journal, written mostly in Berlin during and just before World War II, is, he says, 'a first hand account of a Europe that was already in agony and that, as the months and years unfolded, slipped inexorably toward the abyss of war and self-destruction.'

title: End of a Berlin diary.
summary: A continuation of his Berlin Diary, this volume records the end of the war, the beginnings of peace, the inner workings of the Nazi military machine, the high hopes for the fledgling United Nations, the widening gulf between Russia and the West.

title: Twentieth century journey: a memoir of a life and the times, the start, 1904-1930.
summary: Shirer evokes the turn-of-the-century Chicago of his early childhood and Cedar Rapids, Iowa, where he grew up as a neighbor of Grant Wood and Carl van Vechten and attended Coe College. After that he went to Paris, became a foreign correspondent there and in London, and interviewed many notable world figures, whose portraits he presents here, including Gertrude Stein, Isadora Duncan, Charles Lindbergh, and James Thurber.

title: Memoirs of a lawman.
summary: Liberally edited to ensure the accuracy and readability of the original manuscript, written when Doc Shores was over eighty, the book includes a section of frontier reminiscences and another describing his eight years as sheriff of Gunnison, Colorado.

title: Autobiography.
summary: The distinguished historian and humanitarian worked for the cause of world peace by helping to avert international crises and to negotiate agreements.

title: The winning edge.
summary: The Winning Edge is inscribed on the rings worn by the Miami Dolphins as mementos of their Super Bowl victory in 1973. In 1971 Shula was voted AFC Coach of the Year; in 1972 he became the first NFL coach to win 100 games in his first 10 years. His book describes his coaching experience and philosophy.

title: Ground I walked on: reflections of a college president.
summary: The history of his 21-year presidency of Hunter College and his service as U.S. Deputy Commissioner in Bavaria reflect his concerns for education.

title: Part of a winter: a memory more like a dream.
summary: Sibley's version of we-took-to-the-woods focuses on the life in the Colorado wilderness that he shared with his wife, four young children, one of whom was born there. Editor of a newspaper in Crested Butte, Colorado, he searched throughout this time for the fundamental simplicity and existential unity of life as exemplified by his hero, Henry David Thoreau.

title: Story of the Winged-S: new chapters and illustrations on recent developments of the helicopter; an autobiography.
summary: A pioneer in aviation, Sikorsky developed the helicopter, immigrated to the United States from Russia after the Revolution, and continued to play an important role in the development of helicopters and planes. Those of his company carry the Winged-S emblem.

title: "Judge Sam."
summary: Liberally peppered with anecdotes, this account describes a judge's lifetime on the bench.

title: Here lies Leonard Sillman: straightened out at last/an autobiography.
summary: Theatrical producer Leonard Stillman is credited with introducing to the stage many people who later became stars in theater and films. His various productions of New Faces (1934, 1936 ...) are his most notable accomplishments; 1952 introduced Eartha Kitt.

title: Bubbles: A Self-Portrait.
summary: Opera singer Sills provides an exuberant, delightful, abundantly illustrated survey of her life, generally pleasant and professionally successful. She focuses on her career (especially with the New York City and San Francisco operas) and family — her beloved mother; devoted husband, Peter Greenough; and children, whose birth defects prompted her fund-raising efforts for the March of Dimes.

title: The man who was Bilko: the autobiography of Phil Silvers.
summary: A performer since childhood, Silvers played in all kinds of theatrical undertakings from burlesque to movies, but many people remember him best as Sergeant Bilko in the long-running TV comedy series.

title: This laugh is on me: the Phil Silvers story.
summary: The private life and the up-and-down show-biz career of Silvers, a comedian of vaudeville, burlesque, Broadway, Hollywood, nightclub and television fame.

title: From seven to seventy: memories of a painter and a Yankee.
summary: Simmons, best known for his mural paintings including those in the Library of Congress, writes with good humor about his Puritan forbears (he grew up in Concord in Hawthorne's 'Old Manse'), his exploration of painting sites in Paris, England and Brittany. Instrumental in founding 'Ten American Painters' in 1898, he also explores the dual allegiance of his peers to tradition and to Impressionism.

title: Assignment Huntsville: memoirs of a Texas prison official.
summary: Simmons was general manager of the Texas Prison System 1930-1935, after having been a banker and the manager of the Sherman, Texas, Chamber of Commerce. A fluent writer and good storyteller, he focuses on the highlights of his prison management (including the capture of Clyde Barrow and Bonnie Parker) and his philosophy of treating prisoners— education, hard work, sports, and no-nonsense corporal punishment, if warranted.

title: Letters.
summary: The extensive correspondence (1830-1870) of a South Carolina writer who published 82 volumes of poetry and fiction gives a vivid account of the man, his intellect, and the times.

title: Johnswood.
summary: The author of children's books and the widow of John Gould Fletcher relives the last years of her husband's life in Arkansas in an effort to come to terms with his death. The book includes some letters and poetry by Mr. Fletcher.

title: Cabin on a ridge. Illustrated.
summary: During the Depression when he could no longer earn a living as a painter and book illustrator in New York, the author went to the Ozarks, built a log cabin on a homestead, and settled down to work among the simple mountain people. In the five years he spent there he found a beautiful environment, a simpler, fulfilling life, and friendly, hospitable neighbors.

title: Glory of thy people: the story of a conversion.
summary: Describes conversion of a New York Reformed Jew, a psychiatrist, who became a Trappist monk.

title: Deo Gratias et Mariae: Thanks Be to God and Mary.
summary: Born in a small village in Lithuania, she became a teacher and then a Benedictine nun. She writes of her religious education, her study at the Art Academy, her life as a nun during the German occupation, and later her visit to Rome.

title: Concession to the improbable: an unconventional autobiography.
summary: Simpson discusses his career as a paleontologist and his world-wide fieldwork (often on expeditions for the American Museum of Natural History). A prolific author (during 1939-41 he wrote 63 articles), much of his work focuses on findings in Venezuela, Brazil, and Argentina, though he also did work in Africa, Australia, and the American West.

title: Air with armed men.
summary: A poet writes of his youth, his wartime army experiences, his education, and teaching career. He examines his relationships with the world of contemporary poetry and literature and particularly his friendships with other poets.

title: North of Jamaica.
summary: In an autobiography that has the character of a novel, the author creates the scenes of his childhood in Jamaica, his emigration to the U.S. to attend Columbia, his experience as a rifleman in World War II, and his writing, giving the sounds and smells, the conversations, and occasional reflections on the life he is recalling. The later chapters include a careful look at the literary movements with which he was involved.

title: O.J., the education of a rich rookie. Illustrated.
summary: Simpson's rookie year in professional football did not measure up to his expectations or the expectations others had of him. He had a lucrative contract and endorsements, but his team, the Buffalo Bills, were disjointed and unbalanced, just managing to salvage private triumph from public defeat that year.

title: The story of my life.
summary: Sims' professional peers rate him as the foremost gynecologist of his time because of his innovations with 'Sims' speculum,' 'Sims' position,' and the vesicovaginal repair. Sims focuses here on his childhood in South Carolina, his frustratingly long courtship, and debilitating intestinal problems which overshadow the most significant aspects of his work.

title: West Side cop. Illustrated.
summary: A career guidance book for young people, this volume examines Sims' youth, education, and the events which led him to become a police officer in Chicago.

title: Southern belle.
summary: Raised as a Southern lady, she describes her New York education, her successful marriage to Upton Sinclair, and the life they shared among intellectuals, reformers, and politicians.

title: Trial of the poppy; behind the mask of the Mafia.
summary: For 25 years he worked for the Federal Bureau of Narcotics, exposing the network of international drug traffic and the Mafia bosses who ran it. His book focuses particularly on the Mafia, their codes and methods. It includes a glossary of illegal drug terms.

title: To set the record straight: the break-in, the tapes, the conspirators, the pardon.
summary: Sirica records his involvement with the Watergate affair, a five-year struggle from the first indictments through a series of legal altercations to the final judgment against the high-level conspirators and the eventual presidential resignation. Finally, Sirica renders his judgment on Nixon and the Ford pardon.

title: A Texas cowboy: or, fifteen years on the hurricane deck of a Spanish pony, taken from real life.
summary: A rocky excursions account of Siringo's escapades as a cowboy in Texas, New Mexico and Louis. His work of cowpunching and driving stock to market along the Chisholm Trail was punctuated by encounters with Indians, benign and hostile, buffalo, the capture of Billy the Kid, an attack of smallpox, and amorous misadventures.

title: Fiddler on the roof: the odyssey of concert violinist Jaroslav Siskovsky.
summary: Having received his first violin lesson at age five, he thereafter fiddled his way through various dance band and orchestra engagements until he became a member of the highly respected New York String Quartet. A large portion of his book is devoted to travels throughout the world.

title: My first eighty years.
summary: Sites happily recollects his West Virginia upbringing as one of a blacksmith's thirteen children, his education at Manchester College in Indiana, his career as a schoolteacher in Indiana, as a Y.M.C.A. secretary for a decade in Milwaukee, and as a traveling salesman thereafter for Rand McNally. Over half the book is devoted to an account of his retirement travels throughout the United States, Canada, and Mexico with his wife.

title: I'm Eve.
summary: A candid self-portrayal, written as part of her therapy, by the woman whose classic case of multiple personality became the subject of The Three Faces of Eve. She writes of the heretofore unknown details of her childhood, two marriages, and continuing struggle with her illness.

title: Particulars of my life.
summary: From small town boyhood through his early groping toward his life work, a controversial behaviorist recalls his beginnings with simple clarity.

title: The ape in me.
summary: The book is intended to describe her life as an actress, but it is full of anecdotes about a variety of things that have interested her for a few minutes here and there.

title: Bottoms up!
summary: A collection of short reminiscences describing her girlhood, life on the stage, playing the straw-hat belt, traveling, and lecturing.

title: Happy family.
summary: A family memoir, with good descriptions of the world of American theater evolving from personal details of the Skinner family — Otis, Maud and Cornelia — up to Cornelia's debut as an actress on Broadway. Previously published under title, Family Circle.

title: Nuts in May.
summary: In chapters previously printed in The New Yorker magazine, the author humorously describes incidents in her family and stage life.

title: Our hearts were young and gay.
summary: The hilarious adventures of two young ladies off to Europe on an unchaperoned trip with main stops in London and Paris.

title: Footlights and spotlights: recollections of my life on the stage. Illustrated.
summary: An actor from his youth, Skinner tells of his first part, his rise in the theater, the great actors and actresses of his day, the roles he loved best out of the 325 he played, including 38 parts in 14 Shakespeare plays, and of the plays he produced himself.

title: Scalpel and cross. Illustrated.
summary: A modestly told account of the compassionate endeavors of Dr. Skinsnes, a Lutheran medical missionary, and his wife, a nurse, to build and maintain a hospital in Sinyang, China, during the 1920's and 30's. He was extremely successful in his low-key pursuit of the ideals of good medical care and Christianity, but his endeavors were halted when the Japanese bombed the hospital during the Sino-Japanese War. Evacuated during World War II, he oversaw the successful postwar rebuilding of the hospital.

title: Don't get me wrong — I love Hollywood.
summary: A collection of anecdotes and profiles add to this nostalgic look at the star-studded days of Hollywood by a columnist who was part of that scene since 1933.

title: A naturalist in Costa Rica. Illustrated.
summary: The author is a naturalist who has spent forty years in wild parts of tropical America, principally in Costa Rica. He records here his experiences and observations of plants, birds, insects, animals as he found and studied them in their natural state.

title: My years with General Motors.
summary: His own story and that of General Motors, the corporation he served as chief executive officer for 23 years and as board member and committee participant for 45 years.

title: The long watch.
summary: Five months after Pearl Harbor, the author, aged 37, enlisted in the Navy; later he became an Executive Officer. His book is a moving recollection of the stress of combat, the battle fatigue coming after days without sleep, the teamwork of military life, the fear of separation, loss, and death.

title: Report from Engine Co. 82.
summary: A frightening insider's account of the life and work of a group of firefighters in the South Bronx and a scathing condemnation of the kind of politics that complicates the already dangerous job of firefighting.

title: Two reels and a crank.
summary: The story of his life as one of the first film producers, of his company, Vitagraph, and of the outrageous early days of silent film-making.

title: Through unknown African countries; the first expedition from Somaliland to Lake Lamu.
summary: Combining his interests in sporting trips and in scientific exploration, Smith joined a friend on a journey to Somaliland in 1893 to acquire the requisite knowledge to mount a future expedition. In June 1894 he set out to explore the country, learn as much as possible about the land, the natives, the animals, insects, fish, fossils, and plants.

title: Mennonite country boy: the early years of C. Henry Smith.
summary: The youth, education, and early career of a Mennonite farm boy who later taught and wrote about the beliefs, faith, and principles of the Mennonites and Anabaptists.

title: Different drums: how father and son bridged generations with love and understanding.
summary: A serious rift between father and son, its effect on their relationship, and the understanding they developed in order to bridge the gap. Written by a clergyman.

title: New Jersey political reminiscences, 1828-1882.
summary: A condensation of three journals and reminiscences, this book covers Smith's years in Salem, New Jersey, as a newspaper editor, his political career as leader of the Whig and Republican parties in New Jersey, legislator, and Clerk of the Supreme Court, perhaps the most lucrative sinecure in the state. He records anti-monopoly activities of the 1850's, New Jersey's support for the Union war effort, and the factional rivalry within the Republican Party after the Civil War.

title: Chester A. Smith of Peekskill: his memoir.
publisher: The Historical Committee of the New York Annual Conference of the Methodist Church
summary: Written in response to a resolution of the New York Annual Conference of the Methodist Church, this memoir concentrates on Smith's participation in the affairs of the General Conferences of The Methodist Church, and includes his civic, educational, and church activities in his hometown of Peekskill, New York. Smith toured the Holy Land, built a school in India, and fought liquor traffic during Prohibition.

title: Black book of Clark Ashton Smith.
summary: A notebook by Clark Ashton Smith, a writer of science fiction (mostly for Weird Tales) and occult poetry, which contains plots for stories, drafts of poems, and observations on life and philosophy: 'Communism: the Utopia of army ants' and 'Do others — the modern perversion of the Golden Rule.'

title: David Smith by David Smith.
summary: This stunning collection of photographs of Smith's sculptures and preliminary drawings for them is accompanied by commentaries culled from 10,000 of Smith's Whitmanesque poems, letters, and notes in the Archives.

title: Brief against death.
summary: In an articulate but unsentimental style, Smith recounts the process by which he claims he was wrongly accused of the brutal murder of teenager Victoria Zielinski in 1957 and how, acting as his own lawyer, he pursued every legal means available to gain a new trial and a stay of execution, battling the state of New Jersey, the appellate courts, and occasionally the Supreme Court. Written from Death Row in prison in Trenton.

title: The diary of Elihu Hubbard Smith.
summary: After graduating from Yale at fifteen, Smith was sent to Timothy White's Academy at Greenfield Hill for a year before he returned home to study medicine with a doctor. After three years he went to the College of Philadelphia, where he studied with Benjamin Rush. Still too young to become a doctor, he turned to writing poetry and drama, editing, taking part in a literary circle, the Manumission Society, and other groups.

title: Congressman from Mississippi.
summary: During his twelve years in Congress Smith tried to maintain a moderate course while working toward the gradual elimination of racial discrimination. His book describes his personal and political life in the events that led him to Washington, his conduct in office, the bitter opposition by racists who accomplished his defeat in 1962, and his views about the future.

title: Flights of fancy.
summary: A successful Philadelphia lawyer, he took up flying as an escape from his busy schedule described in his earlier book, Week-end Pilot. Here he tells of more flying adventures, including the fanciful pleasures as well as some highly practical information.

title: Week-end pilot.
summary: When his law career made him overwrought and tense, Smith searched for a hobby as a release. After several abortive tries, he fell in love with flying his own plane. He found it exhilarating and liberating, opening a new door to happiness for himself and his family.

title: P.O.W.: two years with the Vietcong.
summary: Smith, a U.S. Army Special Forces sergeant, was captured by the Vietcong north of Saigon in November 1963. For two years he traveled and lived with the Vietcong in jungle camps. He writes sympathetically of his life in the National Liberation Front's safe areas and of the people we call the VC.

title: For heaven's sake.
