summary: Describes strict upbringing of her younger years as an evangelist's daughter, through her final reconciliation with her father, his acceptance of her on her terms — her marriage and her private life.

title: To hell in a handbasket.
summary: A writer-humorist writes of growing up in Illinois and Ohio and of his work on such newspapers as the Denver Post, the Huntingdon Press, and the New York World-Telegram.

title: The world, the flesh, and H. Allen Smith.
summary: A humorous compilation of anecdotes about Smith's Midwestern upbringing, his family, his career as a newspaperman, and the flamboyant and bizarre people he has known in New York, Hollywood, 'The Wild West,' and suburbia — mostly writers and actors.

title: Our paternal hearth.
summary: Virginia congressman Smith's writing takes the form of a letter to his grandchildren, signed 'Affectionately, Grandaddy.' Delightful nostalgia of Virginia country life from the Civil War era on is punctuated by quotations and line drawings as Smith concentrates on the lives of people around him rather than on his own achievements.

title: Joseph Smith HI and the restoration.
summary: An articulate account of the life of Mormon founder Joseph Smith's grandson, Joseph Smith III, also a prominent Mormon leader. In the book, which is topically organized and divided into short segments that reflect its initial serial publication, Smith discusses his three successive happy marriages and sixteen children; the history of the Mormon Church and settlements at Nauvoo, Illinois, and Utah; leaders, religious philosophies and tenets, disagreements and persecutions — the latter two dominated by church conflict over polygamy, which the Smiths did not practice.

title: Upon my lips a song.
summary: Famous as a singer on radio and television, she writes of her early career experience, the pain of being ridiculed as a 'fat girl,' her long and gratifying friendship with her manager/announcer Ted Collins, and many great names in radio and television.

title: Diaries, 1859-1874, of the Reverend Leonard Smith, circuit rider.
summary: This huge volume is a typed transcription of ten diaries by Reverend Smith, who was a pious clergyman and rode circuit in Ontario and later in Illinois. His diaries are filled with comments on sermon subjects and biblical quotations, observations of nature and the weather, temperance statistics, gossip, current events, and lists of expenses.

title: The journey.
summary: A personal, spiritual quest for the meaning of self and life in contemporary times by the author of Killers of the Dream.

title: Follow me! The apprenticing of disciples.
summary: A Pentacostal clergyman explains how he began a divinely inspired discipleship ministry in Brooklyn in 1972, converting disillusioned Vietnam war veterans and hippies to become active disciples who eventually conducted ministries on their own.

title: "Dearp. Mr. President": the story of fifty years in the White House mail room.
summary: In 1897 Smith became a mail clerk in the White House, opening mail for nine presidents from McKinley through Truman. Here he describes his work, the events, and people associated with the White House during those years.

title: Why I am a Methodist.
summary: A Methodist clergyman in Kansas relates how important his faith has been in his work and life and discusses aspects of the Methodist faith itself.

title: Confessions of a psychic.
summary: Smith recounts her search for a philosophy of life leading to her conviction that spirits communicated with her through automatic writing, ghosts, poltergeists, seances, and other supernatural occurrences.

title: Conversion of a psychic.
summary: A psychic narrates a series of anecdotes and parables that involve a curious mixture of the occult, supernatural, and charismatic Christianity, including speaking in tongues and faith healings. The book combines her history as a Christian with her life as a psychic.

title: Non-existent man: an autobiography.
summary: Throughout a wide-ranging career as professor at several universities, Texas state senator, U.S. congressman, military governor in Sicily and Italy, radio personality, and debater on the Chicago Round Table, he maintained strong convictions of truth and conscience.

title: Life at my fingertips.
summary: At five years he lost sight and hearing when he had spinal meningitis. Inspired by Helen Keller, he became the second deaf-blind person to complete college, earned a Master's Degree from New York University, developed a career as a lecturer and independence in his own apartment.

title: Journey to the beginning.
summary: At 22 he planned to travel around the world, but became fascinated with China, remained as a journalist, and did not return to the United States for thirteen years.

title: The long revolution.
summary: Snow analyzes aspects of modern China — medical care, population control, the cultural revolution, the Chinese Communist Party, the people, and the communes.

title: A hell of a life.
summary: Solomon paints a bitter picture of his childhood in Allendale County, South Carolina, and describes his attempts to integrate local employment and register Blacks to vote.

title: I cannot go back.
summary: The son of country music singer Hank Snow regretfully delineates his childhood and struggles with addiction before converting to Christianity.

title: God-called man: a series of supernatural experiences.
summary: Written as a personal testimony to God's truth, this book conveys experiences through the rhetoric of fire and brimstone.

title: From Missouri.
summary: Snow's autobiography describes small-town life and the agricultural changes in Missouri.

title: Codline's child: the autobiography of Wilbert Snow.
summary: A wandering teacher describes his life through poetry and teaching.

title: From a doctor's heart.
summary: A Russian immigrant doctor shares his narrative on serious heart disease and its personal impacts.

title: Broadway heartbeat: memoirs, of a press agent.
summary: A journalist and press agent shares his experiences on Broadway.

title: The longest street: a memoir.
summary: A Broadway columnist writes of his life and work in show business.

title: Some days were happy.
summary: Descriptions of his boyhood in rural Connecticut and the nostalgia of life after World War II.

title: Fabric of my life: the autobiography of Hannah G. Solomon.
summary: Raised in a pioneer Jewish family, she became a prominent feminist and founded the National Council of Jewish Women.

title: Journeys with the Senator.
summary: A devoted wife describes her world travels as her husband conducts work for the Inter-Parliamentary Union.

title: Rise to follow: an autobiography.
summary: A concert violinist recalls his early years and significant musical experiences.

title: Private journal of John Glendy Sproston, U.S.N.
summary: Sproston was a member of Commodore Perry's expedition to the China Seas and Japan, providing personal observations and sketches.

title: Cheyenne memories
summary: An important contributor to Cheyenne history, Stands in Timber provides insights into the history and culture of his people as they recall and interpret it. He collected reminiscences and lore of his tribe to add to his personal memories for this collective memoir of the Cheyenne.

title: The terrors of justice: the untold tale of Watergate
summary: Although Stans briefly mentions his childhood and youth, his book focuses at length on the Watergate scandal and on what he calls the 'innocent victims,' specifically Stans himself.

title: Brief authority: excursions of a common man in an uncommon world
summary: A personal story of his thirty years in the Foreign Service, chiefly in China and Thailand, where he served as U.S. Ambassador.

title: Eighty years and more (1815-1897); reminiscences of Elizabeth Cady Stanton
summary: The author has written the story of her private life as wife, mother, and housekeeper using diary extracts, sketches of her travels, and her opinions on many social questions. Her public career as a leader in the movement for the emancipation of women is described in her The History of Woman Suffrage.

title: Awakening of India: forty years among the Telugus
summary: An account of the years he and his wife spent as Baptist missionaries in South India, set in a context of the religious and political struggles of the times.

title: Driftwood valley
summary: During 1937-1941 the author and a friend lived in the north-central British Columbia woods. Based on her diary, this book is a story of the wilderness and their relation to it.

title: Up against the brass
summary: Stapp objected to what he saw as openly antidemocratic procedures in the U.S. Army, so he joined the Army and formed the American Servicemen's Union. It provides legal aid, information, and moral support for G.I.'s who are at odds with the military establishment.

title: Out of left field: Willie Stargell and the Pittsburgh Pirates
publisher: Two Continents Publishing Group/A Prairie House Book
summary: This is an illustrated collection of interviews with Willie Stargell, his wife Dee, and other Pittsburgh Pirates during the 1973 season — Nelson Briles, Steve Blass, Richie Zisk, and Dock Ellis. Stargell discusses his career, racial bigotry in the Texas Leagues, life on the road.

title: Growing up, and I find a frontier
summary: These reminiscences evoke an atmosphere of the early twentieth century through incidents from his family life, his pleasant recollections of frontier escapades, and amusing incidents in his youth and early manhood as he became a draughtsman and an architect in Duluth.

title: Starling of the White House: the story of the man whose Secret Service detail guarded five presidents from Woodrow Wilson to Franklin D. Roosevelt
summary: After a brief description of his early years in Kentucky, Starling gives a warm and personal view of the presidents he guarded and the inner life of the White House.

title: Blaze Starr: my life as told to Huey Perry
summary: Born during the Depression of the 1930's in backwoods West Virginia, she overcame her poverty-stricken mountain childhood by making use of her body. She became a sensation as a stripper who defied the moral codes of heartland America.

title: Born in a bookshop; chapters from the Chicago renascence
summary: A detective novelist, historian, critic, poet, anthologist, essayist, columnist, bibliographer, and book collector, Starrett narrates his own adventures with glimpses of the literary life and its participants.

title: An Amherst boyhood
summary: Written for the 125th anniversary of the college, the book describes his boyhood in Amherst, where his grandfather was president of the college, and his own college days.

title: Three years with Company K
summary: An unpretentious narrative of an infantry soldier's daily life during three years of the Civil War, describing his thoughts and adventures in the Grand Old Army.

title: Bluegrass craftsman: being the reminiscences of Ebenezer Hiram Stedman, papermaker, 1808-1885
summary: A Kentucky paper manufacturer in the early 1800's describes his life and work, providing an interesting record of the paper industry.

title: Johan Stal (John Steel) from Smaland: farm lad to Idaho prune king
summary: After describing his Swedish childhood, he writes of his immigration to America in the 1870's, his homestead in Nebraska, brief years in Leadville, Colorado, and finally settling in Boise, Idaho, to develop fruit orchards.

title: I remember . . . with letters to and from Richard St. Clair Steele 1888-1907
summary: Chatty, detailed letters between Jennie Koons and her husband-to-be tell of her experiences as a New England conservatory student and music teacher and his as Indian Agent in the Midwest territories at the turn of the century.

title: Discovery: the autobiography of Vilhjalmur Stefansson
summary: An adventurous, exciting life full of great achievements that made him a top authority on the Arctic and its people is recorded by the polar explorer.

title: The autobiography of Lincoln Steffens
summary: Steffens narrates the story of his life as a muckraking journalist, focusing on various aspects of organized crime and political chicanery in high and low places.

title: Letters
summary: Forty-six years of personal letters to friends, many of them giving warm family anecdotes, others discussing his thoughts and beliefs on current events and social problems.

title: Wolf Willow: a history, a story, and a memory of the last Plains frontier
summary: Stegner analyzes his family's four years of summer homesteading in Whitemud, Saskatchewan, 1915-18, as typical pioneer experiences in a quintessential pioneer settlement.

title: Letters to Elizabeth: a selection of letters from John Steinbeck to Elizabeth Otis
summary: These 44 letters from over 600 that Steinbeck wrote to Elizabeth Otis, his literary agent between 1938 and 1965, provide insight into his work habits and creative process.

title: Bags up! Great balloon adventures
summary: A balloonist's exciting adventures from his first solo to record 1000-mile flights, along with dangerous or amusing feats of other daring men and women.

title: A life in photography
publisher: Published in collaboration with Museum of Modern Art, Doubleday & Co., Inc.
summary: An outstanding photographer, Steichen narrates his first attempts at picture making and his lifetime developing his art.

title: Dreemz
summary: This book consists of a year's worth of diary fragments by a former Nixon speechwriter who goes west to Los Angeles to write film scripts and novels.

title: Dear Sammy: letters from Gertrude Stein and Alice B. Toklas
summary: During his military service in France in World War II, Steward was befriended by Stein and Toklas, with whom he corresponded thereafter.

title: Two: Gertrude Stein and her brother, and other early portraits, 1908-12
summary: In this early period, Stein wrote portraits of herself, her brother, and people she thought were not very important; portraits of characters, not of names.

title: The journal of Judith Beck Stein
summary: Claiming that there has been a consistent long-term conspiracy of sabotage dedicated to the destruction of her life and values, Stein asserts that she has been forcefully and wrongfully kept in Chestnut Lodge Mental Sanitarium.

title: Journey into the self: being the letters, papers, and journals of Leo Stein
summary: The papers, primarily letters written between 1900 and 1947, present a chronicle of an intellectual with diverse interests.

title: Steinbeck: a life in letters
summary: Hundreds of letters covering 45 years reveal Steinbeck's early struggles to get published, his lifelong association with agents, his three marriages and two divorces, and his literary successes.

title: In touch
summary: A straightforward account of his twenty-first year which he spent partly in Vietnam and partly in the United States, discussing war and social issues.

title: From alien to citizen. Modern Jewish Experience
summary: An Austro-Hungarian Jewish immigrant, the author converted to Christianity and became a Congregational clergyman and professor of theology.

title: A brand from the burning: from the depths of despair to the gates of heaven
summary: Stemmer gives an account of his unpleasant life and explains why he rejected traditional religion in favor of spiritualism.

title: Casey at the bat: the story of my life in baseball as told to Harry T. Paxton
summary: A colorful baseball personality since 1912, Stengel shares his ups and downs in the game, stunts he pulled, and his opinions on baseball.

title: "Tell it all": The story of a life's experience in Mormonism: an autobiography
summary: The author writes to tell her own story and to expose the wrongs of Mormon women of Utah, their mistreatment and sufferings under polygamy.

title: Recollections; his diary kept when prisoner at Fort Warren, Boston Harbour, 1865
summary: His prison diary includes extracts from the Bible and the classics as well as comments on his daily routine, conversations, and thoughts.

title: The taste of ashes: an autobiography
summary: Stern narrates his life, focusing on significant events and personal reflections.

title: I am a woman — and a Jew.
summary: She describes her struggle to free herself from the conventions of her religion and womanhood, and then to find herself.

title: Memoirs of a maverick publisher.
summary: After his early years as a journalist he became an editor, publisher, successful owner of seven daily papers, and a powerful political figure in New York, New Jersey, and Philadelphia.

title: With the Weathermen: the personal journal of a revolutionary woman.
summary: The story of her transformation from a shy, conventional student to a militant feminist, SDS organizer, and Weatherman committed to violence.

title: The journey.
summary: Countess Cecilia Sternberg tells of her risky departure by train with her husband and daughter from newly Communist Czechoslovakia.

title: Shadow and light: the life, friends and opinions of Maurice Sterne.
summary: Sterne's autobiographical notebooks and letters, along with art criticism and recollections of his wife and friends, provide a chronology of his life.

title: The diaries of Edward R. Stettinius, Jr., 1943-1946.
summary: The record of an industrialist with scant background in international relations thrust into key positions of foreign policy-making during a crucial period.

title: Time of humanities: an oral history: recollections of David H. Stevens as director in the Division of the Humanities, Rockefeller Foundation, 1930-50.
publisher: Wisconsin Academy of Sciences, Arts and Letters
summary: Stevens describes his direction of the Rockefeller Foundation's Division of the Humanities and his interaction with many scholars of the time.

title: Letters.
summary: This selection by the poet's daughter from 3300 extant letters covers a span of sixty years, including letters that refer to his poetry and contain biographical information.

title: Chip on my shoulder: autobiography of Walter J. Stevens.
summary: The varied life of a Black Bostonian who worked in service at Harvard and later became a labor investigator and a photographer.

title: Adlai Stevenson's public years: with text from his speeches and writings.
summary: Stevenson's speeches reveal a man serious about America's future and at the same time irrepressibly humorous.

title: The papers of Adlai E. Stevenson
summary: An extensive collection of Stevenson's writings and speeches covering various periods of his life.

title: Victoria, Albert, and Mrs. Stevenson.
summary: A collection of letters that provide a frank and witty account of the early Victorian court as experienced by Sarah Stevenson.

title: By a stroke of luck! An autobiography.
summary: Stewart accounts his life, luck, and anti-fascist activities leading to his blacklisting in 1950.

title: Letters of a woman homesteader.
summary: The author writes letters about her life and neighbors while homesteading in Wyoming.

title: Letters on an elk hunt: by a woman homesteader.
summary: Stewart's letters narrate experiences of life in the West and human emotions.

title: Openings and closings.
summary: An account of the actress's childhood through her career achievements.

title: Clyfford Still.
summary: An introduction to Clyfford Still's paintings and philosophy.

title: Early recollections and life of Dr. James Still.
summary: The story of a self-taught Black man who became a doctor despite early educational challenges.

title: The Stilwell papers.
summary: The war journals of General Stilwell during his command in the China-Burma-India theater.

title: On active service in peace and war.
summary: An account of Stimson's public service from his point of view, co-written with McGeorge Bundy.

title: The paintings and the journal of Joseph Whiting Stock.
summary: Stock's journal provides a list of paintings and includes his extant letter and biography.

title: A general's story.
summary: An account of a general's life between the World Wars with anecdotes of military and personal experiences.

title: As I knew them; presidents and politics from Grant to Coolidge.
summary: A review of the period from 1868 through 1926 based on Stoddard's impressions.

title: Recollections, personal and literary.
summary: Stoddard's recollection of his life among nineteenth-century literary figures.

title: Lincoln's third secretary: the memoirs of William O. Stoddard.
summary: A native of Illinois, Stoddard provides a friend and employee's view of Lincoln and the Civil War.

title: Night journey: a story of survival and deliverance.
summary: A political scientist's exploration of what it means to be fully human, recounting his escape from the Nazis and subsequent life experiences.

title: Promises of power: a political autobiography.
summary: The first Black mayor of predominantly white Cleveland describes his efforts to build coalitions and address power structures.

title: Evolution of an architect.
summary: The story of one of the most outstanding American architects of the twentieth century, illustrated with photographs and drawings.

title: Fifty years a journalist.
summary: Stone's account of his journey in journalism and politics spanning his active life.

title: I was a Black Panther.
summary: The experiences of a young boy who joined the Black Panthers, exploring the movement's appeal.

title: Collision course.
summary: Storey's experiences as a bulldozer driver turned Pentecostal evangelist portrayed engagingly.

title: California editor.
summary: Storke interweaves his career in Santa Barbara with a history of the city during its development.

title: I write for freedom.
summary: A Pulitzer Prize-winning editorialist's background for his political philosophy against the John Birch Society.

title: Joseph Story: A collection of writings by and about an eminent American jurist.
summary: A comprehensive collection of writings that highlight Joseph Story's contributions as a jurist.

title: As we remembered Mother: memoirs.
summary: A memoir focusing on the author's remarkable mother and their personalities.

title: I've always done it my way.
summary: The author reflects on personal life experiences and the socio-political landscape since the turn of the century.

title: Life and letters of Harriet Beecher Stowe.
summary: A collection of writings that provide insight into Stowe's life and thoughts.

title: Life of Harriet Beecher Stowe: compiled from her letters and journals.
summary: This compilation focuses on Stowe's Hartford school days, her youthful conversion to Christianity, her marriage and gradual involvement in abolitionism.

title: Men and decisions.
summary: Having served in high-level positions under four presidents, Strauss writes with knowledge and conviction of momentous decisions and events.

title: Don't never say cain't.
summary: Strainchamps writes humorously on the origins and effects of her Ozark Missouri dialect, how she shed it for standard English and eventually became a successful professional writer.

title: Conversations with Igor Stravinsky.
summary: These interviews encompass Stravinsky's views on his own compositions and those of others, his anecdotal impressions of contemporary musicians and writers.

title: Paul Strand: sixty years of photographs: excerpts from correspondence, interviews, and other documents.
summary: A handsome selection of a photographer's lifetime work, prefaced by Calvin Tomkins's biographical portrait and followed by Strand's autobiographical observations.

title: The diary of James J. Strang: deciphered, transcribed, introduced and annotated.
summary: The diary covers a period in Strang's life when he was teaching in a rural school, offering insights into his future as a Mormon prophet and colonizer.

title: Bittersweet.
summary: Details Strasberg's problems with drugs, a failed marriage, and her ultimate triumph over these crises.

title: Palaces and prisons.
summary: An well-written memoir combining reflections on travels with recollections of notable personalities.

title: The eleventh house: memoirs.
summary: A busy book crammed with anecdotes and memories about a life filled with energy and interaction with famous figures.

title: Diary & sketchbook of a journey to "America" in 1866 & return trip up the Missouri River to Fort Benton, Montana.
summary: A description of a five-month journey illustrated by original sketches.

title: The kingdom within: a spiritual autobiography.
summary: Presents an allegory of Stuart's mental state after a heart attack, meditating on his lifetime values.

title: The bureau: my thirty years in Hoover's FBI. With Bill Brown. Illustrated.
summary: Sullivan writes about working as an FBI agent under Hoover, focusing on Hoover's relationships with the U.S. Presidents from Eisenhower to Nixon. He also describes Hoover's various pecadillos (he was a gambler, an egomaniac, and social butterfly) and the FBI scandals and mistakes Hoover concealed.

title: Under orders: the autobiography of William Laurence Sullivan. Preface by Max F. Daskam.
summary: In complex but compelling, occasionally poetic, prose, Sullivan discusses the history and tenets of Roman Catholicism and of liberal Protestantism, using his own life only as a backdrop for the issues.

title: An age of mediocrity: memoirs and diaries: 1963-1972.
summary: The third volume of the memoirs and diaries of a journalist who for nearly four decades interviewed history-making individuals and reported on crucial events throughout the world.

title: Last of the giants. Illustrated.
summary: This volume, one of a series of books correspondent Sulzberger has written, contains interviews and assessments of Charles de Gaulle, Khrushchev and Churchill, and entries from the author's diaries from 1954 through 1963.

title: A long row of candles; memoirs and diaries, 1934-1954. Illustrated.
summary: This book is composed of a reporter's notebooks, jottings of remembered conversations or events which were unusual or pleasant or represented important people in his life.

title: Postscript with a Chinese accent: memoirs and diaries: 1972-1973.
summary: This last volume in his series of memoirs and diaries culminates in his 1973 visit to China after seventeen years attempting to gain admittance.

title: Seven continents and forty years: a concentration of memoirs. Foreword by Andre Malraux.
summary: New York Times foreign correspondent Sulzberger presents fascinating excerpts from his journals (1938-1973), emphasizing politics, heads of states, social and military policies of the countries in Europe and Asia he traveled in.

title: Marina: letters and diaries of Marina Sulzberger. Edited by C.L. Sulzberger.
summary: Marina, wife of New York Times foreign correspondent C.L. Sulzberger, wrote happy, delightful letters to her Greek mother, children, husband, and hosts of friends, describing her world travels with her husband and commenting sensitively on the people they met and the joys of family life.

title: J.D. Sumner; gospel music is my life. Edited by Bob Terrell.
summary: One of the most productive writers of gospel music, he sang with the Sunshine Boys, the Blackwood Brothers, and the Stamps Quartet. He devoted a great deal of time to the Gospel Music Association and was the moving force behind the first National Quartet Convention.

title: Run with the vision. With Stephen Conn. Illustrated.
summary: As president of the Lester Sumrall Evangelistic Association (LeSea), the author ministers by magazine, radio, and TV to millions of people around the world and has founded and supports a Bible College, orphan homes, and other religious causes.

title: A life worth living. Illustrated by Clarence Ellsworth.
summary: A rambling narrative of pioneer life in Minnesota, North Dakota, and California, with details of town life and the development of the railroads by an ordinary but interesting man.

title: I, Willie Sutton. As told to Quentin Reynolds.
summary: A New York bank robber and jail breaker describes his life as a criminal, fugitive, and prisoner. He explains how he succeeded in crime but how his life was ruined as a result of it.

title: Where the money was. With Edward Linn.
summary: Sutton's account of his career as a gentleman bank robber at the top of his profession is exceptional in its candor, excellent style, and analysis of a robber's motives and methods.

title: Frontier mother: the letters of Gro Svendsen. Translated by Pauline Farseth and Theodore C. Blegan with introduction by Theodore C. Blegen.
name_of_translator: Pauline Farseth and Theodore C. Blegen
summary: In affectionate letters to her family in Norway, written between 1861 when she immigrated with her new husband and her death in 1878, Svendsen describes her life and feelings in the New World.

title: My company.
summary: As Captain of Company D. 101st Engineers, he describes the work of his troops in France laying out roads and building machine-gun emplacements, dugouts, trenches, and barbed-wire systems.

title: Fifty years a barrister in Orange County.
summary: While describing his own legal practice in southern California, he includes comments on the early history of Spanish and Mexican culture, notable changes in the practice of law, and the phenomenal development of Santa Ana.

title: Woman's doctor: a year in the life of an obstetrician-gynecologist. With Barbara Lang Stern.
summary: A physician's story of what happens in the delivery and operating rooms, of a surgeon's busy life, of problems encountered, like infertility, venereal disease, and premature delivery.

title: Journal of Lt. Thomas W. Sweeny, 1849-1953. Edited with introduction and notes by Arthur Woodward.
summary: A colorful, gritty account of life in Southwestern military outposts, 1849-53, notably Camp Yuma (Arizona) and San Isabel (California), 'where the thermometer averages 108 degrees in the shade and 130 degrees in the sun.'

title: There must be a better place. As told to Carol Boyle LaPorte. Illustrated by Barbara Sally.
summary: Sweet describes her childhood in Recklinghausen, Westphalia, Germany, during Hitler's rise to power in the 1930's. She was an ambivalent participant in Hitler's youth-work program, studied nursing, and liked serving as a nurse despite heavy bombing and fighting throughout war-torn Germany.

title: The Arapaho way: a memoir of an Indian boyhood, by Althea Bass. Recorded, 1966.
summary: The memoir of one of the last full-blooded Arapaho Indians living on an Oklahoma reservation is remarkable for its detail and nobility, as well as the beautiful reproductions of Sweezy's paintings.

title: My story: immigrant/executive/traveler. Illustrated.
summary: Immigrant Swenson became a Lutheran clergyman in Illinois but eventually found his major contribution as director of a Lutheran publishing concern.

title: When the angels laughed: Eddy Swieson tells his story. With Howard Norton.
summary: An inspirational account of how Swieson, a Chinese born Ie Swie Sing in Indonesia, was reared from malnourished infancy to physical and spiritual adulthood by his foster mother, Rini Tan. Swieson had a religious experience as a teenager that triggered his conversion from Buddhism to evangelical Christianity.

title: "Good evening!": a professional memoir.
summary: As newspaperman, foreign correspondent, and radio commentator, his experiences and contacts comprise a roster of noted events and people from World War I through post-World War II.

title: Living in awe. Edited with preface and epilogue by Marshall Dill, Jr.
summary: This chatty reminiscence of the author's 25-year career as an opera singer in Munich, Berlin, Budapest, London, and New York has been arranged by the editor by geographic location, opera house (Covent Garden, the Metropolitan Opera), and opera, especially works by Wagner, Strauss, and Verdi.

title: Intimate letters of John Cleves Symmes and his family: including those of his daughter Mrs. William Henry Harrison, wife of the ninth President of the United States. Edited by Beverly W. Bond.
publisher: Historical and Philosophical Society of Ohio
summary: A selection of his personal letters and those of his family and intimate friends, intended to portray the everyday family life of the founder of the Miami Purchase.

title: Where the wagon led: one man's memories of the cowboy's life in the Old West.
summary: A cowboy's life on the open range in the days before homesteaders moved in with plows and fences. Symons regrets the passing of a way of life and shares his memories of everyday life on the range, his battles with nature, livestock, rustlers, and progress.

title: Reporters, kings, and other vagabonds: an autobiography.
summary: A journalist writes of his boyhood and education in Hungary, his early experience as a Hungarian reporter, his immigration to the United States, and his long career as a reporter, emphasizing his personal experience rather than the events he wrote about.

title: Leo Szilard: his version of the facts: selected recollections and correspondence. Edited by Spencer R. Weart and Gertrud Weiss Szilard.
summary: An informative account of the developments leading up to and beyond the first atomic bomb, as transcribed from tape recordings, letters, and memos.

title: The best of Stillmeadow: a treasury of country living.
summary: Selections from seven previous volumes describing the author's life in a country home in Connecticut, bought in the late Thirties to escape the chaos of urban and international affairs.

title: Book of Stillmeadow.
summary: To escape from urban living and the threats of war, the author and her friend bought an old farm in Connecticut in the late Thirties.

title: Harvest of yesterdays. Drawings by Pamela Johnson.
summary: A pleasant reminiscence of a writer's early and later years, with charming and amusing anecdotes of people, places and pets.

title: Stillmeadow sampler. Illustrated by Edward Shenton.
summary: Divided by the four seasons and beginning in the spring, this book samples everyday living in the New England country and shares the tranquil contemplation of that life's meaning.

title: Playing for life: Billy Talbert's story. With John Sharnik.
summary: In spite of the diabetes he fought from age ten, he became an international tennis star holding several titles for singles and doubles. His book tells of the lifelong struggle between success and disease.

title: About my mother.
summary: Talbot's book of memories and mourning moves sporadically from one event to another as she recounts incidents in her mother's life, death, and funeral.

title: Memoir of Colonel Benjamin Tallmadge. Eyewitness Accounts of the American Revolution.
publisher: The New York Times & Arno Press
summary: An account of incidents during the Revolutionary War with which he was primarily connected as head of the Second Regiment of Light Dragoons. He came through the war unscathed and later served in Congress for sixteen years.

title: Beyond coincidence: one man's experiences with psychic phenomena. With Harve Ardman.
summary: Citing documentary evidence and scientific verification, Tanous has written about his psychic powers, clairvoyance, healing, telepathic communication, and the uses he has made of these abilities.

title: Better scramble than lose. As told to Jack Olsen. Illustrated.
summary: In a breezy, conversational ramble over his career as quarterback first with the New York Giants and then with the Minnesota Vikings, the author explains successful and controversial plays, shares his feelings when the 'scramble' works and when everything he tries falls through.

title: Your amiable uncle: letters to his nephews.
summary: Written during his first trip abroad with his wife and parents (1903-1904), Tarkington's imaginative, humorous letters were sent to his three nephews in Indiana.

title: Some strike it rich: memoirs and tales of a native son of California.
summary: This series of anecdotes covers the author's adventures as a prospector, miner, and fisherman during the Depression to his extraterrestrial experiences in recent years.

title: The conversion of a Klansman: the story of a former Ku Klux Klan terrorist. Foreword by Leighton Ford. Epilogue by Harold E. Hughes.
summary: Tarrants focuses on his activities as a Ku Klux Klan terrorist in Mississippi in the 1960's, which culminated in his attempt to bomb the home of a Jewish businessman in 1968.

title: The third door: the autobiography of an American Negro woman.
summary: Raised in Birmingham, Alabama, she graduated from college, converted to Catholicism, and started a career in journalism which led her to significant contributions in civil rights.

title: House near Paris: an American woman's story of traffic in patriots.
summary: Remembered as the blond heroine in many Charlie Chan movies, she married a Frenchman just before World War II and remained in France throughout Nazi occupation as an important member of the Underground resistance.

title: Memoirs and opinions, 1926-1974.
summary: A collection of essays, some personal memories written for this book, others previously published, and some critical essays meant to intensify the reader's awareness of literature and art — by a distinguished poet and critic.

title: They call me Assassin.
summary: Tatum, tackle for the Oakland Raiders, discusses his hyper-aggressive style of football, attempting to mitigate his reputation as 'the meanest, dirtiest, hardest-hitting, rottenest bastard who ever played the game of football.'

title: Forces of power.
summary: Taub's rationale for his book is that he has known powerful people in high places and has been involved in important actions including big favors and big money.

title: Coasting captain: journals of Captain Leonard S. Tawes relating his career in Atlantic coastwise sailing craft from 1868-1922.
summary: Tawes' seagoing career pictures the operation of an American coasting schooner plying the East Coast and Chesapeake Bay before steamships took over.

title: The diary of Edward Taylor.
summary: This diary is a record of his journey from England to Boston, his three years' stay at Harvard, and his trip to Westfield.

title: Elizabeth Taylor: an informal memoir by Elizabeth Taylor; With photographs by Roddy McDowell plus a collection from Elizabeth Taylor's family album.
summary: A superficial, public-relations account of Elizabeth Taylor's fairy-tale life: childhood on a four-hundred-acre English estate; emigration to Hollywood to escape World War II; instant child stardom.

title: Way it was with me.
summary: This often hilarious account describes Taylor's career as a singer beginning at fifteen as a vaudeville performer.

title: Swords and plowshares.
summary: After serving in World War II, Taylor became Superintendent of West Point, Commander in Berlin, Commander of the Eighth Army in Korea, then Army Chief of Staff, discussing lessons learned during his career.

title: Seeing the elephant: letters of R.R. Taylor, Forty-Niner.
summary: 'Seeing the elephant' meant graduating from the status of greenhorn, which Taylor did on his Panama voyage to San Francisco and in the gold fields.

title: Diary of a disbarred lawyer: an autobiography.
summary: Most of the book is composed of trial transcripts, with narrative interspersed, written by a lawyer convicted of grand larceny in an insurance fraud.

title: Harem scare'm.
summary: Young graduate on vacation tour of Europe and Africa reports on her travels in Morocco with humor.

title: Reminiscences of my life in camp.
summary: A view of military life in the Civil War by an educated Black woman whose husband was in the First South Carolina Volunteers, the earliest Negro regiment organized by the Union Army.

title: Story of my life.
summary: Taylor's life is interwoven with the religious history of his age; he began riding circuit in Virginia and became a missionary in California in 1849.
other_places_lived: California, Australia, India, Ceylon, South America, Africa

title: Dune boy: the early years of a naturalist.
summary: A naturalist writes with warm affection and nostalgia of his grandparents, their farm in the Indiana Dunes, and the influence of this experience on the development of his values and his career.

title: Aloha, my love to you: the story of one who was born in paradise.
summary: A remarkable, well-written story of her life on a ranch in Hawaii, the early death of her mother, and strong influence of her father's love and values thereafter.

title: Talking to myself: a memoir of my times.
summary: Terkel's stream-of-association roams backward and forward over the high and low spots of life in Chicago, focusing particularly on quintessential interviews he has conducted.

title: I was a monk: the autobiography of John Tettemer.
summary: After spending 25 years as a Roman Catholic monk, Tettemer made the painful decision to leave the order because he had lost his belief in creed and dogma.

title: One mile an hour: the priestly memories of Rt. Rev. Msgr. William J. Teurlings.
summary: Father Teurlings spent 62 years in Louisiana parishes, traveling by horse, bicycle, and car, speaking in Creole when necessary.

title: The traipsin woman.
summary: Raised in a poor Kentucky family, she became a county legal secretary which sent her traveling to remote sections of the hill country.

title: God gets in the way of a sailor.
summary: This provocative book raises a profound philosophical and psychological question about who has the right to determine another person's sanity.

title: My story in black and white: the autobiography of Jesse O. Thomas.
summary: Thomas has written a compelling narrative of his life, which was largely devoted to the betterment of Blacks and to the promotion of interracial harmony.

title: The strength of the hills.
summary: A charming book about Thane's return-to-the-land from London and New York to a 180-acre farm in Vermont.

title: Good evening everybody: from Cripple Creek to Samartana.
summary: Thomas's enjoyment of life and world-wide adventure inspires this tale of his life from boyhood in Cripple Creek, Colorado, until the eve of World War II.

title: Reluctant rebel in Air Force blues: a unique military autobiography.
summary: Theberge writes to explain two court-martial trials involving his alleged robbery of another airman.

title: So long until tomorrow: from Quaker Hill to Kathmandu.
summary: A story of the 1940-1976 adventures of the well-known newscaster known by presidents, popes, and prime ministers.

title: California and other states of grace: a memoir.
summary: Theroux engagingly writes the story of her life as a child, adolescent, and young wife, with memorable relationships.

title: Southwest ramblins.
summary: Therriault kept a diary of winter trips to California, Arizona, and New Mexico, visiting national parks and monuments.

title: Many a night's journey.
summary: Thomas tried to communicate with and warn relevant people because of visions he had concerning future events.

title: Reminiscences of the last sixty-five years.
summary: Thomas writes of the life and times in nineteenth-century America.

title: Dateline: White House.
summary: A White House correspondent under four presidents seems personally affronted when the president does not arrange news breaks for the convenience of the press.

title: The making of a feminist: early journals and letters of M. Carey Thomas.
summary: From journal entries, letters, and editorial additions, Thomas emerges as a remarkably well-educated young woman intensely aware of her sex and determined to give other women a better chance to be educated.

title: Hopping on the border: the life story of a bellboy.
summary: In 1927 he settled down to hopping bell for hotels in several Southern states, having worked in an incredible number and variety of service jobs.

title: By Emily possessed.
summary: A busy actress in theater, movies, and television tells the story of her activities along with those of her actor husband and son.

title: Down these mean streets.
summary: An organizer and worker for the rehabilitation of drug addicts, Thomas writes vividly of his childhood and youth growing up in Spanish Harlem.

title: A musical autobiography. Biography by George P. Upton. Record of works performed. Illustrated.
summary: Thomas's autobiography occupies only 92 pages of this volume; much of the rest is filled with a biographical 'Reminiscence and Appreciation' by George Upton. Thomas describes his career as a violin soloist (begun at age 10) and conductor of various orchestras, notably the Chicago Symphony 1891-1905.

title: Octagonal heart. Illustrated by Arthur Marokvia.
summary: Recollections of a writer's pleasant childhood among her wealthy Greek relatives in St. Louis, Missouri.

title: Sister of the road: the autobiography of Box Car Bertha. As told to Ben Reitman.
summary: Before she began hoboing at the age of sixteen, she lived in a variety of homes, from railroad camps to experimental communes, associating with the I.W.W.'s, anarchists, and others involved in radical lifestyles. Her life as a hobo was a natural extension of her childhood.

title: E-6: the diary of a major league shortstop.
summary: The fast-paced story of shortstop Thompson's 1975 season with the Minnesota Twins and his adjustment to the discovery that he had leukemia. He received experimental treatment at the Mayo Clinic and continued playing through the season in top form.

title: Draggerman's haul: the personal history of a Connecticut fishing captain.
summary: Captain Ellery, well-known and respected draggerman, tells his story like a fisherman examining the haul from his net. He recalls his experiences learning fishing from his father, designing draggers, and trying his hand at music and painting, with natural simplicity and love for his work.

title: American daughter.
summary: The struggle of a young Black girl who grew up in a rural Midwestern farm town, went to college, and then to Chicago in the Thirties to try to find work.

title: Fear and loathing in Las Vegas; a savage journey to the heart of the American Dream.
summary: This work first appeared in Rolling Stone Magazine, no. 95, November 11, 1971, and no. 96, November 25, 1971. It is ostensibly the story of a wild trip from Los Angeles to Las Vegas taken by the author and his attorney. Drugs and alcohol precipitate much of the action.

title: Challenger: Mickey Thompson's own story of his life of speed.
summary: He won his first racing records with a car named 'Challenger' (1959) and during the next three years he set many speed records. His book describes his early experience with cars, the development of his winning cars, and the life of a racer.

title: Autobiography of Elder Wilson Thompson: embracing a sketch of his life, travels, and ministerial labors, in which is included a concise history of the old order of regular Baptist Churches.
summary: Thompson describes his spiritual nurturing and growth, the religious experience that convinced him to become a Baptist clergyman, and his career thereafter as a preacher in rural Kentucky, Indiana, Missouri, and Ohio. He discusses various issues of Baptist doctrine and church trials to determine whether some members of the church had violated these doctrines.

title: Historical letters: a collection of letters of historical interest written by a career officer in the American Foreign Service.
summary: Official and personal letters (mostly to his mother) during his career in the diplomatic service, which ended abruptly at the beginning of World War II.

title: Virgil Thomson.
summary: A composer of opera, symphonic works, and film music as well as critic and witty writer on musical subjects, Thomson comments on his own life and writes portraits of leading musicians, artists, and writers he has known, especially during the decades between the two World Wars.

title: Forty years' residence in America; or, the doctrine of a particular providence exemplified in the life of Grant Thorburn.
summary: An account of forty years of his life in America, his grocery business, his seed and plant business, his purchases, his marriage, his friendships, followed by a long appendix containing brief unconnected scenes from his life including visits to Boston and Providence, letters, newspaper items, and other miscellany.

title: The best of Thoreau's journals.
summary: Selections from the fourteen-volume edition published in 1906 offer a taste of his life and observations from 1837 through 1861. Thoreau drew from his journal for his published works during his lifetime. These selections avoid duplicating those he himself selected.

title: Consciousness in Concord: the text of Thoreau's hitherto 'Lost Journal' (1840-1841).
summary: This segment of his journal (July 30, 1840-January 22, 1841) had a curious history as a 'lost' volume, described fully by Miller, whose comments are longer than these by Thoreau.

title: The correspondence of Henry David Thoreau.
summary: A reprint of the first edition which attempts to include every available surviving letter written by and to the famous man of letters and provides a remarkable portrait of his intellectual development.

title: The journal of Henry D. Thoreau.
summary: Although extracts from Thoreau's journals were published earlier in various formats, the complete edition did not appear until 1906. It and the reprints offer a complete record of the inner life of an individual, his interests and observations, the conception and evolution of his ideas on a wide variety of subjects — in short, the operation of a thinking man's mind.

title: Letters to various persons.
summary: Written between 1840 and 1862, these letters were addressed to various persons, many identified only by initials.

title: Thoreau's world; miniatures from his journal. Illustrated edition.
summary: Excerpts from the Journal provide a sampling of the variety of Thoreau's subject matter. In brief essays, imbedded in the whole journal but intended to stand alone, the author reached a high degree of literary excellence and distinction demonstrated in these 250 examples.

title: A week on the Concord and Merrimack Rivers.
summary: This journal recounts a week's trip that Thoreau and his brother, John, took in 1839 and includes considerable poetry and literary criticism. In emphasizing the river's idyllic aspects, Thoreau presents a posthumous elegiac tribute to his brother and demonstrates his spiritual and artistic growth.

title: A writer's journal. Selected and edited with introduction.
summary: Selections from the fourteen-volume edition are here intended to portray Thoreau's work as a writer and reveal the central principles of his philosophy.

title: It gave everybody something to do. And EM. Nathanson.
summary: The incredible, bizarre story of a deeply disturbed man who led his wife through a terrifying ten years of stealing, bombing, drug experimentation, gun collecting, violence, and murder before she finally became aware of the danger to herself and shot him.

title: East wind, rain — the intimate account of an intelligence officer in the Pacific, 1939-49.
summary: An intelligence officer in the Pacific before, during, and after World War II tells of blunders in the direction of the war, problems in censorship, and the double dealings of presidents and premiers. He examines the background of the Japanese War Crimes trials and gives a personal appraisal of General MacArthur.

title: The memoirs of Lt. Henry Timberlake: 1756-1765.
summary: A journal of the French and Indian Wars, depicting the role of the Cherokee Indians in the southern colonies.

title: Credos and curios.
summary: A collection of oddments — profiles, stories, reminiscences — of real and imagined events and people.

title: My life and hard times. Introduction by John K. Hutchens.
summary: A vintage Thurber collection with hilarious stories of his life in Columbus, including 'The night the bed fell,' 'University days,' and 'The day the dam broke.'

title: Thurber album: a new collection of pieces about people.
summary: With warm, lively wit, Thurber tells stories about himself, his numerous relatives, and a few friends and colleagues. Most chapters are revisions of articles published in The New Yorker.

title: With head and heart: the autobiography of Howard Thurman. Illustrated.
summary: Thurman recounts his life as a Black minister and missionary, active in churches and universities in the U.S. and abroad. He notes the advances made in desegregation and the lessening of racial prejudice, as well as his own progress from one who declared he wanted nothing to do with the church to a man devoted to Christ.

title: Self-portrait. With Mickey Herskowitz.
summary: N/A

title: Letters and literary memorials of Samuel J. Tilden.
summary: Of Tilden's many activities as a public servant, two are most often remembered: his overthrow of the corrupt New York municipal group known as the Tweed Ring and his election by a plurality of the popular vote to the U.S. Presidency. Since no one received a majority vote, the House of Representatives under the Constitution decided the election in favor of Hayes. His letters shed light on many other aspects of his career and personal life as well.

title: My story: a champion's memoirs.
summary: One of the early tennis greats who became a part of the Hollywood scene describes his training and development in tennis and his experience among contemporary stars.

title: Memoir of Lieut. Co. Tench Tilghman, secretary and aide to Washington.
summary: The Memoir (pp. 1-75), copy written by a descendent, Oswald Tilghman, in 1876, describes Tench Tilghman's career as Washington's aide. His journal (pp. 79-105) was kept while he served as Secretary of the Indian Commissioners (1775); diary entries and letters document varied experience through 1783.

title: My travel diary: 1936, between two worlds.
summary: In preparation for a life-and-work ecumenical conference at Oxford in 1937 examining the interrelationships between church, community, and politics, Tillich took part in a study group in 1936. In his diary he recounted his daily experience and personal reactions; his views on the world situation and on the pressing political problems of the mid-1930's.

title: Please don't hate me.
summary: His book recalls his boyhood in Czarist Russia, his early career as a concert pianist in Europe and the United States, and his success as a leading musician in Hollywood, with interesting descriptions of many famous contemporaries and his difficulty in becoming Americanized.

title: I pass: my story. As told to Don Smith.
summary: Tittle writes of his long and brilliant career as a football quarterback who attained fame as Player of the Year in 1957, 1962, and 1963. He held many passing records and is considered one of the greatest all-around quarterbacks in history.

title: Golden opinions.
summary: A reporter for the New York Herald-Tribune writes of life in New York, his Irish neighborhood, and his boyhood in the city, the stories colorful and somewhat nostalgic.

title: Invasion journal.
summary: A war correspondent for the New York Herald Tribune, he kept a detailed daily record of his departure from New York on a troop transport, the preparation for D-Day in London, the invasion and after (April- August, 1944), conveying the conditions and stress of wartime.

title: Diary of A.J. Tomlinson, founder of the Church of God, general overseer, 1903-1943— outstanding leader of the Pentecostal and Holiness movement.
publisher: The Church of God, World Headquarters
summary: The diary of a minister and faith healer who had a strong and stormy life in the politics of the Pentecostal Church. After describing the division over the administration and government of the Church of God,

title: Tomlinson gives an account of the revival of the movement with himself as a leader and of the 29-year court trial over the use of the church's name and funds. Volume I, 1901-1923; Volume II, 1923-1943.
summary: Account of the revival movement and court trial.

title: Ttae crunch
summary: Account of frustrations and experiences of a defensive end in professional football.

title: How my heart sang: the story of pioneer industrial welfare work
summary: Story of industrial welfare work in the pioneer days.

title: Reminiscences of Alexander Toponce
summary: A picture of frontier life by a pioneer who participated in various occupations.
occupations: Pioneer, Stage Coach Driver, Wagon Boss

title: In the pink
summary: Nostalgic memories of childhood in the South.

title: Smile please
summary: Nostalgic recollections of her childhood in Alabama.

title: Straight talk from prison: a convict reflects on youth, crime and society
summary: Compassionate advice from an ex-convict analyzing prison life.

title: Don't quote me
summary: A first-hand report on the television industry and behind-the-scenes stories.

title: The converts
summary: Torres's life story shaped by her family's conversion to Catholicism.

title: My life in the wild
summary: Fascinating account of career as an animal trainer and zoologist.

title: Letters and diary of Laura M. Towne: written from the Sea Islands of South Carolina, 1862-1884
publisher: Negro Universities Press/Div. of Greenwood Press, Inc.
summary: Collection of letters and diary describing Towne's work and life.

title: Hundred proof: Salt River sketches & memoirs of the blue-grass
summary: Sketches and memoirs from life in rural Pennsylvania.

title: A Yankee merchant in Goldrush Australia: the letters of George Francis Train, 1853-55
summary: Letters describing the commercial and social growth during the Australian gold rush.

title: St. Louis woman
summary: Account of a woman's experiences, defying conventions.

title: Office hours: day and night: the autobiography of Janet Travell, M.D.
summary: Autobiography of the first woman physician to the President.

title: Don't stop me now
summary: Autobiography describing youth, military service, and success in real estate.

title: Journal of Captain William Trent from Logstown to Pickawillany, A.D. 1752
summary: Trent's journal focusing on trade center events in the Ohio Valley.

title: Memoirs
summary: Memoirs of a pioneer food scientist.

title: Political animals: memoirs of a sentimental cynic
summary: Cynical reflections on politics and politicians.

title: Grass-roots doctor: memories of a mischievous boyhood and forty fruitful years as an M.D.
summary: Reminiscences of childhood and medical practice.

title: Twenty years too soon
summary: Recounts his years in professional baseball.

title: A woman of parts: memories of a life on stage
summary: Recollections of a life in theater.

title: While it is day: an autobiography
summary: An autobiography reflecting on life built on Quaker principles.

title: Autobiography
summary: Compiled autobiographical fragments covering important life events.

title: Memoirs
summary: Personal account of his presidency and significant decisions.

title: Mr. Citizen
summary: Account of Truman's return to private life after presidency.

title: Mr. President: the first publication from the personal diaries, private letters, papers, and revealing interviews of Harry S. Truman
summary: Portrait of Truman through selected private writings.

title: Off the record: the private papers of Harry S. Truman
summary: Truman's candid private memos providing insight into his decision-making.

title: The Truman years: The words and times of Harry S. Truman
summary: Illustrated narrative focusing on Truman's presidency.

title: Souvenir: Margaret Truman's own story
summary: Personal narrative of Margaret Truman's life.

title: The autobiography of Colonel John Trumbull, patriot-artist, 1756-1843
summary: Account of Trumbull's life and works as an artist.

title: Shem, Ham & Japheth: the papers of W.O. Tuggle comprising his Indian diary, sketches and observations, myths and Washington journal in the Territory, and at the capital, 1879-1882
summary: Tuggle's observations and writings during his time in the Indian Territory.

title: The light of other days
summary: Account of youth in rural western New York state.

title: A measure of independence
summary: Self-portrait of a free-lance writer's adventures.

title: Footsteps of a Giant
summary: Account of Tunnell's experiences in football.

title: Over the Hump
summary: Account of military air transportation operations.

title: The buried life; a nun's journey
summary: Journey of a nun leaving religious life.

title: Out of my heart
summary: A spiritual autobiography exploring life lessons.

title: Chips from my chisel: an autobiography
summary: Autobiography of a sculptor.

title: I remember
summary: Recounting experiences on health and education.

title: Dear Lady: the letters of Frederick Jackson Turner and Alice Forbes Perkins Hooper, 1910-1932
summary: Letters between Turner and Perkins Hooper covering significant years.

title: The original journals of Henry Smith Turner: with Stephen Watts Kearny to New Mexico and California, 1846-1847.
summary: As adjutant of the Army of the West, Turner actively participated in the conquest of New Mexico and California. His graphic journals and forthright letters present his personal reaction to the men and scenes around him as well as objective comments on practical matters such as problems of water and forage and encounters with the Indians.

title: Pro quarterback: my own story.
summary: A famous quarterback tells his personal story, analyzes football strategy and execution, and gossips about training camps, locker rooms, and the players he has known.

title: Big friend; little friend; memoirs of a World War II fighter pilot.
summary: He left college to begin his aviation career in 1941, eventually flying nearly 100 missions in Europe and 17 in the Korean War. His book reflects the patriotic values and motivation characteristic of those times.

title: Memories of a retired Pullman porter.
summary: Turner recounts the characteristics of numerous jobs — a spectrum of those available to Blacks in his time: waiter, bellhop, barbershop porter, shoeshine stand proprietor, janitor, night watchman, culminating in 25 years as a Pullman porter.

title: Vietnam doctor; the story of Project Concern.
summary: Turpin combined his two callings as minister and doctor and began Project Concern, a medical mission which opened clinics in Hong Kong, Kowloon, and Vietnam.

title: Mario.
summary: As a boy, Mario with his family of thirteen lived through the tragic years of World War II, moving from Naples to the village of Pietravairano in an effort to escape the air raids and fighting.

title: Education of a congressman; the newsletters of Morris K. Udall.
summary: These newsletters from the 1960's, arranged chronologically by subject matter, show his thoughts and ideas during that period as he explained his positions to his constituents.

title: The rogue of Publisher's Row: confessions of a publisher.
summary: The president of Exposition Press writes of his career as an entrepreneur of subsidy publishing, arguing the importance of his contribution to research materials as well as the vanity of many of his authors.

title: A pioneer in Northwest America, 1841-1858: the memoirs of Gustaf Unonius.
summary: Originally published in Uppsala in 1861-1862, these volumes reveal the experience and philosophy of one of the earliest and most influential Swedish immigrants in America, describing his experience as a pioneer farmer in Wisconsin and his later work in the ministry of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

title: Private collection.
summary: Gathering together portraits of the intelligentsia, customs, and culture of her intense years, Mrs. Untermeyer shows a gallery of portraits of the poets, writers, artists, and musicians whom she counted as friends through the early years of the twentieth century.

title: Bygones: the recollections of Louis Untermeyer.
summary: A candid account of the life of the poet-anthologist-editor, who met almost everyone in the world of letters, whose life was complicated by four marriages, and who through it all steadfastly advanced the cause of modern poetry in America.

title: Commitment.
summary: An unfortunate victim of the McCarthy era, Uphaus spent a year in jail for contempt of court because he refused to supply lists of names and correspondence of those who attended a camp he established in New Hampshire called World Fellowship, Inc., which state authorities suspected of communist activities.

title: Lost illusion.
summary: The revised edition of The Dream We Lost: Soviet Russia Then and Now concerns her disillusionment with communism and 'Stalinist tyranny' after six years in Russia.

title: Odyssey of a liberal: memoirs.
summary: Memoirs of her life before and after her disillusionment in Russia written to record her 'far ranging experience as a participant observer of the history of our times.'

title: Yesterday and tomorrow.
publisher: A Geneva Book/Carlton Press, New York
summary: Utley tells of her childhood as one of thirteen children of a Black sharecropper on a plantation in North Carolina — always poor, often hungry, sometimes befriended by charitable whites.

title: Trial balance: the education of an American.
summary: A philosophical, introspective narrative written in third person and modeled in part on that of Henry Adams, by a man who devoted forty years to American education.

title: Night stick: the autobiography of Lewis J. Valentine.
summary: Police Commissioner of New York while La Guardia was Mayor, he joined the force in 1903. His book reflects his long commitment to police work and an interesting view of the life of the city, its characters, thugs, and politicians.

title: Let the chips fall.
summary: Vallee's reminiscences of his career as a bandleader emphasize his lust for beautiful women, his callous disregard for people's sensitivities, his ostentatious spending of money, and love of being seen in the 'right' places.

title: My beloved Zebulon; the correspondence of Zebulon Baird Vance and Harriett Newell Espy.
publisher: The University of North Carolina Press
summary: These 121 letters between Vance and his future wife are primarily love letters, but reveal their hopes, ideals, and salient traits, offering glimpses into antebellum North Carolina society.

title: The Revolutionary War memoir and selected correspondence of Philip Van Cortlandt.
summary: A collection of his memoirs and selected correspondence provides a comprehensive account of his actions during the American Revolution.

title: The autobiography of Mark Van Doren.
summary: Revered as a professor of literature at Columbia University and an author of poetry, fiction, and non-fiction, Van Doren writes of his boyhood in Illinois, his education, and, affectionately, of his writing over the years.

title: My tribe.
summary: Written for occupational and career guidance for young people, this book describes Vasquez's youth, his days as a hobo, his various jobs.

title: Steaming up.
summary: This reprint of the 1930 edition describes Vauclain's career with the Pennsylvania Railroad and the Baldwin Locomotive Works.

title: A possible theatre; the experiences of a pioneer director in America's resident theatre.
summary: Written to present "a case history of a creative person working at an important transitional time in one of the performing arts," this book tells of the author's involvement with three pioneering resident theater companies, The New York Shakespeare Festival, the Phoenix Theatre, and the Seattle Repertory Theatre.

title: Rebel coach: my football family.
summary: College football coach Vaught turned the losing University of Mississippi team into a winning football fiefdom. From 1949 until 1971 when he was forced out by ill health, he built a team with an impressive record including six Southeastern Championships and eighteen Bowl games.

title: Devil loves a shining mark: the story of my life.
summary: Reformed criminal and ex-con Vaus quit the syndicate to work with Hell Gate area street gangs. He established Youth Development, Inc., and helped troubled kids through youth camps, schools, a ranch for runaways, a mountaineering program, and his own understanding of and compassion for their problems.

title: Veeck — as in wreck.
summary: Although his leg was amputated as a result of a World War II injury, he led an intensely active life as a baseball executive. His book is full of anecdotes about his executive enterprise and famous baseball characters.

title: Island home.
summary: Living on a 62-acre island, Remire, in the Seychelles in the Western Indian Ocean was both adventuresome and hard work for the author and her family. They depended on fishing, copra production, and other agricultural activities for their livelihood, learning by necessity to become self-sufficient.

title: Woman in battle; a narrative of the exploits, adventures, and travels of Madame Loreta Janeta Velazquez otherwise known as Lt. Harry T. Buford, Confederate States Army.
summary: During the Civil War she served the Confederacy as an officer and spy, disguised as a man. Afterwards she kept adventure in her life by traveling widely, working as a secret agent, broker, and a Western miner, among other things.

title: Personal reminiscences: celebrating sixty years in America (1891-1951), fifty-five years a teacher of foreign languages.
summary: Ventresca, a teacher of Italian, Latin, and other foreign languages in Chicago area high schools, 1896-1960, writes of his childhood in Abruzzi, Italy, and of his immigration to Chicago, his education at Northern Indiana Normal School and the University of Chicago, and his teaching career.

title: Comeback: the Ken Venturi story.
summary: The story of a golf champion who after winning the National Open in 1964 contracted a rare disease of the hands which nearly ended his career. An operation at the Mayo Clinic corrected the condition and enabled Venturi to make a spectacular comeback.

title: Views from a window: conversations with Gore Vidal.
summary: A collection of interviews in which the author discusses his life, interests, and work as well as America's values and politics.

title: A tree is a tree.
summary: Vidor's good-humored, fast-paced account of his career as a film director spans the first six decades of the twentieth century, in the medium he wisely labels "the Grand Illusion." He began with primitive films made in open air and switched to silent films made on sets, including some of his masterpieces, The Big Parade, La Boheme, and The Crowd.

title: seventy: the measure of a year.
summary: In this journal of her seventieth year, Vining exhibits little nostalgia for the past, commenting instead on contemporary progress.

title: Windows for the crown prince.
summary: A chronicle of four years in Japan (1946-1950) where she was appointed English tutor for Crown Prince Akihito.

title: Polish prince.
summary: Ethnic pride prevails in Vinton's story of his rise from small-town musician and band leader to Las Vegas headliner and gold-record-selling singer. He considers a song he wrote with lyrics in Polish as the apex of his career and as a rallying point for people of Polish heritage.

title: An immigrant's story.
summary: In 1933 he immigrated to the United States from Lithuania. His book tells of his youth in Lithuania, then of his experience as an American factory worker. The latter is based on his diary, which makes sharp contrasts between Lithuanian and American life styles and between the American dream and the realities of working life.

title: Home to Texas.
summary: After 26 years as a journalist in New York, he returned to the Texas ranch where he grew up. Here he writes of his youth in Texas, his career, and, philosophically, about his return to the land.

title: 'C'nelia.
summary: Cornelia Wallace's memories of childhood and growing up, her occupations— pianist, country singer, composer, actress, and her life as second wife of Governor George Wallace of Georgia including his near-assassination, paralysis, and adjustment.

title: The unending journey.
summary: A remarkable narrative of her childhood, her education at Wellesley, her career as a professor of French at the University of Chicago, her friendship with Mark Twain, and her reactions to two World Wars during her own old age.

title: Stand up for America.
summary: A lawyer, Alabama governor, and conservative candidate for U.S. President tells his life story (up from rural poverty to the governor's mansion) and articulates his social and political philosophy. He speaks candidly but without rancor about the assassination attempt that left him paralyzed from the waist down.

title: The Wallaces of Alabama: my family.
summary: The son of Governor George Wallace and Governor Lurleen Wallace tells about his parents' lives, political activities, and the well-publicized events that affected their family.

title: My world of birds: memoirs of an ornithologist.
summary: Wallace's fascination with birds is evident from annual lists he made as a teenager in Vermont to his round-the-world explorations in search of exotic species. He describes his studies and years as a professor at Michigan State, and his various roles related to wildlife and birds.

title: Price of vision: the diary of Henry A. Wallace, 1942-1946.
summary: A diary revealing the struggle for authority during his chairmanship of the Board of Economic Welfare, wartime services to the country, and his goals for a postwar economy.

title: The writing of one novel.
summary: A highly detailed account of the conception, gestation, and birth of Irving Wallace's novel, 'The Prize', detailing his writing process, research, and the behind-the-scenes activities.

title: Memories of fifty years.
summary: Wallack, a member of one of the leading theatrical families, recounts his experiences on stage and his roles in various productions, along with a biographical sketch.

title: Reaching for the stars.
summary: From 1934 to 1939 the author and her husband lived in Nazi Germany where they befriended many in the cultured intelligentsia and witnessed the growing Nazi menace.

title: Zeal for your house.
summary: This book is a collection of sermons and speeches by Bishop Walsh over a quarter of a century, detailing his work in the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America.

title: Each man in his time: the life story of a director.
summary: Starting as a cowboy-turned-actor in New York, Walsh became a director and reflects on Hollywood's birth, golden era, and decline in this anecdotal account.

title: Danton's Inferno: the story of a columnist and how he grew.
summary: Broadway columnist Walter tells a humorous account of his life filled with anecdotes about famous and infamous individuals he encountered.

title: Letters of C.F.W. Walther: a selection.
summary: A Missouri Lutheran minister discusses theology and doctrine in his letters, warning against the evils of Catholicism and pietism.

title: The George Washington Papers.
summary: An eloquent, abridged selection (with modernized spelling) from Washington's diaries, letters, addresses, and other papers arranged to represent various aspects of his life: surveyor, soldier, commander-in-chief, 'peaceful squire.'

title: Beyond Concord: selected writings of David Atwood Wasson.
summary: A provocative thinker, Wasson was both like and unlike his contemporaries in New England intellectual history, with writings reflecting standard transcendental teachings and avant-garde attitudes.

title: The autobiography of Robert Watchorn.
summary: Chronicles Watchorn's diverse life, including experiences as a miner, union organizer, immigration officer, and philanthropist.
occupations: Miner, Union Organizer, Immigration Officer, Executive

title: His eye is on the sparrow: an autobiography.
summary: Reminiscences of a long life from poverty to success as an actress and singer, focused on her faith in God.

title: Will you die for me?
summary: Watson details his transformation under Manson's influence, highlighting his subsequent conversion to Christianity in prison.

title: My life with Charles Manson.
summary: Watkins expresses his horror about Manson and the surrounding events, depicting a life free of moral responsibility.

title: The double helix; a personal account of the discovery of the structure of DNA.
summary: A scientific adventure story of the events leading to the discovery of the double-helix structure of DNA, work which merited the Nobel Prize in 1962.

title: Confederate from East Texas: the Civil War letters of James Monroe Watson.
summary: A collection of letters during the Civil War providing personal views of the battles experienced by an uneducated soldier.

title: In friendly candor.
summary: He joined the Atlantic Monthly staff in 1924 and in 1938 became its Editor-in-Chief. Here he writes of his education, many of the friends and authors he worked with, the cultural importance of reading and education, and some thoughts on editing and the changing times.

title: My green age.
summary: Editor of the Atlantic Monthly from 1938 to 1966, Weeks, as his preface states, has tried 'in this book to recapture the wonder and bewilderment of one who was struggling to find where he belonged during the first forty years of this fantastically changing century.'

title: The open heart.
summary: During his long years as editor of the Atlantic Monthly, he traveled widely in search of authors. This book tells of his travels, offering a rich narrative of his favorite people and places.

title: Life-long love affair: the memoirs of Lewis George Weeks.
summary: A happy, articulate account of Week's Wisconsin boyhood, education at the University of Wisconsin (to which he later donated a building), and his career. As a field geologist he traveled throughout South America locating oil sites. He had two exceptionally happy marriages and enjoyed a retirement filled with good works.

title: First lady's lady: with the Fords at the White House.
summary: As Betty's Ford's press secretary, November 1974-January 1977, Weidenfeld recalls events of family life at the White House during the two-year recuperation from Watergate. Weidenfeld's chatty anecdotes are often concerned with media and with style.

title: The con game and "Yellow Kid" Weil: the autobiography of the famous con artist.
summary: A man of many careers and con games, Weil is said to have been America's most successful swindler. Here he describes his early years learning the games and the skills which brought him over $8,000,000.

title: Now the harvest: memories of a county agricultural agent.
summary: A thoughtful, at times philosophical, account of the author's first 32 years, describing his genesis and maturation as a county agricultural agent in southern California at a time when the agents' functions were themselves maturing.

title: Ardent eighties and after: reminiscences of an interesting decade.
summary: Good description of his hard life after immigration from Russia, his early work in a print shop, a Jewish newspaper, and general adaption to American life; with interesting sketches of several important social reformers of the time.

title: The recollections of John Ferguson Weir, Director of the Yale School of the Fine Arts, 1869-1913.
publisher: NY. Historical Society; Associates in Fine Arts at Yale University
