summary: Director of Yale School of Fine Arts for 44 years, Weir was responsible for considerable improvement in the school: he added sculpture, architecture, and art history to the curriculum, acquired the Jarves Collection of early Italian pictures for the gallery, and encouraged professional art education.

title: Radical life.
summary: Weisbord writes with a novelist's consummate skill about the 1920's, when she and her common-law husband, Albert Weisbord, were communist labor organizers in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, and North Carolina.

title: Famous faces: a photograph album of personal reminiscences.
summary: Primarily a photograph album of show business and other famous people, this volume also includes some brief anecdotes and comments by the author about the occasions when the pictures were taken.

title: As I recall my past century.
summary: Written on that remote level of abstraction common to churchmen, the book includes recollections of his early life and education and varied assignments of his ministry, including the presidency of Ohio Wesleyan University and several missionary posts in the Orient.

title: I remain: the letters of Lew Welch and the correspondence of his friends: Vol. 1: 1949-1960; Vol. 2: 1960-1972.
summary: A fascinating but disturbing collection of letters from Welch, an aspiring poet, to his mother and various friends, mostly poets, to whom he sent texts of poems. Welch's alcoholism contributed to his intermittent breakdowns, physical and psychological.

title: What happened in between: a doctor's story.
summary: A specialist in internal medicine and cardiology, Dr. Welch believes in the treatment of people rather than diseases and the importance of human encounter between patient and doctor.

title: War diary and letters of Stephen Minot Weld, 1861-1865.
summary: Weld, a gifted writer, kept a diary throughout most of his service — ultimately as a It. colonel — in the 56th Massachusetts Division, 5th Regiment of the Union Army.

title: Ah-one! ah-two! Life with my musical family.
summary: When ABC cancelled Welk's Saturday evening TV show, thousands of loyal viewers protested. This book tells of his road tour from Hawaii to New Jersey and his relationship with his musical family.

title: My America, your America.
summary: Band leader Welk describes what life is like with his 'Musical Family,' all those who work as entertainers or behind the scenes during his band shows.

title: This I believe.
summary: Band leader Welk wrote this book to express his belief in free enterprise and to show people how hard work, fairness, and profit-sharing make good sense and good business.

title: The diary of Gideon Welles: Secretary of the Navy under Lincoln and Johnson.
summary: Welles's candid diaries, kept assiduously while he was Secretary of the U.S. Navy under Lincoln and Johnson, shed considerable light on the Civil War and the beginning of the Reconstruction Era.

title: The lost landscape: some memories of a family and a town in Connecticut, 1659-1906.
summary: The story of her New England childhood, supplemented by tales of her family, events, and customs in Norwich which are a mixture of fact and fancy.

title: A short time for insanity: an autobiography.
summary: A highly individual and outspoken movie director remembers events of his life through a haze of pain and opiates in a hospital.

title: Life and adventures of Polk Wells (Charles Knox Polk Wells) the notorious outlaw.
summary: An exciting career of lawlessness and daring deeds is presented by Wells, a man of warm and kindly heart despite his crimes.

title: And the bridge is love.
summary: Raised among artists and intellectuals in Austria, she was married to Gustav Mahler and later to Franz Werfel. Her book recalls her rich and varied life in Europe and in the United States after she immigrated.

title: Broadside to the sun.
summary: Story of country life in the Arkansas Ozark mountains; typical of the postwar books on old-fashioned values, but realistic in practical details of daily life.

title: Captain's papers: a log of whaling and other sea experiences.
summary: West was a whaler and captain of several whaling ships, 1882-1899, engaging in a highly dangerous but lucrative trade.

title: Upstairs at the White House: my life with the First Ladies.
summary: As assistant and chief usher of the White House, West was involved in all domestic decisions and all social functions for six presidents and first ladies.

title: Mr. Clutch; the Jerry West story.
summary: At time of publication, West was considered one of the greatest basketball players in the history of the game, especially famous for his clutch shot.

title: Double discovery: a journey.
summary: West combines letters, a travel diary, and her retrospective interpretations to present a charming montage of a four-month trip from California to New York by train, and then to England, Ireland, and Paris in 1929.

title: Hide and seek.
summary: Written during a three-month vacation period alone on the banks of the Colorado River, this work discusses her need for solitude, her special love of nature.

title: To see the dream.
summary: Based on a journal she kept while living at her home in Napa, California, and while working in Hollywood with William Wyler.

title: The woman said yes: encounters with life and death: memoirs.
summary: The lives of two sisters and their illnesses: one fights to live and the other embraces death on her own terms.

title: Goodness had nothing to do with it.
summary: A self-proclaimed sex symbol and legend describes her successes in vaudeville, on Broadway, in touring plays, movies, radio, and dinner theaters.

title: Mae West on sex, health, and ESP.
summary: In a fast-talking, sassy book, Mae West gives her advice on the three topics in the title, telling something about her experiences in the process.

title: The wit and wisdom of Mae West.
summary: Actress West's wit and wisdom consists of one-liners and double entendres about her voluptuous figure, sex, and men.

title: Plant doctoring is fun.
summary: A graduate of Wellesley with a Ph.D. from Cornell, she established a career as The Plant Doctor.

title: The Westmores of Hollywood.
summary: With numerous anecdotes about Hollywood stars in relation to their make-up, Frank Westmore discusses the rise and semi-decline of the dynasty of Westmores.

title: A soldier reports.
summary: A veteran of forty-years service to his country on and off the battlefield, General Westmoreland writes of the shaping of his life and career, his pride in being a professional soldier, and his part in momentous recent events, especially the Vietnam War.

title: The making of a publisher; a life in the 20th century book revolution.
publisher: Reynal & Co., dist. by William Morrow & Co., Inc.
summary: Growing up in rural Maryland, Weybright dreamed of making great literature easily available to the general public.

title: On the edge of evening: the autobiography of a teacher and writer who holds Index to the old ways.
summary: A professor of literature at the University of Pennsylvania and author of seventeen other books writes with warmth and humor of the daily life and background from which those books evolved.

title: Doctor woman of the Cumberlands: the autobiography of May Cravath Wharton, M.D.
summary: Wharton's engaging narrative focuses on the forty years of her career as a physician near Crossville, Tennessee, detailing her services and contributions to the medical community.

title: Yankee from the West: the candid, turbulent life story of the Yankee-born U.S. Senator from Montana.
summary: The controversial Democratic senator from Montana, champion of individualism in politics, did not hesitate to fight for his principles against all comers.

title: I've got good news for you.
summary: He started his journalism career as a New York Herald correspondent at Columbia University during his undergraduate days, eventually becoming a sportswriter and top-notch reporter.

title: Dome of many-coloured glass.
summary: An unusual collaborative memoir written by a wife and husband, both professional writers who traveled extensively during his long career in the diplomatic service.

title: Valborg: an autobiography of Valborg Rasmussen Wheelwright.
summary: Wheelwright describes her impoverished childhood in Copenhagen, her conversion to Mormonism, and her extensive contributions to her community.
occupations: Missionary, midwife, social worker, community organizer

title: Mister rifleman.
summary: A thorough, articulate, abundantly illustrated account of Whelen's career as a rifleman in the U.S. Army, intertwined with a history of the development of the American breech-loading rifle.
other_places_lived: British Columbia, Canal Zone, United States

title: Shepherd of the Cowlitz: the autobiography of Ezra Leroy Whisler.
summary: Whisler's own account of his life and ministry as a Church of the Brethren preacher, supplemented by a biographical account.

title: The beautiful Ohio: a pageant of yesterday.
summary: A business executive muses about life in the good old days before F.D. Roosevelt's New Deal, emphasizing individualism and parental authority.

title: Letters.
summary: This annotated volume is a selection of several hundred letters White wrote throughout sixty years, covering various aspects of his life and work.

title: Points of my compass: letters from the East, the West, the South.
summary: Mostly written for the New Yorker, these episodes depict his experiences and reflections on life across various regions.

title: Experiences of a special Indian agent.
summary: White's experiences among various tribes as a special Indian agent provide delightful and informative reading.

title: How I got published: a Maine author's struggle for recognition.
summary: Farmer White's inspiring struggle for recognition in both business and writing emphasizes moral standards and perseverance despite setbacks.

title: Minor White: rites & passages: his photographs accompanied by excerpts from his diaries and letters.
summary: A biographical essay accompanied by photographs and excerpts from diaries illustrates Minor White's life as a famous photographer, emphasizing his communication through photography.

title: Our Virgin Island.
summary: An author's account of establishing a home and career on a British Virgin Island.

title: In search of history: a personal adventure.
summary: Historian and writer White investigates the making of history, exploring various pivotal moments in his life and the world.

title: Man called White: the autobiography of Walter White.
summary: Light-skinned, blond, and blue-eyed, White chose to work for the N.A.A.C.P. and write about Negro America most of his life.

title: Autobiography of William Allen White.
summary: A rich narrative of his active life in local and national politics, literature, and journalism, written by a newspaper and radio journalist.

title: Letters of William Allen White and a young man.
summary: A collection of letters between White and Gil Wilson depicting the struggles of a young artist and White's support.

title: Selected letters of William Allen White: 1899-1943.
summary: A record of the changing American scene through White's letters over a period of 44 years, depicting him as a middle-class liberal.

title: The warrior who killed Custer: the personal narrative of Chief Joseph White Bull.
summary: Chief White Bull narrates his experiences, including his claim to fame of killing General Custer, with commentary and drawings.

title: Fledgling.
summary: An aviation writer recounts his thrilling experiences in the English Royal Flying Corps during World War I.

title: Opal Whiteley: the unsolved mystery: together with Opal Whiteley's diary, 'The Journal of an Understanding Heart.'
summary: A remarkable depiction of a child's inner life that became a literary curiosity, claiming to reflect her early childhood experiences.

title: Jim Whitewolf: the life of a Kiowa Apache Indian.
summary: The story reflects the impacts of white man's culture on the native tribal culture through the experiences of Whitewolf.

title: Treasure of El Dorado: featuring 'The Dawn Breakers.'
summary: Through mental telepathy, Joseph Whitfield communicates with El Dorado, exploring philosophical questions and imaginary journeys.

title: Forty years of it.
summary: A reflection on the idealism and moral struggles during the years before World War I by a four-term reform mayor.

title: Civil War letters of George Washington Whitman.
summary: Diary and letters of Walt Whitman's brother provide an authentic record of a Union soldier's experiences during the Civil War.

title: Poe's Helen remembers.
summary: A gifted poet and critic, Sarah Whitman is best remembered as Edgar Allan Poe's fiancée, with her correspondence forming a basis for Poe scholarship.

title: Autobiographia; or the story of a life: selected from his prose writings.
summary: A collection of autobiographical prose edited to provide a consecutive account of the poet's life, including diary entries and other writings.

title: Calamus: a series of letters written during the years 1868-1880 to a young friend (Peter Doyle).
summary: Reprints the poet's letters to Peter Doyle, echoing themes of love and community brotherhood.

title: The correspondence.
summary: Includes almost 2900 letters by Whitman, showing his personal concerns and warmth.

title: Daybooks and notebooks.
summary: A collection of Whitman's shipping information, sales figures, correspondence records, and notes from 1876 to 1891.

title: Faint clews and indirections: mss. of Walt Whitman and his family.
summary: Previously unpublished manuscripts from the Trent collection include poems, prose fragments, and letters to his family.

title: Letters written by Walt Whitman to his mother, 1866-1872.
summary: Whitman wrote letters to his mother about his health and experiences, reflecting a personal connection and familial bond.

title: Walt Whitman's backward glances: a backward glance o'er travel'd roads and two contributary essays hitherto uncollected.
summary: A study of the evolution of Whitman's essay 'A backward glance o'er travel'd roads,' exploring themes of composition and aging.

title: Whitman and Rolleston: a correspondence.
summary: Correspondence between Whitman and Irish poet Rolleston reflects friendship and discussions on poetry and promotion of Whitman's work.

title: Memphis, Nam, Sweden; the autobiography of a Black American exile.
summary: A Black Marine's harrowing experiences during and after the Vietnam War, leading to his eventual escape to Sweden.

title: High peaks.
summary: Short chapters describe significant moments in Whitney's life, including marriage and various impactful experiences.

title: Invitation to joy; a personal story. Illustrated.
summary: As Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney she had all that material wealth could provide. She describes her glamourous, exciting life and some of the famous people she knew. After her divorce she became an 'aware Christian' and found a new kind of joy.

title: School and I: the autobiography of an Ohio schoolmaster.
summary: An educator in the Ohio public schools for over fifty years discusses his life and educational theory.

title: Letters.
publisher: Belknap Press of Harvard University Press
summary: Volume I: 1828-45 includes all extant letters from this period. Volume II: 1846-1860 includes all extant letters. Volume III is a selection of 527 letters from the 4500 letters he wrote after 1861.

title: Whittier and the Cartlands: letters and comments.
summary: Family letters between the cousins were written between 1839 and 1888. These, with recollections of his oldest grandchildren and two short essays, portray Whittier in warm family relationships.

title: Whittier's unknown romance: letters to Elizabeth Lloyd.
summary: Whittier and Elizabeth Lloyd were deeply attracted to each other, and, although they were of differing temperaments, both treasured their rich understanding and friendship.

title: Golden friends I had: unrevised memories of Margaret Widdemer.
summary: As part of the New York literary scene since the Twenties Widdemer knew, and here describes, famous friends. She writes of their personal lives and talents, their feuds and friendships, and her theories about developing literary movements as well as her own life.

title: Ex-prodigy: my childhood and youth.
summary: A distinguished professor of mathematics at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Wiener published Cybernetics in 1948, dealing with the science of communications in man and machine. This book deals with the period in which he was a prodigy, beginning college before twelve and completing his doctorate before nineteen.

title: I am a mathematician: the later life of a prodigy.
summary: In technical language, Wiener, who earned a Harvard Ph.D. at 18, discusses his 36-year career as a mathematics professor at MIT, including international teaching and conferences.

title: A Jew today.
summary: Wiesel writes introspectively on what it means to be Jewish in a world that hates Jews. The book is composed of anecdotes and diary entries concerning his thoughts on different meanings of Judaism around the world.

title: The memoirs of Ray Lyman Wilbur.
summary: He achieved national recognition as a medical doctor, educator, humanitarian, and public servant. Raised on the Western frontier, he attended Stanford University where he later served as president for 25 years.
occupations: Medical Doctor, Educator, Humanitarian, Public Servant

title: Invisible core; a potter's life and thoughts.
summary: Warm, human stories of her student days at the Bauhaus, the artists who taught her, and establishing her Pond Farm School in California.

title: Letters I never mailed.
summary: An unconventional, self-confessed maverick, composer of orchestral, chamber, and operatic works and popular songs, Wilder's book is made up of purported letters never mailed to friends, enemies, critics, and acquaintances.

title: West from home: letters of Laura Ingalls Wilder to Almanzo Wilder: San Francisco 1915.
summary: For two months in 1915 during the Panama-Pacific International Exposition in San Francisco, she visited her daughter and wrote letters home to her husband describing the wonders of the trip.

title: Pipe dreams and memories: an autobiography.
summary: This narrative reflects a confused and chaotic life. Reared in poverty in Nova Scotia by a sickly stepmother and an aged, indifferent father, Wiles escaped to a logger's life in upstate New York.

title: Every day's a matinee: memoirs scribbled on a dressing room door.
summary: Stage-struck at an early age, Wilk has acted in summer stock, produced shows for the Air Force during World War II, and has written for stage, radio, TV, and movies. His memories are about many show-business greats and their world.

title: Lenny Wilkens story.
summary: A successful basketball player (eight All-Star games) played with three different professional teams and coached as well. Here he talks about his career, contracts, salaries, integration, team spirit, trades, and other players he has known or played against.

title: Autobiography of Rear Admiral Charles Wilkes, U.S. Navy, 1798-1877.
publisher: Naval History Division, Department of the Navy
summary: Rear Admiral Wilkes draws from voluminous diaries and an extensive memory in describing his 65 years of service in the U.S. Navy. He offers a vivid description of early navy life and keen observations on politics, society, and culture.

title: An artist on the overland trail: the 1849 diary and sketches of James F. Wilkins.
summary: A portrait painter from St. Louis, Wilkins went on the overland trail to California in 1849 and painted the scenery and the people he saw.

title: Letters of Eliza Wilkinson during the invasion and possession of Charlestown, S.C.
summary: A series of twelve letters written in 1782 by a young widow who lived at Yonge's Island near Charleston, South Carolina. She had to flee from British troops several times.

title: Sun over Cerro Gordo.
summary: The author recalls his boyhood on an Iowa farm in Cerro Gordo County at the turn of the century.

title: Memoirs of my own times.
summary: Wilkinson's career included service during the Revolution, Indian Wars, and War of 1812. His controversial activities led to a general court martial and inquiries into his actions.

title: Thru the turnstile: tales of my two centuries.
summary: Williams writes of her golden childhood in Boston and on Nantucket Island at the turn of the century.

title: Billy, the classic hitter.
summary: During fourteen years with the Chicago Cubs, Williams broke many records and was tops in several categories.

title: Iron man.
summary: The story of a Black professional baseball player and how he worked his way up is presented in this series intended as career guidance for young people.

title: Diary of a teacher along the journey to Siberia.
summary: In 1967 Williams' contract as a teacher was not renewed — 'for unethical conduct, insubordination, and inadequacy as a teacher.' Here she protests the injustice of this action.

title: Bridging the gap: my contribution to the growth of industrial research.
summary: From 1929-1941 and 1945-1958, metallurgist Williams was director of Battelle Memorial Institute, a nonprofit technological research organization.

title: Narrative of James Williams, an American slave, who was for several years a driver on a cotton plantation in Alabama.
summary: Williams' narrative describes his youth as a domestic servant and later experience as plantation driver of his fellow slaves.

title: The redeemed captive returning to Zion: or, a faithful history of remarkable occurrences in the captivity and deliverance.
summary: A Protestant clergyman recounts with horror and indignation the events of the capture of himself and his family during King Philip's War.

title: Flashbacks; a twenty-year diary of article writing.
summary: A collection of 24 articles about being a Black writer in the United States covering the period from the early 1950's to 1971.

title: Pioneer surveyor/frontier lawyer: the personal narrative of O.W. Williams, 1877-1902.
publisher: Texas Western Press/University of Texas, at El Paso
summary: An interesting, expertly edited compilation of narrative pamphlets about Williams's activities on the Southwestern American frontier during the last quarter of the nineteenth century.

title: Memoirs.
summary: The shaping of the life of a successful playwright, the effect of events on his life and art, his struggle to achieve recognition, his family, friends, and battles with alcohol and mental illness.

title: Tennessee Williams' letters to Donald Windham 1940-1965.
summary: Williams and Windham met through a mutual friend in 1940 when Windham was nineteen. Thereafter they corresponded, Williams's letters reproduced here being running accounts of his activities and thinking.

title: One man's freedom.
summary: A staunch defender of Constitutional rights, he records trials and documents his concern for individual freedoms guaranteed by the Bill of Rights.

title: My turn at bat; the story of my life.
summary: One of the greatest hitters in baseball writes of his boyhood in San Diego, his early days in the minor leagues, and his outstanding career with the Boston Red Sox.

title: The first Black captain.
summary: One Black man's struggle to rise from a ghetto community to attain dignity and recognition in the police department of Newark.

title: Interviews with William Carlos Williams: "speaking straight ahead."
summary: Williams, a major poet and also a physician in Rutherford, New Jersey, speaks candidly, mostly about American poetry, poetics, and his poetry, to several interviewers.

title: The selected letters of William Carlos Williams.
summary: Includes letters from 1902, when he was a medical student at the University of Pennsylvania, to 1956, when he retired in New Jersey.

title: Fifty years in starch.
summary: Although written in third person and set in a narrative frame, the story is apparently the author's own, describing her long and successful career as a nurse in New York and California.

title: Caracas diary, 1835-1840: the journal of John G.A. Williamson, first diplomatic representative of the United States to Venezuela.
summary: Williamson, American consul and charge d'affaires to Venezuela during its formative years, 1826-1840, kept this perceptive though formal diary during his last five years in office.

title: An autobiography: William Williamson: student, homesteader, teacher, lawyer, judge, congressman and trusted friend.
summary: Williamson's long life was intertwined with the law, politics, and the state of South Dakota, whose interests he represented in Congress, 1921-1933.
occupations: student, homesteader, teacher, lawyer, judge, congressman

title: Yanqui in Patagonia.
summary: Formerly of the U.S. Geological Survey, he went to Argentina in 1910 to explore Patagonia, planning highways, railways, cities, and colonization until 1914.

title: The hundred lives of an ancient mariner: an autobiography.
summary: Willis describes his life, beginning with childhood memories of Germany, to his adventures, including sailing voyages at an advanced age.

title: Confessions of a conservative.
summary: A thoughtful and articulate narration of the development and manifestations of his personal and political philosophy.

title: Turncoat; an American's 12 years in Communist China; the story of Morris R. Wills.
summary: Wills was captured during the Korean War and chose to go to China instead of returning to the United States.

title: And there I stood with my piccolo.
summary: Recollections of the sounds of Iowa, growing up in rural America, then working his way into the music worlds of New York and Hollywood.

title: But he doesn't know the territory.
summary: The third of his autobiographical books, this one as much the story of The Music Man as the author.

title: Eggs I have laid.
summary: The second of three autobiographical books by the composer of The Music Man, including many anecdotes about show business and its personalities.

title: Thy will be done: the autobiography of an Episcopal minister.
summary: A moving story of Wilson's intense desire to minister to the poor.

title: Quest for justice: my confinement in two institutions.
summary: Wilson tells how he was seized and held in mental institutions, denied recourse to a lawyer until he was released.

title: Letters on literature and politics, 1912-1972.
summary: The letters of distinguished critic and author Wilson to a myriad of other eminent writers provide a broad overview of American letters for five decades.

title: Prelude: landscapes, characters and conversations from the earlier years of my life.
summary: Composed of journals and diaries, this book comprises the story of Wilson's youth including his trips abroad and army service during World War I.

title: The Twenties: from notebooks and diaries of the period.
summary: Derived from Wilson's memories and notebook passages, the book views the decade from his position as a central figure in the literary and intellectual circles of the American Twenties.

title: Upstate; records and recollections of northern New York.
summary: Diary selections from 1950 to 1970 and accounts of people who lived in upstate New York.

title: Thus far on my journey.
summary: Wilson carried out his lifetime advocacy of world peace and international understanding through the American Friends Service Committee.

title: Priceless gift: the love letters of Woodrow Wilson and Ellen Axson Wilson.
summary: A selection of letters disclosing the deepest thoughts and feelings exchanged over thirty years of courtship and marriage.

title: Letter from Grosvenor Square: an account of a stewardship.
summary: U.S. Ambassador to Great Britain during World War II, he writes a story of the war as he saw it from the Embassy.

title: Three incarnations.
summary: The book describes the author's three distinct phases of her life as a child in Berlin, a physician, and her marriage later in life.

title: Home by the Bering Sea.
summary: An interesting account of her experience as teacher and matron of a mission orphanage in Unalaska, a small fishing village in the Aleutian Islands.

title: Where the wind blows free.
summary: Winchell was for some fifteen years (c. 1912-1927) the matron of girls at a Methodist mission home for orphans in Unalaska, Aleutian Islands. In this book intended for children, she tells unusual tales of the people, customs, and her experiences in these strikingly beautiful but isolated islands populated by Eskimos, Indians, and whites who live intimately with the sea and cold, fish and whales.

title: Winchell exclusive: "things that happened to me — and me to them".
summary: Reporter and columnist on radio and in newspapers, theater critic, and political gadfly, Winchell here reveals in anecdote and gossip some of his scoops and the stories behind them.

title: I fought with Custer: the story of Sergeant Windolph, last survivor of the Battle of the Little Big Horn.
summary: A member of Colonel Benteen's troop, he claims to have helped with the burial detail after the battle and gives his own view of events before, during, and after it.

title: The journals and Indian paintings of George Winter, 1837-1839.
summary: The book includes his unfinished autobiography (1809-1830), color and black-and-white plates of many of his paintings, as well as the journals recording his extensive experience with the Miami and Potawatomi Indians around Logansport, Indiana.

title: Vagrant memories, being further recollections of other days.
summary: Winter reminisces about important and interesting actors whom he has known and observed including Edwin Booth, Henry Irving, and Julia Marlowe.

title: The wallet of time: containing personal, biographical, and critical reminiscence ofthe American theater.
summary: A noted drama critic for the New York Tribune and other papers, from the fullness of his lifelong experience, wrote these essays spanning sixty years in the nineteenth-century theater in which he 'sought to estimate the motives, achievements, and rank of dominant actors, managers, and dramatists . . . and to designate those methods of theatrical administration which are best calculated to promote the welfare of the Theater by making it entirely and nightly serviceable to Society.'

title: The heart has its reasons: the memoirs of the Duchess of Windsor.
summary: The story of her early life, the events leading to her courtship by the King of England, his abdication, and their later years together.

title: Starts and finishes: coming of age in the Fifties.
summary: Winfrey tells a terse and unpleasant tale of the 1940's when his father trained horses in New York, Florida, and California. In the 50's he graduated from Columbia and joined the Marines.

title: The world is my parish: an autobiographical odyssey.
summary: A clergyman's son, Wirt was reared in North Dakota and Wisconsin, educated at Pacific Theological Seminary (Oakland, California), and ordained as a Congregational minister. As a clergyman, he served in Alaska shortly after the Gold Rush began; in Australia, where he was sent to recuperate from overwork in Alaska; and in Mexico. Wirt led a life of adventure and public service all over the world, including field service with the American Red Cross in France, and Western directorship of the educational program of the National Council for the Prevention of War in California and Hawaii after World War I.
other_places_lived: North Dakota, Wisconsin, Alaska, Australia, Mexico

title: The other side of Henry Winkler: my story.
summary: Winkler, a good Jewish boy from New York, pleasantly discusses his rise to television stardom and makes it sound easy. After graduating from Emerson College (Boston) and the Yale Drama School, Winkler embarked on a Broadway theatrical career until he went to Hollywood to star as 'The Fonz.' Although the character and the actor are very different, Winkler enjoys the challenge.

title: From A to X: reminiscences of Max Winkler.
summary: Anecdotes about his life in America, after immigrating from Austria-Hungary in 1907 and becoming a music publisher.

title: SAH-GAN-DE-OH: the chief's daughter.
summary: Born of Seneca-Cayuga parents, she describes her life as 'completely integrated in the American way' and similar to many other modern Indians. Her story is a plea for understanding which analyzes the difficulties of progress and integration, as well as her own interesting and varied life.

title: If man be mad.
summary: His fight against alcoholism, his experiences as a patient in various mental hospitals and institutions, as well as his later work as an attendant in those institutions led to his knowledge of the material, medical, and psychological conditions that prevail in the treatment of mental illness.

title: And not to yield: an autobiography.
summary: An outspoken woman's account of her full life, her protests against injustice, prejudice and exploitation, and her friendships and passions.

title: Fifth Chinese daughter.
summary: The story of a young woman's successful struggle for individuality while growing up in a traditional, disciplined Christian-Chinese family in San Francisco. Her growth is helped by her father's understanding and her own intelligence.

title: No Chinese stranger.
summary: The author writes of her life during the last 25 years in San Francisco's Chinatown. A potter of considerable reputation, she has worked hard to establish a life independent of but relating to the traditions of her family and culture. The last section describes her trip to China in 1972.

title: Born a gemini; memoirs of a sailor.
summary: Vignettes meant to memorialize a vanishing way of life before it passes from the minds of men describe this sea captain's life from his first voyage as an ordinary seaman, including topics such as Hurricane Carol, the Shellback ceremony, and tattooing.

title: Casting couch and me: the uninhibited memoirs of a young actress.
summary: The breezy memoirs of an aspiring actress and the funny, discouraging, wild, and sometimes frightening experiences she had trying to land modeling or acting roles.

title: Chasing Geronimo: the journal of Leonard Wood, May-September, 1886.
summary: This diary describes the campaign against the Apache Indians led by Geronimo, culminating in his capture, revealing both the brutal character of the undertaking and the courage required of the soldiers.

title: Scholar's testament: two letters from George Edward Woodberry to J.E. Spingarn.
summary: The letters discuss Woodberry's resignation from his position at Columbia and his thoughts on living a life of the mind.

title: Selected letters of George Edward Woodberry.
summary: A representative selection from the lifelong correspondence of this poet-critic portrays his love of humanity and serene urbanity.

title: Union soldier in the land of the vanquished: the diary of Sergeant Mathew Woodruff, June-December, 1865.
summary: His informal diary reveals a view of the peacetime army of occupation after the Civil War from an unsophisticated soldier's viewpoint.

title: Beyond the door of delusion, by Inmate, Ward 8.
summary: Having committed himself to a state hospital because of his alcoholism, he describes his treatment there, the physicians, and the fears of other patients.

title: Gift of life: an autobiography.
summary: A pleasant, well-written review of his first 72 years — poor childhood, education, varied work experiences, and a career as a writer of history, biography, and fiction.

title: Behind closed doors.
summary: Woolf, a lawyer whose clients are athletes on major sports teams, recounts anecdotes about some of his most lucrative and colorful legal affairs.

title: Autobiography of Jack Woodford.
summary: Using Woodford as his pseudonym, he wrote cheap sex fiction and portrays a sense of his cynical distance from the Woodford persona.

title: The journal and major essays of John Woolman.
summary: A new edition of the works of a prominent Quaker minister and abolitionist.

title: From orphans to champions: the story of DeMatha's Morgan Wootten.
summary: A basketball coach discusses winning strategies and highlights from his career at DeMatha High School.

title: Uncle Dick Wootton: the pioneer frontiersman of the Rocky Mountain Region.
publisher: The Lakeside Press: R.R. Donnelly and Sons Co.
summary: An account of a beaver trapper, buffalo hunter, guide, and farmer that also discusses the history of the Western territories and Native American culture.

title: Of mosquitoes, moths and mice.
summary: Dr. Worth includes fascinating information about natural history in his investigations of local fauna.

title: Sign 'em up, Bucky: the adventures of a sports agent.
summary: Woy tells the story of how he became a sports agent representing stars and superstars.

title: Stormy passage: a personal history through two Russian revolutions to democracy and freedom: 1905-1960.
summary: The author recounts his participation in the upheavals, his imprisonments and exiles, and his progress to Germany and finally to the United States.

title: Color me white: the autobiography of a black dancer who turned white.
summary: A victim of vitiligo, this singer and dancer describes his medical treatments and journey of personal discovery.

title: The color of life.
summary: A moving, visual autobiography focusing on the author's philosophy and technique as a painter, interspersed with family stories.

title: Letters of Chauncey Wright; with some account of his life.
summary: Wright's letters reveal the philosophical strengths of his intellect and provide insight into his life in Cambridge.

title: I never grew up.
summary: A well-written account of her ambitions, conflicts between career and family life, and later career as a journalist.

title: An autobiography.
summary: Architect Wright tells of his early life, adversity, success, and the many buildings he designed.

title: Genius and the monocracy.
summary: Wright discusses architectural concepts and his relationship with Louis H. Sullivan.

title: A testament.
summary: A profound discussion of his growth and development in modern architecture.

title: Our house.
summary: A personal record of her life with Frank Lloyd Wright and their daily life.

title: Miracle at Kitty Hawk: the letters of Wilbur and Orville Wright.
summary: Selection of letters showing the differing personalities and ideas of both Wright brothers.

title: American hunger.
summary: The book delineates Wright's experiences in the North, especially in Chicago, depicting his distrust of whites and his experiences in the communist movement.

title: The pastor's wife.
summary: The story of her own imprisonment and survival during her husband's imprisonment in communist Rumania.

title: Correspondence and journals of Captain Nathaniel J. Wyeth, 1831-6.
summary: These letters and journals document Wyeth’s efforts to occupy and bring economic enterprise to the territory.

title: The Wyeths; the letters of N.C. Wyeth, 1901-1945.
summary: A wealth of letters tracing the writer's evolution as an artist.

title: Rio Grande medicine man.
summary: An Albuquerque physician discusses typical cases he handled while practicing medicine in the area.

title: Dear Jeffie: being the letters from Jeffries Wyman, first director of the Peabody Museum, to his son, Jeffries Wyman, Jr.
summary: Wyman wrote letters to his son while suffering from tuberculosis, introducing him to the flora and fauna of the regions he visited.

title: Ed Wynn's son.
summary: A quest narrative by the son of an entertainer seeking his identity overshadowed by his famous father.

title: A life in architecture.
summary: The book features photographs of Yamasaki's major works and discusses the racial discrimination he overcame.

title: My life with Elvis.
summary: Yancey, secretary to Elvis Presley and his father, gives her perspective on 'The King.'

title: The polka king: the life of Frankie Yankovic. As told to Robert Dolgan.
summary: Accordionist and polka bandleader Yankovic's childhood was spent in a Slovenian neighborhood of Cleveland, where he first formed bands which entertained at weddings, night spots, and parties in the evenings while he held factory jobs by day. After a stint in the army during World War II, he went into band work full-time, traveling extensively. As the 'Polka King,' he loves his work though it cost him his first marriage.

title: The time of my life. Drawings by Al Ostervich.
summary: Delightful stories of his life in Iowa up to 1935 when he went to New York to establish his career: the Jewish community in Sioux City; the emergence of the Ku Klux Klan, which was then after the Irish, Jews, and Italians; and the exciting years at the University of Iowa where he became critic-at-large for the student paper and met many contemporary writers and intellectuals.

title: Yaz. With Al Hirshberg.
summary: His father dreamed of his son's becoming a big-league baseball player and began his training as a young boy. The book describes Yaz's Polish family background on Long Island, but focuses mainly on his years with the Boston Red Sox, being groomed to replace Ted Williams, and winning baseball's triple crown in 1967, the year the Red Sox won the World Series.

title: The two worlds of Jim Yoshida. With Bill Hosokawa.
summary: A remarkable story of a Japanese-American youth who, because of legal technicalities, was impressed into the Japanese Army during World War II. His struggle to regain his American heritage after the war led him to volunteer to serve with the allied forces during the Korean War. Eventually he won his suit to reclaim his American citizenship.

title: The lighted heart. Pen drawings by Nora S. Unwin.
summary: In the midst of their active, productive life, her husband lost his sight. Together they established a new life in quieter and simpler surroundings, a farm in Massachusetts. Her book describes their sense of renewal resulting from the joy and freedom they found in country living.

title: Seventy miles from a lemon. Illustrated by John O'Hara Cosgrove.
summary: In 1927 she quit her job as a writer for the New Yorker and with her husband built a small stock ranch in Montana. Her book is an interesting depiction of the spirit and reality of modern pioneering.

title: Richard Yates: Civil War governor.
summary: This is a compilation of letters and speeches by and about Richard Yates, Sr., between 1834, when he was a student at Illinois College, and his death in 1873. Inserted in a biographical matrix by Yates's children, most documents concern Yates's political activities in the Illinois state legislature (1842-50), in the U.S. Congress (1850-60), as Governor of Illinois (1860-64), and U.S. Senator (1865-71). A staunch foe of slavery, he cooperated wholeheartedly with Lincoln and U.S. Grant to aid the promulgation of the Civil War.

title: Serving the republic — Richard Yates: Illinois Governor and Congressman/son of Richard Yates, Civil War Governor/an autobiography.
summary: An earnest style marks this account of Yates's duty-bound life following in his father's footsteps as Governor of Illinois (1900-1905) and U.S. Congressman (1918-1932). Yates also served as judge and Illinois Utilities Commissioner. He embodied the cardinal American virtues: hard work, patriotism, party loyalty, love of family, home, and the American heartland.

title: Red ribbon on a white horse.
summary: Reflections on her struggles with poverty and Jewishness in a Polish village, as an immigrant in New York, and later, after a brief period of wealth in Hollywood, during the Depression in New York, by an author who finally understands her father's spirituality and accepts her own.

title: The days of my years.
summary: Yoder, an Amish Mennonite steeped in the faith, offers a straightforward, thoughtful examination of the Mennonite creed and practices, interwoven with a mixture of church history, the history of the Mennonite Goshen (Indiana) College of which he was president, 1923-1940, and a rich account of his missionary services in Paraguay.

title: And sleep in the woods: the story of one man's spiritual quest.
summary: York, a United Church minister, recalls the events which led to his conversion. In 1962, York fled to Canada with his wife to avoid being sent to Vietnam. Living in solitude, meditation, and prayer led York and his wife to a new understanding of themselves and their relationship.

title: Art Young: his life and times.
summary: Young writes vividly of his life as a cartoonist whose illustrations regularly appeared in national magazines such as Life and Judge, and in socialist and other left-wing publications — The Liberator and New Masses. This entertaining book, illustrated with Young's cartoons, offers a vigorous view of twentieth-century American socialism, its advocates, and a host of other political groups.

title: Confederate wizards of the saddle: being reminiscences and observations of one who rode with Morgan.
summary: Young, a successful attorney and Commander-in-Chief of the United Confederate Veterans Association, recollects and reinterprets events of 55 years relating to his participation in the Eighth Kentucky Cavalry Regiment, Morgan's Raiders, including Morgan's raid into Kentucky (1862), Forrest's raid into West Tennessee (1862), Shelby's Missouri raid (1863) and J. E.B. Stuart's Chambersburg raid (1862).

title: Letters of Brigham Young to his sons.
summary: Of Brigham Young's 46 children (by sixteen wives) who reached maturity, seventeen were sons. The Mormon leader enjoyed a warm relationship with his sons, giving fatherly counsel to them when they were away on proselytizing missions for the Church, studying at Eastern universities, traveling for business reasons, or in the military service.

title: Manuscript history of Brigham Young, 1846-1847.
summary: Diary entries and letters 1846-1847 contain the history of Young and the Mormons from the last days at Nauvoo through the entrance of the pioneer company into the Salt Lake Valley.

title: Autobiography of a pioneer: or, the nativity, experience, travels, and ministerial labors of Rev. Jacob Young.
summary: A faithful record of the incidents of the life of an itinerant preacher who was an early supporter of Methodism. He traveled through various circuits in Ohio preaching the gospel and working for the people.

title: Adventures in advertising.
summary: Beginning with his early days as an Iowa huckster, he writes of his business and pleasure in building a successful career in advertising.

title: The things I had to learn. With Helen Ferguson.
summary: Actress Young projects an aura of wholesome glamour and optimism. She includes brief information about her film and television performances between generalizations about manners and mores.

title: Light in the dark belt; the story of Rosa Young as told by herself. Revised edition.
summary: A simple narrative of the religious life and work of a Black woman who started a school and became a day missionary in rural Alabama.

title: The pavilion: of people and times remembered, of stories and places.
summary: Author and drama critic recalls growing up in Mississippi aristocracy, with extensive detail about his family and friends, life in the South, and the art world.

title: Stark Young: a life in the arts: letters, 1900-1962.
summary: This selection of 939 letters provides, says the editor, 'a full . . . spontaneous account of [Young's] life, his writings, his [personal] relationships.' Young decried materialism and advocated humanism and the respect for culture and tradition as part of the good life.

title: Tales out of Congress.
summary: A play-by-play account of a tough old Democrat, Young's narrative gives the details of several congressional elections, his diplomatic trips abroad, and his two marriages, as well as a fair sprinkling of Washington gossip.

title: Twenty years in the Secret-Service: my life with five presidents.
summary: Guarding the president from risks, threats, and hazards is a job whose tensions and dangers are sometimes compounded by the chief executives themselves. Here the story is told by a secret service agent who worked for five presidents, from Truman to Nixon.

title: Animal doctor.
summary: The story of a veterinarian whose practice for small animals and horses is in southern California.

title: Bohemian girl: Blanche Yurka's theatrical life.
summary: Yurka describes her career as an actress in plays by Ibsen, Shakespeare, and Aristophanes as well as lesser playwrights. Some great moments of fulfillment in her life have come during great roles on Broadway, but others have been before small-town audiences in out-of-the-way places.

title: This life I've led: my autobiography.
summary: A champion golfer and remarkable woman in many ways writes of her childhood, her sports career, some of her friends — intimate and celebrity— and her struggle with cancer, which took her life soon after her book was published.

title: From the hills: an autobiography of a pediatrician.
summary: Using several classic American autobiographies as models, a St. Louis physician writes of his medical career in the context of major historical events, e.g., the 1904 World's Fair and both World Wars.

title: A woman's quest.
summary: After emigrating from Berlin in 1852, she became well-known for her medical work among poor women and children of New York and Boston, was founder of an outstanding hospital for women and children in each city, and was dedicated to the training of women doctors.

title: Devil at my heels: the story of Louis Zamperini.
summary: A dramatic story of a dramatic life. Zamperini's delinquent childhood was transformed by the recognition he received as a high school track runner, setting the world's interscholastic mile record in 1934. After finishing eighth in the Berlin Olympics of 1936, Zamperini attended U.S.C. but dropped out to enlist in the Air Force. Shot down in the Pacific, he remained afloat on a raft for 47 days until captured by the Japanese, who beat and tortured him. After the war he drifted, but was saved by his born-again wife and conversion by Billy Graham to become a successful evangelist.

title: Walls: resisting the Third Reich— one woman's story.
summary: Now living in the United States, Zassenhaus tells the fascinating tale of her work as an interpreter for political prisoners in Germany during the rise of the Third Reich and World War II. An opponent of Nazism, she used her position to smuggle food, vitamins, books and Bibles into the prisons, and made notations of 'send food' on letters given her to censor.

title: Self-portrait: Margot Zemach.
summary: Zemach wrote and illustrated this autobiography for children, emphasizing her travels throughout Europe and America and her career. Her illustrations are often peopled with characters from children's books her husband wrote and illustrated.

title: Trial of Peter Zenger.
summary: The trial in 1735 of printer and journalist Zenger for seditious libel focused on his printing of the political New York Weekly Journal, which criticized New York Governor William Cosley's financial malfeasance in office. Although the case itself did not establish either political liberty or freedom of the press, it paved the way for later political and legal reforms promulgated by Andrew Hamilton. Zenger's narrative explains the case and defends free speech and a free press.

title: The Ziegfelds' girl; confessions of an abnormally happy childhood.
summary: Surrounded by luxury and raised by two famous theatrical parents, both somewhat eccentric, her youth was like a fairy tale spiced by show-business personalities and extravagant events.

title: My own shall come to me; a personal memoir and picture chronicle.
summary: Verbal reminiscences and pictures, a family narrative, essays in art and literary criticism, psychological appraisals, and social commentary are included in this volume. Zigrosser, who founded the Weyhe Gallery, was curator of prints at the Philadelphia Museum of Art and later vice-director and acting director.

title: My own shall come to me; a personal memoir and picture chronicle.
summary: A singer tells of a childhood nearly wrecked by her parents' alcoholism and her father's job problems, her attempt to escape family difficulties through music and the church, her spiritual rebirth, her marriage, her own family, and her rise to success on The Lawrence Welk Show.

title: Punishment without crime: a lifetime in prison for a crime he did not commit.
summary: Convicted in 1938 of conspiracy to murder a detective, Zimmerman spent the next twenty-four years in various New York state prisons until he was finally released because the prosecutor used perjured testimony and deliberately suppressed evidence of Zimmerman's innocence.

title: Doctor Zinn: autobiography, poems, philosophy, tales, etc.
summary: Although Zinn wrote this book 'to encourage young people to buck the odds and do their damndest to achieve their ambition,' he spends so much time discussing his hell-raising as a youth, student, soldier, and divorced man that his career as a surgeon appears subordinate.

title: As I remember him.
summary: The reminiscences of a doctor who became a bacteriologist. His success carried him to far countries in search of causes of diseases such as typhus, syphilis, cholera, and infantile paralysis. He hunted for bedbugs, lice, ticks and fleas for scientific purposes and found human nature to analyze as well; he was concerned with philosophy and humanity and tried to understand the contradictions of his age of human achievement on the one hand and the destruction of war on the other.

title: My eighty years in Texas.
summary: Writing in his old age, Zuber describes his part in the fight for Texas independence, offers detailed accounts of the early years of Texas, gives historical context to his experiences, and shares anecdotes from his life.

title: Liliana's journal: Warsaw 1939-1945.
summary: This is a terrifying account of Liliana's life in occupied Poland and the Warsaw ghetto, 1939-1945. She was eleven at the war's outbreak and matured beyond her years when her mother and grandparents were sent to the concentration camps; she worked in an ink factory and helped to support her family with food the job provided. At sixteen she married a guerrilla who was killed in the Warsaw ghetto uprising. She found the postwar Russian regime too oppressive and escaped to Berlin in 1946 before going to El Salvador to live with relatives and immigrating to the United States in 1953.
other_places_lived: Occupied Poland, Warsaw ghetto, Berlin, El Salvador

title: The public is never wrong: the autobiography of Adolph Zukor.
summary: A movie producer in New York and Hollywood recalls the history of the film industry and the role Mary Pickford played in its development.

title: On watch: a memoir.
summary: Zumwalt details his naval career from the Academy to his position as Chief of Naval Operations, giving special attention to his efforts to upgrade U.S. defense readiness, personnel morale, dress codes, and official positions regarding minority personnel in the Navy. Critical of President Nixon, Kissinger, and Admiral Rickover, Zumwalt decries the decrease of U.S. forces in the face of increasing Soviet military strength.

title: Yesterday: a memoir of a Russian Jewish family.
summary: This evocative memoir traces the generations of Zunser's extended family, Russian Jews who immigrated to New York at the turn of the century. Zunser, a noted playwright for the Yiddish theater in New York, is sensitive to the dramatic nuances of joy and pathos as she characterizes aunts and uncles, grandparents and children (including herself) with an intense commitment to Judaism, their family, and the arts.

title: Three journeys: an automythology.
summary: A 'chance exile from America,' the poet sees himself as a 'wandering Jew' and describes three journeys: his trip to the Sahara Desert, a 'luminous personal space'; a decade in Paris, including a six-year marriage to Michele; and, in New York, a climactic series of 'intense private experiences' triggered by the influence of Swami Muktananda.
